this guy's been doing live space binaural for quite a while now -with modest equipment, and
excellent results. go download his recordings and take a listen for yourselves.

binaural recordings are grate !

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Apollo" <apollo@speakeasy.org>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Wednesday, June 30, 2004 4:49 PM
Subject: [sfraves] Sound With Space and Motion


> Sound With Space and Motion
>
> June 29, 2004
>
>
>   A conversation snaps around you. A string trio plays in front of you as
> you turn your attention from cello to violin. A soprano walks across the
> stage, and you turn your head to follow her voice. Conventional sound
> recording cannot capture those experiences -- but an invention by audio
> engineers at the University of California, Davis is changing that.
>
>   Motion-tracked binaural sound (MTB) captures cues for direction, distance
> and movement and the subtleties of natural, ambient sound that other
> systems don't. Developed by Ralph Algazi, Richard Duda and Dennis Thompson
> at the Interface Laboratory in the UC Davis Center for Image Processing and
> Integrated Computing (CIPIC), the patent-pending technique uses
> off-the-shelf equipment that won't break the bank.
>
> For the listener, it's an eerie experience of listening to invisible people
> talking, playing music or singing around you while you can turn your
> attention from one to another.
>
>   "Conventional audio playback doesn't reflect how you hear in real life,"
> Algazi said. "Your body, the shape of your head and the room acoustics all
> affect how you hear."
>
>   Conventional binaural recording uses microphones embedded in a dummy head
> to record sound, so that playback through headphones mimics the recording.
> That method does a fair job of reproducing sounds to the left and right but
> not to the front, where sounds appear to come from immediately in front of
> or behind your head. Furthermore, it doesn't allow for movement, Duda said.
>
>   "The problem is that people do not keep still," Duda said.
>
>   The new method records through multiple microphones (eight for voice, 16
> for music) spaced around a head-sized ball or cylinder. The sound is played
> back through headphones with a small tracking device attached to the top to
> follow head movements. As you turn your head while listening, the system
> mixes sound from different microphones, reproducing what you would hear if
> you were in the room.
>
>   Listeners can move their heads to locate a sound source, turn to "face" a
> person speaking and tell when sound sources are nearby or far away. In
> addition, MTB captures the ambient sounds of the location, so you recognize
> the echoes in a church or the confines of a conference room.
>
> The engineers have made sample recordings with musicians from the UC Davis
> music department and visiting classical and bluegrass musicians.
>
>   "The system can capture the sound of instruments much more fully than a
> conventional single microphone. It captures changes in sound and the
> effects of a room in a way that is much closer to reality," Algazi said.
>
> "I think they have something really wonderful," said Pablo Ortiz, chair of
> the Department of Music at UC Davis.
>
>   "The thing that's interesting to me is the way that it records space,"
> Ortiz said.
>
>   William Beck, a composer of electronic music and lecturer in the music
> department, said that live recordings could be a major application.
>
>   "The 'being there' feel is something people would really like," Beck said.
>
>   The technique could also be used for teleconferencing, computer games and
> virtual- or augmented-reality systems. The work, which is supported by
> grants from the National Science Foundation, was presented at the 116th
> Convention of the Audio Engineering Society held in May 2004 in Berlin,
> Germany.
>
>   The CIPIC Interface Laboratory is a multidisciplinary research center
> that studies human perception and its role in the interface between humans
> and machines.
>
> http://www.news.ucdavis.edu/search/news_detail.lasso?id=7058
>
>
>
> Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
>
> House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
>
>
> "I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and causes
> me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war,
> corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places
> will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong
> its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is
> aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
> -Abraham Lincoln
>
> "Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the
> rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become
> visible."
> -Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"
>
>   "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of
> life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the
> beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club,
> party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
> -Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves
>

Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm

Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 47437 invoked from network); 1 Jul 2004 16:53:33 -0000
Message-ID: <20040701165330.72586.qmail@web60310.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Thu, 1 Jul 2004 09:53:30 -0700 (PDT)
From: georgeC <newstylesound@yahoo.com>
To: SE/30 <grindingbassline@hotmail.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <BAY8-DAV104JKP17urE00042fea@hotmail.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Sound With Space and Motion

--- SE/30 <grindingbassline@hotmail.com> wrote:
> "The problem is that people do not keep still...  the new method
> records through [16] microphones
> spaced around a head-sized ball... As you turn your head... the
> system mixes sound from different
> microphones, reproducing what you would hear if you were in the
> room."
> 
> interesting, but sounds -*ahem*- like much ado about nothing,

Well, this sound a bit like a shotgun marriage between Binaural
recording and VR (or worse, QuickTime VR ;), in a way-  I can see,
however, where when tiny movements of your head translate into
resultant changes in the orientation of the sound you hear, there might
be some kind of psychoacoustic effect of "putting you in the space",
even if you normally wouldn't give a shit about turning in your seat in
the symphony hall.

An interesting idea nonetheless- surround microphones built into
spheres (multiple mic elements) have been around for some time, but
they've never been tied to some sort of encoding matrix to allow
headphone steering..  Some people just have wacky ideas.

My only worry is that those 16 microphones had better be stringently
calibrated and mounted with a jeweller's attention to spacing and
orientation, or the resultant phase issues would cause ripples in the
3d space, kind of a buzzkill. 

/audio geek

GeorgeC - Origami
www.djorigami.com

immerse the baby's head

> 	attained commercial success or noteriety (sp?), but their best music was
> 	already made.

> 	> I say it was purely a matter of choice in lineup. If that lineup had
> 	> rolled in back in the first years of Lollapalooza (91+) it *would*
> 	> have gone off. Fast-forward to today and it becomes a nostalgic show
> 	> for a limited audience that has since moved on. What is remarkable
> 	> about the first years of Lollapalooza is the lineups that show brought
> 	> to town at that time. I would think that Perry needs to retool
> 	> Lollapalooza and apply that formula to this day and age. Not too many
> 	> high school kids with limited income are going to shell out hard
> 	> earned cash for groups that they don't really know. Warped Tour gets
> 	> it right. The lineup of uber-popular pop-punk draws in the kids. Toss
> 	> in a media blast and you can damn well bet it's going to sell out.
> 	>
> 	> I see certain parallels between raves and concerts here. Cater to the
> 	> demographic that will attend.
> 	>

> 	>> > In 1997, Lollapalooza – Perry Farrell's alternative music and
> 	>> lifestyle
> 	>> > road show – shut down after a strong seven-year run. The
> traveling
> 	>> festival
> 	>> > ended on a dissonant note, squeezing underwhelming bands like

> 	>> > Korn, The Orb, and Orbital onto the stage that once housed giants

> 	>> > Pearl Jam, Sonic Youth, Wu Tang Clan, Ice Cube and the Beastie

> Farrell's
> 	>> > Jane's Addiction, supergroup Audioslave, Jurassic 5 and the Donnas
> 	>> > headlining. The reduced starpower contributed to weak ticket sales,
> 	>> but
> 	>> > Farrell still carried the torch: Fast forward to 2004, and
> 	>> Lollapalooza
> 	>> > seemed to be burning bright.
> 	>> >
> 	>> > Farrell and company believed, some would argue rightly so, that a
> 	>> line-up
> 	>> > consisting of the Pixies, Morrissey, PJ Harvey, The Flaming Lips,
> 	>> Modest
> 	>> > Mouse, Sonic Youth (again) and Wilco would be enough to get iPod
> 	>> Nation up
> 	>> > off its recliners this summer. Apparently, they guessed wrong.
> 	>> Lollapalooza
> 	>> > 2004, citing million dollar losses and anemic sales, had to pull up
> 	>> stakes
> 	>> > on the two-month, cross-country sonic spree.
> 	>> >
> 	>> > Whether or not this is a massive bummer depends on whom you're
> talking
> 	>> to.
> 	>> > If you're talking to the MTV-addled bubble-poppers who've made
> tired
> 	>> Gs
> 	>> > like 50 Cent and Us Weekly-selling starlets like J.Lo into platinum
> 	>> > superstars, well, they'll get over it. And if you're talking
> 	>> post-slackers
> 	>> > that helped explode alternative music through the Lollapalooza
> aorta
> 	>> since
> 	>> > the festival took its first breath in 1991, it seems that they
> might
> 	>> not
> 	>> > have the economic clout they had in the '90s.
> 	>> >
> 	>> > But whomever you're talking to, either they're not interested, not
> 	>> aware,
> 	>> > or not in possession of the ample funds it takes to gain access to
> a
> 	>> > festival concert these days. As Perry notes above, the health of
> the
> 	>> > touring industry is bordering on convalescent, and it's not just
> 	>> > Lollapalooza that has breathed its last gasp. Last year, the
> diverse
> 	>> indie
> 	>> > rock festival All Tomorrow's Parties – curated by Matt Groening
> (you
> 	>> may
> 	>> > remember him from such hit TV shows as The Simpsons or Futurama)
> and
> 	>> > featuring compelling acts like Patti Smith, The Breeders, Nick Cave
> 	>> and a
> 	>> > host of innovative bands – had to cancel its Los Angeles date due
> to
> 	>> > sluggish ticket sales.
> 	>> >
> 	>> > Not all is lost when it comes to blockbuster package tours. Vans
> 	>> Warped is
> 	>> > still going comparatively strong, and it's landing in just as many
> 	>> cities
> 	>> > as Lollapalooza. But Vans Warped, as the name implies, is heavily
> 	>> > sponsored; everyone from big guns like Vans, Hurley, MTV and Dodge
> to
> 	>> small
> 	>> > fries like Slim Jim, Ernie Ball and Hot Topic are lending their
> weight
> 	>> and
> 	>> > support to the skateboarding phenomenon. Plus, with what looks like
> –
> 	>> > according to the event's official site – around 200 bands along
> for
> 	>> the
> 	>> > ride, most of them skewed to a much younger demographic, they're
> 	>> arguably
> 	>> > giving more bang for your buck.
> 	>> >
> 	>> > But demographics don't tell the whole story. Consider OzzFest,
> which
> 	>> is
> 	>> > still going strong – though Ozzy Osbourne himself has been running
> on
> 	>> empty
> 	>> > for years and his TV show is a shadow of its former self. If
> critics
> 	>> of
> 	>> > Lolla think Sonic Youth and The Pixies are too old, then how to
> 	>> explain the
> 	>> > attraction of OzzFest's 2004 headliner, a reunited Black Sabbath?
> 	>> They've
> 	>> > got the Pixies beat by two decades in the age category. True,
> OzzFest
> 	>> > remains relevant by lumping in younger acts like Slipknot,
> Hatebreed
> 	>> and
> 	>> > others, but their main stage acts in 2004 – Sabbath, Judas Priest
> and
> 	>> > Slayer – reads like a headbanger's history book.
> 	>> >
> 	>> > As usual, age doesn't explain everything. Sure, Lollapalooza fans
> are
> 	>> > getting old, but they're still getting involved. In addition to the
> 	>> stellar
> 	>> > headliners, the tour had partnered with MoveOn.org to provide, as
> the
> 	>> > festival always has, discussions, solutions, and avenues for change
> 	>> during
> 	>> > what's shaping up to be the Armageddon of election years. This
> year's
> 	>> model
> 	>> > was going to be the Revolution Solution Tent, a teach-in of sorts
> 	>> focusing
> 	>> > on environmental concerns, workers' rights, media deregulation,
> free
> 	>> speech
> 	>> > and other issues vital to the arts community; they even had a
> 	>> solar-powered
> 	>> > stage geared up for action, featuring punk veteran and Minutemen
> 	>> bassist
> 	>> > Mike Watt as a headliner. The always engaging Watt also penned a
> 	>> running
> 	>> > diary for Lollapalooza on their official site, but a quick click of
> 	>> the
> 	>> > site's "Sponsors" tab tells the whole story. Blank page.
> 	>> >
> 	>> > Some of the blame may lie with Farrell, who had similar problems
> 	>> launching
> 	>> > 2003's comeback Lollapalooza. Originally planning to kick off the
> 	>> festival
> 	>> > in Ionia, Michigan on July 3rd, Rolling Stone reported that Farrell
> 	>> > cancelled the date and rescheduled; in what may be debated as a
> symbol
> 	>> of
> 	>> > Farrell's ego or a funny coincidence, the Lollapalooza party line
> 	>> argued
> 	>> > that the Jane's Addiction's set simply couldn't fit on the
> Fairgrounds
> 	>> > stage. But officials at the venue replied that Farrell's excuse was
> a
> 	>> red
> 	>> > herring; the show had only sold 4,000 tickets and the Fairgrounds
> main
> 	>> > stage had played anywhere from two to five times that capacity
> before.
> 	>> > Making matters worse, the tour had a scheduled stop in Detroit,
> which,
> 	>> some
> 	>> > asserted, cut into Ionia's sales. No matter how you slice it, that
> 	>> show had
> 	>> > problems before the curtain ever lifted.
> 	>> >
> 	>> > And they continue. The problem of "poor ticket sales" takes its
> place
> 	>> with
> 	>> > the others – "too mainstream," "too old," "too masculine," "too
> white"
> 	>> –
> 	>> > plaguing Lolla since it more or less ended in 1997. Which is truly
> a
> 	>> sorry
> 	>> > State of the Slacker Union address, considering the impressive
> 	>> firepower
> 	>> > Farrell amassed for 2004's old college try. After all, the Pixies
> have
> 	>> sold
> 	>> > out almost all of their other reunion dates within minutes; but
> even
> 	>> they
> 	>> > couldn't keep the Lolla boat afloat. Which if you ask diehard fans
> 	>> (like
> 	>> > myself, I admit), it just goes to show that Farrell should've
> tabbed
> 	>> them
> 	>> > for his journeying think piece back when they were changing music
> 	>> forever.
> 	>> >
> 	>> > Which is another way of saying that Lolla's 2004 line-up might have
> 	>> caused
> 	>> > a Who-like stampede had it hit the stage in 1991 or 1992, when most
> of
> 	>> the
> 	>> > headliners were at their best. But now yesteryear's teenagers and
> 	>> > twenty-somethings are well on their way to middle age, and shelling
> 	>> out a
> 	>> > Trump-load of cash for water bottles and bad fries to sit in the
> 	>> blazing
> 	>> > sun for two days straight amongst drunks and frat boys just doesn't
> 	>> sound
> 	>> > like fun anymore.
> 	>> >
> 	>> > So whether you're blaming Farrell, the aging lineup and its older
> 	>> > demographic, the ailing "health of the touring industry," Clear
> 	>> Channel's
> 	>> > stranglehold on the live show circuit, or the fact that most
> Americans
> 	>> just
> 	>> > don't have the kind of disposable income they possessed last
> decade,
> 	>> > Lollapalooza's cancellation is a wake-up call to all of those who
> 	>> think
> 	>> > that crafting an attractive lineup is all is takes to pack them in.
> 	>> >
> 	>> > Lollapalooza 2004's brilliant lineup is perhaps too little, too
> late.
> 	>> Too bad.
> 	>> >
> 	>> >
> 	>> > © 2004 Independent Media Institute. All rights reserved.
> 	>> > View this story online at: http://www.alternet.org/story/19082/
> 	>> >
> 	>> >
> 	>> > Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
> 	>> >
> 	>> > House Music 101:
> 	>> http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
> 	>> >
> 	>> >
> 	>> >
> 	>> >
> 	>> > "A human being is part of a whole, called by us the 'Universe,' a
> part
> 	>> > limited in time and space. He experiences himself, his thoughts and
> 	>> > feelings, as something separated from the rest--a kind of optical
> 	>> delusion
> 	>> > of his consciousness. This delusion is a kind of prison for us,
> 	>> restricting
> 	>> > us to our personal desires and to affection for a few persons
> nearest
> 	>> us.
> 	>> > Our task must be to free ourselves from this prison by widening our
> 	>> circles
> 	>> > of compassion to embrace all living creatures and the whole of
> nature
> 	>> in
> 	>> > its beauty."
> 	>> > -Albert Einstein
> 	>> >
> 	>> >
> 	>> >
> 	>> >
> 	>> >
> 	>> >
> 	>> >
> 	>> >
> 	>> >
> 	>>

dGluZyBldmlkZW5jZSBmb3IgdGhpcywgYW5kIEkgdGhpbmsgaGUncyB3cm9uZyBvbiB0aGlzIHBv
aW50Lg0KCT4gRm9yDQoJPiAgICAgICA+PiBleGFtcGxlOg0KCT4gICAgICAgPj4NCgk+ICAgICAg

Message-ID: <BAY8-DAV62tNG8s9djl0003b0be@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 01 Jul 2004 18:32:26.0691 (UTC) FILETIME=[C2414930:01C45F99]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Sound With Space and Motion

well, i agree 100%...  the turning of your head, or moving through space, or whatever, *will* cause
psycho-acoustical variations -some of which *could* be calculated and adjusted for with 16 inputs
and mixed with in some impact-plane and difraction-delay estimated fashion- but is it smarter than
one's own ear ?

the binaural recordings ximm and many of simpson's are made by placing the microphones *inside*
their own ears, while allowing them to move freely... thereby representing nearly the exact
psycho-acoustical representation of their own listening experience, and presenting it to the
listener.

so the question is, which is more accurate... a subjectively processed and error-prone pseudo-mixed
down binaural representation of what is actually happening, or a direct binaural recording of what
*is* actually happening ?

..one dumb head an'two microphoooooones....

:)

-=dave

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "georgeC" <newstylesound@yahoo.com>
To: "SE/30" <grindingbassline@hotmail.com>; <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Thursday, July 01, 2004 9:53 AM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Sound With Space and Motion


> --- SE/30 <grindingbassline@hotmail.com> wrote:
> > "The problem is that people do not keep still...  the new method
> > records through [16] microphones
> > spaced around a head-sized ball... As you turn your head... the
> > system mixes sound from different
> > microphones, reproducing what you would hear if you were in the
> > room."
> >
> > interesting, but sounds -*ahem*- like much ado about nothing,
>
> Well, this sound a bit like a shotgun marriage between Binaural
> recording and VR (or worse, QuickTime VR ;), in a way-  I can see,
> however, where when tiny movements of your head translate into
> resultant changes in the orientation of the sound you hear, there might
> be some kind of psychoacoustic effect of "putting you in the space",
> even if you normally wouldn't give a shit about turning in your seat in
> the symphony hall.
>
> An interesting idea nonetheless- surround microphones built into
> spheres (multiple mic elements) have been around for some time, but
> they've never been tied to some sort of encoding matrix to allow
> headphone steering..  Some people just have wacky ideas.
>
> My only worry is that those 16 microphones had better be stringently
> calibrated and mounted with a jeweller's attention to spacing and
> orientation, or the resultant phase issues would cause ripples in the
> 3d space, kind of a buzzkill.
>
> /audio geek
>
> GeorgeC - Origami
> www.djorigami.com
>

Subject: RE: [sfraves] Sound With Space and Motion

I'm not 100% sure, but can we really say that our timpanic membrate and
all those little hairs work exactly the same as a microphone? Probably
not, probably more like a million little microphones each with a small
frequency range reception pointed in different directions in the ear
canal. Also, what about sound that filters through your sinus cavities
from your nose and mouth? Isn't that connected to the ear also?=20

X-MS-Has-Attach:

Thread-Topic: [sfraves] turntables, was: help. please?
Thread-Index: AcRbE4+4lGrEEtD4Roe19XplJaGl+gEqul+g
From: "Steve Osteen" <SOsteen@pinnaclesys.com>
To: "AndyW" <andy@saturn5.com>,
	"Sean Casey" <sean@cloudfactory.org>
Cc: "Brandon S." <invibe@hotmail.com>,
	<sfraves@hyperreal.org>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 01 Jul 2004 22:58:32.0832 (UTC) FILETIME=[EED11000:01C45FBE]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] turntables, was: help. please?

Speaking of turntables, do you guys think that DJ's that only mix with
the pitch (like me) and never touch the vinyl and going to wear out
their pitch slider a lot faster? BTW - I use M3D's that don't have a
zero lock, but a button instead.

Osteen
A pitched up and out DJ/Producer
www.tussinspace.com

-----Original Message-----
From: AndyW [mailto:andy@saturn5.com]=20
Sent: Friday, June 25, 2004 5:22 PM
To: Sean Casey
Cc: Brandon S.; sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Re: [sfraves] turntable help. please?


Probably a dirty pitch slider.

No, it's not power fluctuations.  I've run decks off of really bad
power,
the sound system is browning out, the lights will stop working, but
the mix still sticks.

Hit the slider with the Caig stuff.

If it's near your 0 point, it's likely that you're drifting between the
pitch being locked and not locked (looking at the platter dots, is it
going from perfectly motionless to a slight drift?).  Basic zero adjust
(the easiest service to do on 1200s, you can do it yourself) should help
or fix it altogether.  Also, get in the habit of leaving your tables at
0
lock when not playing them.  That way, any wear at the point the slider
is
left at is at a point where it's not being used.

Those things are surprisingly durable.  Mine have been to at least a 100
parties/outdoors/clubs/houseparties and never have required service.
I've
pitched them up and down again (although ALWAYS TURN OFF THE DECK WHEN
YOU
TAKE OFF THE PLATTER... you can kill a 1200 that way), and they feel
better than when I brought them home new.

vinyl, whoooo!
andyw

On Fri, 25 Jun 2004, Sean Casey wrote:
-&e->Brandon S. <invibe@hotmail.com> said...
-&e->> ok, so i've been noticing that my mixes at home have been majorly
sucking
-&e->> at times, so i decided to blame it all on my turntables.
however, upon
-&e->> close inspection, i believe the problem IS my tables!
-&e->>
-&e->> one of my 1210mk2s, when the pitch is set close to zero, tends to
nudge
-&e->> itself forward in small, random intervals.  i noticed because i
stared at
-&e->> the red LED and watched the little dots move by themselves.
-&e->>
-&e->> anyhow, does this mean my tables need tuning?  could fluctuations
in my
-&e->> electrical current be a cause (our wiring in our place is old and
shotty).
-&e->> any other suggestions?
-&e->
-&e->I've never heard of an SL12xx turntable with pitch creep. Hmmm..
-&e->Maybe the pitch slider hardware has gone foo?
-&e->
-&e->I'd hit up Don Spence and ask his advice. He's local and has
-&e->a good rep for doing repairs/mods on 1200s.
-&e->
-&e->Sean
-&e->

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Sound With Space and Motion

i think i missed your point steve

mine was that a binaural in-ear mic system seems as if it would, 1) be simpler, 2) do a better job,
and 3) have ample previous work cited, than the capturing of this complex audio environment by the
16-microphone arrangement with outboard "mystery" processing that the article showcases as
"innovative."

i assume you're saying it's not possible at all ?  well nothing is "perfect" but if we got 100%
caught up in that, none of us would listen to anything but live music.

regardless... the more research into audio capture and reproduction, the better...  music is grate !

-=dave

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Steve Osteen" <SOsteen@pinnaclesys.com>
To: "SE/30" <grindingbassline@hotmail.com>; "georgeC" <newstylesound@yahoo.com>;
<sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Thursday, July 01, 2004 11:39 AM
Subject: RE: [sfraves] Sound With Space and Motion


I'm not 100% sure, but can we really say that our timpanic membrate and
all those little hairs work exactly the same as a microphone? Probably
not, probably more like a million little microphones each with a small
frequency range reception pointed in different directions in the ear
canal. Also, what about sound that filters through your sinus cavities
from your nose and mouth? Isn't that connected to the ear also?

-----Original Message-----
From: SE/30 [mailto:grindingbassline@hotmail.com]
Sent: Thursday, July 01, 2004 11:24 AM
To: georgeC; sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Sound With Space and Motion

well, i agree 100%...  the turning of your head, or moving through
space, or whatever, *will* cause
psycho-acoustical variations -some of which *could* be calculated and
adjusted for with 16 inputs
and mixed with in some impact-plane and difraction-delay estimated
fashion- but is it smarter than
one's own ear ?

the binaural recordings ximm and many of simpson's are made by placing
the microphones *inside*
their own ears, while allowing them to move freely... thereby
representing nearly the exact
psycho-acoustical representation of their own listening experience, and
presenting it to the
listener.

so the question is, which is more accurate... a subjectively processed
and error-prone pseudo-mixed
down binaural representation of what is actually happening, or a direct
binaural recording of what
*is* actually happening ?

.one dumb head an'two microphoooooones....

:)

-=dave

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "georgeC" <newstylesound@yahoo.com>
To: "SE/30" <grindingbassline@hotmail.com>; <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Thursday, July 01, 2004 9:53 AM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Sound With Space and Motion


> --- SE/30 <grindingbassline@hotmail.com> wrote:
> > "The problem is that people do not keep still...  the new method
> > records through [16] microphones
> > spaced around a head-sized ball... As you turn your head... the
> > system mixes sound from different
> > microphones, reproducing what you would hear if you were in the
> > room."
> >
> > interesting, but sounds -*ahem*- like much ado about nothing,
>
> Well, this sound a bit like a shotgun marriage between Binaural
> recording and VR (or worse, QuickTime VR ;), in a way-  I can see,
> however, where when tiny movements of your head translate into
> resultant changes in the orientation of the sound you hear, there
might
> be some kind of psychoacoustic effect of "putting you in the space",
> even if you normally wouldn't give a shit about turning in your seat
in
> the symphony hall.
>
> An interesting idea nonetheless- surround microphones built into
> spheres (multiple mic elements) have been around for some time, but
> they've never been tied to some sort of encoding matrix to allow
> headphone steering..  Some people just have wacky ideas.
>
> My only worry is that those 16 microphones had better be stringently
> calibrated and mounted with a jeweller's attention to spacing and
> orientation, or the resultant phase issues would cause ripples in the
> 3d space, kind of a buzzkill.
>
> /audio geek
>
> GeorgeC - Origami
> www.djorigami.com
>

me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war, 
corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong 
its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-Abraham Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Steve Osteen" <SOsteen@pinnaclesys.com>
To: "AndyW" <andy@saturn5.com>; "Sean Casey" <sean@cloudfactory.org>
Cc: "Brandon S." <invibe@hotmail.com>; <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Thursday, July 01, 2004 3:58 PM
Subject: RE: [sfraves] turntables, was: help. please?


Speaking of turntables, do you guys think that DJ's that only mix with
the pitch (like me) and never touch the vinyl and going to wear out
their pitch slider a lot faster? BTW - I use M3D's that don't have a
zero lock, but a button instead.

Osteen
A pitched up and out DJ/Producer
www.tussinspace.com

-----Original Message-----
From: AndyW [mailto:andy@saturn5.com]
Sent: Friday, June 25, 2004 5:22 PM
To: Sean Casey
Cc: Brandon S.; sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Re: [sfraves] turntable help. please?


Probably a dirty pitch slider.

No, it's not power fluctuations.  I've run decks off of really bad
power,
the sound system is browning out, the lights will stop working, but
the mix still sticks.

Hit the slider with the Caig stuff.

If it's near your 0 point, it's likely that you're drifting between the
pitch being locked and not locked (looking at the platter dots, is it
going from perfectly motionless to a slight drift?).  Basic zero adjust
(the easiest service to do on 1200s, you can do it yourself) should help
or fix it altogether.  Also, get in the habit of leaving your tables at
0
lock when not playing them.  That way, any wear at the point the slider
is
left at is at a point where it's not being used.

Those things are surprisingly durable.  Mine have been to at least a 100
parties/outdoors/clubs/houseparties and never have required service.
I've
pitched them up and down again (although ALWAYS TURN OFF THE DECK WHEN
YOU
TAKE OFF THE PLATTER... you can kill a 1200 that way), and they feel
better than when I brought them home new.

vinyl, whoooo!
andyw

On Fri, 25 Jun 2004, Sean Casey wrote:
-&e->Brandon S. <invibe@hotmail.com> said...
-&e->> ok, so i've been noticing that my mixes at home have been majorly
sucking
-&e->> at times, so i decided to blame it all on my turntables.
however, upon
-&e->> close inspection, i believe the problem IS my tables!
-&e->>
-&e->> one of my 1210mk2s, when the pitch is set close to zero, tends to
nudge
-&e->> itself forward in small, random intervals.  i noticed because i
stared at
-&e->> the red LED and watched the little dots move by themselves.
-&e->>
-&e->> anyhow, does this mean my tables need tuning?  could fluctuations
in my
-&e->> electrical current be a cause (our wiring in our place is old and
shotty).
-&e->> any other suggestions?
-&e->
-&e->I've never heard of an SL12xx turntable with pitch creep. Hmmm..
-&e->Maybe the pitch slider hardware has gone foo?
-&e->
-&e->I'd hit up Don Spence and ask his advice. He's local and has
-&e->a good rep for doing repairs/mods on 1200s.
-&e->
-&e->Sean

> delta 9 poisoned me when i saw him play in L.A. (orange show complex)
> (1996)
>
> i was horrified by his intense evil nature.
>
> it was 6am.  i was coming down and looking fwd to some morning house.
>
> he deprived me of such a comfort and proceeded to split my skull / psyche
> / personality until i felt like i might do things that were terribly
> wrong.
>
> i wanted the onslaught to stop, but that just made him pound me more.
>
> i had know idea that such music existed before that.
>

> torture dementia master.

>> early

>> LOSER",

>> appeared all

>> control,

>> to
>> -&e->present to you Delta 9 for his first Bay Area Appearance!

>> with awesome gags like having their pictures taken with big names DJs
>> with
>> their cocks hanging out of their pants, interviewing kids at parties
>> that
>> are puking off their E, snowboarding into bushes and faking car
>> accidents.
>>

>> edited
>> and funny as all hell.  And shy of some weird change in the last few
>> years, he plays good old' american midwest warehouse/barn/legionhall
>> paint
>> peeling hardcore without the happy.
>>

yeah it is true d9 was doing more house style, but now he's been doing
more "nu style" which i don't know if many of ya'll know about but it's
more of a slower dutch type style he just put a record out with tron in
that style.  tron's label blood n' guts was one of my favorites back in
1997 / 98... some good hc shit!

that have traveled.  no one will be turned away for lack of funds.

l8,

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Re: Sound With Space and Motion

At 10:08 AM 7/1/2004, you wrote:
>  A conversation snaps around you.

blah blah blah... ;P   This isn't an offensive post... I've not had time to 
even read the replies... The majority of this "breaking discovery" is 
fluff.  These researchers found a way to encode binaural audio 
without  HRTF (Head Related Transfer Function) filtering.  The 
HRTF/binaural thing has been around a while and is in wide use for things 
such as computer game audio engines (all that creative labs shizzle, etc.). 
There are also cheap tools to use this technique in music production.

Of some interest might be ambisonics. The theory has been around since the 
70's (with a tech path leading from much earlier work), yet now in 
application via software it's possible to pull off some really crazy shit.

http://members.tripod.com/martin_leese/Ambisonic/
http://members.tripod.com/martin_leese/Ambisonic/faq_latest.html

--------

I just got back from Sun's JavaOne where I presented my real time graphics 
and audio work; now got a Quake3 based game engine and a full ambisonic 
spatialization engine for audio built with Java. I will be releasing the 
game engine (but not my super secret audio engine) and more in September 
for free (open source). I made some contacts with some press folks from 
O'Reilly who made my presentation (BOF) and might get my work "officially 
reviewed"..  It was a trip going to conference as I didn't run into another 
attendee that wasn't corporately sponsored/associated; got a free ticket 
for speaking.

Blah blah blah...  Ooooo... So I got my 1st booking this year.. I should be 
headlining the Black & White ball again out at Defcon in Las Vegas.. ooo..

That will of course be in addition to other chaos that weekend including 
our own party with DDR & SarahFAB performing.

I'll also be playing out in SF at some time in July though...

Anyone make it to the Skinny Puppy show Thursday night? I was still in SF 
and caught it... guess who I saw in disguise.... Black Forest.... oooohhh.. 
spooky... ;P That and some other folks too... It was ok.. overall the show 
was much better than their latest album... (I guess that really isn't 
saying much though or is it?)... ;P

Ahhhhh....  Cya...
--Mike

Subject: [sfraves] BSP:  Bam @ 550 w/ Planet of the Drums, Saturday

god, now i feel like i'm totally biting off Amber (sorry Amber!) but i was 
intending to do this despite her posting.

well, this saturday i'm opening up the back room at 550 Barnaveld.  the main 
room headliners are Dieselboy, Dara and AK1200 w/ J Messinian (aka Planet of 
the Drums).

so why am i emailing you all?  because 550 holds a pretty special place in 
my raver heart (ack, stop it brandon!) and it would mean lot to see some 
people in the room when i'm playing.  oh, i know, the woes of the opening 
DJ!  but seriously, i play from 10pm to 11pm and it's reduced admission 
before 11pm...so save some money and join me early!

550 is one of my all time favorite clubs in SF for many reasons.  one, i've 
been to so many kick ass events there from Thump to Analog (RIP) and various 
one off events.  so much incredible talent, so many late nights dancing.  
two, i've met and gotten to know so many kick ass people at 550.  from 
pretty random run-ins with some guy named Tim and this girl Eva to this guy 
Moshen who was hitting on my friend....but they all turned out to become 
really good friends of mine!  to getting really drunk off redbull and vodka 
with Osby and talking to a drunken Veanne outside...550 rocks.

and this saturday i have the pleasure of playing in the back room, which 
happens to be my favorite room of the place (cozy, great sound, and always 
groovy).  so come on out.  i'd love to see you there!


Method One & Breakthru presents
QUALITY
proper drum & bass + breakbeats

SATURDAY JULY 3 at SPACE 550 (550 Barneveld, SF)

Main Room:
THE PLANET OF THE DRUMS TOUR 2004

featuring
AK1200 (run recordings / miami)

Subject: [sfraves] BSP + more!!! READ ME DJ'S!!!!

Hey all you folk out there in SFRaver land!

I am REALLY excited to announce that I have been booked with one of my best 
friends and tag-team partners to play a 3 hour set at the world famous BUZZ 
back home (for me) in Washington DC on August 20th of this year.

This is huge for me. The majority of my time spent in "the scene" was back 
in DC, and Buzz was always my target goal as far as places to play. Some of 
my fondest memories were created there, and I have seen some of the best 
talent in the EDM world perform there.

Anyway - I want to bring back some of what the Bay Area has to offer as far 
as music is concerned, and would like to try and get some of you yahoo's 
booked out east if I can!!!!

MY idea is to get PROMO PACKS from any DJ who is SERIOUSLY interested in 
trying to get some cross-country bookings. I cannot guarantee anything, but 
I am good friends with a bunch of diff. promoters out there, and this way 
your stuff can go directly into their hands - if they like you, most likely 
you will get dragged out there eventually!

If you are interested, a promo pack should include: at least ONE cd of your 
current material (if you spin multiple genres, please include 1 cd per 
genre), any/all contact/booking info, a bio/press pack (a little about 
yourself, try and do a list of gigs you played, etc.).

These can either be given to me in person before I roll out there in August, 
or mailed to me. (email me for my address)

I WILL NOT download sets off your site and burn them for you, I don't have 
the time or material needed to do it!!!

IF YOU HAVE YOOUR OWN PRODUCTION WORK ON DISC, PLEASE include it, because as 
we all know, producer/dj's get gigs much easier these days. Original 
material is a GOOD THING.

Anyhoo...thanks for reading, I hope I can help spread the love from coast to 
coast!

Marc(O)
*THWAP!*//Substructure//Mario Bros.
DC/MD/VA/CA
deep.funky.techy.tribal.progressive.nuskool.beats&bass
AIM:  OPKing138

Subject: [sfraves] boh! and location and stuff

OK so hello all so I just want to make this quick. a while back I
created a gigantic series of rants about the effect location has on
the evolution of musical culture. so, just in case anybody actually
paid attention to that, basically, the fact that I'm back in
California shouldn't necessarily be taken as a conclusion in that. I
came back to California because the guy who bought me the plane ticket
told me I was going to Chicago. kind of a weird misunderstanding with
a consulting agency. anyway I **DO** appear to be back for good, or at
least for now, but it doesn't necessarily mean anything. OK carry on.

-- 
Giles Soundwave
www.djsoundwave.com [spiderman]
www.bowkett.net [peter parker]

Only put off until tomorrow what you are willing to die having left undone.
(Pablo Picasso)

SF Bay Area California, USA

Friday, July 2, 2004 ** Atmosfere (The closing party of the Black President=
 exhibition **

Join us for the closing party of the Black President: The Art and Legacy Of=
 Fela Anikulapo Kuti  exhibition at the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts, an=
d a book release (Fela: From West Africa to West Broadway) by Trevor Schoon=
maker, the Black President exhibition curator.

Black President:The Art and Legacy Of Fela Anikulapo - Kuti
                         Closing  July 4th,  2004

Yerba Buena Center for the Arts,701 Mission Street @ 3rd

                                 San Francisco

                                    Atmosfere
                            Friday, July 2nd @ Mighty
                119 Utah Street, (between 15th & 16th)

                  An underground spiritual jam session.

                           With Resident DJ: Said
                                 &
                                   Special Guest
                                Jerome Sydenham
                            (Ibadan Recordings, NY)
The founder of Ibadan recordings was born and raised in Ibadan, Nigeria to =
an English father and Jamaican mother. As a teenager, he migrated to Englan=
d as a scholar and later to New - York in the early 80's. Here, he became d=
eeply involved in the underground dance music scene both as a DJ and a prom=
oter. He later succeeded in crossing over to the main stream through a unif=
ied approach with Joe Claussell and Kerri Chandler on the prestigious Ten C=
ity's catalogue project. Sydenham's work today is largely influenced by the=
 cultural diversity of his up bringing, echoes of indigenous African and co=
ntemporary western music.

                                             +

                            Soji Odukogbe ( Live guitar)
Nigeria's Soji Odukogbe was for five years the lead guitarist for the late =
Fela Kuti. He draws on an extensive=20
background in Nigerian Afro - beat, highlife and spiritual music, bringing =
unique sensibility to the highlife guitar interpretation.

                                              &

Rasaki Aladokun(Live drum, bongo, conga & talking drum)
Rasaki is a miracle percussionist with over 25 years of experience.  He has=
 been a featured artist in the recording of many notable musicians such as =
King Sunny Ade, Stevie Wonder and Babatunde Olatunji to name a few. Don't m=
iss his extraordinary fusion of talking drum, conga, bongo and Afro-house m=
usic.


Afro-Beat  aesthetic dance performance by  Go Go Pro

                Front Image design by: HONEST

                  $12 / 10pm-4am / 21+  with ID

                          www.fatsouls.com,
      www.mighty119.com,  www.yerbabuenaarts.org

A portion of the proceeds will benefit Yerba Buena Center for the Art, a no=
n profit organization and the Bay Area's premier venue for adventurous art.

There will be lots of giveaways. Early arrival is strongly recommended.

San Francisco California, USA

Friday, July 2, 2004 ** *****TOKYO ELECTRIC***** **

Matthew Curry, aka Safety Scissors, has never been a purist when it comes t=
o musical styles. He would much rather destroy them and glue them back toge=
ther to his own gusto only to bring us his fresh take on pure, quirky, elec=
tric funk that is truly beyond genre definitions. Call it Italo Disco, Elek=
tro, Techno or Berlin-o-tronix and you'll still wonder about the rest. Alon=
g with releases/remixes on FORCE TRACKS, BPITCH CONTROL, CONTEXT, with his =
own platform, PROPTRONIX, getting the well deserved recognition, he must be=
 really after little funk monsters that are messing up the dance floor.

Hear the latest in Electro, Techno, Synthpop, EBM and 80s!=20
This months Special guest: Safety Scissors along with residential dj pressu=
re from Julian DeStrukt, TeflonJacket and Caltrop.

ering to celebrate friendship, unity and good times. We were a small collec=
tive out of Monterey, California that has since left the area but our ties =
remain strong. We are all over the world now, from Barcelona to Seattle to =
L.A. and the time has come for us to reunite in Southern Oregon under the l=
ight of the full moon.

Some of us have brought children into the world since our departure from Mo=
nterey. Lets welcome the little ones as we strengthen our bonds with each o=
ther and the great mother. This event will take place at a beautiful, fores=
ted ecological school called D.E.E.P. For more info please visit:  www.deep=
wild.org

There will be campground space, parking, facilites, full kitchen, playgroun=
d, fabulous gardens, a 20-person teepee, a creek, various ponds, a two-stor=
y cabin, organic vegetables, and an open meadow where we plan to dance unti=
l the sun rises.

A great opportunity to rekindle old friendships and make new ones. Bring th=
e little ones. This is the perfect event for those looking for a positive f=
amily vibe.

Friday night: potluck and acoustic jam
bring some food, your guitar, drum, etc.

Saturday we'll be playing house until the early morning hours.

Line-up:
Ornette AKA Logic
Mr. Ben
Genami
Crystal
Cardinal
DJ Wizard
Real Eyes
DJ Deaf

Everyone welcome. Please bring a can of food or an article of clothing sinc=
e we will be collecting these items for local charity.

Please be advised: self-accountability and responsible partying are a must.=
 This is an ecological school, please respect the grounds by not littering =
and smoking only in the designated areas. D.E.E.P. has asked that no one br=
ing meat to this event. We hope this is not a problem.

Please contact us if you wish to be a part of this event.


http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar2/events/view?identifier=3D1502
Medford area California, USA

Saturday, August 7, 2004 ** Kidz at Play by Kidz at Play **

Hello boys and girls. It is that time again for us to pull out our childhoo=
d games from the past and that youthful spirit that we all remember and lov=
e, where we had no responsibilities but to be Kidz at Play. So Paul the Fan=
man and Dingo (Kidz at Play) would like to invite you to our 1 Year Anniver=
sary Party titled Kidz at Play on August 7th, 2004. Fellow kidz playing wil=
l be: DYNAMIC INTERVENTION aka Mik Cree [UK Dip] - is one of the most infam=
ous producers in the scene today. His trademark hard house/nrg meets acid/t=
rance sound had influenced the very foundation of the underground nu-nrg sc=
ene. He has produced tracks for all the best labels including DIP, TidyTrax=
, Honey Pot, Mohawk and E-Traxx as well as engineered tunes for the most re=
nowned producers such as Andy Farley, Paul Glazbe, Chris C, Madam Zu, and S=
ol Ray. His tunes have been picked up for various worldwide compilations in=
cluding The Nukleuz Hard House Anthems Series, Trade, and Hard House Nation=
=2E Mik is now taking his underground 303 driven style global, with tours o=
f Europe, Australia, South Africa, Asia and North America. TOM SLIK and DYL=
OOT [Skills/Dancing Spirit] - The master minds behind the infamous Skills P=
arties will show us why they have stayed on top for so long. From their out=
 of this world parties to the impeccable presence on stage with their maste=
rful blends of hard and melodic trance. They promise to take you on a journ=
ey never traveled before. MORGAN [Lotek/hardnrg.com/Audio Metamorphosis] - =
Co-owner of the first UK hard house label in America. Lotek Records is gett=
ing mad respect from the other global heavyweights. Along with running an i=
nternational record label, Morgan has produced tracks on Kaktai Records and=
 DIP. Morgan has never failed to bring the house down, so expect the same f=
or this show. KIDZ AT PLAY [Paul the Fanman and Dingo] - For over a year, P=
aul the Fanman and Dingo have joined forces as Kidz at Play, and have been =
shredding the decks together ever since. They blend classic hard house trac=
ks with modern nrg and a twist of psychedelic trance to create their own di=
stinguishable sound. With their solid friendship and dedication to the scen=
e's positive development, they are sure to continue throwing quality partie=
s for everyone to enjoy. MICHAEL LIU and LUKASZ [Illumination Records/Audio=
 Metamorphosis] - The legendary Michael Liu and the rising star Lukasz are =
going to snap the dance floor in half with their hard psychedelic sound. Th=
ey will leave the crowd begging for more. AUDIO ASSAULT [Fury and Cooraw] -=
 These two rising future superstars have created a unique sound all their o=
wn. Taking hard, bouncy, nrg from Cooraw and Fury's hard driving tech nrg w=
ill bring absolute mayham on the dance floor. DJ GIRLIE and CARLOS ALFONSO =
[BR Productions/LiquidVinylDJs] - These two long time best friends and BR P=
roductions Residents have talked and wanted to do a 2x4 set for a long time=
=2E So why keep the public waiting. ERICK! [Audio Metamorphosis] - Making h=
is solo debut, Erick! has a promising future in the SF Bay area scene. So l=
et him show you for himself why his skills behind the decks has landed him =
a deserving spot on the Audio roster. ON-IT [Audio Metamorphosis/Preserve P=
roductions] - Also making his solo debut, the name says it all. From props =
to promotion and finally djing, he will show you why his name is On-It. Pro=
duction for the party: 6 stacks of thundering JK Sound, 4 studio spots and =
2 green eye rippin lasers by Stimulights, and childhood decore created by A=
udio Preservation. Tickets available July 1st. Limited $5, $10, and $15 pre=
sales and $20 at the door. Tickets available at the following locations: Sk=
ills - 510.704.9876, Frequency 8 - 415.221.4142, Solid Grooves - 408.248.63=
99, Beaucoup Beatz - 650.344.8060. Party details: 1000+ capacity, all respo=
nsible ages, east bay location.

Subject: [sfraves] a raver survey

Hello everyone,

I am doing some preliminary research into EMDR (eye movement 
desensitization and reprocessing)
and am wondering if there might be some sort of link to the eye rolling 
prevalent on MDMA

so I was wondering of you all wouldn't mind answering a few questions to 
help me get a direction

1) the nystagmus - was it back and forth like in REM sleep or more random?

2) did it seem to be correlated with any specific internal processing (e.g. 
you were not using MDMA
in a party context but more for introspective work).  Or - what was going 
on in your head when you
noticed the eye rolling?

3) if in a party context, could you describe the psychological or emotional 
state you were in at that time?
Was it "in the moment"?  I guess this goes to why people take E and my 
hypothesis is that the nystagmus
is a sign of information processing - if so, then it may be when people get 
into the right state of "flow"
and the conditions are right (lots of free serotonin around), the 
brain/mind is in a state where it can rewire
itself.  I remember someone "back in the day" telling me he looking forward 
to the nystagmus...

3.5) would you say the repeated experience of nystagmus helped you in some 
way ?

of course, intent and one's focus of attention are important variables, so 
I am trying to get a handle on them

4) was the nystagmus problematic or anxiety inducing, etc?

thank you and science thanks you too :)

Of course, all replies will be DES triple encrypted and stored on a 8 inch 
floppy for security purposes.
If I don't delete them first after doing a NSA certified disk wipe

doug

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  Medical Marijuana Vote in Congress THIS WEEK! 

--=====================_5031895==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed



If you've been following the issue, you probably remember that last summer 
the United States House of Representatives held an important vote on 
medical marijuana:  An amendment sponsored by Rep. Maurice Hinchey (D-NY), 
cosponsored by Rep. Dana Rohrabacher (R-CA), would have forbid the US Dept. 
of Justice from using its resources to interfere with state medical 
marijuana laws.  Though the Hinchey amendment was defeated, the number of 
members who voted for it, 152, represented a 150% increase in Congressional 
support for medical marijuana since the only previous House vote on the 
issue five years before.  Rep. Hinchey is again championing his amendment 
this summer, and it is anticipated that a vote on it will take place 
sometime next month.

I am writing today to ask you to e-mail and call your US Rep. to ask him or 
her to vote YES on the Hinchey medical marijuana amendment when it comes to 
the House floor.  IT IS LIKELY THAT THIS WILL HAPPEN THIS WEEK, MAYBE EVEN 
TUESDAY JULY 6TH OR WEDNESDAY JULY 7TH.  Whether you think your Rep. is 
likely to support the Hinchey amendment or to oppose it, it is important 
that he or she hear from constituents like you who have the power to vote 
stay or go in their reelection campaign in November.  That's why I hope 
you'll take a few moments to contact your Rep. today regarding this issue.

To take action, please do the following:

1) Please visit http://stopthedrugwar.org/medicalmarijuana/ to write to 
your US Rep. in support of the Hinchey amendment.

2) Please call your Rep.'s office on the phone to follow up.  You can use 
the Congressional Switchboard at (202) 224-3121 to reach the office, or to 
find out who your Rep. is if you don't know, or you can find the direct 
phone number at http://www.house.gov online.  When you're done, send us an 
e-mail to DRCNet at alert-feedback@drcnet.org 
(mailto:alert-feedback@drcnet.org) to let us know you've taken action and 
to report to us any information you receive from the staffer taking your 
call on your Rep.'s intentions.  DRCNet will forward any such information 
to lobbyists working on this bill here in Washington.

3) Please forward this e-mail to as many friends and other likely medical 
marijuana supporters know that now is the time to take action.

Thanks for being a part of this important effort.  Visit 
http://stopthedrugwar.org to learn all about this issue and how to be a 
part of bringing about change.

          http://stopthedrugwar.org/medicalmarijuana/



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war, 
corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong 
its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-Abraham Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

  "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

Subject: Re: [sfraves] I hope it's worth it

I've been lusting after this mixer since it was announced.  For me
it's not so much old mixer/new mixer or old car/new mixer, it's more
that this looks like the first "perfect" mixer.  It's like a pioneer
but w/o the shitty quality.  It's like a Rane but with features.  It's
like a big Allen & Heath with a useful layout and crossfader.  Street
of $1699 puts it out of reach
for the near future however.

If anyone knows where I can demo one of these, I'd love to spend some
time on it.

-Erik

Just a note.  If you can't attend physically, you can participate virtually:

ATTEND THE ACLU MEMBERSHIP CONFERENCE VIRTUALLY

If you can't join us in San Francisco for our 2004 Membership Conference, 
you can be there in spirit by joining our conference webcasts over the next 
three days. Whether online or in person, we need as many people as possible 
to "Stand Up for Freedom" and make this conference a huge success.

Highlights of the conference include a debate featuring former Vermont 
Governor Howard Dean and Colorado Governor Bill Owens, and remarks by FBI 
whistleblower Coleen Rowley, former National Security Advisor Richard 
Clarke, MoveOn.org co-founder Joan Blades, and San Francisco Mayor Gavin 
Newsom. You don't have to miss out on these great sessions. Please join us 
for our webcasts. You can watch them live or view them later in our video 
archive:

http://www.aclu.org/2004memberconf/?orgid=n&MX=1365&H=0


Welcome Plenary
Featuring ACLU Executive Director Anthony D. Romero
Tuesday, July 6th Approximately 5:45 PM PST

Civil Liberties Developments in the U.S. Supreme Court
Wednesday, July 7th, Approximately 8:45 AM PST

Say "I Do" to Marriage for Same-Sex Couples
Wednesday, July 7th Approximately 9:30 AM PST

Usual Suspects: Racial Profiling in America
Wednesday, July 7th Approximately 12:30 PM PST

The Gala Dinner
Wednesday, July 7th Approximately 6:15 PM PST

Freedom's Foundation: The First Amendment
Thursday, July 8th Approximately 8:30 AM PST

Balancing National Security and Liberty:
Keeping America Safe and Free
Thursday, July 8th Approximately Noon PST

Civil Liberties and the War on Terrorism.
Thursday, July 8th Approximately 5:30 PST

The Next Generation of Civil Libertarians
Thursday, July 8th Approximately 5:30 PST


Participation via the Internet in these events is free. To attend the web 
casts use the following link:

http://www.aclu.org/2004memberconf/?orgid=n&MX=1365&H=0

There is still time to attend the full conference by registering in-person. 
Use the following link for details, agenda, and registration information:

http://www.aclu.org/2004memberconf/?orgid=n&MX=1365&H=0




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and causes 
me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war, 
corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong 
its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-Abraham Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

  "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

Subject: [sfraves] SRR: More Than Music and Style

--=====================_5371443==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit



More Than Music and Style




By , The Black Commentator
Posted on July 5, 2004, Printed on July 6, 2004


"We need a national agenda to make sure that our community has more than 
music and style. We can't continue to do bootleg activism. We've got to do 
institutional activism, creating media outlets that will push our propaganda."
 Jeff Johnson, America Votes youth coordinator and commentator for BET's 
"Rap City"

"We're all activists. The question is, what are we active for? Are we 
active to forward a rightwing agenda in America, or are we active for 
liberation?"
 Rosa Clemente, co-founder, National Hip Hop Political Convention (NHHPC)

"Just as the Christian Coalition tapped into an existing infrastructure of 
conservative churches, we as a hip hop generation are tapping into an 
existing infrastructure that has been created by the hip hop movement."
 Bakari Kitwana, author and co-founder, NHHPC

American capitalism markets everything it can package and discards or 
mangles the rest. As a result, most "information" found in the marketplace 
is, by definition, disinformation  a "product" molded to suit a 
transaction, containing no reliable connection to the truth.

In the absence of a mass black political movement, the generation born 
after 1965 has been named for the culture it created, rather than  as with 
the preceding generation  the political goals for which they fought. Hip 
hop culture, the miraculous invention of black and Latino youth, is now 
marketed to the world by five multinational corporations. The social 
"reality" and political worldview of an entire generation (now going on two 
generations) has been packaged for sale to both its creators and the larger 
market: the planet.

Having been commercially defined as a raw demographic  a cohort of 
customers and product-modelers  the hip hop generation stares into a 
mirror that has been purposely cracked and deformed for somebody else's 
profit. Its activists, as brilliant as any produced at any time or place in 
history  and intent, like all healthy young humans, on changing the world 
 find that they must first confront the marketed version of themselves.

The 3,000 young people who attended the National Hip Hop Political 
Convention in Newark, New Jersey, June 16-20, were determined to define 
themselves through a politics of struggle  to begin to redraw the map of 
the world through the prisms of their own experience.

"We are here today as young people under the hip hop umbrella," said Ras 
Baraka, the 34-year-old Deputy Mayor of Newark, New Jersey, and one of the 
organizers of the event. "Politics is about the seizure of power," Baraka 
told the crowd. "Some of us don't understand what that means. Our kids 
think that seizing power is standing on a corner and doing the things they 
usually do." Each of the 500 official delegates from 17 states had 
registered 50 voters to earn the right to represent their generation.

Baraka, who is also an assistant public school principal, doesn't show up 
on the Right's short list of hip hop generation "leaders." By cynically 
misinterpreting polling data that show black youth to be increasingly 
estranged from the Democratic Party, and through relentless national media 
exposure of young, corporate-sponsored black politicians, the Right 
attempts to package the hip hop generation as essentially more 
"conservative" than its elders. The darlings of the Right include Tennessee 
Congressman Harold Ford, 34, the Democratic Leadership Council's most 
prominent voice in the Congressional Black Caucus, and Cory Booker, the 
35-year-old former Newark Councilman who, with the backing of the national 
conservative political and funding network, nearly captured City Hall in 2002.

What the conservatives prove is that the current younger generation 
contains its share of opportunists  just as did the last generation, and 
the one before that. But opportunists only show up when they get paid, and 
represent nothing but the finances of their sugar daddies. The National Hip 
Hop Political Convention had no deep-pocket sponsors, yet it succeeded on 
the strength of the organizers' peer credibility, and the near-universal 
desire among black youth to overturn the status quo.

Continuity of Struggle

So vacuous has American political discourse become that corporate 
spin-makers posing as journalists find it possible to produced 24-hour news 
cycles that reveal nothing at all except the political preferences of media 
owners. The mass marketing of attitudes and styles in place of issues and 
substance seeks to drain the language itself of the capacity to resist 
power. A generation of black youth that is imprisoned in astronomical 
numbers is simultaneously deployed as lifestyle models for the privileged, 
prison-immune classes  mass-produced insanity on its face. Yet in the 
continuity of black struggle, people and truths "crushed to earth" 
inevitably rise again to confront oppression.

"I believe that we are in this room because some slave willed us here," 
said Rev. Osagyefo Sekou, the 30-something Executive Director of New York 
Common Ground, and a mover-and-shaker of the convention. "We need a living 
wage for everyone. I call that a moral question."

Moral people seek to end injustice, mass media's truly taboo topic. Only by 
relentless avoidance of the continuity of injustices against black people 
can the media create the impression of vast chasms between black generations.

"Get the foot of oppression off our necks." From the hip hop perspective, 
54-year-old Rev. Calvin Butts, of Harlem's Abyssinian Baptist Church, 
qualifies as an elder. Yet his irreducible demand, delivered at a Town Hall 
meeting on the first full day of the convention, was identical to that of 
his hip hop audience. Many were aware of Butts' history of broad brush 
criticism of hip hop culture. However, in the context of a shared struggle 
against historical oppression, differences shrink. "Organizing must be done 
around a moral core. That moral core must respect all of us  our women, 
our children, our elders," said the preacher. "Without a moral core, the 
revolution is wiped out."

Who would argue with that?

Rich corporations mass-market immorality (after all, they are the only ones 
who can), and then label their products as authentic representations of hip 
hop generation morals. Righteously, the organizers of the Newark convention 
gave primacy to the morality of struggle  to the chapter and verse of 
resistance.

A secular elder, Ron Daniels, currently Executive Director of the Center 
for Constitutional Rights and a prime mover in over three decades of black 
political conventions, showed the seamless connections between culture, 
morality, and politics. "Art must be functional and committed," said 
Daniels. "This generation must come to the forefront and lead us to change 
America." Nevertheless, "We cannot, in the name of 'realness,' denigrate 
ourselves."

"Denigration" was the last thing on these young people's minds. At the core 
of the convention were perhaps a thousand committed activists  ranging 
from seasoned, 30-something veterans to promising neophytes  who have the 
potential to do great damage to the powers-that-be.

Fight the Power

In what now seems the Golden Age of socially conscious hip hop, Public 
Enemy's Chuck D demanded that his audiences "fight the powers that be." 
Born in 1960, Chuck D and his peers, the inventors of the culture, are the 
political and chronological links between the so-called "Black Power" and 
hip hop generations. Currently a host on radio's Air America network, Chuck 
D recalled the suppression of hip hop. "From 1979 to 1992, there was a 
sheer abandonment [of hip hop music by black radio programmers]," he said. 
They banned it."

During that period, hip hop broke out of the neighborhoods and fueled the 
founding of a host of independent (mostly white-owned) record labels  an 
explosion of musical creativity and social commentary of all kinds. But not 
until the early nineties, after mega-corporations moved to swallow up the 
genre, did black-programmed radio embrace the music of black youth. 
Programmers ponderously intoned that hip hop fans were too young to attract 
advertisers, that they were not a valuable demographic  an amazing claim, 
since the R & B music that carried black radio to new heights in the 
Sixties was also the music of youth. But many in the hip hop industry 
understood the real deal: Black programmers were afraid of projecting a 
street "image." Essentially, hip hop had an intra-black, class problem. Don 
Cornelius wouldn't touch it, even though his "Soul Train" TV audience 
skewed to the younger demos.

In one of the great ironies of African American cultural history, black 
radio finally embraced hip hop in the early nineties  precisely when the 
huge corporate record labels shifted to gangsta rap. Industry researchers 
discovered that hip hop's most "active" consumer base was composed of 12- 
and 13-year-olds  tweens  a cohort that is drawn to repetitive profanity 
and, not having reached the sexual pairing-off stage of development, revels 
in misogyny. Artists and recordings (A & R) executives put great pressure 
on rap acts to become more "real"  a word that became a euphemism for 
egregiously profane and abusive language. In no time at all, the industry 
began churning out music geared primarily to younger juveniles. Black 
radio, which had had such a problem with hip hop before the 
corporate-guided ascendance of gangsta rap, dived into the cesspool with 
wild enthusiasm. The airwaves became filled with edits, bleeps and audio 
interruptions that did nothing to hide the "denigrating" content.

Black middle-class propriety was trumped by the servile imperative to 
follow the (white) corporate leader. No one can measure the accumulated 
arrested development afflicting youngsters raised on a profane corporate 
formula designed for tweens.

New Times, New Tasks

However, the music industry's version of "real" hasn't blotted out reality 
for the entirety of the hip hop generation. Mutulu, of Dead Prez, sees the 
world, clearly. "We gotta keep going," he urged the Newark convention. "If 
we don't keep going, rap will continue to be drafted into the capitalist 
world, the crack world, the prison industrial complex."

With a seriousness that wholly contradicts hip hop stereotypes, 
conventioneers fanned out in the scorching sun over three connected 
campuses  Essex County College, Rutgers-Newark and New Jersey Institute of 
Technology  to attend 50 workshops on every conceivable aspect of organizing.

The "movement" that was largely demobilized by an upwardly mobile, 
self-conscious "leadership class" in the late sixties, was getting an update.

"We looked at cities that have higher levels of black cops," Monifa Bandele 
explained to a workshop titled: Why Vote? Community Voices on the Criminal 
Justice System. "What we saw, clear as day, is that high levels of black 
cops is not the solution."

Bandele is a Brooklyn leader of the Malcolm X Grassroots Movement, which 
also has chapters in Alabama, Mississippi and California  all represented 
at the Newark convention. Black cops are often an active or passive 
problem, she said, as was revealed in the 1997 torture of Abner Louima. 
"You would be shocked to know how many black cops were there, in the 
precinct [where Louima was sodomized with a mop handle], and they said 
nothing, they did nothing."

At a workshop on Our Schools, Our Kids and the Money, gray-bearded Junius 
Williams, a legendary Newark scholar/activist who directs the Rutgers 
Abbott Leadership Institute, spoke of a brief period when street youth were 
drawn to political warfare rather than mindless gang-banging.  "Had these 
men been around 30 or 35 years ago," said Williams, referring to local gang 
members who had spoken to the convention the night before, "they would have 
been in a group like the Black Panthers or the Young Lords."

Whether as neo-Panthers (the New Black Panther Party was represented at the 
convention), as hip hop advocacy journalists (former Source Magazine 
executive editor Bakari Kitwana co-founded the convention), or among the 
numerous young teachers gathered in Newark under the hip hop "umbrella," 
what's crucial is that youth become engaged in struggle of some 
kind.  Rather than whine about older politicians who refuse to get out of 
the way, convention co-chair Angela Woodson exhorted: "Don't wait for the 
old guard. If you're ready, run!"

Electoral politics, the route taken to the exclusion of all others by 
critical elements of a previous generation's movement, has demonstrated its 
hollowness in the absence of year-round, grassroots organizing. "Electoral 
politics is futile, until they put revolution on the ballot," said Dead 
Prez's Mutulu, 32. But he says it without prejudice to those who choose 
electoral political action  as long as they act!

Very late on a Saturday night, hours behind schedule due to failure to 
anticipate a flurry of amendments, the exhausted delegates to the National 
Hip Hop Political Convention adopted a Five-Point Agenda on Education, 
Economic Justice, Criminal Justice, Health and Human Rights.

Last week, hip hop music blared at the entrance to a downtown Chicago park, 
where a huge food- and drink-tasting festival was underway. The local 
chapter of the National Hip Hop Political Convention was busy, registering 
voters. All across the country, they are taking action.


 2004 Independent Media Institute. All rights reserved.



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

Subject: [sfraves] Re: NRR: Anyone attending the ACLU conference?

	Other American Civil Liberties Union conference highlights include 
Wayne LaPierre, Executive Vice-President of the National Rifle 
Association, and former Republican Congressman Bob Barr & former 
Independent Counsel Ken Starr who helped get a president who was 
abusing his power impeached for only the second time in U.S. history.

	I'm not aware of any outright libertarians on the line-up this year, 
but ACLU president Nadine Strossen has spoken at Libertarian 
conventions. Props to the ACLU for recognizing that people on the left 
aren't the only ones working for freedom, and that there is more to the 
Constitution than is dreamt of in Michael Moore's philosophy. I'll 
probably go down and check out some of the happenings tomorrow...

Peace, love & liberty,
					<<< Starchild >>>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Re: NRR: Anyone attending the ACLU conference?

the ACLU!

when I was 18, I did a radio talk show on the legalization of
marijuana, and one of my guests was the director of the Chicago ACLU.
the other guest was the school nurse. I had an activist lawyer whose
specialty was public policy debating the school nurse. it was
ruthless, underhanded, and magnificent. afterwards I got kicked off
the radio station, but every stoner for thirty miles knew who I was.

anyway I was able to recruit him for this because I actually organized
a high school chapter of the ACLU when I was in high school. this was
the only high school ACLU chapter in existence at the time, and it
probably still is. wait wait wait maybe that was pathetic and geeky
and too lame for words. okay actually none of that ever happened.
ever. I made it all up.

anyway whatever. my position on the ACLU these days is different. they
rock but it's not my thing. BUT, on the topic of politics, and
apologies if it's already been posted, BUT, on the topic of politics,
Governator Schwarzenegger is doing a public policy poll on gay
marriage and the conservatives are coming out in force. (no pun
intended.) so, if you feel that all Americans have the same rights to
life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness, if you feel that it's an
American right to define your own pursuit of happiness, without some
sick religious wacko from Alabama telling innocent people what they
can and can't do, then please:

>Call (916) 445-2841
>On the phone tree, press in order:
>Press #5 for "Hot Issues."
>Press #1 for Same Sex Marriage.
>Press #1 to support gay marriage in California.
>You're done.
>Thanks!
>PLEASE REPOST THIS!

I did it. It felt good.

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] The concord bouncey gym place ?

hehe yeah, small world. . .

there was one outdoor party I went to in livermore off vasco once. As I was
driving there I was thinking like "where in the hell would this place be".
When I turned into the glowstick marked entrance, I realized it was Sandhill
Ranch, this big mining area/motocross track owned by an alcoholic asshole
named Tom anderson (if I remember right, he always rode around on race day
on a quad with a teddy bear strapped to the front).

wierd experience. The actual main dancing area was their lil 1/4 mile oval
track with the pussy mx track in the middle. People were dancing on top the
doubles, and there were lasers n lights on "godzilla" (this big hill making
up part of the main mx track).

I used to ride there almost weekly when they were open. Cool place to
explore, caves n trails. . .they also used to have paintball games there.
Had some of my best races there, even tho the dirst was always so dry and
fukked. . .I hate tracks where in the morning they're super muddy n slick,
and an hour later it's so dusty you can't see a thing. I've raced there when
it was 100+ deg outside, and when it was like 28 deg outside. Hard to go
fast when you can't move your fingers.

and I think the gym is just called like Mikes Gym or something like that. If
I go up there tomorrow I'll check it out and let you know, not like it's
really important, but now I kinda need to know. . . just cuz. . .

: )

arycK

X-Scanned-By: MIMEDefang 2.43

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: UpLift at SubLounge Thursday

UpLift
July 8th, 2004 (2nd Thursdays)

AuraSF returns for its monthly event at the SubLounge: "UpLift"

Come down and relax as the middle of summer is your excuse to come
unwind, have some drinks and make your workweek a little bit shorter.
There is no cover, lots of free parking and some drink specials that
will not burn a hole in your pocket!

With beats served up from some of the Bay's greatest @ Sublounge, voted
the Bay's #1 "Dance Music" spot and "Best Bar, Best DJ Bar & Best New
Club" BY SFWeekly & Bay Guardian

Featuring Electro, Breaks, Trance, Drum & Bass, House & Hip-Hop.

Rotating Resident DJ's
Koroma (AuraSF, Digital Empire); Floorcraft (AuraSF, Hosstribe) ; JC
(AuraSF, KZSU, Epiphany); Iyad (Hosstribe)
with Guest Dj's Monthly
This month's guest DJ: DJ Lantz (Netamp)

Chris Fabbri Spinning some downtempo from 6p-8p

Visuals: Art Up Under Lights by Chris Fabbri & Dan Martinez

Rotating Art by Chris Fabbri

Guest Artist - Dan Martinez
www.artistbyday.com

Venue: SubLounge

Address: 628 20th Street @ 3rd Street, San Francisco, CA (Near SnoDrift)

Time: 8pm - 2am

Cover: Free All Night, 21+



http://www.jcthedj.com

right, and Bush is in the Whitehouse.

"Opinions are my own only, and do not necessarily represent those of
KZSU Radio or Stanford University." (or words to that effect.)
