From sfraves-return-113732-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Thu Jul 08 02:52:56 2004
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-113732-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 53320 invoked by uid 1103); 8 Jul 2004 02:52:54 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 53296 invoked from network); 8 Jul 2004 02:52:53 -0000
Message-Id: <6.1.1.1.2.20040707195227.02407190@localhost>
X-Sender: apollo@localhost
X-Mailer: QUALCOMM Windows Eudora Version 6.1.1.1
Date: Wed, 07 Jul 2004 19:52:47 -0700
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
From: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
	boundary="=====================_11690019==.ALT"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] HEY DJ:  FUCK YOU!!!

--=====================_11690019==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

HEY DJ:  FUCK YOU!!!

Anyone Can Rock the Party (from VICE Magazine)

You know that thing called DJing? Playing records in bars or at stupid art 
openings for money? Guess what DJing is? The biggest fucking bullshit con 
of all time! People who get over as DJs are making the easiest money ever, 
because they've convinced every PR person and club owner in the world that 
they're doing something only a few natural-born geniuses can do. It's 
laughable. A 70-year-old blind Ethiopian leper with 10 broken fingers can 
"spin" just as well as any B-list celebrity at any instore party for some 
gay snowboarding jeans company. I promise.

And those other guys who do all the little flick-flick, crabby moves on 
records that are covered with spots of adhesive tape that are supposed to 
mean something? Those aren't DJs! I don't know what to call them. Nerds, 
maybe? They called themselves "turntablists" five years ago, but I think 
that got embarrassing. One thing is for sure, though: Those guys don't DJ 
on the actual paying gig circuit that I'm on, because no hammered jock 
chicks or guidos from West Orange, N.J., will dance to an hour-long 
abstract scratch frenzy over a P-Funk B-side.

I've been making loads of supplementary income by DJing for a few years 
now, and I can barely even scratch my own back. All you really need is a CD 
burner, Kazaa, and passably cool taste in music. Here, I'll tell you all 
about my life as a party DJ:

TECHNIQUE
FLOW: The only slightly ephemeral skill to learn is flow. Have you ever 
made a mixtape for someone you had a crush on? Then you already know what 
flow isthe ability to maintain a mood. I was at a party once where the DJ 
kept playing one danceable hip-hop track, then one undanceable slow 
classic-rock track, one hip-hop, one slow rock, on and on like that for an 
hour! We would get up and dance, and then sit down, and then we finally 
just stayed down and shot him really dirty looks. It was the opposite of 
flow. To master flow, you just need to not be a fucking moron. Can you 
handle that?

Segueing from one genre to a totally different one is easy. You just build 
tiny little bridges instead of taking one big leap. For example, let's go 
from a hip-hop set to a punk-rock set. You play your last rap song, then a 
Prince track. Then maybe some ESG. Then the Slits. Boom! You're into the 
punk before they know what hit 'em.

LCD: This is your audience. It stands for Lowest Common Denominator. You 
are DJing for drunks and cokeheads, and they need the aural equivalent of 
safety blankets. What would you rather hear when you're high as fuck in a 
bar: Journey or some obscure acid-house? (If you're a geek, don't answer 
that.)
I used to spend all my time collecting the rarest tracks, stuff that when I 
heard it at home it would totally blow my mind. Guess what? No one cared. 
In fact, they stopped dancing. Now I stick to playing stuff that I liked 
when I was a teenager (the Misfits, "O.P.P.," and songs from John Hughes 
movies) and I'm golden. When in doubt, go nostalgic.

CUEING: This is where you enact the flow thing I just told you about. You 
have two sides, right and left. When something's playing on the right, 
think of a song that would sound good after it. Cue that song up on the 
left by pressing the same buttons on a CD player that you've pressed 1,000 
times before (or putting a needle down in the appropriate groove on a 
record). When the song on the right side is about to end, slide the little 
thingy in the box between the decks to the left. When you're a little less 
than halfway over, press "play" on the CD or "start" on the turntable. 
Congratulations, you're DJing. Can I get a "That was easy"?

PERKS
LINES: A huge guilty pleasure is cutting the line and marching right up to 
the velvet rope all casual, going, "Hi, I'm the DJ." I like to go to a gig 
dressed like a total slob. The nicer the club, the shittier I look. Then I 
can stroll past all the people who used to spit on me in high school and 
make a big huge deal about going through the door first.

MONEY: Depending on who you are, a DJ's salary for one night can range from 
a few free drinks to obscene amounts (for the big shots) that make you hate 
capitalism. I heard Paul Sevigny got fucking $15,000 to DJ at Sundance. I 
hope that is DJ urban legend. Most DJs I know are pretty psyched if they 
get a couple hundred. Art openings should pay more, like $350. And 
remember: Always get paid in cash on the night of. Within 24 hours all 
money magically transforms into cocaine blown up some model's ass.

COMPLIMENTS: One of the best things about DJing is when you play a really 
kickass song and people come up to you dancing, going "I love this song!" 
You get all proud and pretend you wrote it. You're like, "Thanks!" Yeah, I 
downloaded "Youth Gone Wild," I rule. It's like being told your air-guitar 
skills are fucking SICK.

GEAR
NEEDLES: Those sleek, aerodynamic, $500 fancy-pants needles are the second 
biggest scam in DJing besides convincing people that DJing is hard. For 
totally serviceable needles, go to one of those electronics stores on Canal 
Street and get the cheapest set possible. You can talk them down on the 
price, too. I got a pair plus some shitty headphones for $90 after I 
sweet-talked the sales guy for a minute. (BTW, the cheap needles are called 
hip-hop needles and that's mean against blacks.)

MIXERS: There are a few brands of mixers, but who cares. DJs would like for 
you to think mixers are all complicated, but they're really about as hard 
to figure out as a home stereo. I once spun at this lesbian party where I 
ended up giving girls DJ lessons all night. They were lined up across the 
room, and it only took me a few seconds to show each of them the basics. As 
Garfield would say, "Big fat hairy deal." Once I showed them how simple it 
really is, they were shocked at the big deal that people make about the 
whole thing. Yeah, there are cute little tricks you can do. If you're 
playing a hip-hop song, it's fun to cut out the bass after the second verse 
and then kick it back in full force on the chorus. It's a nifty party trick 
and it makes girls lose their shit. But you can also just say, "Fuck it," 
set them all in the middle, and read a book in between tracks.

WHEELS OF STEEL: Please don't call them that. Don't call them "the ones and 
the twos" either. It sounds like your mom saying, "Homie don't play that."

ETIQUETTE
OOPS: You're going to fuck up. The record will skip or you'll be distracted 
by some drunk kid telling you how much "Bizarre Love Triangle" means to him 
or you'll let two Wire songs play in a row. No big whup. Everyone's too 
wasted to care. You should be too. Just take the opportunity to make 
announcements. I usually shout out important information such as, "Don't 
stop the rock, motherfuckers!" or "I need to pee!"

REQUESTS: Try not to cry when people request Missy Elliott, again. Or "Hey 
Ya!" or "Milkshake." Or Cher when you are spinning Minor Threat. Or simply 
"hip-hop." Or any genre of music, in fact. You wouldn't believe how often 
people request an entirely different genre of music than what the DJ is 
playing. It's infuriatingly rude. You're telling the DJ that you hate his 
or her music. If you don't like what I'm playing, wait 10 fucking minutes 
and I'll be onto a new thing anyway.

If you simply must request a song, it better be within the scope of what 
I'm playing at that very second AND it better be such an insane song that 
it'll make me go, "Oh shit, yeah, why didn't I think of that?"

True fact: That's only happened to me once out of hundreds and hundreds of 
requests. The song was "Sweet Emotion" by Aerosmith, believe it or not.

SAVING YOUR BEST STUFF: This is tricky. You don't want to blow your load 
before the night hits maximum party time, so you squirrel away your 
guaranteed crowd-pleasing monster jams and you wait, thinking, "Now? Now? 
Do I drop it?" And finally you're like, "It's time, I'm gonna hit it." And 
boom! It's a fuckin' nuclear-bomb explosion. A roomful of people you would 
barely be able to look at in the daytime are freaking out like they just 
won the lottery, all because you pressed a button. That's why you do this 
shit. That, and the fact that you are a total fucking spaz.

AMY KELLNER


Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and causes 
me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war, 
corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong 
its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-Abraham Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

  "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

--=====================_11690019==.ALT--

places

prolong

wealth is

> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: Apollo [mailto:apollo@speakeasy.org]
> > Sent: Wednesday, July 07, 2004 7:53 PM
> > To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
> > Subject: [sfraves] HEY DJ: FUCK YOU!!!
> >
> > HEY DJ:  FUCK YOU!!!
> >
> > Anyone Can Rock the Party (from VICE Magazine)
> >
> > You know that thing called DJing? Playing records in bars or at stupid
>art
> > openings for money? Guess what DJing is? The biggest fucking bullshit
>con
> > of all time! People who get over as DJs are making the easiest money
>ever,
> > because they've convinced every PR person and club owner in the world
>that
> > they're doing something only a few natural-born geniuses can do. It's
> > laughable. A 70-year-old blind Ethiopian leper with 10 broken fingers
>can
> > "spin" just as well as any B-list celebrity at any instore party for
>some
> > gay snowboarding jeans company. I promise.
> >
> > And those other guys who do all the little flick-flick, crabby moves
>on
> > records that are covered with spots of adhesive tape that are supposed
>to
> > mean something? Those aren't DJs! I don't know what to call them.
>Nerds,
> > maybe? They called themselves "turntablists" five years ago, but I
>think
> > that got embarrassing. One thing is for sure, though: Those guys don't
>DJ
> > on the actual paying gig circuit that I'm on, because no hammered jock
> > chicks or guidos from West Orange, N.J., will dance to an hour-long
> > abstract scratch frenzy over a P-Funk B-side.
> >
> > I've been making loads of supplementary income by DJing for a few
>years
> > now, and I can barely even scratch my own back. All you really need is
>a
> > CD
> > burner, Kazaa, and passably cool taste in music. Here, I'll tell you
>all
> > about my life as a party DJ:
> >
> > TECHNIQUE
> > FLOW: The only slightly ephemeral skill to learn is flow. Have you
>ever
> > made a mixtape for someone you had a crush on? Then you already know
>what
> > flow is-the ability to maintain a mood. I was at a party once where
>the DJ
> > kept playing one danceable hip-hop track, then one undanceable slow
> > classic-rock track, one hip-hop, one slow rock, on and on like that
>for an
> > hour! We would get up and dance, and then sit down, and then we
>finally
> > just stayed down and shot him really dirty looks. It was the opposite
>of
> > flow. To master flow, you just need to not be a fucking moron. Can you
> > handle that?
> >
> > Segueing from one genre to a totally different one is easy. You just
>build
> > tiny little bridges instead of taking one big leap. For example, let's
>go
> > from a hip-hop set to a punk-rock set. You play your last rap song,
>then a
> > Prince track. Then maybe some ESG. Then the Slits. Boom! You're into
>the
> > punk before they know what hit 'em.
> >
> > LCD: This is your audience. It stands for Lowest Common Denominator.
>You
> > are DJing for drunks and cokeheads, and they need the aural equivalent
>of
> > safety blankets. What would you rather hear when you're high as fuck
>in a
> > bar: Journey or some obscure acid-house? (If you're a geek, don't
>answer
> > that.)
> > I used to spend all my time collecting the rarest tracks, stuff that
>when
> > I
> > heard it at home it would totally blow my mind. Guess what? No one
>cared.
> > In fact, they stopped dancing. Now I stick to playing stuff that I
>liked
> > when I was a teenager (the Misfits, "O.P.P.," and songs from John
>Hughes
> > movies) and I'm golden. When in doubt, go nostalgic.
> >
> > CUEING: This is where you enact the flow thing I just told you about.
>You
> > have two sides, right and left. When something's playing on the right,
> > think of a song that would sound good after it. Cue that song up on
>the
> > left by pressing the same buttons on a CD player that you've pressed
>1,000
> > times before (or putting a needle down in the appropriate groove on a
> > record). When the song on the right side is about to end, slide the
>little
> > thingy in the box between the decks to the left. When you're a little
>less
> > than halfway over, press "play" on the CD or "start" on the turntable.
> > Congratulations, you're DJing. Can I get a "That was easy"?
> >
> > PERKS
> > LINES: A huge guilty pleasure is cutting the line and marching right
>up to
> > the velvet rope all casual, going, "Hi, I'm the DJ." I like to go to a
>gig
> > dressed like a total slob. The nicer the club, the shittier I look.
>Then I
> > can stroll past all the people who used to spit on me in high school
>and
> > make a big huge deal about going through the door first.
> >
> > MONEY: Depending on who you are, a DJ's salary for one night can range
> > from
> > a few free drinks to obscene amounts (for the big shots) that make you
> > hate
> > capitalism. I heard Paul Sevigny got fucking $15,000 to DJ at
>Sundance. I
> > hope that is DJ urban legend. Most DJs I know are pretty psyched if
>they
> > get a couple hundred. Art openings should pay more, like $350. And
> > remember: Always get paid in cash on the night of. Within 24 hours all
> > money magically transforms into cocaine blown up some model's ass.
> >
> > COMPLIMENTS: One of the best things about DJing is when you play a
>really
> > kickass song and people come up to you dancing, going "I love this
>song!"
> > You get all proud and pretend you wrote it. You're like, "Thanks!"
>Yeah, I
> > downloaded "Youth Gone Wild," I rule. It's like being told your
>air-guitar
> > skills are fucking SICK.
> >
> > GEAR
> > NEEDLES: Those sleek, aerodynamic, $500 fancy-pants needles are the
>second
> > biggest scam in DJing besides convincing people that DJing is hard.
>For
> > totally serviceable needles, go to one of those electronics stores on
> > Canal
> > Street and get the cheapest set possible. You can talk them down on
>the
> > price, too. I got a pair plus some shitty headphones for $90 after I
> > sweet-talked the sales guy for a minute. (BTW, the cheap needles are
> > called
> > hip-hop needles and that's mean against blacks.)
> >
> > MIXERS: There are a few brands of mixers, but who cares. DJs would
>like
> > for
> > you to think mixers are all complicated, but they're really about as
>hard
> > to figure out as a home stereo. I once spun at this lesbian party
>where I
> > ended up giving girls DJ lessons all night. They were lined up across
>the
> > room, and it only took me a few seconds to show each of them the
>basics.
> > As
> > Garfield would say, "Big fat hairy deal." Once I showed them how
>simple it
> > really is, they were shocked at the big deal that people make about
>the
> > whole thing. Yeah, there are cute little tricks you can do. If you're
> > playing a hip-hop song, it's fun to cut out the bass after the second
> > verse
> > and then kick it back in full force on the chorus. It's a nifty party
> > trick
> > and it makes girls lose their shit. But you can also just say, "Fuck
>it,"
> > set them all in the middle, and read a book in between tracks.
> >
> > WHEELS OF STEEL: Please don't call them that. Don't call them "the
>ones
> > and
> > the twos" either. It sounds like your mom saying, "Homie don't play
>that."
> >
> > ETIQUETTE
> > OOPS: You're going to fuck up. The record will skip or you'll be
> > distracted
> > by some drunk kid telling you how much "Bizarre Love Triangle" means
>to
> > him
> > or you'll let two Wire songs play in a row. No big whup. Everyone's
>too
> > wasted to care. You should be too. Just take the opportunity to make
> > announcements. I usually shout out important information such as,
>"Don't
> > stop the rock, motherfuckers!" or "I need to pee!"
> >
> > REQUESTS: Try not to cry when people request Missy Elliott, again. Or
>"Hey
> > Ya!" or "Milkshake." Or Cher when you are spinning Minor Threat. Or
>simply
> > "hip-hop." Or any genre of music, in fact. You wouldn't believe how
>often
> > people request an entirely different genre of music than what the DJ
>is
> > playing. It's infuriatingly rude. You're telling the DJ that you hate
>his
> > or her music. If you don't like what I'm playing, wait 10 fucking
>minutes
> > and I'll be onto a new thing anyway.
> >
> > If you simply must request a song, it better be within the scope of
>what
> > I'm playing at that very second AND it better be such an insane song
>that
> > it'll make me go, "Oh shit, yeah, why didn't I think of that?"
> >
> > True fact: That's only happened to me once out of hundreds and
>hundreds of
> > requests. The song was "Sweet Emotion" by Aerosmith, believe it or
>not.
> >
> > SAVING YOUR BEST STUFF: This is tricky. You don't want to blow your
>load
> > before the night hits maximum party time, so you squirrel away your
> > guaranteed crowd-pleasing monster jams and you wait, thinking, "Now?
>Now?
> > Do I drop it?" And finally you're like, "It's time, I'm gonna hit it."
>And
> > boom! It's a fuckin' nuclear-bomb explosion. A roomful of people you
>would
> > barely be able to look at in the daytime are freaking out like they
>just
> > won the lottery, all because you pressed a button. That's why you do
>this
> > shit. That, and the fact that you are a total fucking spaz.
> >
> > AMY KELLNER
> >
> >

exactly!

it was written by somebody who plays music she hates for people she hates.

she's a fool, and I would pity her, but that's a job for Mr. T.

magazines suck anyway. I wrote stuff for a prominent technology
magazine in the mid-90s, right before the dot-com boom. the experience
totally sucked. there was also a DJ magazine that took posts I made on
this very list and then reprinted them in their magazine as letters to
the editor. they did it twice. they didn't give me any money, and they
didn't give me complementary copies, either. later I started actually
reading the magazine. they ran an article on hip-hop, which I used to
know a lot about, and I noticed a few mistakes. then they ran an
article on new-school breaks, which I do know a lot about, and I
noticed a ton of mistakes. like three out of five statements were
inaccurate in some way or another. really four out of five. that's
when I realized magazines just don't matter.

--

At 08:05 PM 7/7/2004, DJ Pat wrote:
>That article was grate!
>
>Who the fuck is this amy kellner cunt?  Sounds like oakenfold (HA!) is a
>better DJ than her...

>either way.... it just made me wanna punch her lights out.

LOL...I thought the piece was funny, in the context of VICE 
magazine.  Originally this was a small punk zine that now has morphed into 
somewhat of a business including an online site that, as the three ex-punks 
who founded the mag and online version say:  "...is a collection of the 
irreverent, hilarious and downright scary gonzo journalism that brought 
three losers from the crack houses of Le Plateau to the deluxe apartments 
of Manhattan."

The same issue had an article questioning whether there was any difference 
between frat and punk parties, illustrated with photos of guys vomiting and 
one of the writers pissing on his vomit.  So...irreverence?:)

Love,

Apollo



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and causes 
me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war, 
corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong 
its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-Abraham Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

  "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

Subject: RE: [sfraves] HEY DJ: FUCK YOU!!!

It's obvious she's talking about dj'ing traditional styles of music, and not 
EDM, and has not CLUE ONE as to what "our" version of DJ'ing is. I have seen 
many of the old punk rock/industrail dj's back in DC try their hand at 
DJ'ing EDM, and fail MISERABLY. But almost all would agree after trying it 
that it's much harder than they had thought it would be. She's right if you 
look at it from the point of view of someone who has no concept of 
beatmatching, track progression, building, tricks, tone blending or anything 
else.

As someone who comes from the punk scene, I can laugh at it, while at the 
same time I shake my head at her obviously narrowminded point of view.

Of course, this dumbass probably still buys safety pins in bulk to adorn her 
patch covered pants, and thinks that the squatter punk look is cool.

:)

8/20/04: Cubik (aka BUZZ) @ Nation (Washington, DC)
8/22/04: Delivery @ Skylounge (Baltimore, MD)
8/28/04: CONCEPTION - massive field party in VA (e-flier on: 
http://www.djsinestro.com )


>From: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>
>To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
>Subject: [sfraves] HEY DJ:  FUCK YOU!!!
>Date: Wed, 07 Jul 2004 19:52:47 -0700
>
>HEY DJ:  FUCK YOU!!!
>
>Anyone Can Rock the Party (from VICE Magazine)
>
>You know that thing called DJing? Playing records in bars or at stupid art 
>openings for money? Guess what DJing is? The biggest fucking bullshit con 
>of all time! People who get over as DJs are making the easiest money ever, 
>because they've convinced every PR person and club owner in the world that 
>they're doing something only a few natural-born geniuses can do. It's 
>laughable. A 70-year-old blind Ethiopian leper with 10 broken fingers can 
>"spin" just as well as any B-list celebrity at any instore party for some 
>gay snowboarding jeans company. I promise.
>
>And those other guys who do all the little flick-flick, crabby moves on 
>records that are covered with spots of adhesive tape that are supposed to 
>mean something? Those aren't DJs! I don't know what to call them. Nerds, 
>maybe? They called themselves "turntablists" five years ago, but I think 
>that got embarrassing. One thing is for sure, though: Those guys don't DJ 
>on the actual paying gig circuit that I'm on, because no hammered jock 
>chicks or guidos from West Orange, N.J., will dance to an hour-long 
>abstract scratch frenzy over a P-Funk B-side.
>
>I've been making loads of supplementary income by DJing for a few years 
>now, and I can barely even scratch my own back. All you really need is a CD 
>burner, Kazaa, and passably cool taste in music. Here, I'll tell you all 
>about my life as a party DJ:
>
>TECHNIQUE
>FLOW: The only slightly ephemeral skill to learn is flow. Have you ever 
>made a mixtape for someone you had a crush on? Then you already know what 
>flow isthe ability to maintain a mood. I was at a party once where the DJ 
>kept playing one danceable hip-hop track, then one undanceable slow 
>classic-rock track, one hip-hop, one slow rock, on and on like that for an 
>hour! We would get up and dance, and then sit down, and then we finally 
>just stayed down and shot him really dirty looks. It was the opposite of 
>flow. To master flow, you just need to not be a fucking moron. Can you 
>handle that?
>
>Segueing from one genre to a totally different one is easy. You just build 
>tiny little bridges instead of taking one big leap. For example, let's go 
>from a hip-hop set to a punk-rock set. You play your last rap song, then a 
>Prince track. Then maybe some ESG. Then the Slits. Boom! You're into the 
>punk before they know what hit 'em.
>
>LCD: This is your audience. It stands for Lowest Common Denominator. You 
>are DJing for drunks and cokeheads, and they need the aural equivalent of 
>safety blankets. What would you rather hear when you're high as fuck in a 
>bar: Journey or some obscure acid-house? (If you're a geek, don't answer 
>that.)
>I used to spend all my time collecting the rarest tracks, stuff that when I 
>heard it at home it would totally blow my mind. Guess what? No one cared. 
>In fact, they stopped dancing. Now I stick to playing stuff that I liked 
>when I was a teenager (the Misfits, "O.P.P.," and songs from John Hughes 
>movies) and I'm golden. When in doubt, go nostalgic.
>
>CUEING: This is where you enact the flow thing I just told you about. You 
>have two sides, right and left. When something's playing on the right, 
>think of a song that would sound good after it. Cue that song up on the 
>left by pressing the same buttons on a CD player that you've pressed 1,000 
>times before (or putting a needle down in the appropriate groove on a 
>record). When the song on the right side is about to end, slide the little 
>thingy in the box between the decks to the left. When you're a little less 
>than halfway over, press "play" on the CD or "start" on the turntable. 
>Congratulations, you're DJing. Can I get a "That was easy"?
>
>PERKS
>LINES: A huge guilty pleasure is cutting the line and marching right up to 
>the velvet rope all casual, going, "Hi, I'm the DJ." I like to go to a gig 
>dressed like a total slob. The nicer the club, the shittier I look. Then I 
>can stroll past all the people who used to spit on me in high school and 
>make a big huge deal about going through the door first.
>
>MONEY: Depending on who you are, a DJ's salary for one night can range from 
>a few free drinks to obscene amounts (for the big shots) that make you hate 
>capitalism. I heard Paul Sevigny got fucking $15,000 to DJ at Sundance. I 
>hope that is DJ urban legend. Most DJs I know are pretty psyched if they 
>get a couple hundred. Art openings should pay more, like $350. And 
>remember: Always get paid in cash on the night of. Within 24 hours all 
>money magically transforms into cocaine blown up some model's ass.
>
>COMPLIMENTS: One of the best things about DJing is when you play a really 
>kickass song and people come up to you dancing, going "I love this song!" 
>You get all proud and pretend you wrote it. You're like, "Thanks!" Yeah, I 
>downloaded "Youth Gone Wild," I rule. It's like being told your air-guitar 
>skills are fucking SICK.
>
>GEAR
>NEEDLES: Those sleek, aerodynamic, $500 fancy-pants needles are the second 
>biggest scam in DJing besides convincing people that DJing is hard. For 
>totally serviceable needles, go to one of those electronics stores on Canal 
>Street and get the cheapest set possible. You can talk them down on the 
>price, too. I got a pair plus some shitty headphones for $90 after I 
>sweet-talked the sales guy for a minute. (BTW, the cheap needles are called 
>hip-hop needles and that's mean against blacks.)
>
>MIXERS: There are a few brands of mixers, but who cares. DJs would like for 
>you to think mixers are all complicated, but they're really about as hard 
>to figure out as a home stereo. I once spun at this lesbian party where I 
>ended up giving girls DJ lessons all night. They were lined up across the 
>room, and it only took me a few seconds to show each of them the basics. As 
>Garfield would say, "Big fat hairy deal." Once I showed them how simple it 
>really is, they were shocked at the big deal that people make about the 
>whole thing. Yeah, there are cute little tricks you can do. If you're 
>playing a hip-hop song, it's fun to cut out the bass after the second verse 
>and then kick it back in full force on the chorus. It's a nifty party trick 
>and it makes girls lose their shit. But you can also just say, "Fuck it," 
>set them all in the middle, and read a book in between tracks.
>
>WHEELS OF STEEL: Please don't call them that. Don't call them "the ones and 
>the twos" either. It sounds like your mom saying, "Homie don't play that."
>
>ETIQUETTE
>OOPS: You're going to fuck up. The record will skip or you'll be distracted 
>by some drunk kid telling you how much "Bizarre Love Triangle" means to him 
>or you'll let two Wire songs play in a row. No big whup. Everyone's too 
>wasted to care. You should be too. Just take the opportunity to make 
>announcements. I usually shout out important information such as, "Don't 
>stop the rock, motherfuckers!" or "I need to pee!"
>
>REQUESTS: Try not to cry when people request Missy Elliott, again. Or "Hey 
>Ya!" or "Milkshake." Or Cher when you are spinning Minor Threat. Or simply 
>"hip-hop." Or any genre of music, in fact. You wouldn't believe how often 
>people request an entirely different genre of music than what the DJ is 
>playing. It's infuriatingly rude. You're telling the DJ that you hate his 
>or her music. If you don't like what I'm playing, wait 10 fucking minutes 
>and I'll be onto a new thing anyway.
>
>If you simply must request a song, it better be within the scope of what 
>I'm playing at that very second AND it better be such an insane song that 
>it'll make me go, "Oh shit, yeah, why didn't I think of that?"
>
>True fact: That's only happened to me once out of hundreds and hundreds of 
>requests. The song was "Sweet Emotion" by Aerosmith, believe it or not.
>
>SAVING YOUR BEST STUFF: This is tricky. You don't want to blow your load 
>before the night hits maximum party time, so you squirrel away your 
>guaranteed crowd-pleasing monster jams and you wait, thinking, "Now? Now? 
>Do I drop it?" And finally you're like, "It's time, I'm gonna hit it." And 
>boom! It's a fuckin' nuclear-bomb explosion. A roomful of people you would 
>barely be able to look at in the daytime are freaking out like they just 
>won the lottery, all because you pressed a button. That's why you do this 
>shit. That, and the fact that you are a total fucking spaz.
>
>AMY KELLNER
>
>
>Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
>
>House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
>
>
>"I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and causes 
>me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war, 
>corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
>will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong 
>its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is 
>aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
>-Abraham Lincoln
>
>"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
>rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
>visible."
>-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"
>
>  "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
>life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
>beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
>party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to 
>that..."
>-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

On Wed, 7 Jul 2004, aK wrote:

> hehe yeah, small world. . .
>
> there was one outdoor party I went to in livermore off vasco once. As I was
> driving there I was thinking like "where in the hell would this place be".
> When I turned into the glowstick marked entrance, I realized it was Sandhill
> Ranch, this big mining area/motocross track owned by an alcoholic asshole
> named Tom anderson (if I remember right, he always rode around on race day
> on a quad with a teddy bear strapped to the front).
>
> wierd experience. The actual main dancing area was their lil 1/4 mile oval
> track with the pussy mx track in the middle. People were dancing on top the
> doubles, and there were lasers n lights on "godzilla" (this big hill making
> up part of the main mx track).
>
> I used to ride there almost weekly when they were open. Cool place to
> explore, caves n trails. . .they also used to have paintball games there.
> Had some of my best races there, even tho the dirst was always so dry and
> fukked. . .I hate tracks where in the morning they're super muddy n slick,
> and an hour later it's so dusty you can't see a thing. I've raced there when
> it was 100+ deg outside, and when it was like 28 deg outside. Hard to go
> fast when you can't move your fingers.

<electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:
> It's obvious she's talking about dj'ing traditional styles of music, and not
> EDM, and has not CLUE ONE as to what "our" version of DJ'ing is. I have seen
> many of the old punk rock/industrail dj's back in DC try their hand at
> DJ'ing EDM, and fail MISERABLY. But almost all would agree after trying it
> that it's much harder than they had thought it would be. She's right if you
> look at it from the point of view of someone who has no concept of
> beatmatching, track progression, building, tricks, tone blending or anything
> else.

yah. she's talking about this kind of DJing:

http://www.marketingfordjs.com

weddings, frat parties, corporate events, bar mitzvahs, etc.; the type
of DJs they're talking to in catalogs when they say "don't miss
another gig because you don't have karaoke!"

I actually worked for a company that did that very briefly right after
high school. imagine a bunch of 13-yr-olds who want to hear Tupac, but
Mom is footing the bill, and Mom wants them to listen to Celine Dion
and play hula hoop -- and you're the guy handing out hula hoops.

basically, the fourth circle of hell.

"I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and causes 
me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war, 
corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong 
its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-Abraham Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

  "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

Evil Eddie Richards/sfraves trivia: the hyperreal.org domain was named
after "Hyperreal," a song by the Shamen, which appeared on their album
"En-Tact" in 1992. The lead single for that album, released in 1991,
was "Move Any Mountain," and Evil Eddie Richards did a remix.

I'm wicked at Trivial Pursuit. :-)

Dear Friends,

The Federal Marriage Amendment is expected to come to a vote in
the US Senate in early July. We must let our Senators know that
we do NOT want discrimination written into the constitution!

Even if you've already spoken out on this issue before, our
Senators need to hear from us often and loudly during the next
few weeks! Please, join me in sending a personalized letter from
the Human Rights Campaign Action Center at:

http://www.hrcactioncenter.org/campaign/senate_oppose_fma_alternet?rk=Kd1_HlF1OalSW
 
or

Subject: Re: [sfraves] The concord bouncey gym place ?

On Thu, 8 Jul 2004 09:52:15 -0700 (PDT), Terry Estioko wrote
> Mmmm....Sandhill Ranch....Freedom 96/97....legendary....good times =)
> 
> And was that really the space shuttle that one year or some kind of
> mass hallucination?

I remember that party.  I think it was a satellite, but who knows...maybe
that's what "they" want you to think ;)

Memorable moment #2: The fire that started at the first (I think) Freedom.  I
recount a bottle rocket shooting over the dancefloor, coherced by the wind,
onto the grassy hill that everyone would always view the sunrise.  The small
fire grew quickly into a problem.  My friends and I were trying to figure out
if it was planned when the music stopped and Martin shouted "We can all put
this out together!"  At that moment, we were sure of it...it was planned! 
Everyone cheered and hauled the 5 gallon bottles of water from the bar up the
hill to extinguish the blaze.  It didn't take long to realize that the fire
was spreading too quickly, and maybe that whole idea of it being a planned
activity was incorrect.  When the fire department arrived they saw 3000
confused ravers running up a hill with 5 gallon jugs of water toward the fire.
 Next thing Martin gets on the mic instructing everyone to get *off* the hill.
 They just don't throw 'em like they used to.

-li

Subject: [sfraves] Greetings from Germany

Moin! Guten tag!

whats up folks! ive been here in Deustchland since June and im having a 
blast so far, sightseeing, visiting relatives, Legoland in Denmark (the very 
first one since 1960s...) then the Lego factory, partying, graffiti walls, 
checkin out the hiphop culture as well as the techno side of things, 
absorbing the culture and they way of life. Just here for a couple of 
months, im staying in the Schleswig-Holstein area, about a couple of hours 
north of Hamburg and 45 mins away from Denmark, a nearby big city would be 
Kiel, it's like the SF equivalent bc of the harbor, etc.

I'm off to Berlin tomorrow morning with my folks, going to spend the week 
there.  It sucks when you're a hiphop and techno fan at the same 
time...there's a hiphop show goin down with DJ Hype (for u D&B junkies, u 
kno who this cat is) and then since the Love Parade is cancelled, a bunch of 
other techno parties are up and about...The Love From Above is the huge one, 
about 6000 party people expected or capacity iono which one is which...but 
it's tomorrow, same day as the hiphop show.  Paul Van Dyk is headlining that 
one.

Any suggestions? DJ Hype or Paul Van Dyk.  I'll take votes haha. other than 
that, hope all is well back in the bay. i missed 1999 and im upset, i was so 
looking forward to that party, nothing but the good ol' jams i heard. peace 
and love.  if u need more info on the Love party, google it up and see all 
the info if ur curious.

Tschuss!

Paul
dj_choco@hotmail.com

-&e->I'm off to Berlin tomorrow morning with my folks, going to spend the
-&e->week there.  It sucks when you're a hiphop and techno fan at the same
-&e->time...there's a hiphop show goin down with DJ Hype (for u D&B
-&e->junkies, u kno who this cat is) and then since the Love Parade is
-&e->cancelled, a bunch of other techno parties are up and about...The
-&e->Love From Above is the huge one, about 6000 party people expected or
-&e->capacity iono which one is which...but it's tomorrow, same day as the
-&e->hiphop show.  Paul Van Dyk is headlining that one.

Please don't Paul Van Dyk techno.

-&e->Any suggestions? DJ Hype or Paul Van Dyk.  I'll take votes haha.
-&e->other than that, hope all is well back in the bay. i missed 1999 and
-&e->im upset, i was so looking forward to that party, nothing but the
-&e->good ol' jams i heard. peace and love.  if u need more info on the
-&e->Love party, google it up and see all the info if ur curious.

I'd strongly recommend DJ Hype.  Sick sick sick turntable shit, and he
usually busts out with a strong sound covering several different styles of
jungle (besides innovator and badass pioneer of the sound in general, he
was cutting and scratching jungle before most anybody over here knew what
it was)...  with PVD you might catch a couple tunes you haven't heard or
even a clean mix or two.

andyw

Subject: [sfraves] ayn rand

I'm sorry, this has absolutely nothing to do with anything, but we
were talking about Ayn Rand on this list a while back, and I just
accidentally discovered a truly fascinating article which explains how
Larry Wall (the inventor of Perl) is just like Howard Roark, from the
Ayn Rand novel "The Fountainhead," while Larry Ellison (head of Oracle
Corporation, a huge database company) is just like Hank Rearden, from
the Ayn Rand novel "Atlas Shrugged."

I'm not endorsing this, I just think it's funny.

http://www.perl.com/pub/a/2002/09/04/perlfororacle.html

"Once again, rolling forward a couple of generations and modernizing
the names, if Ayn Rand were to replace the key productive technology
of 1950s America with that of early twenty-first century America, she
would probably choose to write about databases."

And the scary thing is, she probably would.

From sfraves-return-113764-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Fri Jul 09 03:32:43 2004
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-113764-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>

Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>

list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 80598 invoked from network); 9 Jul 2004 03:32:39 -0000
Date: Thu, 8 Jul 2004 19:28:09 -0700
Mime-Version: 1.0 (Apple Message framework v553)
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII; format=flowed
From: Starchild <sfdreamer@earthlink.net>
To: SFraves@hyperreal.org
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Message-Id: <9E4CA4BC-D14F-11D8-9C3C-003065DA480A@earthlink.net>
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.553)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) Why Larry Hiibel refused to show his identification

WINNEMUCCA, NEV. - A lot of people want to know why I went all the
way to the Supreme Court rather than give my name to a policeman. 
"What's
so important about that?" they ask. "What's the big principle at
stake?" And last week, when the Supreme Court ruled against me,
maybe some thought I was foolish to have done it. But I still think I 
did
the right thing and that there were some issues that had to be
decided.

The story began May 21, 2000, when I was on a rural road near my
ranch in Winnemucca, Nev. My daughter and I had gotten into an argument.
She was driving, and I was the passenger. We stopped by the side of the
road, parked legally, and we continued our argument. I figured we
would finish it out and then cool off for a moment.

That's when I heard sirens, and all of a sudden a police car drove
up. A deputy walked up to me and demanded my "papers." I asked him what
the problem was. "Why do you guys have me surrounded?" I asked,
because by now there were two or three more police cars.

He refused to explain why he was there or why he wanted my papers.
Eleven times he demanded my identification. I refused to give it to
him each time, and he finally handcuffed me and took me to jail. The
cops threw my daughter on the ground, cuffed her hands behind her and
demanded her name as well, but by that time I was on my way to the
county jail. I got there at midafternoon and stayed overnight.

I hadn't been argumentative; I wasn't picking a fight. Basically,
when Deputy Dove demanded my papers - and he didn't ask for them, he
demanded them - I didn't say, "Hey, cop, I'm not going to give you
nothing." I just asked why he wanted them. "What have I done?" I
asked.

If he'd explained what he was doing there, perhaps it could have been
settled on the spot. But his position was that he wanted the papers
first. [Editor's note: The police had received a report of a man
striking a woman in a pickup truck.]

Here's why this was so important to me: I don't believe that the
authorities in the United States of America are supposed to walk up to 
you and
ask for your papers. I thought that wasn't lawful. Apparently I was
wrong, but I thought that that was part of what we were guaranteed 
under the
Constitution. We're supposed to be free men, able to walk freely in
our own country - not hampered, not stopped at checkpoints. That's
part of what makes this country different from other places. That's
what I was taught.

And it's not just because it's in the Constitution. It's something
that you just kind of know. It's kind of obvious. If you haven't
committed a crime, you shouldn't be harassed by the police. If they
suspect you of something, I don't see why they shouldn't explain it.
I wasn't violent. And it was proved later in court that I hadn't
committed any crimes.

These days, it's as if we're all guilty until proved innocent. You
walk into an airport and everybody's a suspect. Like the way people
were treated in Soviet Russia, in Red China, in Castro's Cuba. We
don't want the US to become that.

I don't have a superclear understanding of the Constitution. I'm not
an attorney. I've never even read the whole thing. I went through
only eighth grade. But I remember what I learned, and it seems to me 
that
the whole idea of "your papers, please" goes completely against the
grain of the American people. As I understood it, the state was
supposed to serve us - we aren't supposed to serve the state. Laws
were supposed to protect the people against the government, not the
other way around.

Maybe in Los Angeles and other places across the country, the police
have browbeaten the people into more acceptance of this police-state
mentality than where I am. I live out on a ranch, the nearest town is
30 miles away, and it has only 7,000 or 8,000 people. I think that
has an effect on our mentality.

It's not that I'm against law enforcement. Criminals should be
apprehended. But I don't think we've got to take everybody's rights 
away just so
that we can be safe. If you do that, you've defeated your purpose. I
don't think people want to be protected to the extent that they
become slaves.

I'm very disappointed by this decision. I think a basic freedom has
been lost. What bothers me the most is that my children and
grandchildren are going to have to live with this law. It moves us a
step closer to control of the people by the government, and I don't
think that's a step forward.

*     *     *

This article appeared first in the Los Angeles Times.

--Larry Dudley Hiibel, a cattle rancher, was the plaintiff in Hiibel
v. Nevada, which was recently decided by the US Supreme Court. You
can read the details of his case at http://www.PapersPlease.org

Joshua Lagos/ICD/Fas 


For those of you who support Kerry, I just received this email from some
friends. 

You are invited to join a multicultural crowd of young Americans at
Bush's Going Away Party , a fundraiser for John Kerry, the next
President of the United States .   

Keynote speaker: 


Bill Press, political commentator and author of Bush Must Go: The Top 10
Reasons Why George Bush Doesn't Deserve a Second Term
(http://www.billpress.com/books/bushmustgo_main.html).   


  


Other great speaker s from these organizations will tell you how to get
involved: 


 
<http://65.54.184.250/cgi-bin/linkrd?_lang=EN&lah=86c8931018136ebe559d34
e0a88f9a07&lat=1089388457&hm___action=http%3a%2f%2fwww%2eredefeatbush%2e
org%2f> www.redefeatbush.org 


 
<http://65.54.184.250/cgi-bin/linkrd?_lang=EN&lah=18633e6ec3bc469db4f9e8
426b6a33e8&lat=1089388457&hm___action=http%3a%2f%2fwww%2emoveon%2ecom%2f
> www.moveon.com 


 
<http://65.54.184.250/cgi-bin/linkrd?_lang=EN&lah=68c4b00abb8787ee5d184d
4f98277082&lat=1089388457&hm___action=http%3a%2f%2fwww%2eonetermpresiden
t%2ecom%2f> www.onetermpresident.com 


John Kerry for President Campaign (
<http://65.54.184.250/cgi-bin/linkrd?_lang=EN&lah=e6a9a24aca0f0233c1e81b
8a2feec06c&lat=1089388457&hm___action=http%3a%2f%2fwww%2ejohnkerry%2ecom
%2f> www.johnkerry.com ) 


  


Location : Anzu - 2nd Floor, 2436 18th Street, NW, Washington, DC 


                near the intersection of Columbia Road in Adams Morgan 


  


Date/time : Tuesday, July 13, 2004 , 6:30 pm to midnight 


                  Program will begin at 8:00 pm 


  


Menu highlights : Free hors d'oevres and drink specials ($3 beer and
rail drinks) 


  


Music : Great Indian/Latin/Hip Hop/Funk/R&B tunes provided by Felipe
Chapa and Nitin Mukul (aka DJ Distraction) with Richards (from
<http://65.54.184.250/cgi-bin/linkrd?_lang=EN&lah=68c4b00abb8787ee5d184d
4f98277082&lat=1089388457&hm___action=http%3a%2f%2fwww%2eonetermpresiden
t%2ecom%2f> www.onetermpresident.com ) on drums 


  


Minimum donation : $15 on/before Tuesday, July 6 


                                 $20 on/before Monday, July 12 


                                 $25 at door (no on-line contributions
on July 13) 


                                 100% of your donation will go to the
Kerry Campaign 


  


Space is limited so reserve your spot now by visiting:
http://volunteer.johnkerry.com/member/118509 


?and hit the ?make your contribution now? link 


( also check this site for the latest fundraiser updates) 


  


Don't miss the fun!   Mark your calendars now, and please don?t forget
to tell your other friends !!!

"I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and causes 
me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war, 
corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong 
its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-Abraham Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

  "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

--=====================_23886817==.ALT--

OK.. I needed lastnight sooo much man... I swear.. I been so fuckin' stressed out from school that I was sooo looking 4 the perfect release... I kinda "unexpectedly" stayed longer than i meant 2 @ Cloud 9 lastnight 'cause well. i saw my Homie Mike again & we just kept chatting about like old school days & shit... it was nice!

Buit so on 2 more funner stuff.... The Jungle lastnight was fuckin sick.. OK.. Hello 2Day... Bicolos & E$KR were Awesome.. I Loved their tag set alot.. but man.. I happen 2 Love E$KRs tracks more.. LoL I mean.. they played alot like new stuff i guess.. but it was funny.. kinda dubby & fun... it was Dope.. YUM!  Oh yeah... but I did Love how Bicolous dropped ok... some of his own produced tracks or hella new tracks he busted out on CD.. YUMMY!!!

Then OK... ummm.. LoL.. Sharp & Mal got on.. OK.. LoL.. Hello 2Day.. they started out kinda mellow (mellow 4 them anyway.. LoL) & played alot ok.. bleepy bloopy kinda jungle.. I mean.. lol.. i dunno how wlse 2 really describe it... but then it all got old school & ooooh man.. it was Hella Dope!@!!  LoL

Ooooh man.. I Loved it so much.. I was dancing as much & as hard a possible lastnight... it was Groovy man. I Loved it sooooooo much!!  Oh Yeah!  I mean.. I totaallly needed this...

The Crowd was Groovy.. small but fun!!!  Really good energy!!!  Loved it!!  YAY



Take Care,
Peace-> ObY {8O)

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

"I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and
causes 
me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war, 
corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places

will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong

its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth
is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed." -Abraham
Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the

rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually
become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

  "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of

life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to
that..." -Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

well ... huh.

i don't recognize your email address.  we've just kind of been doing 
this for years.  the random threads nstuff.  if you're only looking for 
party info, you can subscribe to just the calendar, or for the more 
"mature" sfraves that's supposed to be "drama-free" i think there's 
like an "sfr-lite" or "sfr-planners" or something like that.  there's 
also an sf-oasis list, which i'm not sure if i'm on or not, that i 
think is about the same as this one.

anyway, my answer to your question why you are getting random email is 
because you're subscribed to sfraves.  ravers are random in their 
dancing and in their conversation.  sorry.  it's not just me -- really.

"I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and causes 
me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war, 
corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong 
its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-Abraham Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

  "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

Subject: [sfraves] Outdoor Madness... Wow.. Good F&^%#n S&%t Man!!! =)

Lastnight the beach party was fun.. Ooooooooooh My Goodness, Oh My Gosh, Hello 2day... so much fun!!!

OK.. so getting there was interesting... caught the bus @ 10:30 @ night 2 get 2 bart by 11:15 & got 2 the City by 12... then Big G & I like totally get on the mini late night road trip 2 the spot... Love the location.. I mean.. this like hidden beach cove I guess kinda area.. haven't been there in like 3 years.. it was SO DOPE!

Music was Groovy the whole time!!!  Breakbeats mostly the whole night! Loved Indigo's set was soooo fuckin' Sick.. he played alota vocal breakbeat tracks & acid.. it was Dope!!  Loved it!! OK.. there was this Electro Clash set.. it was fuckin' sick.. OK.. I heard 1 of my all time fave Electro Clash tunes.. I keep 4getting the name of it.. but then the DJ mixed it w/ Push It by Salt & Pepa.. Oooooooooooh my goodness man.. LOVED IT!!!  I Loved Aaron Jae's Future Breakbeats set... niiiiiiice!!  I mean.. I Loved all the sets.. But I yeah, la la la.. 

OK.. but GHETTOTEK @ 5 in the fuckin' Morning.. WTF.. I Loved that aloooot!!  Thanks Sticky & Kinkers.. I mean.. Konkers!!!  WOW!!!

OK.. & I could not help daning my ass off.. I mean.. it was hard dancing in the sand, muchless walking around the beach like a drunkk person, but man.. it was Dope.. I had 2 find altenate ways 2 dance 'cause well. I couldn't really move my feet.. so yeah.. there was alota pelvic dancing & arm/hand moving.. I t was fun!!

Yeah... it was So Dope hangin' w/ Family that night & meeting alota new people & seein' old friends again!!  Ryan.. you're a dork.. LoL... Wow man.. had soo much fun! YAY!!  I'm like hella buggin' still =)

Take Care,
Peace-> ObY {8O)

Subject: [sfraves] Disco Demolition Anniversary

--=====================_1637344==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Today, July 12th, is the 25th anniversary of the Disco Demolition Night 
spectacle.  In Chicago Dahl and his cronies will be celebrating their 
homophobic act again.  So - in response - spin some disco on today to show 
that we respect this seminal dance music and the people who produced it.

Learn about the vocal talents that reveal the anti-disco story that only 
Donna Summer was a worthy disco vocalist to be a lie (witness Teddy 
Pendergrass, Jocelyn Brown, Martha Wash, Stephanie Mills, Barry White, 
etc.)  Learn about the disco message songs that expose the falseness of the 
anti-disco view that all disco is meaningless and vapid (witness "Bad 
Luck", "Ain't No Stoppin' Us Now", "Who Can We Trust", "I Will Survive", 
"Lost in Music", etc.)  Learn about the disco songs that were recorded and 
released and even became hits after 1979, to show that Steve Dahl did not 
succeed.  And then share this knowledge with others.

Love,

Apollo



Disco Demolition Anniversary Celebrates 'The Day Disco Died'

     CHICAGO, July 8 /PRNewswire/ -- Monday, July 12 marks the 25th anniversary
of "The Day Disco Died," when nearly 90,000 people showed up at Chicago's
Comiskey Park to participate in radio disc jockey Steve Dahl's Disco
Demolition. The "Disco Sucks" demonstration is widely credited for causing the
official demise of disco, and 25 years later, Dahl is sending a message to the
world again: "Disco Still Sucks."

     "People said I did the world a favor by taking one of the most inane music
genres and relegating it to karaoke bars for all time," says Dahl. "I was just
doing what came naturally: hating disco."

     The event began as an effort to sell seats at a White Sox/Detroit Tigers
double-header, and turned into a mass anti-disco movement from which disco
never recovered. Fans were encouraged to show up with an admission of $0.98
and a disco record that would be blown up at center field between the games;
chaos ensued when tens of thousands of baseball fans and listeners stormed the
field, causing the Chicago White Sox to forfeit the second game.  The rare
cancellation of an American League baseball game due to fans destroying the
field is still listed by ESPN as one of the top 10 most shocking moments in
baseball history.

     The event earned Dahl national notoriety, and 25 years later he is still
Chicago's no. 1 disc jockey among 25- to 54-year-olds, with a listening
audience of about 400,000 people each week on WCKG-FM (105.9) weekday
afternoons from 2 - 7 p.m.

     A movie about the Disco Demolition is in development with State Street
Pictures, the producers behind the Chicago-based blockbusters "Soul Food,"
"Barbershop" and "Barbershop II: Back in Business." The script is being
written by Second City alumni Bob Odenkirk (HBO's "Mr. Show") and Jim Zulevic.

     And disco has never recovered.

      Contact:
      Susanna Homan
      PR21
      312-396-9750
      susanna.homan@pr21.com

SOURCE Disco Demolition
Photo Notes: NewsCom:
http://www.newscom.com/cgi-bin/prnh/20040708/CGTH009 AP
PhotoExpress Network: PRN3 PRN Photo Desk,
photodesk@prnewswire.com





Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and causes 
me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war, 
corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong 
its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-Abraham Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

  "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
References: <6.1.1.1.2.20040712112037.0241eee0@localhost>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Disco Demolition Anniversary

Hey now. In all fairness this was as much a negative reaction to
corporate music as a homophobic thing. Probably more anti-corporate
than homophobic, really. I'm from Chicago and Steve Dahl is a bit of
an ape, but the story I got from "Last Night A DJ Saved My Life" went
like this:

1. Disco, the underground scene
    (The Loft, The Paradise Garage)

2. Is discovered by corporations

3. And given loads of money

4. Corporate re-creations of disco songs and clubs
    (Studio 54, Dolly Parton's disco song)

5. Corporations are desperate for new ideas

6. Corporations absolutely hammer the disco thing
    ("Saturday Night Fever")

7. Public gets really sick of it

8. Steve Dahl/"Disco Sucks" riot

it's kind of like what happened with the dot-com boom, in a way.

-- 
DJ Soundwave
www.djsoundwave.com

http://www.djsoundwave.com/docs/short_sharp_shock.mp3

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

At 11:49 AM 7/12/2004, DJ Soundwave wrote:
>Hey now. In all fairness this was as much a negative reaction to
>corporate music as a homophobic thing. Probably more anti-corporate
>than homophobic, really. I'm from Chicago and Steve Dahl is a bit of
>an ape, but the story I got from "Last Night A DJ Saved My Life" went
>like this:
>
>1. Disco, the underground scene
>     (The Loft, The Paradise Garage)

I know Bill Brewster and I worked at the Paradise Garage.  Perhaps you had 
to live through it all....:)  One of the reasons disco really died is that 
the corporations really didn't make all the money they thought they 
would.  Twelve inch singles weren't that profitable, and compilation EPs 
didn't have the mixes the public wanted.

However, there was a strong middle America reaction to what was perceived 
then as the homosexualization of America.  If you want some background on 
the times written by those who experienced them (in the USA), you might 
read my "House Music 101" or the well-researched work recently published by 
Duke University Press:  "Love Saves the Day," by Tim Lawrence.

Love,

Apollo



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and causes 
me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war, 
corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong 
its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-Abraham Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

  "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

--=====================_10954892==.ALT--

At 02:33 PM 7/12/2004, DJ Soundwave wrote:
> > I know Bill Brewster and I worked at the Paradise Garage.  Perhaps
>
>woah! really?

Bill is revising the "Last Night" book to correct and expand some of the 
discussion of the disco era.  He plans to interview me and others from 
those days when he visits the states soon.  He and Frank also have a 
website and discussion board in the UK.


> > you had to live through it all....:)  One of the reasons disco
> > really died is that the corporations really didn't make all the money
> > they thought they would.
>
>bit similar to the dot-com thing innit...

Everyone is always looking for a fast and easy way to make loads of 
money:)  Nothing new here.  A large chunk of the disco business was, 
however, controlled by gay entrepreneurs like Mel Cheren (West End 
Records).  His lover ran the PG and Mel was the money behind the 
club.  Barry Lederer, one of the original DJs at the gay firehouse in the 
early seventies, wrote the disco columns in Billboard, etc. We used to call 
them the "Disco Mafia."

Love,

Apollo



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and causes 
me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war, 
corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong 
its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-Abraham Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

  "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

--=====================_14155674==.ALT--

hello, this is a continuation of a fictional piece:
 
"hey, listen to this:
 
'what if everyone decided to have a great idea that they each thought was just totally original at the same time, but the idea was actually the same or very, very similar to each and every other person's idea, and THEN, they all on their own put the idea into motion at about the same time, and THEN, after that, other people got the idea on their own to copy that idea, and isn't that how civilization got started?' "
 
"is that your book?"
 
"no. it is just my idea. thank god for fiction. it is the only thing that truly matters." :)

at 34 I

energy as

Subject: [sfraves] * HAPPY TOGETHER 3! Saturday, September 4th! $1 PRESALES / ALL AGES   <bsp>

Yeah, we know. It's been almost 2 years since the last one. There hasn't 
been a single party we get asked more about, so here it is, the finale.. 
Liquidvinyldjs.com is unbelieveably proud to present:

HAPPY TOGETHER 3
SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 4TH 2004
LABOR DAY WEEKEND
ALL AGES | 9:00pm-6:00am
2000+ CAPACITY BAY AREA LOCATION!


We've taken great pride in putting together this once in a lifetime lineup! 
Prepare for one of the biggest hard lineups the West Coast has ever seen!


SCOTT BROWN
|| Evolution Records - Scotland || *FIRST BAY AREA APPEARANCE!*
Considered by many around the world as Hardcore's #1 DJ and Producer, Scott 
Brown has achieved more in his career than many in any other genre. He's 
developed his Evolution Records label into what many reguard as the top 
Hardcore label in the world, along with releasing tracks with many of 
Hardcore's top Producers. With massive hits like "ELYSIUM", "NOW IS THE 
TIME", "TURN UP THE MUSIC", and "ICE COLD", chances are if you've been to a 
party in the past 10 years, you've heard his music. As a DJ, he is known for 
his rock solid skills on the decks, often building his sets into energetic 
frenzies that result in mayhem after it's all said and done! This will be 
Scott Brown's first Bay Area Appearance, please join us to make it 
memorable!

DJ HIXXY
|| RaverBaby / HTID / Bonkers - U.K. ||
>From his novice DJ days in 1991 to his International Hardcore Superstar 
status of today, Hixxy has worked long and hard making a name for himself in 
the Hardcore circuit. From his early releases "TOY TOWN" and "WANTING TO GET 
HIGH" to his current hits "TANTRIC" and his remix of "FALLING IN", Hixxy has 
enjoyed enormous success as a Producer. As a DJ, Hixxy helped launch the 
enormously popular "BONKERS" series on React, which continues to break sales 
records for Hardcore CD compilations. His mixes are known to be uplifting 
and energetic, so be ready as we bring Hixxy for a very rare USA appearance!

TOMMYKNOCKER
|| Traxtorm Records - Italy || *FIRST BAY AREA APPEARANCE!*
As one of the fastest rising Hardcore producers today, we are extremely 
excited to bring you Tommyknocker for his first Bay Area Appearance. Hailing 
from Italy, his unique sound has been in demand by all of the world's top 
Hardcore DJs, with hard hittin' releases like "THE AFTERMATH", "REVOLUTION", 
and "DEMOLITION". He is also an accomplished DJ, playing huge events like 
Love Parade, Hellraiser, Megarave, and Masters of Hardcore. If you like your 
Hardcore rough and rugged, Tommyknocker is your man!

DELTA 9
|| Psychotik Records / Adam Recordings - Chicago, IL || *FIRST BAY AREA 
APPEARANCE!*
Quite possibly the biggest name in American Hardcore, Delta 9 is widely 
respected and admired throughout the world of Hardcore. With his early 
releases like "HARDCORE CHICAGO", "HATE TANK", and "REAL HARDCORE", to his 
present material like "DONKEY PUNCH", "NO ESCAPE", and "PUNK LOSER", he 
continues to evolve his style to the Hardcore massive. He has appeared all 
around the globe showcasing his incredible DJ skills and crowd control, 
often taking crowds beyond their peak and back again. We are proud to 
present to you Delta 9 for his first Bay Area Appearance!

DJ VENOM
|| Volume Productions / Topaz Records - Providence, RI || *FIRST BAY AREA 
APPEARANCE!*
Looked upon as one of the most talented Hard DJ's in America, Venom's style 
and persona are only comparible to his music: wild and crazy! He goes 
seamlessly from US Hard House to Hardcore in his mixes, as showcased on such 
top-selling CD compilations as his "RAISE THE VOLUME" series, his "STRAIGHT 
BANGIN" series, and the immensely popular "HOUSE BLEND VOLUME 7-8". From his 
jaw-dropping scratching to his crowd rockin stage displays, it's no wonder 
why Venom is in such huge demand all around the country. We are hyped to 
bring you DJ Venom's first Bay Area Appearance!


CLOUDSKIPPER
|| Raw Elements / KFA / Liquidvinyldjs.com ||
The one, the only. Cloudskipper is widely recognized and respected as one of 
the top Hardcore DJ's in America. With his recent tour of the U.K. as well 
as his very busy touring here in North America, crowds all around the world 
continue to be amazed and captivated by his upfront Hardcore sets. Often 
immitated, never duplicated, Cloudskipper sets the bar other Hardcore DJ's 
will be trying to reach... next year.

DJ TRONIC
|| Resistance Recordings / Liquidvinyldjs.com / BeatSupreme.com ||
Label owner. Producer. DJ. Promoter. Is there anything he doesn't do? 
Probably not. DJ Tronic has continued to build his label Resistance 
Recordings from the ground up, watching it become one of the premiere Hard 
labels in the world with many top DJ's playing his material. All this along 
with his recent touring of France and Spain, as well as his busy touring 
schedule in the USA, it's no wonder why Tronic is such a rising talent.


THE NICE GUYS [NO LEFT TURN & DJ REESE]
|| KFA / Liquidvinyldjs.com ||
When they're not out being nice somewhere, they're out getting drunk. All 
jokes aside, these two are starting to make waves in the Hardcore world, 
with their two upcoming releases on KFA, as well as other material released 
on Raw Elements and Bedlam. Prepare for the Nice Guys, dropping a 
not-so=nice set!

THE NATURAL DISASTERS [THE DOCTOR & RECLIPSE]
|| Bayraves.com / Liquidvinyldjs.com ||
The Doctor and Reclipse, forces in their own right come together to form the 
Natural Disasters. While they're not wrestlers, they drop some of the 
hardest hittin material in the Bay, ranging from DrumNBass to Hardcore to 
Gabber, these two will be shaking the dancefloor HARD!

J-MARR & CARLOS ALFONZO
|| Bayraves.com / Liquidvinyldjs.com / Soop Recordings / BeatSupreme.com || 
[/b]
Alright, the last time we had these two together during a set, they did more 
passing out of food than actually playing. While we can't promise the same 
feast, we can promise a rockin set that only these two can bring!

Subject: Re: [sfraves] logic pro audio certification class?

On Mon, 12 Jul 2004 10:23:37 -0700, innocentchild
<innocentchild@hotmail.com> wrote:
> I know Andrew Phelan is in music theory classes and ProTools classes there.
> He has only good things to say about the place...

well worth considering. you know I like theory.

or at least, you may or may not know I like theory, depending on how
much you had to drink the other night, after I told you that I like
theory, but I do, as it happens, like theory.

after literally years of frustration and burnout I randomly picked up
a bass -- having totally lost interest in any and all aspects of
electronic music except for listening to it in the car -- and I found
I was suddenly interested again. not only that, but I actually sounded
all right, too. especially once I started brushing up on scales,
modes, and keys.

studying theory is the shit.

doot dee doo.

-- 
DJ Soundwave
www.djsoundwave.com

20 minute mini breaks mix:
http://www.djsoundwave.com/docs/short_sharp_shock.mp3

original breaks tracks and remixes:
http://www.djsoundwave.com/docs/out_there.mp3
http://www.djsoundwave.com/docs/word_up.mp3
http://www.djsoundwave.com/docs/example.mp3

original drum and bass tracks:

http://www.djsoundwave.com/docs/coffee.mp3

political underground hip-hop track:
http://www.djsoundwave.com/docs/gangsta.mp3

graphic design, paintings, space bunnies:
http://www.bowkett.net

Subject: Re: [sfraves] logic pro audio certification class?

You're crazy. I took 2 years of theory in college. As much as it gave terms
and names to things that I understood inherently it also ruined a lot of my
desire to pursue music professionally. When I started getting into theory
that was so math like in teachings I turned off and lost interest. Btw - I
do remember a big chunk of our convo, but it's fragmented. =)

It was good seeing//talking to you though!
