From: dennis barton <dbarton@pacbell.net>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 500/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Twenty five years ago! [skylab2000]


Wow.

Twenty five years ago TODAY, the US space station "skylab" fell out of 
orbit and crashed to the ground in Australia!!

In the weeks before there was widespread worldwide panic as no one really 
knew where the 78 ton ship would crash!!!!  Ah, fun times..

Back here today, Dennis of skylab2000 is well out of orbit and is safe in 
the studio working on new music.

Some news: New releases on compilations coming out in late July and in 
early October. Live skylab2000 shows in July, Aug, Sep, Oct in NY, Philly, 
LA and many more cities. Full details can be found on the skylab2000 web site:

http://skylab2000.com

Lastly, since there's always new folks on the net, I'm gonna slip some 
quick bio info in here for the folks who don't know about us. If you are 
familiar with the band, thanks for reading this!

Mission control out


  +++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

skylab2000 is not a DJ or a 'laptop' band. This is a 100% LIVE performance. 
With a full set of synths, samplers and a computer onstage, a skylab2000 
show is an experience. This music is made live, changing to the crowds 
needs and creating a ride to remember.

Where did it start? Since 1994, Dennis Barton has been traveling city to 
city as skylab2000 playing his brand of hard hitting dance music. Hard 
house, progressive, techno, and trance are skylab2000's calling cards.

With a father from Detroit and mother from Belgium, he's got dance music in 
his blood. Growing up in NY's disco heyday, and then the early UK rave 
scene, sealed his fate as a electronic music composer.

Los Angeles is now home base, but it's rare to find skylab2000 at home. The 
road is his living room, where most weekends he's off playing an event. 
Local events, massives, and international overseas festivals. He's played 
New York, Chicago, Los Angeles, Dallas, Miami, Las Vegas, Anchorage, Puerto 
Rico, Vancouver, Montreal, Russia, Hong Kong, Istanbul, and literally 
hundreds more cities worldwide.

Playing live is the main focus, but this energy is often recorded and 
released. The US release of 'Auburn' includes the first remix by LA's 
Taylor. In the UK, Journeys by DJ released alternate UK mixes, getting a 
huge reaction, including a prestigious leading spot on the BBC with Pete 
Tong's Radio One Essential Selection. Auburn was played heavily by DJs such 
as Sasha, Carl Cox, Keoki, Pete Tong and Taylor. A series of follow up 12" 
releases have gathered similar response.

A handful of tracks were released exclusively on the internet. On the giant 
mp3.com music site alone, two skylab2000 tracks became the number ONE most 
downloaded songs overall. On that site alone, skylab2000 songs clocked 
almost a million downloads!

You can find skylab2000 tracks on mix CDs by Thomas Michael, Superstar DJ 
Keoki, Grover, DJ Psycho-Bitch, John Kelly, Sol Brothers, and Taylor, on 
labels such as Moonshine, Phatt Phunk, 3am Records, Brainiak (UK), City of 
Angels, Genesis Project, JDJ and so many more.

2004 is here. New releases - new cities. Stay tuned!

Feel the energy. Live.


---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

house, progressive, techno, and trance are skylab2000's calling cards.

With a father from Detroit and mother from Belgium, he's got dance music in 
his blood. Growing up in NY's disco heyday, and then the early UK rave 
scene, sealed his fate as a electronic music composer.

Los Angeles is now home base, but it's rare to find skylab2000 at home. The 
road is his living room, where most weekends he's off playing an event. 
Local events, massives, and international overseas festivals. He's played 
New York, Chicago, Los Angeles, Dallas, Miami, Las Vegas, Anchorage, Puerto 
Rico, Vancouver, Montreal, Russia, Hong Kong, Istanbul, and literally 
hundreds more cities worldwide.

Playing live is the main focus, but this energy is often recorded and 
released. The US release of 'Auburn' includes the first remix by LA's 
Taylor. In the UK, Journeys by DJ released alternate UK mixes, getting a 
huge reaction, including a prestigious leading spot on the BBC with Pete 
Tong's Radio One Essential Selection. Auburn was played heavily by DJs such 
as Sasha, Carl Cox, Keoki, Pete Tong and Taylor. A series of follow up 12" 
releases have gathered similar response.

A handful of tracks were released exclusively on the internet. On the giant 
mp3.com music site alone, two skylab2000 tracks became the number ONE most 
downloaded songs overall. On that site alone, skylab2000 songs clocked 
almost a million downloads!

You can find skylab2000 tracks on mix CDs by Thomas Michael, Superstar DJ 
Keoki, Grover, DJ Psycho-Bitch, John Kelly, Sol Brothers, and Taylor, on 
labels such as Moonshine, Phatt Phunk, 3am Records, Brainiak (UK), City of 
Angels, Genesis Project, JDJ and so many more.

2004 is here. New releases - new cities. Stay tuned!

Feel the energy. Live.


---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

From: georgeC <newstylesound@yahoo.com>

  DJ Soundwave <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <BAY9-DAV295a9Gdh3d0000988b9@hotmail.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] logic pro audio certification class?

Theory's cool..  It's one of those things like speaking a language or
riding a bike- once you're really set with all the knowledge you need,
the "theory" part of things dissapears and suddenly you're left with
the mysterious ability to name chords by ear and compose without going,
"Shit, what key am I in?  What notes would I hit if I knew what key I
was in?".  Until that happens, you're surrounded by textbooks and
menial piano excercises and you're saying, "What in hell has this got
to do with music?".  

That said, obviously a whole lot of people have made staggering music
without any formal theory training.  In certain genres it's almost
considered a disadvantage to have any.  However, writing it off
completely is kind of like saying, "I'm going to write a novel, in
French!  Forget learning how to conjugate verbs though- that's for
losers." ;)  

It's all about what you want to make and what viewpoint you're shooting
for.  Personally, I think I wrote better keyboard parts before I
started learning how to play.  Go figure.  Now that the hands sort of
know where to go, they don't go to the random places they used to.  I
can always revisit the days when I didn't know jack, though- it's
called "smoking mad trees". :)

GeorgeC aka origami
www.djorigami.com

On Mon, 12 Jul 2004 17:22:54 -0700 (PDT), georgeC
<newstylesound@yahoo.com> wrote:
> Theory's cool..  It's one of those things like speaking a language or
> riding a bike- once you're really set with all the knowledge you need,
> the "theory" part of things dissapears and suddenly you're left with
> the mysterious ability to name chords by ear and compose without going,
> "Shit, what key am I in?  What notes would I hit if I knew what key I
> was in?".  Until that happens, you're surrounded by textbooks and
> menial piano excercises and you're saying, "What in hell has this got
> to do with music?".

theory is awesome. I almost feel like musical education is worth
pursuing for its own sake. right now I'm building up this mad list of
all the classes I want to take and it's basically not gonna give me a
moment to even sleep. but it's totally worth it.

for me tho it's not about getting the knowledge I need, it's about
keeping things interesting. check it out. I'm from Chicago originally.
in Chicago I had no money and no social life, but the music I made was
very satisfying. I'm almost tempted to say I was good. then I left
Chicago because I had no money and no social life. literally, I lived
alone, in a ghetto. it was rough. so I moved to California. and I got
money and I got friends. and my music SUCKED. so then I got rid of all
my money and all my friends, which turned out to be a mistake, and
eventually I got decent at making music again. and the thing that made
it happen is something I could have done with money and a life. I
started studying theory again, and I remembered that in Chicago, I was
perpetually unemployed, so I had a lot of time, and I spent a lot of
that time studying theory. I did jazz tracks in 5/4 and classical
music based on "Godel, Escher, Bach." and it was crap, but it was just
done for the sake of learning shit, and later on, when I made
something I actually cared about, my brain was trained on all that
weird shit and it came up with interesting stuff. so yeah. if you ever
decide that making good music is more important to you than having
friends or a safe place to live, don't give up the friends or the safe
place to live. just take some fucking classes. that's my advice in
case anybody out there is half the crazy motherfucker I am.

god, this is ridiculous. I need some sleep. I went to bed at 1am last
night, after working on a track. I woke up again at 3am and started
working on it again. then at 6am I went to Denny's, had breakfast,
came back home, and did some more work. then at 9am I went to my day
job.

ying tong iddle I po.

--

Message-ID: <20040713082015.L19342@kzsu.stanford.edu>
X-No-Archive: yes
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Scanned-By: MIMEDefang 2.43
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] BSP: DJ Pat on An Epiphany Of Sound today, 9a-11a

California's pioneering dj pat, is undoubtably north americas first
wet&hard dj.

After years of spinning traditional techno & trance, he finally decided
it was time for a well needed change in direction.  Having been inspired
by the hot new sounds of wet&hard (an infectous new style of underground
club music evolving from new 'eastern' europe) he chose adventure over
security to take this exciting pathway down the road of controversial
club music. And at one of his first wet&hard gigs he was almost arrested
for doing it too!

For those of you who have already been lucky enough to experience the
aural pleasures of dj pat's wet&hard sets, then the sound of this
dj-session will not cum as a surprize to you.  For those who are hearing
this saucy music for the first time, just take a moment to listen to the
music and question why do people like to go to clubs and dance? the
mysteries will be revealed to you over the next two hours.

Some of you may feel embarrassed by the openness of this sound of new
Europe, but that is only an initial, instant shock-reaction towards
blatently approaching the subject of sexuality within an everday
environment.  Give yourself a moment, keep listening and once that shock
has worn off, your expanded tolerance level will allow you to enjoy the
sounds - as the pictures in your mind flash by.

So, what is wet&hard and what makes it so controversial?

Wet&Hard is an original and entertaining underground sound created from
the ruins of techno/trance by top hungarian dj/producer corvin dalek and
berlin based 'flesh' label initiator, Mark Reeder.

Mark Reeder's involvement in electronic music dates back over 20 years.
His most notable (or notorious) accomplishment was creating trance music
in 1989, however he's done so much more.  From making the world's first
record using a roland 606, to releasing the worlds first electronic
music title on MiniDisc, Mark has always been at the forefront of
everything.  When history looks back on electronic music someday, one of
the things that will stand out the most will be the little record label
that Mark founded in communist East Germany.  In spite of its humble
beginning, MFS today stands atop a short list of record labels that have
truly changed electronic music.  While all of its contemporaries
(Harthouse, Guerilla, etc) have gone the way of the dinosaur, MFS has
been there for it all.  The philosophy behind MFS has led it to
accomplish seemingly amazing feats with little or no resources to work
with.  The special vision behind MFS has led to the discovery of now
superstar DJs such as Paul van Dyk, Mijk van Dijk, Humate, Marco
Zaffarano, etc. and their development from obscurity into household
names.  It is a commitment to choosing talent and fresh ideas over a
quick buck that has led MFS to where it is now, and the man behind that
commitment is Mark Reeder.

Corvin meanwhile, has already created some classic wet&hard clubtracks
for marks/the flesh label, such as the legendary pounds&penz, a real man
or pornoground. He successfully performs his musical style around the
world, from colombia to canada, london to china or miami to mexico and
always to ecstatic crowds. mark has also released further wet&hard
material from young people such as jan kessler, fidelity kastrow,
michael burian or eiven major also on flesh.

The message of wet&hard is a positive one. To present to a 21st century
audience an open-minded and tolerant lifestyle and inject more sexuality
into electronic clubmusic, as that is basically what clubbing is really
all about - the sexual ritual of dancing. people used to dance together,
now they dance alone. wet&hard brings the people back together.

It is about openly accepting sex as part of ourselves and our lives and
expressing our sexuality through the language of music - wet&hard music.
remember, we are all the product of one beautifully euphoric event - an
orgasm - and what is bad about that? wet&hard is certainly not violent.
it does not promote racism, nor does it incite intolerance or threaten
mass destruction. it embraces everyone willing to accept its message -
rich, poor, fat, thin, gay, straight, tall or small.

Wet&Hard provides deep piledriving beats and throbbing-groovy basslines
to melt away your inhibitions and turn you on. you can make love to the
music as the music makes love to you. it is not stony-faced industrial,
or seriously minimal like techno can be and its not tawdry or tedious
like tv-trance is. wet&hard is just like falling in love, mysterious and
exciting. it is spongy and yet tough, it is hot and sexy, it is
thrilling and funny and it is very very entertaining.

Its controversy comes from the puritanical attitudes towards music and
the narrow-minded view of how club music should 'apparently' sound. that
is merely an elitist opinion. surely, some of you will hate it and some
of you will love it. but you decide for yourself.

Wet&Hard is imaginitive, fresh, young music for a new generation of
open-minded and adventurous clubbers to play with. with wet&hard you can
also be a part of something new and exciting too. so, simply soak in the
sounds, cum with us and think about what you would really like to do
after work.

90.1 FM, and online at http://kzsulive.stanford.edu


http://www.jcthedj.com

-- 
Sometimes I think I live in bizarroland, where up is down, left is
right, and Bush is in the Whitehouse.

"Opinions are my own only, and do not necessarily represent those of
KZSU Radio or Stanford University." (or words to that effect.)

---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

> all about - the sexual ritual of dancing. people
> used to dance together,
> now they dance alone. wet&hard brings the people
> back together.
> 
> It is about openly accepting sex as part of
> ourselves and our lives and
> expressing our sexuality through the language of
> music - wet&hard music.
> remember, we are all the product of one beautifully
> euphoric event - an
> orgasm - and what is bad about that? wet&hard is
> certainly not violent.
> it does not promote racism, nor does it incite
> intolerance or threaten
> mass destruction. it embraces everyone willing to
> accept its message -
> rich, poor, fat, thin, gay, straight, tall or small.
> 
> Wet&Hard provides deep piledriving beats and
> throbbing-groovy basslines
> to melt away your inhibitions and turn you on. you
> can make love to the
> music as the music makes love to you. it is not
> stony-faced industrial,
> or seriously minimal like techno can be and its not
> tawdry or tedious
> like tv-trance is. wet&hard is just like falling in
> love, mysterious and
> exciting. it is spongy and yet tough, it is hot and
> sexy, it is
> thrilling and funny and it is very very
> entertaining.
> 
> Its controversy comes from the puritanical attitudes
> towards music and
> the narrow-minded view of how club music should
> 'apparently' sound. that
> is merely an elitist opinion. surely, some of you
> will hate it and some
> of you will love it. but you decide for yourself.
> 
> Wet&Hard is imaginitive, fresh, young music for a
> new generation of
> open-minded and adventurous clubbers to play with.
> with wet&hard you can
> also be a part of something new and exciting too.
> so, simply soak in the
> sounds, cum with us and think about what you would
> really like to do
> after work.
> 
> 90.1 FM, and online at http://kzsulive.stanford.edu
> 
> 
> http://www.jcthedj.com
> 
> -- 
> Sometimes I think I live in bizarroland, where up is
> down, left is
> right, and Bush is in the Whitehouse.
> 
> "Opinions are my own only, and do not necessarily
> represent those of
> KZSU Radio or Stanford University." (or words to
> that effect.)
> 
>

>JC,
>
>Thanks for the informative write up.
>
>You know I'm really digging this sound, whether its
>Tues or Thurs, plus wet&hard style might give me an
>excuse to finally play that track "Finger Fuck" I
>bought for some unknown reason one day when I was
>drunk a few years back...

>best,
>
>Peter
>
>--- "J.C." <dougm@kzsu.stanford.edu> wrote:
> > California's pioneering dj pat, is undoubtably north
> > americas first
> > wet&hard dj.
> >
> > After years of spinning traditional techno & trance,
> > he finally decided
> > it was time for a well needed change in direction.
> > Having been inspired
> > by the hot new sounds of wet&hard (an infectous new
> > style of underground
> > club music evolving from new 'eastern' europe) he
> > chose adventure over
> > security to take this exciting pathway down the road
> > of controversial
> > club music. And at one of his first wet&hard gigs he
> > was almost arrested
> > for doing it too!
> >
> > For those of you who have already been lucky enough
> > to experience the
> > aural pleasures of dj pat's wet&hard sets, then the
> > sound of this
> > dj-session will not cum as a surprize to you.  For
> > those who are hearing
> > this saucy music for the first time, just take a
> > moment to listen to the
> > music and question why do people like to go to clubs
> > and dance? the
> > mysteries will be revealed to you over the next two
> > hours.
> >
> > Some of you may feel embarrassed by the openness of
> > this sound of new
> > Europe, but that is only an initial, instant
> > shock-reaction towards
> > blatently approaching the subject of sexuality
> > within an everday
> > environment.  Give yourself a moment, keep listening
> > and once that shock
> > has worn off, your expanded tolerance level will
> > allow you to enjoy the
> > sounds - as the pictures in your mind flash by.
> >
> > So, what is wet&hard and what makes it so
> > controversial?
> >
> > Wet&Hard is an original and entertaining underground
> > sound created from
> > the ruins of techno/trance by top hungarian
> > dj/producer corvin dalek and
> > berlin based 'flesh' label initiator, Mark Reeder.
> >
> > Mark Reeder's involvement in electronic music dates
> > back over 20 years.
> > His most notable (or notorious) accomplishment was
> > creating trance music
> > in 1989, however he's done so much more.  From
> > making the world's first
> > record using a roland 606, to releasing the worlds
> > first electronic
> > music title on MiniDisc, Mark has always been at the
> > forefront of
> > everything.  When history looks back on electronic
> > music someday, one of
> > the things that will stand out the most will be the
> > little record label
> > that Mark founded in communist East Germany.  In
> > spite of its humble
> > beginning, MFS today stands atop a short list of
> > record labels that have
> > truly changed electronic music.  While all of its
> > contemporaries
> > (Harthouse, Guerilla, etc) have gone the way of the
> > dinosaur, MFS has
> > been there for it all.  The philosophy behind MFS
> > has led it to
> > accomplish seemingly amazing feats with little or no
> > resources to work
> > with.  The special vision behind MFS has led to the
> > discovery of now
> > superstar DJs such as Paul van Dyk, Mijk van Dijk,
> > Humate, Marco
> > Zaffarano, etc. and their development from obscurity
> > into household
> > names.  It is a commitment to choosing talent and
> > fresh ideas over a
> > quick buck that has led MFS to where it is now, and
> > the man behind that
> > commitment is Mark Reeder.
> >
> > Corvin meanwhile, has already created some classic
> > wet&hard clubtracks
> > for marks/the flesh label, such as the legendary
> > pounds&penz, a real man
> > or pornoground. He successfully performs his musical
> > style around the
> > world, from colombia to canada, london to china or
> > miami to mexico and
> > always to ecstatic crowds. mark has also released
> > further wet&hard
> > material from young people such as jan kessler,
> > fidelity kastrow,
> > michael burian or eiven major also on flesh.
> >
> > The message of wet&hard is a positive one. To
> > present to a 21st century
> > audience an open-minded and tolerant lifestyle and
> > inject more sexuality
> > into electronic clubmusic, as that is basically what
> > clubbing is really
> > all about - the sexual ritual of dancing. people
> > used to dance together,
> > now they dance alone. wet&hard brings the people
> > back together.
> >
> > It is about openly accepting sex as part of
> > ourselves and our lives and
> > expressing our sexuality through the language of
> > music - wet&hard music.
> > remember, we are all the product of one beautifully
> > euphoric event - an
> > orgasm - and what is bad about that? wet&hard is
> > certainly not violent.
> > it does not promote racism, nor does it incite
> > intolerance or threaten
> > mass destruction. it embraces everyone willing to
> > accept its message -
> > rich, poor, fat, thin, gay, straight, tall or small.
> >
> > Wet&Hard provides deep piledriving beats and
> > throbbing-groovy basslines
> > to melt away your inhibitions and turn you on. you
> > can make love to the
> > music as the music makes love to you. it is not
> > stony-faced industrial,
> > or seriously minimal like techno can be and its not
> > tawdry or tedious
> > like tv-trance is. wet&hard is just like falling in
> > love, mysterious and
> > exciting. it is spongy and yet tough, it is hot and
> > sexy, it is
> > thrilling and funny and it is very very
> > entertaining.
> >
> > Its controversy comes from the puritanical attitudes
> > towards music and
> > the narrow-minded view of how club music should
> > 'apparently' sound. that
> > is merely an elitist opinion. surely, some of you
> > will hate it and some
> > of you will love it. but you decide for yourself.
> >
> > Wet&Hard is imaginitive, fresh, young music for a
> > new generation of
> > open-minded and adventurous clubbers to play with.
> > with wet&hard you can
> > also be a part of something new and exciting too.
> > so, simply soak in the
> > sounds, cum with us and think about what you would
> > really like to do
> > after work.

I haven't seen them around for a while.  Last time my
wife and I saw them it was maybe 2 years back a bit
before Sunshine and Moonbeam had their son.  It was a 
DJ set in the basement at Club 6, and well, it was
REAL GOOD.  There was one track in particular in which
Sunshine rapped about the sparkly party people that
got it and those other people that didn't in the most
positive uplifting sort of way.  It was a really
precise and skillful delivery of his message that you
just don't hear in any medium very often.  Anyhow I've
been trying to get this track ever since, but hey I
forgot to ask what it was called ;)  

If they play in SF I'll  be there (and hopefully my
wife too).

hello, we are aware that sometimes some folks are just way interested, but also, just was too busy to keep up or that they accidentally erase, read into, fall asleep, fall into a state, etc., and that prevents them from keeping up or getting on with it. so, here is a rerun from yesterday's installment in the spirit of dr. phil reruns:

hello, this is a continuation of a fictional piece:

"hey, listen to this:

'what if everyone decided to have a great idea that they each thought was just totally original at the same time, but the idea was actually the same or very, very similar to each and every other person's idea, and THEN, they all on their own put the idea into motion at about the same time, and THEN, after that, other people got the idea on their own to copy that idea, and isn't that how civilization got started?' "

"is that your book?"

"no. it is just my idea. thank god for fiction. it is the only thing that truly matters." :)

Hey guys, only a few days until the best party of the summer.  Lets get away
from indoor only venues that get way to hot and move to a venue like this
that has TWO stages outside and two inside.  Lets party overlooking the
water as well.  If you haven't been to Kelly's then you'll really enjoy
this.  And if you have been to Kelly's, you can tell everyone else why they
should come for this 18+ event there.

JON BISHOP, ST JOHN, GRIDLOK, METHOD ONE, CHRIS JACKSON, DRAGN'FLY, MYSTRE
... just to name a few.

And remember, Dragn'fly's birthday party (as well as mine).

http://www.squid.com/

/Squid Nick

===================

Squid.com, in conjunction with DJDragnfly.com, Space Monkey, and
MollyMush.com, proudly present.


>> E N G A G E !!! <<


Friday, July 16th 2004
@ Kelly's Mission Rock in San Francisco
This is an 18+ event

This will be an event to remember.  Four crews come together under the same
roof for a single night to impress everyone.

* Four areas of music
* 100% Fully permitted venue
* Two bars for the 21+
* Indoor and Outdoor settings
* Plenty of parking

>MAIN ROOM<
[Booked By Squid.com]

* JON BISHOP
(Tidy Trax, One World, djjonbishop.com)
America's Premier Hard House DJ/ Producer

St John - (Wild 94.9 HouseNation, SoFierce) Felipe Avelar - (Wild 94.9
HouseNation, Select, BR) Dragn'fly - (Shaolin, Audio Metamorphosis,
djdragnfly.com) ("Breaking the Silence" CD Giveaway) MollyMush vs. Valerie
Sparks - (HCFTP, RaveNBeats, k00terk0re) vs. (Femme DJs, Bay Raves)


>DOWNSTAIRS<
[Booked by MollyMush.com]

* GRIDLOK
(p51, Violence, Virus)

Method One - (Method-One.com, Covert Operations, TestFlight Recordings) -
(Special Old Skool Set) CLANDESTINE MASH UP - (Clandestine Club) Shard vs.
Yagi - (OTC, HCFTP) DoubleDay - (Swatchdog Recordings) dj TriZkuT -
(Squid.com)

w/ MC's Ax1om and Fish for the night

 
>FAR DOCK<
[Booked by DJDragnfly.com]

* CHRIS JACKSON
(Resource Records, Jump Recordings, Refined Music)

Morgan - (Lotek Records, Hardnrg.com)
Cantos - (CPRecordings, selekta.com, djcantos.com) Scepter - (Shaolin
Productions)
Sascha23 - (Xtort Productions)
John Schiffer - (HIDN, GCS)


>ENTRY DOCK<
[Booked By Space Monkey]
 
* MYSTRE
(F8, Dancing Sprit, Wild 94.9 HouseNation)
 
Kevin Kind - (Ghostribe, Feelgood Entertainment, Space Monkey)
Majere - (Elektrosorcery)
James Dub - (Space Monkey)
DJ Girlie - (Space Monkey, BR Productions)
Timo - (Space Monkey)
 
 
 
Sound Provided By HARDSCIENCE
 
Tickets available May 21st at the following locations:
*        Solid Grooves (Santa Clara)
*        Skills (Berkeley)
*        Frequency 8 (San Fran)
*        Dimple @ Arden (Sac)
*        In Tha Mix (Sac)
 
Very limited $5 presales are available online at http://www.squid.com
http://www.squid.com/>.  Then prices will go to $10 and then $15.  Door
tickets will be $20.  For the 21+, door prices will be $10 before 10pm.


INFOLINE: 415-356-9845
 
We are looking for additional promoters in the San Francisco and Sacramento
regions.  Please contact nicholas@blasgen.com for further information.

Special thanks to Select Events, LiquidVinylDJs.com, HardScience, and
BayRaves for helping out.

Subject: [sfraves] BSP:  The Bush Liberation Party

--=====================_1391250==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Thursday, July 15 (8pm - 1:30am)
StudioZ (314 11th Street @ Folsom, 415.252.7666)
$7.50 - $20 (sliding scale, tickets available at the door or online at
https://www.wecount.org/02donate.cfm)

Event Page: https://www.wecount.org/George_Bush_Liberation_Party.cfm

Party Description:
Let's party to defeat King George and tell Kerry to change his tune to a 
rhythm that's in sync with a more compassionate world vibe!  Come hear 
great music, dance, listen to a quick word from Daniel Ellsberg (in person) 
and help WeCount raise much needed funds to help get Bush out of office and 
push Kerry to the left.

This is a benefit party for WeCount.org to go to the National Democratic 
Convention in Boston.  WeCount.org a San Francisco NGO working for a more 
progressive America -- an America with compassion for all people of the 
world, one that protects the environment and does not wage unjust war.

Performers include Riffat Sutlana & Party, DJ Beatwalla, NEO EON ONE, 
Micropixie, Stellar Gas Jets and live tabla players.

Appetizers provided. 21 and over please.

Special Guest Daniel Ellsberg!
With his courageous outing of the Pentagon Papers in 1969, Mr. Ellsberg is 
famous for helping to bring an end to the Vietnam War.  Now he's working 
against the Bush Administration's next generation war machine.

Special Appearance by Jeff Grubler of the Ronald Reagan Home for the 
Criminally Insane!
SF Bay Guardian Local Hero award winner Jeff Grubler has prepared a special 
rap and will debut it at the party.

Performers/Line-up:

Riffat Sultana & Party
A beautiful, powerful and infectious voice that always gets people dancing. 
Riffat is the daughter of Ustad Salamat Ali Khan, who was universally 
recognized and acclaimed as the finest Pakistani Classical singer of his 
time. Riffat's family represents a 500-year lineage of musicians hailing 
from the Sham Chaurasi Gharana (school of music). Riffat's vocals have been 
recorded for numerous labels including Ark 21/Universal, Triloka/Mercury, 
Hearts of Space, City of Tribes, 6 Degrees and XDot25.

neo
eon
one...
combines lush, intricate soundscapes with insightful lyrics, culminating in 
a surprisingly entertaining mix. His audacious audio and vivacious video
shows at San Francisco's Oxygen Bar have become a monthly treat for steady 
fans and random passersby alike. His first full-length CD is expected to 
land in 2004.

DJ Beatwalla...
dishes up delectable dance grooves concocted from the some of the grooviest 
international beats available.  Dance 'til closing time.

Stellar Gas Jets...
taps into the collective groove encircling spaceship Earth and opens up a 
channel of killer sounds for us all to share.  Specialists of live 
instrumentation using keyboards, drum and bass, Stellar Gas Jets' alchemy 
of acid jazz transports the willing and able to a new cosmic plane.

Micropixie...
is a singer-songwriter, verbal & visual artist who hails from London via 
Paris [altho' she was made in Bombay]. Her cosmic gypsy meanderings have 
recently landed her in San Francisco. A debut album, due for release in 
Summer '04, fuses her love of technology with a musically minimalist
sensibility. Her lyrics are disarmingly personal; it's as if you're 
eavesdropping on her inner life as an alien on this planet.

Online Info:
Event Page: https://www.wecount.org/George_Bush_Liberation_Party.cfm
WeCount.org: https://www.wecount.org
Riffat Sultana: http://www.riffatsultana.com
Neo Eon One & Micropixie: http://www.utmosis.net
StudioZ: http://www.studioz.tv




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and causes 
me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war, 
corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong 
its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-Abraham Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

  "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

--=====================_1391250==.ALT--

From: John B <SvnLyrBrto@yahoo.com>

To: DJ Soundwave <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.618)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Disco Demolition Anniversary

Or perhaps, even, he just really.... really.... disliked disco.  It's 
not like it's impossible just to greatly dislike a genre of music, 
without actually hating the people who like said genre of music.  For a 
good example of the latter, I like happy hardcore.... a lot....  the 
cheezier, the better.  And there are people I could name, on SFRaves, 
with whom I get along just fine, who have had quite the negative lot to 
say about happy hardcore.  In fact, I'd bet that happycore is easily 
the most-maligned genre on the whole list.

OTOH, having been a mere toddler when disco was dying, and I think it 
be wiser to defer to Apollo's first-hand experience in this matter.  If 
he remembers a homophobic message on the part os this Steve Dahl (Any 
relation to Geri, I wonder?) character, I don't doubt it was there.

On the gripping hand, I think it's a mistake to equate 'anti-disco' 
with 'homophobic'.

I'm bi, out, and to be honest, trending significantly more towards boys 
than girls  (Ironinc thing being, I'm increasingly finding myself in 
situations where it's more socially awkward to admit that I still like 
some girls than it used to be to admit that I like boys.... but that's 
another story.).  And I can't stand disco.

I wouldn't go so far as to say I actively *HATE* disco.  And I 
certainly wouldn't waste my time starting an 'anti-disco' movement....  
But you certainly won't catch me a '70s night.  And, even at a real 
party, if I'm in the house room, and the DJ starts playing something 
that sounds like it's tainted by the touch of disco, I'll make a quick 
beeline to the other room.  I think I'd even rather be in a jungle room 
than a disco room.  More than one time, this year at Pride, I found 
myself thinking: "For fuck's sake.... the organizers of this shindig 
have GOT to realize, eventually, that the '70s are over, dead, and best 
buried and forgotten!".  I thanked my lucky stars, several times, for 
the Tantra stage, and its refuge of real dance music in a sea of crap*.

So, since I hate disco, and I'm more homo than hetro, does that mean I 
hate myself?  Obviously, no.

(* Which could lead me off onto another tangent about how the "gay 
scene" has the stereotype of having superior music; and how untrue I've 
found that stereotype to be.  Yeah, I know: stereotypes are bad, 
hmkayy.  But that was a POSITIVE stereotype!)


cya,
john




On Jul 12, 2004, at 11:49 AM, DJ Soundwave wrote:

> Hey now. In all fairness this was as much a negative reaction to
> corporate music as a homophobic thing. Probably more anti-corporate
> than homophobic, really. I'm from Chicago and Steve Dahl is a bit of
> an ape, but the story I got from "Last Night A DJ Saved My Life" went
> like this:

UTOPIA 

join us for a journey around the world in celebration of electronica with some of todays best electronic artists and DJs as well as the legendary visionaries that pioneered the genre.  with an extremely rare colaboration of international talent & extreme sound and lighting by stimulights, we will be transforming this venue into a true Utopia for all.

Saturday July 17, 2004 

featuring... 
---------- 
Area 1 - Hosted By Di Moda & Von Dutch 
----- 
SNEAKER PIMPS 

(Perfecto, Virgin, Just Say Agency / London, UK) 
Sneaker Pimps are responsible for the classic records "Spin Spin Sugar" which was remixed by Armand Van Helden & "6 Underground" which was remixed buy Paul Oakenfold & was featured on the cruel intentions motion picture soundtrack. From Alternative Rock, to Break Beats & Trance, Antipop of Sneaker Pimps has produced and performs it all. Among other credits to his name Antipop has opened for Radio Head on the Massive Attack Tour & Hosted Pete Tong's Essential Mix 13 times. His music has also appeared on albums like Chillout Ibiza on Ministry of Sound, Dave Seamans Back to Mine album, Armand van Heldens Repro CD, Back to the Old Skool Ibiza on Ministry of Sound, and Erik Morillos session 9 CD. 

BLUE 
(Toga - LA) 
Don't miss LA's hottest UK Hard House DJ! 

DYLOOT 
(Skills - Berkley) 

ST JOHN 
(Wild949, House Nation - SF) 

DUTCH 
(Thump Radio - SF) 

GIANNI 
(Spundae, Most Wanted - SF) 

DISKO SHAWN 
(SubSonic, Live105 - SF) 

KIDZ AT PLAY 
(Audio Metamorphisis - SF) 
----- 
---------- 
AREA 2 - Hosted by Kontrast Recordings 
----- 
JESSE SAUNDERS 
(Numark, Just Say - Chicago) 
What more can be said about Jesse Saunders? The world renowned DJ extraordinaire with over 20+ years of experience, who has made millions of fans and party goers all over the world testify to his unprecedented sets where he takes the crowd on a musical journey through the evolution of Electronic music. Known as "the Originator", Jesse is the producer credited with creating the first House Music record ever (On & On - 1983).  

ANGEL ALANIS 
(A2, In-Stereo, IHR, Moody, Contaminated, Eden, Kontrast, Solmatic, Moonshine, STX - Los Angeles) 
A legend in the house & techno industry Angel Alanis is one of the most prolific electronic music producers ever. His work has been acclaimed by every major House and Techno Dj & Producer including Dj Dan, Donald Glaude, Armand Van Helden, Bad Boy Bill, Carl Cox, Trevor Rocklife, Conga Squad, Josh Wink, Judge Jules, & So many others. Angel Alanis now tours the world spreading the sounds of techno & house. 

BRYAN COX 
(Subliminal, STX, Funkteck, Weapon, Kontrast, Bush, Ammo - Dallas, TX) 
Bryan is the hottest house producer with remixes for Dj Dan & Dj Irene rockin dance floors all over the world! His music appears on Richard Humpty Vission's new CD and Donald Glaude's New record label. 

HIGH CALIBER 
(Olive, Nocturnal, Kontrast, Moody, Nine, Ammo - Chicago) 
High Caliber's music has been charted by Paul Van Dyke, Judge Jules, Bad Boy Bill, Dj Dan, & many others... They have also remixed for CZR, Angel Alanis, Synthique, & have released over 30 tracks on vinyl. 

PAUL ANTHONY 
(Nocturnal, Kontrast - Chicago) 
Witness amazing turntablizm & mixing skills from the Midwest master! You won't believe all the tricks Paul Anthony has up his sleeves! See why he rocks 100s of shows all over the US per year and don't miss his set! 

JON PEGNATO 
(A2, In Stereo, Eden, Olive, Kontrast - LA) 
With heavy support from Dj Dan & Donald Glaude, plus working with Angel Alanis has made Jon Pegnato one of the fastest rises stars in house music, don't miss his set! 

DJ FREQUENCY 
(www.djfrequency.info, Kontrast, Weapon, Ammo - SF) 
With support from heavy weights like CZR, David Garcia, Raoul Zerna, Joey Mazzola, Bam Bam, & Josh the Funky1 + remixes out for Bryan Cox, High Caliber, & Jon Pegnato, Frequency is making his mark on the international house scene. 

RON REESER 
(Djronreeser.com, Funkteck, Kontrast, Solmatic - SF) 
A local house music hero partly responsible for throwing some of the largest electronic music shows ever in northern California through clockwork eventz, Ron now is in the studio full time working on music for Funkteck, Kontrast, Solmatic, and many other record labels. Be on the look out for Ron's music on record store shelves soon, and be prepared to see this awesome talent tour the world in 2005. 

FELIPE AVELAR & RECKLESS RYAN 
(House Nation, Wild 94.9, Kontrast, Bassline FM, Solid Grooves, Ammo - SF) 

FUNKE MIGUEL 
(Plaztech, Organic Vibe - SF) 

---------- 
Area 3 - Hosted By Dr. Free Clouds 
----- 

RON D CORE 
(DrFreeclouds.com - Costa Mesa) 
Ron D Core has been there from the start. Since the mid 1980's he's been an icon in the electronic music scene. Best known for his Mad Doctor & Decible Destruction mix compilations, Ron is now stationed in LA owning and operating his store Dr Freeclouds recordings which specializes in hardcore. 

ANDREA ALEXIS 
(Sexual Mindset, Butterfly Beatz - NYC) 
Andrea Alexis is known in NYC as one of the hottest hardcore / hard trance djs in the scene. Don't miss her first CA appearance! 

VALERIE SPARKS 
(Femme Djs, Bayraves - SF) 

AARON JAE 
(Evil Breaks, Aaronjae.com - SF) 

DJ DOZA & ORIONZ 
(Bay Raves, Zapatistas, Next Level - SF) 

SASCHA 23 & DJ WARREN 
(Xtort, Amory - SAC) 

MATT FROST & SERG ROCKWELL 
(Rokrite, Global Funk, Organic - SF) 

JOE VICIOUS & DJBJ 
(Caltrance - SF) 

ELUZION 
(Organic - SF) 
----------

Friday, July 16th 2004
@ Kelly's Mission Rock in San Francisco
This is an 18+ event

This will be an event to remember. Four crews come together under the same
roof for a single night to impress everyone.

* Four areas of music
* 100% Fully permitted venue
* Two bars for the 21+
* Indoor and Outdoor settings
* Plenty of parking

---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: they arehere <theyarehere911@hotmail.com>
Date: Wed, 14 Jul 2004 11:35:51 +0200
Subject: wet 'n' hard/dj pat/corvin dalek
To: dj.soundwave@gmail.com
Cc: djpat@dj-pat.com

We are reading the coments on DJ Corvin Dalek & DJ Pat & his wet 'n' hard
sound.
We think it is sad when you are thinking like this. You are ignorant
Americana with NO idea about anything what is happening here in Eastern
European underground music scene. We in East now more about scene in USA &
UK & you know nothing about us!
How many Eastern Europe DJs have you seeing play? How many partys have you
been too in East Europe? Why Corvin play with 12 decks? you say it is
marketing. What is wrong with marketing? you live in USA biggest marketing
country of the world, USA wanted East Europe to become Capitalist menatilty
so we destroyed the Communists & became Capitalist. Now we are being told is
wrong to make marketing? Techno is famous with marketing, Trance is famous
with marketing or? You have to read the Biog on his website. It was special
event & Corvin was special DJ of night.  He wanted to make impress in West
as East DJ is that wrong? Corvin Dalek is our Guru. He is exzellent & most
famous East DJ. He is residnet DJ in The Gallery in London most famous club
& He is headlining DJ in many countries of world. If he is shit DJ why? if
he playing shit music why? No. Corvin is creating a new style of music for
East to be proud with. He has inspiretion us all here & given us motivation
too show how we are without direct copying UK or USA style. We have all been
inspired by US & UK music from the past times, but now we play our own style
with a few Eastern European style & new name to make distances, like a
remix. YOU just do not understand anything or maybe you are all scared of
likeing erotikmusic style?.
keep it wet 'n' hard!
TAH

http://www.djsoundwave.com/docs/word_up.mp3
http://www.djsoundwave.com/docs/example.mp3

original drum and bass tracks:
http://www.djsoundwave.com/docs/fremont.mp3
http://www.djsoundwave.com/docs/coffee.mp3

political underground hip-hop track:
http://www.djsoundwave.com/docs/gangsta.mp3

graphic design, paintings, space bunnies:
http://www.bowkett.net

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "John B" <SvnLyrBrto@yahoo.com>
To: "DJ Soundwave" <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>
Cc: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Tuesday, July 13, 2004 9:45 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Disco Demolition Anniversary


> Or perhaps, even, he just really.... really.... disliked disco.  It's
> not like it's impossible just to greatly dislike a genre of music,
> without actually hating the people who like said genre of music.  For a
> good example of the latter, I like happy hardcore.... a lot....  the
> cheezier, the better.  And there are people I could name, on SFRaves,
> with whom I get along just fine, who have had quite the negative lot to
> say about happy hardcore.  In fact, I'd bet that happycore is easily
> the most-maligned genre on the whole list.
>
> OTOH, having been a mere toddler when disco was dying, and I think it
> be wiser to defer to Apollo's first-hand experience in this matter.  If
> he remembers a homophobic message on the part os this Steve Dahl (Any
> relation to Geri, I wonder?) character, I don't doubt it was there.
>
> On the gripping hand, I think it's a mistake to equate 'anti-disco'
> with 'homophobic'.
>
> I'm bi, out, and to be honest, trending significantly more towards boys
> than girls  (Ironinc thing being, I'm increasingly finding myself in
> situations where it's more socially awkward to admit that I still like
> some girls than it used to be to admit that I like boys.... but that's
> another story.).  And I can't stand disco.
>
> I wouldn't go so far as to say I actively *HATE* disco.  And I
> certainly wouldn't waste my time starting an 'anti-disco' movement....
> But you certainly won't catch me a '70s night.  And, even at a real
> party, if I'm in the house room, and the DJ starts playing something
> that sounds like it's tainted by the touch of disco, I'll make a quick
> beeline to the other room.  I think I'd even rather be in a jungle room
> than a disco room.  More than one time, this year at Pride, I found
> myself thinking: "For fuck's sake.... the organizers of this shindig
> have GOT to realize, eventually, that the '70s are over, dead, and best
> buried and forgotten!".  I thanked my lucky stars, several times, for
> the Tantra stage, and its refuge of real dance music in a sea of crap*.
>
> So, since I hate disco, and I'm more homo than hetro, does that mean I
> hate myself?  Obviously, no.
>
> (* Which could lead me off onto another tangent about how the "gay
> scene" has the stereotype of having superior music; and how untrue I've
> found that stereotype to be.  Yeah, I know: stereotypes are bad,
> hmkayy.  But that was a POSITIVE stereotype!)
>
>
> cya,
> john
>
>
>

quoth DJ Soundwave:
> I just got an exzellent e-mail.

pretty damned funny. This guy takes himself *way* too seriously.

> From: they arehere <theyarehere911@hotmail.com>
*snip*
> > We think it is sad when you are thinking like this. You are ignorant
> > Americana with NO idea about anything what is happening here in
> > Eastern European underground music scene. We in East now more about
> > scene in USA & UK & you know nothing about us!

That's a nice attitude. DJ Pat seemed to make it very clear that he was
a champion of "wet&hard", and it sounds as though people were
underwhelmed. So either Pat didn't do a very good job of representing
the sound, or the sound itself isn't that impressive. Obviously though,
you can't judge a style of music by a single DJ set.

Personally I found it very similar to deep progressive house and (as
Van Mundegaarde mentioned) the New York tribal stuff (Tenaglia, et al).
Maybe the Final Scratch malfunction is to blame, but what I heard
certainly didn't sound as fresh and unique (or raw and sexy, for that
matter) as what had been advertised. That's my 2c.

From: "DJ Pat" <djpat@dj-pat.com>
To: "shawn allen" <shawn@alterior.net>,
	<sfraves@hyperreal.org>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] make distances, like a remix

Good lord...  man what a bunch of unnessary drama.

First of all I would like to apologize for the technical difficulties
yesterday.  It was the first time I had used final scratch in a 'random'
environment and all of the horror stories I had heard about it came
true, and then some.  I know what you are saying about feeling
underwhelmed, I was too.. I was practically in tears.  I hate it when
gear fucks up and this time it was my fault (I could have just burned
all that shit to cd and brought CD players but I was lazy).

Quite clearly I didn't do a good job of representing the sound.  To say
wet & hard is similar to progressive house is quite wrong.  Yesterday I
was lucky enough to have a crate of "tool" records with me in the car so
I ended up mostly playing those while final scratch attempted to burn
the building down, so it may just be that my extra shit sounded
progressive.  Needless to say, I didn't plan on playing most of what I
played yesterday. =20

Now as far as wet & hard goes, and what the forwarded email said (I have
no clue who this guy is but it was probably one of the thousands of
polish people who visit my website) I would have to agree, at least in
part, with what he said and his attitude.

I must say however, that the reactions that I saw on SF raves (and the
other ones J.C. was kind enough to send me from other places he spammed)
was exactly what I have expected, albeit a little less creative than I'm
used to.

I'm not directing this at anyone in particular because your comments
were quite tame... but I know there were others out there that had even
more severe thoughts about the BSP or the 'set' (although I wouldn't
call it a set.. it was more like fill in the blank space so jc doesn't
kill me) and chose not to send them to sfr for whatever reason.

To you... I pity you. You have completely missed the point of what we
(myself, corvin, etc) are doing.  As a little bit of history.. the man
behind wet & hard (mark reeder) is the same genius (or idiot if u
prefer) who invented trance back in the 80s.  And being the old fart
that I am, I remember quite clearly criticisms very similar to these
being said about trance in the early 90s.  First it was "its not real".
Then it was "it sounds like techno to me" then it was "trance is gay"
and finally 15 years later it is now "god im so sick of this trance
bullshit".  Along the way Mark was kind (or evil) enough to bring you
today's superstar djs and producers like Paul van Dyk, Cosmic Baby,
Humate, Mijk van Dijk, and so on. =20

This is the same process that trance went through during the early 90s.
To us, it was very real.  To the haters, it was just a marketing trick.
Or a gimmick. =20

It is so easy to copy what others have done before, but how boring is
that? We are the adventurous ones laying the foundations for something
new, and if you see no value in that then more power to you.  All I can
say is that the same things were said about trance and the people who
didn't have an open mind back then were left behind.

Nobody is expecting wet & hard to become massive.  It is much too sexual
and purposefully so.  It will never get peak radio time here in the
states and probably won't ever get any mass attention like trance and
house have.  And to that I say good.  Look at what a heaping pile of
hamster shit trance has become over the last 5 years.  But on the flip
side of the coin, the same was said of trance and look what happened.  =20

Over the last two years corvin has managed to not only crack the ranks
of the superstar dj world but he's completely defined it.  Who would
have ever thought that a crowd at creamfields (not exactly known for
promoting the must underground or best music) would boo oakenfold off
the stage so they could watch a midget from hungaria play wet & hard,
but that's exactly what happened last year. =20

I could go on and on but you're already bored by now.  All I can say is
thanks to J.C. for having the open mind that he does and giving me the
rare opportunity to do my thing with no strings attached.  And thanks to
you guys on SF raves who were open minded enough to at least read and
tune in for a bit.  I'm terribly sorry that final scratch tried to burn
the building down and hence you didn't get a proper introduction to the
sound, but I thank you at least for giving it a try.

Hopefully the next time I can crawl out from under this pile of shit on
my desk and play again, things will work properly and you will get a
real opportunity to experience wet & hard for what it is:  wet & hard. =20

And that's what it is.  Its not a marketing trick, its not a gimmick,
and its not a stunt.  It literally cums from the clubs of eastern Europe
and hence I don't expect any of you to recognize that as valid or even
give a shit.  There literally hasn't been anything new in electronic
dance music in almost 10 years.  Wet & hard is new.  Its new for the
21st century.  Whether or not you think of it as a steaming pile of crap
is for you to decide.  I just want to make it clear that if you do think
it's a steaming pile of crap, just keep in mind that it's a new pile of
crap that you haven't stepped in before and maybe you might enjoy
stepping in it =3D).  And in the end I think having a new pile of crap =
to
step in is a good thing, and even better yet you have people like J.C.
who work to bring you new shit....

I'm sorry it was such a disaster J.C.... speaking of which I forgot to
mention that most of the "wet & hard" stuff is not legal to play on air
here in the states.  You were going to get a watered down set anyways.
So if that set was a watered down version of a significantly watered
down version of wet & hard...  it probably is as provocative as its said
to be....

Breast wishes,
p a t

> and hence I don't expect any of you to recognize that as valid or even
> give a shit.  There literally hasn't been anything new in electronic
> dance music in almost 10 years.  Wet & hard is new.  Its new for the
....

ghetto-tech...and you mentioned midgets in your e-mail...the other guy
said something about "the pornoground"...that combination makes me
nervous...what has capitalism done to Eastern Europe? they didn't have
Hungarian midget porn ghetto-tech under the Communists...

I dunno, dude, all I really said is that it sounds like tribal house
to me and giving it a distinct genre name seems kinda unrealistic. and
that Corvin Dalek only played on 12 turntables so he could say "I
played on 12 turntables." I'm not a hater. haters care...

anyway, if you're posting my address on your web site, you have to
post my sig too.

content-class: urn:content-classes:message
Thread-Topic: [sfraves] make distances, like a remix
Thread-Index: AcRp4fNE7OLHMeJ5S0iXIv/Nh3ssRgAAC9Zw
From: "DJ Pat" <djpat@dj-pat.com>
To: "DJ Soundwave" <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>,
	<sfraves@hyperreal.org>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] make distances, like a remix

Haha... sorry yo... I sent some of the comments off to the label owner
and left in the "from sent to" bit on a few of them. =20

I didn't call you a hater.  In fact I specifically said in my email how
SF raves was quite open minded (compared to elsewhere) and how u at
least took the time to read the email and/ or tune in.

If I make it sound like some sort of Slavic equivilant to ghetto-tech
I'm terribly sorry as that is the last thing I want to do.

As much as I love ghetto tech, and as much as I love having andy w come
up to sac and piss off everybody at my parties by completely shocking
them...  the only thing ghetto-tech and wet & hard have in common is...
they can both be pressed on vinyl =3D)

" what has capitalism done to Eastern Europe? they didn't have Hungarian
midget porn ghetto-tech under the Communists..."

That is the funniest shit I've ever read.  I have to find a way to
incorporate that into something.  Its just too funny to forget...

I think the point about wet & hard is this:  eastern Europe is almost
entirely catholic (even under communism).  I'll leave you to fill in the
blanks but we've all heard stories/jokes or actively pursued catholic
school girls for some strange reason.  You put two and two together...
Wet & hard, unlike ghetto tech, is not meant to be offensive (although
I'd love to send one of my CDs to asscroft and secretly watch his
reaction) and its certainly not ghetto.  Wet & hard is the sound of
eastern European clubbers, who are definitely far more sexual than their
American counterparts.  And it's a celebration of that sexuality, not
makin fun of it like ghetto tech does.  And by sexuality I don't mean
everybody there is a whore.  What I mean is that to them, there are no
puritanical taboos about sexuality like there are here in the states.
It's a different culture and that difference is definitely reflected in
the music.

Anyways... I didn't specifically direct my comments at you.  I found
nothing wrong with your comments.  If you wanna call my music tribal
house... more power to you!  You can call it whatever you want.  Wet &
hard is what you make of it.  Its your fantasy... if you fantasize about
tribal house...  then who am I to judge?=20

I didn't mean to personally attack anybody.. I just felt that I needed
to explain something since my so-called 'set' yesterday was such a
steaming pile of shit.  Normally, the music pretty much explains itself
but since I hardly played any wet & hard... there wasn't much of an
explanation....

Keep it wet & hard...
XXX,
p a t

Subject: RE: [sfraves] make distances, like a remix

Heres a few links:

http://www.flesh-berlin.de/

>From montreal:

http://www.montreal-raves.com/download.php?op=3Dviewsdownload&sid=3D3&ord=
erb
y=3DdateD

I must warn you.  I played at that show with corvin and it was fucking
cold.  So fucking cold I spent the next two weeks in bed.  Its split in
the middle because final scratch died (go figure!) so I'm not going to
say that's the best mixing ever... but it's a very good cross section of
wet & hard tracks.

There's also a ton of w&h sets on my website ranging in quality from
absolutely mindblowingly good to utter pieces of shit that I haven't had
time to take down yet =3D).  You can get them at www.djpat.com

I think corvin also has some links at www.corvindalek.de

And you can check out (but I don't have the time this second to puruse
them for the actual set links):

http://www.eivenmajor.com/

http://www.jankessler.com/

http://www.mrsam.tv

http://electromajk.com/


I'll dig up some more links to stuff online if anybody is interested...

Also, timo maas briefly toyed with wet & hard a few years ago
(2000,2001) so any of his sets from that time period would be wet &
hard.  And today mr. sam and Oliver Klein both play a pg13 version of
wet & hard.  They've both made some really awesome wet & hard tracks and
remixes over the last few years and the forthcumming album by mr sam on
tiesto's label is...  wet & hard... which is quite shocking.  They
aren't nearly as over the line as someone like corvin dalek is, but they
play wet & hard nonetheless.  They just do it in their own way.  So
check soulseek for some sets by them.  Stay away from their commercial
mix CDs however, as they are known as "trance" djs and hence their
commercial (aka have to pay the bills) CDs reflect that...

Breast wishes,
p a t

Subject: Re: [sfraves] make distances, like a remix

Pat,

You know I've heard you play wet & hard scores of times. I, and most 
everyone else in the place, always compares it to techouse or NY tribal.

Whoever it was that said "it's more of a brand than a new genre" was as on 
point as can be. Or maybe it's a sub-sub-genre?

You're the one that told me that "Cookie Dough Dynamo" and a few other 
Sondos releases were Wet & Hard. How are people NOT going to compare it to 
NY Tribal?

Either way, the sub-sub-genre has some phenominal tracks to be played from 
time to time. I was playing some "wet & hard" mixes of some techno tracks 
remixed by Corvin, Evian Major, Samuel L Sesions, and Timo Maas well before 
anyone refered to it as a genre.


- Gavin Varitech

>From: Love Parade SF News <info@loveparadesf.org>
>To: lovelist@loveparadesf.org
>Subject: [lovelist] Newsletter #2
>Date: Tue, 13 Jul 2004 12:06:35 -0700
>
>The Love is Coming... October 2, 2004
>July 12th, 2004
>
>Greetings from Love Parade San Francisco Headquarters! Hope everyone is 
>enjoying their summer. Here in San Francisco we are having our more 
>'wintry' weather like our neighbors in the Southern Hemisphere. But we 
>can't wait to dance in the streets with all of you during the heat of our 
>summer in October. Warm and sunny!
>
>We know you are eagerly awaiting news of what's going on and our small 
>nonprofit group is working hard to bring it all together. Expect more 
>details about the route, who's playing and where you can stay in the coming 
>weeks. But just briefly...
>
>Volunteer Meeting Wednesday, July 14th</B>We are hosting three volunteer 
>meetings with the first one being held
>
>July 14th, 7:00PM
>LGBT Community Center
>Room 300
>1800 Market St (at Octavia)
>San Francisco
>
>Another meeting will take place in August and the final volunteer meeting 
>in late September before the event.
>
>We would strongly encourage those who can attend the first meeting to 
>please do so.  This will enable us to delegate tasks out to those who wish 
>to take them on, freeing our Love Parade Board members to accomplish other 
>pressing tasks.
>
>If you can not attend the first or second volunteer meeting(s) or live 
>outside of the San Francisco Bay Area, you can volunteer in a big way by 
>spreading the word! >Download our press release 
><http://www.loveparadesf.org/about.html and other  pertinent items (the 
>flyer will be posted soon) and email them to your friends and contacts.
>
>Video Clip
>Never been to a Love Parade and want to see what it's all about?
>Click here for a video clip of the Love Parade (12.6 MB)
>http://www.loveparadesf.org/cliphi.html
>
>Float Applications
>If your company or DJ collective is interested in doing a float at Love 
>Parade, stay tuned! You will be receiving the application by next week.
>
>
>The Love is Coming... October 2, 2004
>The world's largest electronic music festival and parade is coming to San 
>Francisco on October 2, 2004. First held in Berlin in 1989, Loveparade San 
>Francisco is expected to draw thousands of revelers to the Bay Area for a 
>celebration of electronic music with a mission of fostering tolerance, 
>respect and understanding between nations.
>http://www.loveparadesf.org
>
>Need on or off this list? Visit
>http://www.photon.cc/mailman/listinfo/lovelist
>

Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed
Message-ID: <BAY8-F24U9NTJtjFEkw0009d75d@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 14 Jul 2004 22:02:03.0087 (UTC) FILETIME=[31BDC5F0:01C469EE]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] make distances, like a remix

Now before I get roasted for sounding argumentative, let me preface this by 
saying - I am listening to this "IamDalek" mix, and it is not too damn bad 
at all.

But I seriously don't see this as anything new. I could go to any number of 
places in NYC and hear similar sounds, complete with sleazy vocals, beats, 
etc.

It never ceases to amaze me how many times a year, some "new" genre of EDM 
comes out, and everyone who plays it wants to make it into the "next big 
thing" or call it "innovative" when clearly to anyone who has been listening 
to dance music for the last 20 years or so, it's really not. ALL dance music 
is about sex, and freedom, and letting yourself go, and vibe, etc. etc. I 
have heard deep house sets that were every bit as sexy, if not moreso 
(albeit they were sans porno vocals). I have heard breakbeat sets that had 
the dancefloor practcally writhing - and the same can be said for techno, 
trance, D&B, etc.

This sound is good - it's hard, it's pulsating, and it grooves, but it is 
nothing new.

That being said - where can a genre slut such as myself find some of this 
shit on vinyl? I will gladly mix some of into one of my sets. I can hear 
this stuff slipping right in the middle of some nasty breaks or tech-house, 
or even progressive (the hard, driving kind).

ez.

M-

From sfraves-return-113893-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Wed Jul 14 22:26:40 2004
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-113893-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org

Received: (qmail 20757 invoked from network); 14 Jul 2004 22:26:36 -0000
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="us-ascii"
Date: Wed, 14 Jul 2004 15:26:33 -0700
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Message-ID: <46474C2DBB20D645896D8102CC07EA690D1A6E@djpat.dyndns.org>
X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft Exchange V6.0.6487.1
X-MS-Has-Attach: 
X-MS-TNEF-Correlator: 
content-class: urn:content-classes:message
Thread-Topic: [sfraves] make distances, like a remix
Thread-Index: AcRp7jH74hzsBKsFQCin8TaeHb+2iAAAUTpg
From: "DJ Pat" <djpat@dj-pat.com>
To: "Van Mundegaarde" <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>,
	<shawn@alterior.net>,
	<sfraves@hyperreal.org>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] make distances, like a remix

I don't see anything arugmentative in your email at all.  J.C. gave
everybody a chance to hear wet & hard (many for the first time)
yesterday and my final scratch blew it.  Without hearing the music its
kinda lame to comment on it, but after hearing it if you still feel that
it sounds like the old NYC tribal house sound (ala tribal America, etc)
then more power to you. =20

You've now gotten to hear wet & hard.  Before you hadn't.  As for buying
the vinyl...  I dunno what to tell you.  You and everybody else (incl
pete tong and all the other washed up old men) wants that stuff on
vinyl.  Eveything you are hearing on the "I am a dalek" CD was either
not released, or it was pressed on vinyl by Flesh Records Berlin, an MFS
sublabel created specifically for wet & hard (because MFS is still
associated with trance and techno people like paul van dyk and humate).


For the remixes that corvin, oliver, mr. sam etc have done I always try
juno.co.uk or any of your online record stores.  The problem with
finding "wet & hard" stuff is one guy calls it NYC tribal house, the
next guy calls it trance, the next guy calls it techno.  You will see
the same record listed many different ways on different websites.

The best place to get stuff from jurgen driessen (one of the best wet &
hard producers there is by far, even tho he doesn't have the balls to
call it wet & hard) is from www.mutekki-media.de.  Jurgen is the nicest
guy in the world and will get you your shit fast.  If he doesn't have
something in stock he'll find it for you.  Now that's only for two
labels.  The stuff on Q Records can be bought directly from their
website. =20

MFS/Flesh doesn't have an online shop yet so your stuck tryin to find it
somewhere else. =20

The names to watch out for are people like corvin dalek, jurgen
driessen, oliver klien, eiven major, mr sam, martin H.  You just have to
search and listen.  The sordid nature of the music has really kept it
underground (which is good) so some of the artists (like mr. sam) make
trance records to pay the bills and then make the real shit on the side.
It's a pain in the ass...  but once you start looking you'll notice a
pattern real quick on which stores carry which crap.

juno.co.uk always carries EVERY record that oliver klein and corvin
dalek remix. The problem is... they sell out and then they're gone.  A
number of other producers in Europe typically associated with " techno"
have tested the wet & hard waters on occasion just for the hell of it.
These are people like DJ Hooligan, Samuel l sessions, Filterheadz, etc.
These are people that have no problem with wet & hard... its just not
their main thing.  But from time to time they'll make a track just for
the hell of it... so you kinda just gotta watch out for them.  But after
a while you'll notice its always the usual suspects.  So just watch the
stores and listen to the Mp3s and what not.  There isn't a buttload of
w&h cuming out every week so its not like yer gonna bankrupt yourself by
looking every week....

I hope that helps and if not I'll give ya more detailed info when time
permits.....

Breast wishes,
p a t

--- Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org> wrote:
> HEY DJ:  FUCK YOU!!!
> 
> Anyone Can Rock the Party (from VICE Magazine)
> 
> You know that thing called DJing? Playing records in
> bars or at stupid art 
> openings for money? Guess what DJing is? The biggest
> fucking bullshit con 
> of all time! People who get over as DJs are making
> the easiest money ever, 
> because they've convinced every PR person and club
> owner in the world that 
> they're doing something only a few natural-born
> geniuses can do. It's 
> laughable. A 70-year-old blind Ethiopian leper with
> 10 broken fingers can 
> "spin" just as well as any B-list celebrity at any
> instore party for some 
> gay snowboarding jeans company. I promise.
> 
> And those other guys who do all the little
> flick-flick, crabby moves on 
> records that are covered with spots of adhesive tape
> that are supposed to 
> mean something? Those aren't DJs! I don't know what
> to call them. Nerds, 
> maybe? They called themselves "turntablists" five
> years ago, but I think 
> that got embarrassing. One thing is for sure,
> though: Those guys don't DJ 
> on the actual paying gig circuit that I'm on,
> because no hammered jock 
> chicks or guidos from West Orange, N.J., will dance
> to an hour-long 
> abstract scratch frenzy over a P-Funk B-side.
> 
> I've been making loads of supplementary income by
> DJing for a few years 
> now, and I can barely even scratch my own back. All
> you really need is a CD 
> burner, Kazaa, and passably cool taste in music.
> Here, I'll tell you all 
> about my life as a party DJ:
> 
> TECHNIQUE
> FLOW: The only slightly ephemeral skill to learn is
> flow. Have you ever 
> made a mixtape for someone you had a crush on? Then
> you already know what 
> flow isthe ability to maintain a mood. I was at a
> party once where the DJ 
> kept playing one danceable hip-hop track, then one
> undanceable slow 
> classic-rock track, one hip-hop, one slow rock, on
> and on like that for an 
> hour! We would get up and dance, and then sit down,
> and then we finally 
> just stayed down and shot him really dirty looks. It
> was the opposite of 
> flow. To master flow, you just need to not be a
> fucking moron. Can you 
> handle that?
> 
> Segueing from one genre to a totally different one
> is easy. You just build 
> tiny little bridges instead of taking one big leap.
> For example, let's go 
> from a hip-hop set to a punk-rock set. You play your
> last rap song, then a 
> Prince track. Then maybe some ESG. Then the Slits.
> Boom! You're into the 
> punk before they know what hit 'em.
> 
> LCD: This is your audience. It stands for Lowest
> Common Denominator. You 
> are DJing for drunks and cokeheads, and they need
> the aural equivalent of 
> safety blankets. What would you rather hear when
> you're high as fuck in a 
> bar: Journey or some obscure acid-house? (If you're
> a geek, don't answer 
> that.)
> I used to spend all my time collecting the rarest
> tracks, stuff that when I 
> heard it at home it would totally blow my mind.
> Guess what? No one cared. 
> In fact, they stopped dancing. Now I stick to
> playing stuff that I liked 
> when I was a teenager (the Misfits, "O.P.P.," and
> songs from John Hughes 
> movies) and I'm golden. When in doubt, go nostalgic.
> 
> CUEING: This is where you enact the flow thing I
> just told you about. You 
> have two sides, right and left. When something's
> playing on the right, 
> think of a song that would sound good after it. Cue
> that song up on the 
> left by pressing the same buttons on a CD player
> that you've pressed 1,000 
> times before (or putting a needle down in the
> appropriate groove on a 
> record). When the song on the right side is about to
> end, slide the little 
> thingy in the box between the decks to the left.
> When you're a little less 
> than halfway over, press "play" on the CD or "start"
> on the turntable. 
> Congratulations, you're DJing. Can I get a "That was
> easy"?
> 
> PERKS
> LINES: A huge guilty pleasure is cutting the line
> and marching right up to 
> the velvet rope all casual, going, "Hi, I'm the DJ."
> I like to go to a gig 
> dressed like a total slob. The nicer the club, the
> shittier I look. Then I 
> can stroll past all the people who used to spit on
> me in high school and 
> make a big huge deal about going through the door
> first.
> 
> MONEY: Depending on who you are, a DJ's salary for
> one night can range from 
> a few free drinks to obscene amounts (for the big
> shots) that make you hate 
> capitalism. I heard Paul Sevigny got fucking $15,000
> to DJ at Sundance. I 
> hope that is DJ urban legend. Most DJs I know are
> pretty psyched if they 
> get a couple hundred. Art openings should pay more,
> like $350. And 
> remember: Always get paid in cash on the night of.
> Within 24 hours all 
> money magically transforms into cocaine blown up
> some model's ass.
> 
> COMPLIMENTS: One of the best things about DJing is
> when you play a really 
> kickass song and people come up to you dancing,
> going "I love this song!" 
> You get all proud and pretend you wrote it. You're
> like, "Thanks!" Yeah, I 
> downloaded "Youth Gone Wild," I rule. It's like
> being told your air-guitar 
> skills are fucking SICK.
> 
> GEAR
> NEEDLES: Those sleek, aerodynamic, $500 fancy-pants
> needles are the second 
> biggest scam in DJing besides convincing people that
> DJing is hard. For 
> totally serviceable needles, go to one of those
> electronics stores on Canal 
> Street and get the cheapest set possible. You can
> talk them down on the 
> price, too. I got a pair plus some shitty headphones
> for $90 after I 
> sweet-talked the sales guy for a minute. (BTW, the
> cheap needles are called 
> hip-hop needles and that's mean against blacks.)
> 
> MIXERS: There are a few brands of mixers, but who
> cares. DJs would like for 
> you to think mixers are all complicated, but they're
> really about as hard 
> to figure out as a home stereo. I once spun at this
> lesbian party where I 
> ended up giving girls DJ lessons all night. They
> were lined up across the 
> room, and it only took me a few seconds to show each
> of them the basics. As 
> Garfield would say, "Big fat hairy deal." Once I
> showed them how simple it 
> really is, they were shocked at the big deal that
> people make about the 
> whole thing. Yeah, there are cute little tricks you
> can do. If you're 
> playing a hip-hop song, it's fun to cut out the bass
> after the second verse 
> and then kick it back in full force on the chorus.
> It's a nifty party trick 
> and it makes girls lose their shit. But you can also
> just say, "Fuck it," 
> set them all in the middle, and read a book in
> between tracks.
> 
> WHEELS OF STEEL: Please don't call them that. Don't
> call them "the ones and 
> the twos" either. It sounds like your mom saying,
> "Homie don't play that."
> 
> ETIQUETTE
> OOPS: You're going to fuck up. The record will skip
> or you'll be distracted 
> by some drunk kid telling you how much "Bizarre Love
> Triangle" means to him 
> or you'll let two Wire songs play in a row. No big
> whup. Everyone's too 
> wasted to care. You should be too. Just take the
> opportunity 
=== message truncated ===

On 14 July 2004, shawn allen wrote:

> That's a nice attitude. DJ Pat seemed to make it very clear that he was
> a champion of "wet&hard", and it sounds as though people were
> underwhelmed. So either Pat didn't do a very good job of representing
> the sound, or the sound itself isn't that impressive. Obviously though,
> you can't judge a style of music by a single DJ set.
>
> Personally I found it very similar to deep progressive house and (as
> Van Mundegaarde mentioned) the New York tribal stuff (Tenaglia, et al).
> Maybe the Final Scratch malfunction is to blame, but what I heard
> certainly didn't sound as fresh and unique (or raw and sexy, for that
> matter) as what had been advertised. That's my 2c.
>
> Cheers,
>

Well, you should have seen how upset Pat was with the set (his
girlfriend was almost upset to tears.)  He didn't get to play hardly ANY
of the really wet'n'hard stuff (and this doesn't take into
consideration the FCC limitations I had to place on him, eliminating
even MORE stuff.)

So I guess what I'm saying, is he deserves the benefit of the doubt.
His set yesterday  wasn't really a true representation of the genre.
For that, he wouldn't be able to play it on the radio. ;)

Oh, and SFR peeps.  One thing Shawn didn't mention is that he'll be on
the show next week.  NOT playing wet'n'hard style.


http://www.jcthedj.com

find a copy of winternalsERD, put it in reboot (good sysadmins will make it 
so you cant boot to the cdrom) when it loads up select the partition with 
the winOS you want to get in to, once it boots it will give you a windows 
interface use 'locksmith' to change any password on the sys. if you can get 
that far your sustem admin will wonder what happen the next time they go tot 
remote in and his password does not work, he gets mad! you get fired for not 
following the exceptable usage policy.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Disco Demolition Anniversary
