At 09:45 PM 7/13/2004, John B wrote:


>OTOH, having been a mere toddler when disco was dying, and I think it be 
>wiser to defer to Apollo's first-hand experience in this matter.  If he 
>remembers a homophobic message on the part os this Steve Dahl (Any 
>relation to Geri, I wonder?) character, I don't doubt it was there.
>
>On the gripping hand, I think it's a mistake to equate 'anti-disco' with 
>'homophobic'.

Of course, John, and I never implied that those who hate disco are 
homophobic.  That's absurd.  I've always had an ambivalent attitude towards 
the genre myself.  Much of the mainstream product was horrible and my 
tastes in dance music require a bit more funk than folks like the Bee Gees 
supplied:)  I turned my back on the genre completely in the eighties and 
only recently began to look at this music more objectively -- for a variety 
of reasons, but primarily because some folks I knew back in seventies in 
NYC have been supplying me with recorded sets (I knew they existed, but 
people have now begun to rerecord the tapes digitally and produce CDs) made 
at the Paradise Garage, the Loft, the Troc and other excellent dance 
venues.  Virtually nothing that one hears on these tapes was commercially 
successful (mainstream) but there was, and I should have known this because 
I danced to and spun the stuff myself, some awesomely good disco music back 
then.  Even some of the more popular hits, like Le Freak, are quite 
compelling today as recorded and are being rediscovered and remixed -- 
given new life.

But back to Dahl and the disco demolition anniversary.

One really must look at this incident in the context of the times.  After 
Stonewall in 1969 gays began to fight for their rights and the gay urban 
"lifestyle" began to emerge over the next ten years.  I have written about 
this in some detail in House Music 101.  The sexual freedom philosophies of 
the sixties were actualized in the seventies and gay people led the 
way.  To be brief, it was really possible for a decade or so to completely 
fulfill even the most esoteric sexual fantasies without consequence and 
there were subcultures that eagerly supported this "hard and wet" 
experimentation.  I would think that most of you, if you were transported 
back to seventies NYC or SF, would be quite astonished by the ubiquitous 
culture of desire.  These times are so much more "conservative."

Central to the emerging gay subculture was dance.  Before disco, gays 
danced to R&B, Motown and the like and all this morphed into disco.  Gays 
pretty much emulated black dance culture then.  The dancefloor was the 
place where we could come together and celebrate without restriction our 
community and sexuality.  Disco, and the fashion and that emerged from the 
dance, were exclusively "gay" until the mid-seventies.

In the mid-seventies the gay subculture was enthusiastically emulated by 
the mainstream, and this included the eroticization of the male.  A 
hallmark event here was the first Calvin Kline male underwear billboard in 
Times Square:  a hot, hunky male with nothing on but Jockey shorts sporting 
a noticeable bulge in the crotch area.  Men, both straight and gay, began 
wearing VERY tight pants, skimpy shorts, and other gear that were designed 
to be sexually provocative.  This was a first, I think.  The Tarzan of the 
thirties movies may have run about in a loin cloth, but one didn't see him 
bumping and grinding on the dancefloor.

Women's liberation was in full swing.  Birth control was available.  STDs 
could be cured with a shot.  So everyone just jumped on the flesh pile and 
had a good time.  There were straight as well as gay sex clubs.  Swingers 
groups.  Sexual definition was becoming increasingly ambiguous.  I would 
frequently bump into guys who I thought were "straight" in gay orgy 
rooms.  Mick Jagger made a homoerotic film and talked about being 
"bi."  Celebrities would show up in the most unusual places, and there was 
a rumor circulating about that Jackie O fist-fucked one of the dancers at 
the Anvil on night.  Respectable publications would write reviews about new 
sex clubs like the "Toilet."  I realized just how much all this had been 
mainstreamed when, on Halloween, the top selling kids' costumes in NYC were 
based on the Village People, who represented, of course, four popular gay 
sex fetishes.

Middle America began to believe our American way of life was in serious danger.

Hard to recreate all this in a short post, which is growing much too long:)

In the late seventies a conservative reaction to the perceived 
"homosexualization" of America was setting in.  By 1977 the religious right 
was beginning to organize against the gay menace, and one of their most 
successful spokespeople was Anita Bryant, a former pop singer, orange juice 
saleswoman, and Miss America runner up.  In 1978 the US Supreme Court (FCC 
vs Pacifica Foundation) approved restrictions on broadcast material that 
was "indecent" to block gay-themed programming.  The gay liberation 
movement was beginning to meet stiff resistance.  Then, in one defining 
action that same year, Dan White shot and killed openly gay supervisor 
Harvey Milk and Mayor Moscone here in SF City Hall.  The next year White 
was acquitted of first degree murder (the Twinkie defense) and convicted of 
simple manslaughter (he got out of prison in 1985).  Gays rioted in the 
streets everywhere, and in SF police cars were set afire.

It was  in this historical context that Dahl organized the disco record 
burning in Chicago.  Disco, the symbol of gay subculture and its threat to 
many manly males, was ritually burned and a testosterone charged riot 
ensured.  Mainstream culture moved in the direction you grew up in.  AIDS 
put the final nail in the proverbial coffin of sex as pleasure, the 
business of America became productivity and business once again, and here 
we are.

Very brief, skimpy overview of those complex times, but ya get my drift?:)

Love,

Apollo



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and causes 
me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war, 
corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong 
its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-Abraham Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

  "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

Subject: RE: [sfraves] make distances, like a remix

Haha!  I wish I was that creative.  But sorry to say the pissed off
eastie kid was for real.  I forwarded some of the funny emails from SF
raves to the label owner because I thought he would find them humorous
(I know I did).  We get the same reaction all the time.  He forwarded
them on to some of his buddies who he thought would find them amusing
and so on.  Apparently one of the easties didn't find it too
entertaining. =20

If you listened to the music and didn't find it different or original,
then I must thank you for at least LISTENING to it.  That's more than
you would get out of most Americans in this day and age....

And as for it being a "commercial"...  well duh!  The last time I played
on J.C.'s show a bunch of people called him, wrote him and wrote sf
raves asking "what the fuck is wet & hard" even though they just got
done hearing it or were in the process of hearing it.  The last time
though, people were asking "what is this music, I've never heard
anything like it" not comparing it to danny tenaglia.  I just thought it
would be a good idea to explain what it was before hand.  And still
there is drama.  So much for the luck of the irish.

At any rate I thank you for giving the music a chance and glad you liked
it.

Keep it wet & hard...
XXX,
p a t

On Saturday, July 17th, from noon until 6pm+, we will
be having an outdoor day party on Treasure Island.
Come dance in the sun to celebrate how lucky we are to
live in this beautiful place.

Pyd Piper (Skynet)              * Trance *
DJ Luke with Steve M on guitar  * House Live PA *
Phaedrus (Moksha)               * Drum & Bass *
Drifter (Tech Support)          * Drum & Bass *
Lewt (Cannabass)                * Drum & Bass *
Happy (Cannabass)               * Drum & Bass *

We're going to be doing some interesting things with
multiple turntables, mixers, laptops, keyboards and
other fun things. We're doing this because we love
music and people and people who love music. So if you
are a person, or you are music, you should come spend
the afternoon with us!

Outdoor location on Treasure Island complete with
grills, picnic tables and a tire swing. Bring picnic
stuff. There is a lot of space, so dancers, b-boys &
girls, poi spinners, tumblers, whateva, join us, bring
yo shit and have a fit cause we gettin lost on the
island.

Directions from the Bay Bridge:

HILLCREST RD becomes TREASURE ISLAND RD
TREASURE ISLAND RD becomes AVENUE PALMS
Jog (slight left, then right) onto AVENUE PALMS
Turn right onto 9TH ST
Look for the big park on the right, roughly at the
intersection of 9th and H

Subject: [sfraves] nrr:  Chris Vierra  gone

(From Dj Liquid):

I am writing regretfully to inform you that our beloved friend, Chris Vierra 
passed away this morning in a fatal fire in his home.

Chris (Terratraxx Recordings, PI Prod. Seattle) was was not only a gifted 
hard breaks dj but a good person but carried a great spirit and was and will 
always be a positive inspiration.

Chris and his partners in Terratraxx Recordings put their heart and soul to 
develop and re-invent dance music as we have all come to know it... 
innovative sounds, banging tunes, and captivating energy drives its 
owners/co-founders. Nick TerraNova (Dj TerraNova), Alex TerraNova (Dj 
AlxOne) and Chris Vierra (Dj Chris Vierra) push the envelope in the Trance, 
House, Techno and Breakbeat genres.

------
i didn't know chris  as a friend, but his name was well known in the breaks 
scene here.  he played at the first party that i and evil breaks threw, 
FURIOUS.  i played right after him.  he fucking tore it up and was there 
cheering me on when i played.

my thoughts and prayers go out to his family and friends.  god rest his 
soul.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Disco Demolition Anniversary

-------------------------------1089902984
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Thanks to Apollo for a very eloquent and informative recounting of the  disco 
era. I was "there" but on the outskirts, not at the actual clubs the way  
Apollo was. I was still an impressionable high school student in the late 70s  
and I agree that Disco was portrayed as "very gay" the whole time I was around.  
I listened to the Rolling Stones and Pink Floyd, and even though the Rolling  
Stones had a disco hit ("Miss You"), most of the disco that I heard -- on the 
 radio, as I was not going to clubs -- was the very commercial variety (Bee 
Gees,  "Disco Duck," and worse) and sounded pretty awful to someone who loved 
music. If  I'd been in New York, going to the clubs Apollo frequented, I 
probably would  have had quite a different impression. 
 
I remember reading about that anti-disco stunt at the ballpark. I couldn't  
stand most of the disco records, but even then I could see that the furor was  
anti-gay in a fascistic pseudo-"populist" way that paved the way for  
hate-mongers like today's Rush Limbaugh and Michael Savage. (Soon after, disco  
bashing would give way to Iran bashing and Sammy Hagar extorting fans to  
collectively hate Ayatollah Khomeini. Later, of course, Iran became our "friend"  
because they were enemies with Iraq.) 
 
When I started going out clubbing (1982), Disco was still around but was  
losing steam. Donna Summer was still a staple at the I-Beam (big Haight St  
club), and her "Last Dance" was indeed the last song played at many clubs each  
night.  Motown music, updated, continued to be popular.  
 
However, I was a wallflower, and I missed out on the Age of Sexual Excess  
simply because I was too shy to get any dates. It took a while to get past that. 
 
I've saved Apollo's post on my computer because I want to be reminded of  the 
days just before I got into dance music.   Thanks  again!

:)
John

-------------------------------1089902984--

Subject: [sfraves] [bsp] SKYNET @ SOMA Sessions - Fri July 23

SOMA Sessions
SF Drum 'n Bass Fourth Fridays
http://www.somasessions.com

SOMA Sessions is San Francisco's premier Friday night
Jungle/Drum 'n Bass party.  On every Fourth Friday we
invite leading hand-picked DJ talents from around the
globe to play extended sets in an intimate setting
which forms the idea of the "session"...


Friday July 23, 2004

SKYNET (Skynet Recordings, Discrete, nVision - UK)
Following his early years as a self-aware nuclear
defense system hell-bent on the destruction of the
humans, Brighton's Skynet kindled his creative side
and forged innovative D&B with partner Stakka on the
Liftin' Spirit, Audio Blueprint and Underfire labels. 
Producing together since 1993, their efforts
culminated in the timeless Clockwork LP of 2001.
Winding forward, 2004 finds Skynet bearing a prolific
solo output and no fewer than three imprints- Skynet
Recs, Discrete and nVision. Join The Terminator
himself on this mission into the future of
techstep....

RANDO (Levitated Recordings, Phuturo - SF)

DJ M (SOMA Sessions)


** Discount $8 presale will call tickets available now
at http://somasessions.com **

Tickets:  $8 presale, $10 door
Hours:  10:30pm - 3am
Entry:  21+ with photo ID
Bar:  $3 drink specials all night

Sponsored by:
RINSE Magazine [http://rinsemag.com] - Drum & Bass /
Jungle / Breakbeats

Location:
AsiaSF, 201 Ninth Street at Howard St, SF
Before the show try AsiaSF's Cal-Asian cuisine and
nightly performances!  For dinner reservations call
415.255.ASIA or visit http://asiasf.com.

Branding & print design:
Ryan @ Citizen-7 [http://www.citizen-7.com]


- - - - - - - - - - - -
NEXT MONTH - Friday Aug 27

BAY AREA DRUM 'N BASS DRUNKEN MASTER CHAMPIONSHIP 2004
SOMA Sessions is proud to host the first event of its
kind in the Bay. Watch DJs as they battle - to keep
the room from spinning! Insane drink specials, prizes
and giveaways all night...

Contestants:
CLANDESTINE + COMPRESSION + RHYTHM METHOD + SOULSTREAM
+ URBAN DRUMS + MORE TBC...

Hosted by SF's favorite mic controllers:
AUDIO ANGEL + MC DUH

Overseen by a panel of distinguished judges:
DMARIE + SOUND:BOY + MORE TBC...

Subject: [sfraves] (((Utopia)))  This Saturday!!  <bsp>

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii


UTOPIA 

join us for a journey around the world in celebration of electronica 
with some of todays best electronic artists and DJs as well as the 
legendary visionaries that pioneered the genre.  with an extremely rare 
colaboration of international talent & extreme sound and lighting by 
stimulights, we will be transforming this venue into a true Utopia for all.

Saturday July 17, 2004 

featuring... 
---------- 
Area 1 - Hosted By Di Moda & Von Dutch 
----- 
SNEAKER PIMPS 

(Perfecto, Virgin, Just Say Agency / London, UK) 
Sneaker Pimps are responsible for the classic records "Spin Spin Sugar" 
which was remixed by Armand Van Helden & "6 Underground" which was 
remixed buy Paul Oakenfold & was featured on the cruel intentions motion 
picture soundtrack. From Alternative Rock, to Break Beats & Trance, 
Antipop of Sneaker Pimps has produced and performs it all. Among other 
credits to his name Antipop has opened for Radio Head on the Massive Attack 
Tour & Hosted Pete Tong's Essential Mix 13 times. His music has also 
appeared on albums like Chillout Ibiza on Ministry of Sound, Dave 
Seamans Back to Mine album, Armand van Heldens Repro CD, Back to the Old 
Skool Ibiza on Ministry of Sound, and Erik Morillos session 9 CD. 

BLUE 
(Toga - LA) 
Don't miss LA's hottest UK Hard House DJ! 

DYLOOT 
(Skills - Berkley) 

ST JOHN 
(Wild949, House Nation - SF) 

DUTCH 
(Thump Radio - SF) 

GIANNI 
(Spundae, Most Wanted - SF) 

DISKO SHAWN 
(SubSonic, Live105 - SF) 

KIDZ AT PLAY 
(Audio Metamorphisis - SF) 
----- 
---------- 
AREA 2 - Hosted by Kontrast Recordings 
----- 
JESSE SAUNDERS 
(Numark, Just Say - Chicago) 
What more can be said about Jesse Saunders? The world renowned DJ 
extraordinaire with over 20+ years of experience, who has made millions of 
fans and party goers all over the world testify to his unprecedented 
sets where he takes the crowd on a musical journey through the evolution 
of Electronic music. Known as "the Originator", Jesse is the producer 
credited with creating the first House Music record ever (On & On - 
1983).  

ANGEL ALANIS 
(A2, In-Stereo, IHR, Moody, Contaminated, Eden, Kontrast, Solmatic, 
Moonshine, STX - Los Angeles) 
A legend in the house & techno industry Angel Alanis is one of the most 
prolific electronic music producers ever. His work has been acclaimed 
by every major House and Techno Dj & Producer including Dj Dan, Donald 
Glaude, Armand Van Helden, Bad Boy Bill, Carl Cox, Trevor Rocklife, 
Conga Squad, Josh Wink, Judge Jules, & So many others. Angel Alanis now 
tours the world spreading the sounds of techno & house. 

BRYAN COX 
(Subliminal, STX, Funkteck, Weapon, Kontrast, Bush, Ammo - Dallas, TX) 
Bryan is the hottest house producer with remixes for Dj Dan & Dj Irene 
rockin dance floors all over the world! His music appears on Richard 
Humpty Vission's new CD and Donald Glaude's New record label. 

HIGH CALIBER 
(Olive, Nocturnal, Kontrast, Moody, Nine, Ammo - Chicago) 
High Caliber's music has been charted by Paul Van Dyke, Judge Jules, 
Bad Boy Bill, Dj Dan, & many others... They have also remixed for CZR, 
Angel Alanis, Synthique, & have released over 30 tracks on vinyl. 

PAUL ANTHONY 
(Nocturnal, Kontrast - Chicago) 
Witness amazing turntablizm & mixing skills from the Midwest master! 
You won't believe all the tricks Paul Anthony has up his sleeves! See why 
he rocks 100s of shows all over the US per year and don't miss his set! 

JON PEGNATO 
(A2, In Stereo, Eden, Olive, Kontrast - LA) 
With heavy support from Dj Dan & Donald Glaude, plus working with Angel 
Alanis has made Jon Pegnato one of the fastest rises stars in house 
music, don't miss his set! 

DJ FREQUENCY 
(www.djfrequency.info, Kontrast, Weapon, Ammo - SF) 
With support from heavy weights like CZR, David Garcia, Raoul Zerna, 
Joey Mazzola, Bam Bam, & Josh the Funky1 + remixes out for Bryan Cox, 
High Caliber, & Jon Pegnato, Frequency is making his mark on the 
international house scene. 

RON REESER 
(Djronreeser.com, Funkteck, Kontrast, Solmatic - SF) 
A local house music hero partly responsible for throwing some of the 
largest electronic music shows ever in northern California through 
clockwork eventz, Ron now is in the studio full time working on music for 
Funkteck, Kontrast, Solmatic, and many other record labels. Be on the look 
out for Ron's music on record store shelves soon, and be prepared to 
see this awesome talent tour the world in 2005. 

FELIPE AVELAR & RECKLESS RYAN 
(House Nation, Wild 94.9, Kontrast, Bassline FM, Solid Grooves, Ammo - 
SF) 

FUNKE MIGUEL 
(Plaztech, Organic Vibe - SF) 

---------- 
Area 3 - Hosted By Dr. Free Clouds 
----- 

RON D CORE 
(DrFreeclouds.com - Costa Mesa) 
Ron D Core has been there from the start. Since the mid 1980's he's 
been an icon in the electronic music scene. Best known for his Mad Doctor 
& Decible Destruction mix compilations, Ron is now stationed in LA 
owning and operating his store Dr Freeclouds recordings which specializes 
in hardcore. 

ANDREA ALEXIS 
(Sexual Mindset, Butterfly Beatz - NYC) 
Andrea Alexis is known in NYC as one of the hottest hardcore / hard 
trance djs in the scene. Don't miss her first CA appearance! 

VALERIE SPARKS 
(Femme Djs, Bayraves - SF) 

AARON JAE 
(Evil Breaks, Aaronjae.com - SF) 

DJ DOZA & ORIONZ 
(Bay Raves, Zapatistas, Next Level - SF) 

SASCHA 23 & DJ WARREN 
(Xtort, Amory - SAC) 

MATT FROST & SERG ROCKWELL 
(Rokrite, Global Funk, Organic - SF) 

JOE VICIOUS & DJBJ 
(Caltrance - SF) 

ELUZION 
(Organic - SF) 
---------- 

***NOW @ THE SPOT WHERE SKILLS THREW 1998 & 1999... 
18+ @ THE REGENCY CENTER! - 1290 Sutter St. San Francisco, CA 

- 6pm - 2am 
- 200,000 watts of premium sound 
- Extreme Lasers by Stimulights 
- 100% Fully & Secured Venue 
- $250 dance contest!
- Exotic Go Go Dancers 
- Intense Lighting & Visuals 
- Black light show by dosed 
- Friendly Security

www.groovetickets.com

Newtrendz
Saturday, 7/31/2004

for something DIFFERENT, something NEW, something FUN!!!! Well, Newtrendz is 
Giving it To You Baby!!! Join Newtrendz for... THE SUMMER BOAT PARTY 
EXTRAVAGANZA!!! It's Going Down Saturday July 31 st!!!! Leaving from Pier 40 
(near Pac Bell Park)!!! Boat Departs Promptly at 7:30pm! There will be 3 
Themed Rooms, 3 Bars (E'ry body on the Boat Gettin' Tipsy!), 11 Promotional 
Companies and 10 DJ's spinning your favorite HIP-HOP, R & B, Old Skool, Club 
Classics, Dancehall, Reggae, SALSA, Tropical Rhythms, and every other 
Musical Craving you can think of!!! Who are the DJ's you asked? Only the Bay 
Area's Finest on the 1's and 2's, featuring... MIND MOTION, RICK LEE, FUZE, 
SUPREME, DJ SHUG, DJ LASH, SAKE-1, MAURICIO, SAUL and HAPPY!!! And it 
doesn't stop there!!! Because....... AFTER THE BOAT, IT'S THE AFTERPARTY! 
LOCATION TBA... LIMITED DISCOUNT TICKETS CURRENTLY AVALIABLE! ONCE THE 
DISCOUNT TICKETS ARE GONE, THE PRICE WILL INCREASE!
Doors Open at: 7:00 PM
Doors Close at: 11:30 PM
Will Call for Ticket Pick-up Closes at: 7: PM
Ages: 21 and up
Event Capacity: 450
Pier 40
Pier 40 Embarcadero
San Francisco, CA 94105 United States




SFR: Ranger
Santa Cruz
plurranger@hotmail.com

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Boat Parties: Where R They?

They don't happen as often since the one incident where a drunk bitch tossed
another guy overboard. Guy ended up dying from that incident and now you
have all the boat charters freaked out over another incident occuring. I
know that had a huge impact on RedMelon boat parties and a lot to do with
why they don't happen now. Pacific Sound (www.pacificsound.net) does still
do Sunset boat parties. They just had one on 4th of July weekend. Beyond
that the people the run Anu in SF (celtic something) throw boat parties
every now and then. Last year they brought out Hybrid.

The party you listed here looks booty ass trashy to me...

:: r y a n ::

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (((Utopia)))  This Saturday!!  <bsp>

FYI - The Sneaker Pimps that you probably know and love are a completely
different group these days. They're *nothing* like what you heard on
Becoming X. The girl that was singing has since left the group and the last
cd was more alt-rock in sound with all male vocals. If you go there looking
for the Sneaker Pimps of 1997 you won't find them...

all.
>
> Saturday July 17, 2004
>
> featuring...
> ---------- 
> Area 1 - Hosted By Di Moda & Von Dutch
> ----- 
> SNEAKER PIMPS
>
> (Perfecto, Virgin, Just Say Agency / London, UK)
> Sneaker Pimps are responsible for the classic records "Spin Spin Sugar"
> which was remixed by Armand Van Helden & "6 Underground" which was
> remixed buy Paul Oakenfold & was featured on the cruel intentions motion
> picture soundtrack. From Alternative Rock, to Break Beats & Trance,
> Antipop of Sneaker Pimps has produced and performs it all. Among other
> credits to his name Antipop has opened for Radio Head on the Massive
Attack
> Tour & Hosted Pete Tong's Essential Mix 13 times. His music has also
> appeared on albums like Chillout Ibiza on Ministry of Sound, Dave
> Seaman's Back to Mine album, Armand van Helden's Repro CD, Back to the Old
> Skool Ibiza on Ministry of Sound, and Erik Morillo's session 9 CD.
>
> BLUE
> (Toga - LA)
> Don't miss LA's hottest UK Hard House DJ!
>
> DYLOOT
> (Skills - Berkley)
>
> ST JOHN
> (Wild949, House Nation - SF)
>
> DUTCH
> (Thump Radio - SF)
>
> GIANNI
> (Spundae, Most Wanted - SF)
>
> DISKO SHAWN
> (SubSonic, Live105 - SF)
>
> KIDZ AT PLAY
> (Audio Metamorphisis - SF)
> ----- 
> ---------- 
> AREA 2 - Hosted by Kontrast Recordings
> ----- 
> JESSE SAUNDERS
> (Numark, Just Say - Chicago)
> What more can be said about Jesse Saunders? The world renowned DJ
> extraordinaire with over 20+ years of experience, who has made millions of
> fans and party goers all over the world testify to his unprecedented
> sets where he takes the crowd on a musical journey through the evolution
> of Electronic music. Known as "the Originator", Jesse is the producer
> credited with creating the first House Music record ever (On & On -
> 1983).
>
> ANGEL ALANIS
> (A2, In-Stereo, IHR, Moody, Contaminated, Eden, Kontrast, Solmatic,
> Moonshine, STX - Los Angeles)
> A legend in the house & techno industry Angel Alanis is one of the most
> prolific electronic music producers ever. His work has been acclaimed
> by every major House and Techno Dj & Producer including Dj Dan, Donald
> Glaude, Armand Van Helden, Bad Boy Bill, Carl Cox, Trevor Rocklife,
> Conga Squad, Josh Wink, Judge Jules, & So many others. Angel Alanis now
> tours the world spreading the sounds of techno & house.
>
> BRYAN COX
> (Subliminal, STX, Funkteck, Weapon, Kontrast, Bush, Ammo - Dallas, TX)
> Bryan is the hottest house producer with remixes for Dj Dan & Dj Irene
> rockin dance floors all over the world! His music appears on Richard
> Humpty Vission's new CD and Donald Glaude's New record label.
>
> HIGH CALIBER
> (Olive, Nocturnal, Kontrast, Moody, Nine, Ammo - Chicago)
> High Caliber's music has been charted by Paul Van Dyke, Judge Jules,
> Bad Boy Bill, Dj Dan, & many others... They have also remixed for CZR,
> Angel Alanis, Synthique, & have released over 30 tracks on vinyl.
>
> PAUL ANTHONY
> (Nocturnal, Kontrast - Chicago)
> Witness amazing turntablizm & mixing skills from the Midwest master!
> You won't believe all the tricks Paul Anthony has up his sleeves! See why
> he rocks 100s of shows all over the US per year and don't miss his set!
>
> JON PEGNATO
> (A2, In Stereo, Eden, Olive, Kontrast - LA)
> With heavy support from Dj Dan & Donald Glaude, plus working with Angel
> Alanis has made Jon Pegnato one of the fastest rises stars in house
> music, don't miss his set!
>
> DJ FREQUENCY
> (www.djfrequency.info, Kontrast, Weapon, Ammo - SF)
> With support from heavy weights like CZR, David Garcia, Raoul Zerna,
> Joey Mazzola, Bam Bam, & Josh the Funky1 + remixes out for Bryan Cox,
> High Caliber, & Jon Pegnato, Frequency is making his mark on the
> international house scene.
>
> RON REESER
> (Djronreeser.com, Funkteck, Kontrast, Solmatic - SF)
> A local house music hero partly responsible for throwing some of the
> largest electronic music shows ever in northern California through
> clockwork eventz, Ron now is in the studio full time working on music for
> Funkteck, Kontrast, Solmatic, and many other record labels. Be on the look
> out for Ron's music on record store shelves soon, and be prepared to
> see this awesome talent tour the world in 2005.
>
> FELIPE AVELAR & RECKLESS RYAN
> (House Nation, Wild 94.9, Kontrast, Bassline FM, Solid Grooves, Ammo -
> SF)
>
> FUNKE MIGUEL
> (Plaztech, Organic Vibe - SF)
>
> ---------- 
> Area 3 - Hosted By Dr. Free Clouds
> ----- 
>
> RON D CORE
> (DrFreeclouds.com - Costa Mesa)
> Ron D Core has been there from the start. Since the mid 1980's he's
> been an icon in the electronic music scene. Best known for his Mad Doctor
> & Decible Destruction mix compilations, Ron is now stationed in LA
> owning and operating his store Dr Freeclouds recordings which specializes
> in hardcore.
>
> ANDREA ALEXIS
> (Sexual Mindset, Butterfly Beatz - NYC)
> Andrea Alexis is known in NYC as one of the hottest hardcore / hard

> > With support from heavy weights like CZR, David Garcia, Raoul Zerna,
> > Joey Mazzola, Bam Bam, & Josh the Funky1 + remixes out for Bryan Cox,
> > High Caliber, & Jon Pegnato, Frequency is making his mark on the
> > international house scene.
> >
> > RON REESER
> > (Djronreeser.com, Funkteck, Kontrast, Solmatic - SF)
> > A local house music hero partly responsible for throwing some of the
> > largest electronic music shows ever in northern California through
> > clockwork eventz, Ron now is in the studio full time working on music 
>for
> > Funkteck, Kontrast, Solmatic, and many other record labels. Be on the 
>look
> > out for Ron's music on record store shelves soon, and be prepared to
> > see this awesome talent tour the world in 2005.
> >
> > FELIPE AVELAR & RECKLESS RYAN
> > (House Nation, Wild 94.9, Kontrast, Bassline FM, Solid Grooves, Ammo -
> > SF)
> >
> > FUNKE MIGUEL
> > (Plaztech, Organic Vibe - SF)
> >
> > ----------
> > Area 3 - Hosted By Dr. Free Clouds
> > -----
> >
> > RON D CORE
> > (DrFreeclouds.com - Costa Mesa)
> > Ron D Core has been there from the start. Since the mid 1980's he's
> > been an icon in the electronic music scene. Best known for his Mad 
>Doctor
> > & Decible Destruction mix compilations, Ron is now stationed in LA
> > owning and operating his store Dr Freeclouds recordings which 
>specializes
> > in hardcore.
> >
> > ANDREA ALEXIS
> > (Sexual Mindset, Butterfly Beatz - NYC)
> > Andrea Alexis is known in NYC as one of the hottest hardcore / hard
> > trance djs in the scene. Don't miss her first CA appearance!
> >
> > VALERIE SPARKS
> > (Femme Djs, Bayraves - SF)
> >
> > AARON JAE
> > (Evil Breaks, Aaronjae.com - SF)
> >

> > (Bay Raves, Zapatistas, Next Level - SF)
> >

> > (Xtort, Amory - SAC)

> > (Caltrance - SF)

> > (Organic - SF)

From: "innocentchild" <innocentchild@hotmail.com>
To: "Ranger -" <plurranger@hotmail.com>,<sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Boat Parties: Where R They?
Date: Thu, 15 Jul 2004 11:12:58 -0700

They don't happen as often since the one incident where a drunk bitch tossed
another guy overboard. Guy ended up dying from that incident and now you
have all the boat charters freaked out over another incident occuring. I
know that had a huge impact on RedMelon boat parties and a lot to do with
why they don't happen now. Pacific Sound (www.pacificsound.net) does still
do Sunset boat parties. They just had one on 4th of July weekend. Beyond
that the people the run Anu in SF (celtic something) throw boat parties
every now and then. Last year they brought out Hybrid.

The party you listed here looks booty ass trashy to me...

:: r y a n ::

fyi, red melon didn't go bye-bye, it just became harder to
throw boat parties.  they still throw parties, i think their
latest spot is "mighty" on utah.

i seem to remember two separate incidences of people being
tossed (or jumping) overboard.  one was a doc martin boat party
where someone went overboard, and someone else went after
him/her.  both died.  the other was the RM party.

> cd was more alt-rock in sound with all male vocals. If you go there looking

>one of the things said is that the sneaker pimps WILL NOT be their

Sneaker Pimps will be there, but who cares?  They won't be doing a live preformance, just spinnin.  I think the promoters could have done better to not hype up the DaftPunk/Sneaker Pimps thing... cuz now thats all anyone's talking about, and it's taking all the focus from what really seems to be a great party.

The whole deal with Thomas Bangalter is someone claiming to be him managed to get booked to the On and On tour through Virgin music and Jesse Saunders production company.  They billed the tour with Daft Punk everywhere, something like 35 or 40 US locations plus international dates (England, France, Costa Rica, Brazil, etc.)  Of course, the real Thomas Bangalter heard about this and that's when the fiasco started... unfortunate really cuz it doesn't seem to be anyone involved with the tours fault.  check out this site for the whole story: http://www.justsayagency.com/artistpage.php?aid=78

Even with all that drama, the lineup honestly looks like one of the best I've seen in a very long while.  If you've never seen any of these people I think that it would be well worth your 25 bux to check it out. (I am!)  Jesse Saunders and Bryan Cox are nothing short of amazing!  I saw both of em at a show in Manchester a few years back.  I've never seen the rest of the headliners except for Angel Alonis (who is also way sick) but I'm familiar with most of their music some of it's great and some I'm not a huge fan of but it definetly isn't the same old bullshit trax that every DJ has.  Ya got the founders of House music and NRG there for jeeps sake. 

All the best local talent will be there too (except Denise which is a let down)

I went to one other party thrown by organicvibe (w/ infected mushroom, don't remember the name) and it was pretty sweet, the only let down was that it seemed like it wasn't promoted well or something cuz the space never really filled up.  Friends that have been to more of their parties say the crew is consistantly good with their events.

sorry so long -- really hope to see you guys there.

-pAUL

Message-ID: <b7941d4c040716085626cd3dff@mail.gmail.com>
Date: Fri, 16 Jul 2004 08:56:30 -0700
From: g00fRiDER <goofrider@gmail.com>
To: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <6.1.1.1.2.20040707195227.02407190@localhost>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
References: <6.1.1.1.2.20040707195227.02407190@localhost>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] HEY DJ: FUCK YOU!!!

That was too funny.

I want to take this chance to share one of my pet peeves.....

Often when I meet DJs, I ask them what they play. There are 2 answers
I dread the most: "everything" and "house".


Everything:

I absolutely hate it when DJs say they play "everything". Do they just
want to brag about how diverse they are? Or just can't make up their
mind about what they play? There's only one type of DJs that play
"everything" -- wedding DJs. If you don't really have a specific style
you play most, you're either the kind of DJ who always play something
because it's popular at the moment, or your sets are just
incomprehandsibly incoherent.

You gotta have a style (or 2, or 3) you play most. Why not just say
it? No-one's trying to typecast you. There's no shame in what you
play, right?

House:

I hate it when DJs say they play house. Not that I don't like house,
but there are about 23 types of house: NY vocal house, west coast
loungy house, banging chicago house, funky disco house, techy tribal
house, deep dark progressive house..... A DJ saying he/she plays house
is like a guiatrist saying he/she plays rock. It means ABSOLUTELY
NOTHING.

I asked you what you play right? Then please take your time to
elaborate. If I care enough to ask, I probably care enough to know,
and know enough to understand.


Pz y'all,

- Jeff

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Sparks - (HCFTP, RaveNBeats, k00terk0re) vs. (Femme DJs, Bay Raves)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] HEY DJ: FUCK YOU!!!

On Thu, 8 Jul 2004 11:38:27 -0700, DJ Soundwave <dj.soundwave@gmail.com> wrote:

> yah. she's talking about this kind of DJing:
> 
> http://www.marketingfordjs.com
> 
> weddings, frat parties, corporate events, bar mitzvahs, etc.; the type
> of DJs they're talking to in catalogs when they say "don't miss
> another gig because you don't have karaoke!"
> 

Oh yeah, another thing. I always find it kinda amusing that
wedding/party DJs can just call themselves  __DJs__ with a str8 face,
like they were real DJs. They never volunteer the "wedding" part.  Is
it like strippers calling themselves dancers?

But then, there are turntablists who thinks DJs who can't scratch are
just cueing records.

Personally, I prefer to say that "I play records". Kinda like "I play
guitar" or "I play piano". It implies that I'm doing something musical
with records, rather than just cueing and beatmatching.

- Jeff

Subject: Re: [sfraves] HEY DJ: FUCK YOU!!!

What if you're like me, and you :

A) hate subgenres
B) play MANY styles of a particular genre

What then?

When someone asks me what I play - I tend to say "everything" because I play 
most styles of EDM to some degree or another. When I play house, I play many 
styules of house - not just "nyc house" or "disco house' or "vocal house". 
In fact, most house dj's I know mix it up a bit. This makes them bad people? 
They HAVe to pick ONE style to say they play? That's pretty limiting.

>From: g00fRiDER <goofrider@gmail.com>
>To: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>
>CC: sfraves@hyperreal.org
>Subject: Re: [sfraves] HEY DJ: FUCK YOU!!!
>Date: Fri, 16 Jul 2004 08:56:30 -0700
>
>That was too funny.
>
>I want to take this chance to share one of my pet peeves.....
>
>Often when I meet DJs, I ask them what they play. There are 2 answers
>I dread the most: "everything" and "house".
>
>
>Everything:
>
>I absolutely hate it when DJs say they play "everything". Do they just
>want to brag about how diverse they are? Or just can't make up their
>mind about what they play? There's only one type of DJs that play
>"everything" -- wedding DJs. If you don't really have a specific style
>you play most, you're either the kind of DJ who always play something
>because it's popular at the moment, or your sets are just
>incomprehandsibly incoherent.
>
>You gotta have a style (or 2, or 3) you play most. Why not just say
>it? No-one's trying to typecast you. There's no shame in what you
>play, right?
>
>House:
>
>I hate it when DJs say they play house. Not that I don't like house,
>but there are about 23 types of house: NY vocal house, west coast
>loungy house, banging chicago house, funky disco house, techy tribal
>house, deep dark progressive house..... A DJ saying he/she plays house
>is like a guiatrist saying he/she plays rock. It means ABSOLUTELY
>NOTHING.
>
>I asked you what you play right? Then please take your time to
>elaborate. If I care enough to ask, I probably care enough to know,
>and know enough to understand.
>
>
>Pz y'all,
>
>- Jeff

Message-ID: <b7941d4c040716095774c63216@mail.gmail.com>

From: g00fRiDER <goofrider@gmail.com>
To: Van Mundegaarde <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>
Cc: apollo@speakeasy.org, sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <BAY8-F8AsdVgWUaOfXp000104aa@hotmail.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
References: <BAY8-F8AsdVgWUaOfXp000104aa@hotmail.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] HEY DJ: FUCK YOU!!!

I must have struck one of your nerves or something.  LOL

I did mention that no-one is trying to typecast anybody. I most
certainly do not expect DJs to limit themselves. Everybody plays a
little bit of everything, but there's always a ballpark or 2 a DJs
stay in. What I was saying is, a lot of DJs tend to just say
"everything" instead of identifying those ballparks. And it's a real
drag cuz I'm trying really hard to make some conversation with some DJ
I just met.  :)

About subgenres... I totally forgot how some people hate subgenres. It
wouldn't be so bad if ppl don't just pull new subgenres out of their
asses every other week.

Anyways, it's not so much about subgenres, but elements. As many
different styles you play, I'm sure that you tend to look for certain
elements or moods.

Every DJ plays a lot of different things, but rarely literally
EVERYTHING. It's all these different, specific things a DJ plays that
shape his/her sound. I hinestly don't think it's so unreasonable to
expect a DJ (who's not trying to blow me off) to summarize his/her
sound in a few words, rather than just a simple "everything".

It's like....

"Hey, what do u play?"

   "everything"

"Where do u play?"

   "everywhere"

"Well, um... nice meeting ya then."


- Jeff

References: <BAY8-F8AsdVgWUaOfXp000104aa@hotmail.com> <b7941d4c040716095774c63216@mail.gmail.com>
Date: Fri, 16 Jul 2004 10:21:26 -0700
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Priority: 3
X-MSMail-Priority: Normal
X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook Express 6.00.2800.1158
X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V6.00.2800.1165
Message-ID: <BAY9-DAV818cbKTrRVX000017a8@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 16 Jul 2004 17:20:16.0364 (UTC) FILETIME=[296012C0:01C46B59]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] HEY DJ: FUCK YOU!!!

Beyond hating subgenres too many people out there don't even know that the
subgenres *exist* So if you say *I play chicago house* you might get a *oh
you play house* er yeah sure kid... It's really just easier to say you play
house at first and if the person has a brain they'll ask *what kind?* =)

When people say they play everything I immediately ask *what's everything?*
then they usually rattle off a few genres. That's when you pop out the
*which do you play primarily?* and you get an answer and all is well and
good. I see the non-specific answers as the lazy answers which work for a
lot of lazy people that go to clubs and parties and don't shit about the
music anyway.

:: r ::

> I must have struck one of your nerves or something.  LOL
>
> I did mention that no-one is trying to typecast anybody. I most
> certainly do not expect DJs to limit themselves. Everybody plays a
> little bit of everything, but there's always a ballpark or 2 a DJs
> stay in. What I was saying is, a lot of DJs tend to just say
> "everything" instead of identifying those ballparks. And it's a real
> drag cuz I'm trying really hard to make some conversation with some DJ
> I just met.  :)
>
> About subgenres... I totally forgot how some people hate subgenres. It
> wouldn't be so bad if ppl don't just pull new subgenres out of their
> asses every other week.
>
> Anyways, it's not so much about subgenres, but elements. As many
> different styles you play, I'm sure that you tend to look for certain
> elements or moods.
>
> Every DJ plays a lot of different things, but rarely literally
> EVERYTHING. It's all these different, specific things a DJ plays that
> shape his/her sound. I hinestly don't think it's so unreasonable to
> expect a DJ (who's not trying to blow me off) to summarize his/her
> sound in a few words, rather than just a simple "everything".
>
> It's like....
>
> "Hey, what do u play?"
>
>    "everything"
>
> "Where do u play?"
>
>    "everywhere"
>
> "Well, um... nice meeting ya then."
>
>
> - Jeff

> > >
> > >Everything:
> > >
> > >I absolutely hate it when DJs say they play "everything". Do they just
> > >want to brag about how diverse they are? Or just can't make up their
> > >mind about what they play? There's only one type of DJs that play
> > >"everything" -- wedding DJs. If you don't really have a specific style
> > >you play most, you're either the kind of DJ who always play something
> > >because it's popular at the moment, or your sets are just
> > >incomprehandsibly incoherent.
> > >
> > >You gotta have a style (or 2, or 3) you play most. Why not just say
> > >it? No-one's trying to typecast you. There's no shame in what you
> > >play, right?
> > >
> > >House:
> > >
> > >I hate it when DJs say they play house. Not that I don't like house,
> > >but there are about 23 types of house: NY vocal house, west coast
> > >loungy house, banging chicago house, funky disco house, techy tribal
> > >house, deep dark progressive house..... A DJ saying he/she plays house
> > >is like a guiatrist saying he/she plays rock. It means ABSOLUTELY
> > >NOTHING.
> > >
> > >I asked you what you play right? Then please take your time to
> > >elaborate. If I care enough to ask, I probably care enough to know,
> > >and know enough to understand.

Ahhhahahahahaha narc.

Go chug a bottle of Robotussin Max strength. It's one of the strongest psy 
drugs available and it's legal. Problem is, 1 out of every 3 people 
doesn't have the correct stomache enzyme to break it down and they end up 
having really crappy trips. So it's only for the elite. Oh and don't mix 
with MDMA since it's the complete opposite (outer vs. inner).

MDMA takes you deep inside yourself
DXM takes you deep outside.

Oh and I don't do drugs, just know a lot about them.

Thread-Topic: [sfraves] Spirit of Raving: Q1: Best experience @ an Event...
Thread-Index: AcRrXgVJvSfLuHxBQo+yGYdLxlS2lgAANNYw
From: "Steve Osteen" <SOsteen@pinnaclesys.com>
To: "Karina" <karina@hyperreal.org>,
	<sfraves@hyperreal.org>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 16 Jul 2004 18:12:21.0061 (UTC) FILETIME=[6FD6FF50:01C46B60]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] Spirit of Raving: Q1: Best experience @ an Event...

Being at the first "Orgy" event at 550 back in 2000 and having the "red
room" transform into a feeling of togetherness and love I had ever felt
before (even though most people were complete strangers) while the music
instantly took on another meaning then what can be described in words. I
could feel the music roll up my spine and out through my chest. I could
feel each and every hair on my head, every beat of the house drum, the
smile on some strangers face, the way that girl in the corner was
outstreached on the couch, arching her back, rubbing up against me, and
instantly in that moment I understood what it was all about. What life
was all about. What love was all about. What I had been hiding from
myself. The person I now knew I could be. How that feeling wasn't just a
one moment chemical creation, but a prescription for how to live your
everyday life from that moment on.

Oh and I don't do drugs, just know a lot about them.

Steve Osteen
Progressive DJ/Producer
www.tussinspace.com

=20

On Friday, July 16, 2004, at 11:12  AM, Steve Osteen wrote:

> Being at the first "Orgy" event at 550 back in 2000 and having the "red
> room" transform into a feeling of togetherness and love I had ever felt
> before (even though most people were complete strangers) while the 
> music
> instantly took on another meaning then what can be described in words. 
> I
> could feel the music roll up my spine and out through my chest. I could
> feel each and every hair on my head, every beat of the house drum, the
> smile on some strangers face, the way that girl in the corner was
> outstreached on the couch, arching her back, rubbing up against me, and
> instantly in that moment I understood what it was all about. What life
> was all about. What love was all about. What I had been hiding from
> myself. The person I now knew I could be. How that feeling wasn't just 
> a
> one moment chemical creation, but a prescription for how to live your
> everyday life from that moment on.
>
> Oh and I don't do drugs, just know a lot about them.
>
> Steve Osteen
> Progressive DJ/Producer
> www.tussinspace.com
>

> >
> >
> > >
> > >I must have struck one of your nerves or something.  LOL
> > >
> > >I did mention that no-one is trying to typecast anybody. I most
> > >certainly do not expect DJs to limit themselves. Everybody plays a
> > >little bit of everything, but there's always a ballpark or 2 a DJs
> > >stay in. What I was saying is, a lot of DJs tend to just say
> > >"everything" instead of identifying those ballparks. And it's a real
> > >drag cuz I'm trying really hard to make some conversation with some DJ
> > >I just met.  :)
> > >
> > >About subgenres... I totally forgot how some people hate subgenres. It
> > >wouldn't be so bad if ppl don't just pull new subgenres out of their
> > >asses every other week.
> > >
> > >Anyways, it's not so much about subgenres, but elements. As many
> > >different styles you play, I'm sure that you tend to look for certain
> > >elements or moods.
> > >
> > >Every DJ plays a lot of different things, but rarely literally
> > >EVERYTHING. It's all these different, specific things a DJ plays that
> > >shape his/her sound. I hinestly don't think it's so unreasonable to
> > >expect a DJ (who's not trying to blow me off) to summarize his/her
> > >sound in a few words, rather than just a simple "everything".
> > >
> > >It's like....
> > >
> > >"Hey, what do u play?"
> > >
> > >    "everything"
> > >
> > >"Where do u play?"
> > >
> > >    "everywhere"
> > >
> > >"Well, um... nice meeting ya then."
> > >
> > >
> > >- Jeff
> > >
> > >

> > > > >From: g00fRiDER <goofrider@gmail.com>

> > > >
> > > >
> > > > >
> > > > >That was too funny.
> > > > >
> > > > >I want to take this chance to share one of my pet peeves.....
> > > > >
> > > > >Often when I meet DJs, I ask them what they play. There are 2 
>answers
> > > > >I dread the most: "everything" and "house".
> > > > >
> > > > >
> > > > >Everything:
> > > > >
> > > > >I absolutely hate it when DJs say they play "everything". Do they 
>just
> > > > >want to brag about how diverse they are? Or just can't make up 
>their
> > > > >mind about what they play? There's only one type of DJs that play
> > > > >"everything" -- wedding DJs. If you don't really have a specific 
>style
> > > > >you play most, you're either the kind of DJ who always play 
>something
> > > > >because it's popular at the moment, or your sets are just
> > > > >incomprehandsibly incoherent.
> > > > >
> > > > >You gotta have a style (or 2, or 3) you play most. Why not just say
> > > > >it? No-one's trying to typecast you. There's no shame in what you
> > > > >play, right?
> > > > >
> > > > >House:
> > > > >
> > > > >I hate it when DJs say they play house. Not that I don't like 
>house,
> > > > >but there are about 23 types of house: NY vocal house, west coast
> > > > >loungy house, banging chicago house, funky disco house, techy 
>tribal
> > > > >house, deep dark progressive house..... A DJ saying he/she plays 
>house
> > > > >is like a guiatrist saying he/she plays rock. It means ABSOLUTELY
> > > > >NOTHING.
> > > > >
> > > > >I asked you what you play right? Then please take your time to
> > > > >elaborate. If I care enough to ask, I probably care enough to know,
> > > > >and know enough to understand.
> > > > >
> > > > >

From: g00fRiDER <goofrider@gmail.com>
To: Karina <karina@hyperreal.org>
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <20040716105338.V90501@taz3.hyperreal.org>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
References: <20040716105338.V90501@taz3.hyperreal.org>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Spirit of Raving: Q1: Best experience @ an Event...

On Fri, 16 Jul 2004 10:55:00 -0700 (PDT), Karina <karina@hyperreal.org> wrote:
> What was your best experience/memory at an event/party?
> 

1. Ultra 2000 @ 21st St Beach (WMC 2000)

The very last Ultra on the beach (and my first). I hate massives (all
u ppl in SoCal I feel your pain), but there was something REALLY
SPECIAL about this event. The amount of enthuiasm was unbelievable.
Everybody knew EXACTLY who's the DJ that's playing -- these weren't
just your typical e-tards who go to parties for an excuse to get high,
they came from all over the country because they care about their
music, and they're serious about their music. They got so excited
everytime another DJ came on because u knew they've waited years to
see each and one of them (I know I did). I've never felt that kind of
excitement and togetherness since Back-In-Da-Day(TM), and most
certainly not in this scale (30,000 ppl).

It was the first time I exprienced the scene in a national/global
scale. I met ppl from all over the country and the world, and got a
slice of what the scene is like in their hometown. For the first the I
saw how far the scene had spread, how we're all connected, and how
much it motivated us. To me,  that event wasn't just a regular party,
it was purely a celebration of EDM itself.

I was rolling my bawls off (sorry guys), completely shirtless (I NEVER
take my shirt off in public, much less @ a party), dancing with a
complete random guy so closed together we might as well be making out
(and I absolutely hate dancing with guys in such close proximity @
clubs/parties). The sun was setting, reflecting off the beautiful
Altantic, while some 40 DJs I've wanted to see in YEARS played one
after another....  It was soooo beautiful... and I was soooo fucking
high..... It was liberating.

I was surrounded by 30,000 ppl who actually cared about our music. It
was the event that inspired me to start playing records. I decided I
shouldn't care if I never gonna get any good, I'm gonna do it just
because I love it. It's the first time I felt identified with the
scene (and I've been partying for years), that I realized my life and
this music is inseparable. I live and eat and breathe this shit and I
should just get over it and accept that this is where I belong. It was
almost like coming out of the closet.

-----------------

2. Sunrise on New Year's Eve 1999 @ Miami Beach (not a party)

I was completely sober all nite (thank u very much). After a night of
clubbing I rounded up about 20 strangers in my apt for afterhours. My
friends were rolling bawls but I was pretty much just socializing and
babysitting (had to deal with a case of serotonin syndrome for the
first time in my life). @ 6am or so a few of us decided to go down to
the beach, turned out thousands of ppl had the same idea. There were
so many ppl on the beach it was like a saturday afternoon. As the sun
began to rise above the horizon over the Atlantic, thousands of ppl
clapped and cheered "HAPPY NEW YEAR!!!"

Feeling the same excitement with our ppl is one thing, feeling it with
the general population is another. Bear in mind that all these ppl on
the beach are just regular ppl -- thousands of them, coming out to the
beach in the middle of the night, probably still drunk. It's just so
strangely beautiful that all these ppl (including myself) just
spontaneously came to the beach, and spontaneously we cheered, as the
new millienium begins (OK technically the millenium begins in 2001 but
what did we care then?)

It wasn't an event, it wasn't a party, it wasn't planned by anyone, it
just HAPPENED. It's a moment that I'll never forget in my life.

It was also symbolic to all the spontaneous afterhours adventures I
had in Miami, all the strangers I met and became best friends for one
nite, and I never quite knew how the evening/morning will end. This
one, however, is the most surprising and spectacular of them all.

---------------------------------------------------------------------

From sfraves-return-113960-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Fri Jul 16 19:42:00 2004

Message-ID: <20040716194156.20053.qmail@web51708.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Fri, 16 Jul 2004 12:41:56 -0700 (PDT)
From: matthew johnson <mpj_bay@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <A93F3CA0-D756-11D8-99B2-003065DA480A@earthlink.net>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Spirit of Raving: Q1: Best experience @ an Event...

Same...

One of many great experiences was the first party I
went to. 

I never liked the bar scene or drinking. I ran around
with a 2 foot mowhawk; pitting at punk shows and punk
rallies was my thing. 70's-80's. The punk thing got to
main stream for me and I hung low for a while. Cut my
hawk. Hiked around and rode my bike. Got back into
other things. One day my roomies asked me to go to a
rally in Sacramento on the capital step for a
demonstration, there were decks set up and DJ's
spinning. The music was called techno. I have old
records from back in the day and the funny thing is
that some techo sounded like house, some sounded like
drum and bass, some sounded like trace, breaks, acid
house, but back then it was called techno. As far as I
knew anyway.

After the demonstration my roomies said there was a
break-in warehouse party. Whatever the hell that
means. What is there to do in a warehouse? My
curiosity was peaked. I was into anything new and
different than the proposed norm. 

At this point in my life the only experience with
drugs was knowing that my hippy parents did so many
that I was turned off to the idea. You never want to
be like your parents right? When I was a tike mom told
me that if I ever wanted to try anything ever she
would get a hold of it and we could do it together.
"I've tried it all" she said. Boy that sounds like
fun. I had a few drinks over the years but didn't like
to drink. Clove and menthol cigs was all, what was I
thinking... Smoked reef a couple times but wasn't into
it back then.  

So we go to some dark ass ally in some sketch
neighborhood just outside of downtown sac. I start to
hear this low thump, thump, thump, thump, thump,
thump... We drive past, find a place to park. Walk up
to the warehouse, no line, no fee, no one even
watching the door. Walk through a tunnel of black
sheets and BAM sweat all over the place. Wicked music,
people dancing, some half naked. The back door of the
warehouse was open and a cool breeze was cooling off
the dance floor which was the entire warehouse. The
only lights were a strobe and a black light, oh yeh
and a smoke machine. No alcohol. I loved it. People
getting on dancing, having a great time and there was
no booze.   
Wicked energy, I started dancing. Felt like I was out
of my body. The night went on, sweating, dancing,
hands in the air. I didn't care about time, the night
could have gone on forever and I wouldn't have
noticed. After a while I thought it would be good to
find my roomies. I had my shirt off from dancing, the
warehouse was like a sauna. I found my roomies. We
started chatting. Both my roomies have been to parties
before so we we talked about how great it was. A
beautiful girl/woman came up to me. She had this thing
in her hand that looked like saturn. A metal ball with
rings around it. She told me to put my hand on top of
the ball, her hand was on the button holding this
contraption. I put my hand on the orb, she ran her
finger from my sweaty chest down to my belt line then
back up around my neck, leaned in and kissed me. The
orb created an electric link to whatever part of our
bodies touched and causes a little muscle spasm that
felt like a tiny euphoric massage. My whole face lit
up. I was in ecstasy. She walked away. The night
finally came to an end. We went home. The beutiful
thing was, I never saw the girl again. There was no
reason to exchange information because we were both
sharing a moment that was only appropriate for that
time in space. I did not do drugs and didn't need any.
The music, people, energy and visuals kept me high. I
WAS HOOKED. 

This community for me has always been part of a life
that proceeds the normal. We are one step ahead. We
think ahead. We act ahead. We love each other. We
create our beautiful surroundings. We know what is
right and wrong without authority. 

=)
~matt
aka dub

"I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and causes 
me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war, 
corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong 
its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-Abraham Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

  "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] Wild 94.9 Freestyle Explosion (for Osby and others)


OK here we go VERY embrassing confession by Yours truly!!

I use to rock every single track way back in the day on that list with the 
exception of the two groups near the end never heard of them. But yo why 
aint they repping the 408 with the Spanish fly boys, Orig (which my friends 
brother was the lead singer) and the second edition crew???

They should have mixed in some of the "Hip-House" sound as well.. ya'll know 
what im talking about those old enough to remember way back then.. Let me 
paint you a lil picture of the hip house sound. Cross Color Jeans, Pants 
possible worn backwards,Afro-centric gear (I.E carribean and african flag 
colors,African Medallions etc) and for the music you had DJ Lee "Get busy" 
Kwami (Forget his songs??) DJ Fast Eddie"yo,yo get funky", Cut it up Def 
records.. You had DJ Cameron Paul the first Producer the I had been exposed 
to that could sample like a mutha fucka..

awww memories of my youth in the late eighties/early 90's

PS: Funny thing is I still hear people playing those jams as if they were 
new and it was the thing to do.. It's like HELLO that track came out in like 
1987!!! How un-progressive is that!!  =D


M

Subject: [sfraves] SODA tomorrow night (Sat 7.17)

Thought some of y'all might be interested... don't forget to catch Hector
with Doc Martin tonight @ Club Six!


SODA

featuring special guest Hector Moralez (Robsoul)
plus residents The Fresh Blend (IRIS, Trouble)
and Philip Sherburne (flavorpill, Trouble)

Tomorrow Soda goes acid with Hector Moralez. Hector is one of the mainstays
of Paris' Robsoul Recordings label, home of the hottest acid house in a
decade, and as Fries & Bridges, his duo with Robsoul founder Phil Weeks,
Hector has recorded for labels like Music for Freaks, Primal, and Brique
Rouge. Expect some seriously minimal temptation (as his new track with Chris
Carrier is titled -- hear it at http://www.robsoulrecordings.com/rb24.html)
and maximal squelch.

SODA residents The Fresh Blend and Philip Sherburne keep it locked, loaded
and lubed with a couple of crates full of the finest minimal techno,
microhouse, and electro-techno you'll hear in the Bay Area. If you're a fan
of labels like Ghostly, Kompakt, Perlon, Playhouse, and Output, you won't
want to miss it.

Saturday, July 17
Rx Gallery (132 Eddy St @ Mason)
9pm-2am
$6

www.robsoulrecordings.com
www.freshblend.com
www.philipsherburne.com
www.rxgallery.com

philip sherburne
full sentences on demand

a blog: http://www.philipsherburne.com

subscribe: http://www.earplug.cc

Subject: Re: [sfraves] HEY DJ: FUCK YOU!!!

I'd rather deal with an "everything" deejay than the ones who make up 
their own genres on the spot, "I play progressive hard trip turntablist 
West Coast trance hop." If I can't tell when someone is being 
pretentious or a goofball, that's never good.


goofrider@gmail.com wrote:

>That was too funny.
>
>I want to take this chance to share one of my pet peeves.....
>
>Often when I meet DJs, I ask them what they play. There are 2 answers
>I dread the most: "everything" and "house".
>
>
>Everything:
>
>I absolutely hate it when DJs say they play "everything". Do they just
>want to brag about how diverse they are? Or just can't make up their
>mind about what they play? There's only one type of DJs that play
>"everything" -- wedding DJs. If you don't really have a specific style
>you play most, you're either the kind of DJ who always play something
>because it's popular at the moment, or your sets are just
>incomprehandsibly incoherent.
>
>You gotta have a style (or 2, or 3) you play most. Why not just say
>it? No-one's trying to typecast you. There's no shame in what you
>play, right?
>
>House:
>
>I hate it when DJs say they play house. Not that I don't like house,
>but there are about 23 types of house: NY vocal house, west coast
>loungy house, banging chicago house, funky disco house, techy tribal
>house, deep dark progressive house..... A DJ saying he/she plays house
>is like a guiatrist saying he/she plays rock. It means ABSOLUTELY
>NOTHING.
>
>I asked you what you play right? Then please take your time to
>elaborate. If I care enough to ask, I probably care enough to know,
>and know enough to understand.
>
>
>Pz y'all,
>
>- Jeff
>
>---------------------------------------------------------------------
>To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
>For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org
>
>  
>

In-Reply-To: <b7941d4c04071616017777bd86@mail.gmail.com>
User-Agent: Mutt/1.4i
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] WMC suckage

quoth g00fRiDER:
> Frankly WMC sucks big cocks nowadays.

You're entitled to your opinion, but as I recall this year kicked some
serious ass. The only thing that sucked was that there were too many
great things to do at any one time (day or night). It was only my first
year, but most of the veterans I spoke with said it was the best time
they'd had down there in a while.

I'm definitely going back next year. If it affords me the opportunity to
see Richie Hawtin, Derrick Carter, Matthew Dear, Luomo, Michael Mayer,
Telefon Tel Aviv, Mr. Scruff, Smith & Selway, Phil Kieran, Mistress
Barbara, Asad Rizvi, Mazi, Tyler Stadius, and too many other incredible
DJs and artists to name, *and* I get to bond with friends and meet new
people... I'd say it's worth having to hang out in South Beach with a
bunch of assholes for a weekend.

So did you go, or are you just talking out of your ass?

Toodles,
-- 
shawn allen
  mailto://shawn@alterior.net
  phone://+1.415.577.3961
  http://alterior.net
  aim://shawnpallen

References: <BAY22-F24bBTlLwYxEb0001b44a@hotmail.com> <b7941d4c04071616017777bd86@mail.gmail.com> <20040717015319.GM6823@hubble>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] WMC suckage

I went 2000-2002 (3 yrs). I had a HORRIBLE time in 2002 though
(relative to previous years).

The consensus I got from my friends who went this year (or friends who
live there) is that it's somewhat better than 2003, but still not as
good as a few years back. Enthuaism is steadily declining and replaced
with commercialism. For someone who hasn't been to WMC, by all means
go. But I just don't feel like I have to go every year now. The bigger
parties is getting outrageously expensive ($60 each club, if you try
to hit 3 big clubs in one night that's almost $200 a night, not
counting waiting in line for each), and they're becoming a magnet for
the star-gazed DJ worshipping pimps-&-hos e-tards, which makes it as
aggravating to attend as 1015 or Ruby Skye. But if I disregard the big
parties (and most of them should be avoided anyways) and just consider
the smaller parties and afternoon pool parties, WMC is full of
suprises and lots of new msuic that hasn't been played anywhere else,
and you can indeed have a fabulous time still.

BTW, the assholes in SoBe u spoke of, there weren't as many of them in
previous years. 2000 was all love for me, I can only imagine how nice
1998/1999 was.

I'd be the last guy who hang on to the good ol' days like Britney
holding onto her allerged cherry. I know things gets commercialized
and exploited all the time. The unfortunate thing is that Miami is
particular known to be a place for selling out. So I'm not very
optimistic about the viability of WMC in the long term. A west coast
alternative is very attractive, not only that it's much closer for
most of us, having something similiar in SF probably won't get
exploited as rapidly as in Miami.

So I take it back. WMC doesn't quite suck. It'll probly suck if you
follow the herd to all the big parties and try to catch all the big
names, but if you're looking to sit by the pool all afternoon and kick
it and have a drink with all your fellow DJs for an entire week,
you'll be in heaven.

WMC is still a unique exprience, there's no other time or place in US
where u see thousands of DJs hanging out on the street, and running
into famous DJs at every bar and resturant and get to say hi and chat
with them like u'r old friends.

But don;t say I didn't warn u, that novelty wears of after your 2nd or
3rd year.  :)

So, go again. Enjoy it. Who cares what I said?  :)  

Love, 

- Jeff

Subject: [sfraves] Comback for the ppl who cut in line

This one is my favorite line to use on ppl who try to cut in line in
front of me, I forgot who/where I got it from (it was years ago), but
I find it indispensible. If it's not new to you, just pretend it is. 
:)


"Hey, I probably don't mind letting you go ahead of me personally, but
I think you might want to ask the rest of the ppl behind me if they
do."

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] WMC suckage

The last few years I've gone to WMC it's been a great time.  So it's changed
since it started (everything does), and gotten bigger...there are great
parties all over the place, great DJs, and a lot of energy everywhere.  You
have everything from a super massive event to major club one offs to tight
little underground communities getting together on an outdoor patio with
good beats.  Sure there's plenty of South Beach cheese, but guess what?
It's South Beach.  If you can't figure out how to have a good time and find
what you want out there, well you're jaded beyond repair...

I heard more great music out there in one week than in all the months since
I got back.  And there's no vibe like 200 heads into exactly the music you
are that are all djs/producers/promoters that know what up, and someone is
jacking it behind the decks, and EVERYBODY appreciates to the fullest
because they know inside and out what it takes to be that good...

-Andrew

=09

Well I went to the WMC this year and ROAR! had both a booth and we were =
on a
couple panels. I have mixed reviews. The conference itself needs more =
focus,
and the conference panelists need to show up. The parties are ok, but
overall its waaay to expensive. Pick one party a night, and its =
afordable,
and don't miss the free promo parties during the day by various =
magazines
and record labels.

About Ultra...i dunno. waaay too expensive imho, but you can see just =
about
every dj in the world in one event.

--
Eric Tomasi, Managing Director
www.roargroup.org

ps: ROAR! 3, Sept. 18, at the US Capitol.

> > > >
> > > >I absolutely hate it when DJs say they play "everything". Do they
just
> > > >want to brag about how diverse they are? Or just can't make up =
their
> > > >mind about what they play? There's only one type of DJs that play
> > > >"everything" -- wedding DJs. If you don't really have a specific
style
> > > >you play most, you're either the kind of DJ who always play =
something
> > > >because it's popular at the moment, or your sets are just
> > > >incomprehandsibly incoherent.
> > > >
> > > >You gotta have a style (or 2, or 3) you play most. Why not just =
say
> > > >it? No-one's trying to typecast you. There's no shame in what you
> > > >play, right?
> > > >
> > > >House:
> > > >
> > > >I hate it when DJs say they play house. Not that I don't like =
house,
> > > >but there are about 23 types of house: NY vocal house, west coast
> > > >loungy house, banging chicago house, funky disco house, techy =
tribal
> > > >house, deep dark progressive house..... A DJ saying he/she plays
house
> > > >is like a guiatrist saying he/she plays rock. It means ABSOLUTELY
> > > >NOTHING.

From: Starchild <sfdreamer@earthlink.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Message-Id: <FF89AC1E-D918-11D8-8B73-003065DA480A@earthlink.net>

Subject: [sfraves] (NRR) There are 14 candidates running for president of the United States, not 2

--Apple-Mail-4-219890065
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Type: text/plain;
	delsp=yes;
	charset=US-ASCII;
	format=flowed

	According to most mainstream media outlets, there are only two  
candidates running for U.S. president this year -- George Bush and John  
Kerry. If you're lucky, they might tell you that Ralph Nader is also  
running (often incorrectly describing him as the Green Party's  
candidate), and if you're even luckier, they may acknowledge that  
Michael Badnarik, David Cobb and Michael Peroutka are running too.

	Beyond that, there is a virtual media blackout. But in fact there are  
not 2, 3, 4, or 6, but 14 candidates running for president of the  
United States this year! (See list below.) Unfortunately you will not  
see most of them on your ballot because of the restrictive ballot  
access laws that have been established by Democrats and Republicans.  
However Michael Badnarik, David Cobb, Ralph Nader and Michael Peroutka  
are all expected to be on a sufficient number of state ballots that if  
enough people voted for them, they could win a majority of votes in the  
Electoral College and become president.

	Of course with this media blackout, and the resulting low poll numbers  
that give the established parties an excuse to keep them out of the  
major presidential debates, they hardly stand a chance. That's not the  
way elections should be held in a free country. Voters deserve to know  
who all the candidates are, and to have the opportunity to hear their  
ideas and decide for themselves who would make the best president.

	We wouldn't like it if we only had two choices of where to work, what  
kind of car to buy, where to go to school, or what to do this weekend.  
So why, when it comes to something as important as electing a  
president, do we accept the media telling us the news as if there were  
only two people we should consider voting for?

	Let's demand that at least the 6 candidates theoretically able to win  
the election -- Badnarik, Bush, Cobb, Kerry, Nader and Peroutka -- be  
given equal media coverage and allowed into the televised presidential  
debates.

	Please take a few moments to write a letter to the editor (choose your  
own paper, or write the San Francisco Chronicle at  
letters@sfchronicle.com). I would ask you to write to the Commission on  
Presidential Debates, but they are fully aware that people are upset  
about this and so they make it difficult for even the media to get in  
touch with them, let alone the general public! (See  
http://www.debates.org/mediacenter/index.html.)

	Come September, if Bush and Kerry's cronies are still shutting the  
other candidates out, please join a protest at the debate location  
nearest you:

First presidential debate:
Thursday, September 30
University of Miami
Coral Gables, FL

Vice presidential debate:
Tuesday, October 5
Case Western Reserve University
Cleveland, OH

Second presidential debate:
Friday, October 8
Washington University
St. Louis, MO

Third presidential debate:
Wednesday, October 13
Arizona State University
Tempe, AZ

	If you care about democracy and freedom in the United States, please  
forward this email to your friends and to other lists. Finally, be sure  
to sign these petition for fair and open debates:

http://www.opendebates.org/yourrole/petition/
http://www.debatethis.org/tvalert.html
http://www.electionreform.org/ERMain/getinvolved/petition/petition05.asp
http://www.e-thepeople.org/petition/11647/view

For liberty,
				<<< Starchild >>>


 From a news story in 2000 -- the protests should be much bigger and  
louder this time around!

Protesters demand open presidential debates
October  2, 2000
Web posted at:  9:22 AM EDT (1322 GMT)

ATLANTA (CNN) -- Chanting and waving signs, a group of about 100  
demonstrators marched in front of CNN Center Sunday, calling on the  
network to host open debates among several third-party presidential  
candidates. "You can get public money to help your campaign, but you  
can't get access  to the public airwaves in a debate," shouted a  
Libertarian Party supporter through a megaphone.

The protesters represented the Green Party, the Natural Law Party, the   
Reform Party and the International Socialist Organization, among other  
groups.  One member of the ISO said demonstrators had collected 85,000  
signatures on a  petition they hoped to deliver to CNN...


(from  
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ 
List_of_candidates_in_the_U.S._presidential_election%2C_2004)

List of candidates in the U.S. presidential election, 2004

Candidates in the U.S. presidential election, 2004 , who are expected  
to be on the ballot in enough states to theoretically win a majority in  
the Electoral College are marked in bold . Candidates who are known to  
have withdrawn from the race, suspended their presidential campaign, or  
failed to earn their party's nomination are marked in italics.

Gene Amondson (Prohibition; Leroy Pletten, vice-president)
Michael Badnarik (Libertarian; Richard Campagna, vice-president)
George W. Bush (Republican)
Roger Calero (Socialist Workers; Arrin Hawkins, vice-president)
Walt Brown (Socialist; Mary Alice Herbert, vice-president)
David Cobb (Green; Pat LaMarche, vice-president)
Earl F. Dodge (Prohibition; Howard Lydick, vice-president)
John Kerry (Democrat)
Charles Jay (Personal Choice; Marilyn Chambers, vice-president)
Ralph Nader (independent, Reform ; Peter Camejo, vice-president)
John Parker (Workers World ; Teresa Gutierrez, vice-president)
Michael Peroutka (Constitution; Chuck Baldwin, vice-president)
Diane Templin (American; Al Moore, vice-president)
Bill Van Auken (Socialist Equality; Jim Lawrence, vice-president)

Blake Ashby (Republican)
Richard Bosa (Republican)
Carol Moseley Braun (Democratic)
John Buchanan (Republican)
Edie Bukewihge (Republican)
Michael Callis (Republican)
Peter Camejo (Green)
Wesley Clark (Democratic)
Howard Dean (Democratic)
John Edwards (Democratic)
Richard Gephardt (Democratic)
Paul Glover (Green)
Bob Graham (Democratic)
Robert Haines (Republican)
Millie Howard (Republican)
Donnie Kennedy (Republican)
Dennis Kucinich (Democratic)
Lyndon LaRouche (Democratic)
Tom Laughlin (Republican)
Joe Lieberman (Democratic)
Yehanna Malone (Republican)
Kent Mesplay (Green)
Carol Miller (Green)
Robert Mills (Republican)
Gary Nolan (Libertarian)
John Rigazio (Republican)
Aaron Russo (Libertarian)
Lorna Salzman (Green)
Al Sharpton (Democratic)
Ken Stremsky (Republican)
Bill Wyatt (Republican)

                                *       *       *

> > yah. she's talking about this kind of DJing:
> >
> > http://www.marketingfordjs.com
