> > weddings, frat parties, corporate events, bar mitzvahs, etc.; the type
> > of DJs they're talking to in catalogs when they say "don't miss
> > another gig because you don't have karaoke!"
> 
> Oh yeah, another thing. I always find it kinda amusing that
> wedding/party DJs can just call themselves  __DJs__ with a str8 face,
> like they were real DJs. They never volunteer the "wedding" part.  Is
> it like strippers calling themselves dancers?
> 
> But then, there are turntablists who thinks DJs who can't scratch are
> just cueing records.
> 
> Personally, I prefer to say that "I play records". Kinda like "I play
> guitar" or "I play piano". It implies that I'm doing something musical
> with records, rather than just cueing and beatmatching.

OK I missed a lot of this because gmail filed it as one thing, I had
no idea it was still going, etc., anyway, two things.

first is that once upon a time I actually auditioned for a job as a
strip club DJ. I don't know if audition is really the word, though. it
was the second time I'd ever been in a strip club in my life. it was a
club in the middle of nowhere, the DJ's job was to play whatever CD
the stripper handed him and do a spiel in between about how the guys
in the club should give the girls lots of money. it was basically the
same thing as the weddings/corporate events/bar mitzvahs thing (bad),
except with lots of naked ladies (good -- well, mostly good, anyway)
and a really weird kind of low-rent backcountry scumbag vibe (very
bad).

anyway. that was quite an experience. I didn't so much as audition as
show up and sit around for a while enjoying the free beer and chatting
with the strippers. but the beer was American and the strippers were a
mixed bunch. there were snowboarders, and there were hoes. that's
basically what it came down to, actually, snowboaders and hoes. some
were cool and some were lame. some were hot and some were dooky. but a
job that consisted of nothing more than going "look at those
bazongas!" and playing Kid Rock didn't really appeal to me.

anyway the second thing is that I think assuming that other people
will load the term "DJ" with the same extended meanings that ravers,
promoters, producers, designers, dancers, and DJs will is a bit like
expecting everybody you meet to speak Azerbaijani or something. DJs
are artists in this world, but we have a special world, and not
everybody outside it even knows that it exists.


--

	OK, let me ask you a couple questions...

	Did you vote for an alternative party in the last election? And how do  
you plan to vote for Congress, State Assembly, etc., in the upcoming  
election?

	If you've voted for alternative candidates in the past, or if you plan  
to vote Libertarian, Green, or what-not on the rest of your ballot  
outside of the presidential race this November, that gives your words  
below some real weight.

	But if you have regularly voted for Democrats in the past, and plan to  
keep doing so in the future, then let's not pretend like it's such a  
huge deal that people vote for Kerry this time around when your actions  
(which speak louder than words) are saying this election is just like  
every other election.

Peace, love & liberty,
					<<< Starchild >>>

P.S. - The bold, italicized and otherwise altered text didn't come  
through in my original email, resulting in part of what I quoted from  
the website listing the candidates not making much sense. Here is a  
revised version of my letter in which I also dropped the former  
candidates from the list, since it just makes the email longer and  
confuses people, and made a couple other minor corrections.

Yours in liberty,
                                         <<< Starchild >>>


On Sunday, July 18, 2004, at 06:57  PM, Starchild wrote (CORRECTED  
VERSION):

> There are 14 candidates running for president of the United States,  
> not 2!
>
> 	According to most mainstream media outlets, there are only two  
> candidates running for U.S. president this year -- George Bush and  
> John Kerry. If you're lucky, they might tell you that Ralph Nader is  
> also running (often incorrectly describing him as the Green Party's  
> candidate), and if you're even luckier, they may acknowledge that  
> Michael Badnarik, David Cobb and Michael Peroutka are running too.
>
> 	Beyond that, there is a virtual media blackout. But in fact there are  
> not 2, 3, 4, or 6, but 14 candidates running for president of the  
> United States this year! (See list below.) Unfortunately you will not  
> see most of them on your ballot because of the restrictive ballot  
> access laws that have been established by Democrats and Republicans.  
> However Michael Badnarik, David Cobb, Ralph Nader and Michael Peroutka  
> are all expected to be on a sufficient number of state ballots that if  
> enough people voted for them, they could win a majority of votes in  
> the Electoral College and become president.
>
> 	Of course with this media blackout, and the resulting low poll  
> numbers that give the establishment parties an excuse to keep them out  
> of the nationally televised presidential debates, they hardly stand a  
> chance. That's not the way elections should be held in a free country.  
> Voters deserve to know who all the candidates are, and to have the  
> opportunity to hear their ideas and decide for themselves who would  
> make the best president.
>
> 	We wouldn't like it if we only had two choices of where to work, what  
> kind of car to buy, where to go to school, or what to do this weekend.  
> So why, when it comes to something as important as electing a  
> president, do we accept the media telling us the news as if there were  
> only two people we should consider voting for?
>
> 	Let's demand that at least the 6 candidates theoretically able to win  
> the election -- Badnarik, Bush, Cobb, Kerry, Nader and Peroutka -- be  
> given equal media coverage and allowed into all presidential debates.
>
> 	Please take a few moments to write a letter to the editor (choose  
> your own paper, or write the San Francisco Chronicle at  
> letters@sfchronicle.com). I would ask you to write to the Commission  
> on Presidential Debates, but they are fully aware that people are  
> upset about this and so they make it difficult for even the media to  
> get in touch with them, let alone the general public! (See  
> http://www.debates.org/mediacenter/index.html.)
>
> 	Come September, if Bush and Kerry's cronies are still shutting the  
> other candidates out, please join a protest at the debate location  
> nearest you:
>
> First presidential debate:
> Thursday, September 30
> University of Miami
> Coral Gables, FL
>
> Vice presidential debate:
> Tuesday, October 5
> Case Western Reserve University
> Cleveland, OH
>

> Protesters demand open presidential debates
> October  2, 2000
> Web posted at:  9:22 AM EDT (1322 GMT)
>
> ATLANTA (CNN) -- Chanting and waving signs, a group of about 100  
> demonstrators marched in front of CNN Center Sunday, calling on the  
> network to host open debates among several third-party presidential  
> candidates. "You can get public money to help your campaign, but you  
> can't get access  to the public airwaves in a debate," shouted a  
> Libertarian Party supporter through a megaphone.
>
> The protesters represented the Green Party, the Natural Law Party, the  
>  Reform Party and the International Socialist Organization, among  
> other groups.  One member of the ISO said demonstrators had collected  
> 85,000 signatures on a  petition they hoped to deliver to CNN...
>
>

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Meat hook dangling craze mystifies

Sunday, July 18, 2004 Posted: 6:54 PM EDT (2254 GMT)

MIAMI, Florida (Reuters) -- Law enforcement officials in the
Florida Keys are mystified by a bizarre new pastime -- young
people dangling themselves from meat hooks on a popular sandbar.

A U.S. Coast Guard spokeswoman said on Sunday that the Monroe
County sheriff's office and Coast Guard were called on July 12
to the sandbar off Whale Harbor in Islamorada where locals say
wild behavior is becoming a tradition.

They found that five young people had erected a bamboo tripod
and hung meat hooks from it. A young woman, her feet brushing
the surface of the shallow water, dangled from the frame, hooks
embedded firmly in her shoulders.

According to a Coast Guard video, she did not seem to mind the hooks.

Lt. Tom Brazil of the Coast Guard told the Key West Citizen
newspaper that a young man, who also had hooks embedded in his
heavily pierced and tattooed skin, assured him the group was
"just enjoying the afternoon."

A Coast Guard spokeswoman in Miami said the group had clearly
done this before and intended to post photos of themselves on
a Web site dedicated to "body modification" -- the ritualistic
piercing of the body.

"It looked like a daily routine for them," she said, adding
that the hooks had been inserted in the skin in a professional
manner and had drawn very little blood."

"As long as they weren't creating any kind of ruckus or riot
within a crowd they really weren't breaking any laws."

The Coast Guard passed the video on to federal justice authorities but no 
further action will be taken.



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

"I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and causes 
me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war, 
corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong 
its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-Abraham Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

  "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

From: Peter Rothman <dangrsmind@yahoo.com>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (NRR) There are 14 candidates running for president of the United States, not 2

I'm hoping that your comment about riots being "fun"
was a joke.  

Riots generally do the most harm to individual small
business owners and communities who have nothing to do
with the issue at hand, and historically they damage
poor urban communities the most.  Wealthy real estate
investors in San Francisco would like nothing better
than to have riots drive more poor and middle class
families from the city.

Riots have little real impact on the issues that
trigger them.  The riots after the Rodney King trial
did nothing (IMO) to end racism of police brutality. 
Riots in San Francisco won't change the outcome of a
presidential election.

The truth is that an angry mob is still an angry mob
even if they are angry about racism, war and poverty. 
And nothing good ever comes from anger.  Please
consider this before going out and burning police cars
or whatever...

Regards,

Peter

Subject: [sfraves] Sat Night... kinda Rhythm Method & HOOGER MOOOGER... BOOGER

I didn't really need it 4 this math lesson this week, but hey.. it's extra credit point.. la la la... then spent the late morning 2 early evening ummmmmm... doin' a scavenger hunt for my Homeboy's birthday... it was actually pretty interesting & fuckinn' Looong... yeah...

So around like 8:30-9ish PM... I went over 2 Shadow Lounge 2 C who was hangin' out & most of the Rhythm Method Crew was there setting up & talked w/ Senor Bicolus & Mr E$KR...   YAY!!  I mean.. I did wanna stay there 4 some of the Jungle Groovy, but I didn't have $10, but I did want them 2 know they had atleast a portion of my support of the night.. so it was good seein' a few Jungle Homies!

Then I walked over 2 Mr Wham Bam's pad & we kicked it 4 a few... I mean seriously.. when Bam & I get 2gether.. there's alwaaaays somethig 2 talk about w/ him & it's Groovy!!  YAY!!

Finally got 2 my actual set Destination 4 the night.. Hooger Mooger.. OK.. Hello 2Day.. it was soooooooo much fuckin' fun!!!  LoL

OK.. so like Li was on the decks when i got there.. YAAAAAY.. Breakbeats.. YUM!!  Then Andy get's on & ok.. so they did a tag set, ya know!  LoL.. I did hear alot Bad Ass songs in their set.. LoL.. Andy busted like these 80 remix tracks... ummmmm... the only 1 that comes 2 my mind right now is "Sunglasses @ Night",, but there was like 2 more I think.. LoL.. all in all, it was fun!  There was some 4x4 bleep bleep bleep bloop kinda songs that were funny well... yeah funny... I mean.. the whole set kinda went all over the Breakbeats genres & I liked it alot!! It was fun 2 dance 2!  I mean.. I totally Love when Andy & Li tag 'cause their sets always depict some sort of mood... well in my opinion anyway.. but Sat night was all about Cheesey fun =)

OK.. but the main reason that i wanted 2 go was 'cause Katharsis was spinning... I mean.. Heeeeeeello 2Day.. I Love this Dude's sets!  So he got there an hour b4 he played.. so we preety much had time 2 catch up...  Awesome!  LoL.. Then when he went on.. he started out really kinda mellow w/ the Techno tunes... got really hard mid set.. ok.. then it sounded like he was playing some fucked up salsa tech house or something 'cause like well.. that what that song sounded like, la la la... LoL.. & these Russian couple were on the dance floor the whole time groovin.. it was fun!!!  I mean.. LoL>.. I totally yelled hella time during this set.. Loved it!!

The turn out was pretty good... ummmmmm... if U know like Chris & Heather... they were there.. not 2 much family oh oh oh.. Monchichi showed up also...

OK... Li (my Guru) Thank U soooooooooo much 4 the Ride home & the Awesome fuckin' conversations throughout the night!! Very inspirational. seriously!!

Andy... it was fun hangin' w/ U ofcourse my dear Bog Bro... it was Groovy getting nostalgic oh oh oh & talkin' about drive in movies & movies...

But yeah.. it was a Good night... I dunno who's spinning next one... but I bet it's gonna be hell fun!! SO GO!!!




Take Care,

From sfraves-return-114019-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Mon Jul 19 19:23:46 2004

Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org

Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 57706 invoked from network); 19 Jul 2004 19:23:45 -0000
Date: Mon, 19 Jul 2004 12:23:42 -0700
From: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Message-ID: <20040719192342.GE567@hubble>
Mail-Followup-To: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>,
	sfraves@hyperreal.org
References: <20040719172700.89508.qmail@web50310.mail.yahoo.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Disposition: inline
In-Reply-To: <20040719172700.89508.qmail@web50310.mail.yahoo.com>
User-Agent: Mutt/1.4i
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] looking for techno in SF...

quoth Monikat:
> i haven't been on this list in a while so i'm a little behind on
> what's going on these days, but if there's any regular minimal techno,
> or dare i say it, detroit techno or kompakt style stuff going on
> please please pass the word.

I know of only two regular techno events in SF, and they're both on the
third Saturday of every month:

Hugger-Mugger at Lit
<http://tech-on.com/huggermugger.html>

SODA at the Rx Lounge
<http://rxgallery.com/>

Hugger-Mugger is all about the tougher stuff, whereas SODA features
deeper (and yes, Kompakt-style) minimal techno and tech-house.

> oh, and is anyone playing booty house or ghetto tech around here these
> days?

That would be AndyW. He's a resident at Hugger-Mugger.

And I'll be sending out a BSP later today, but you can catch some of the
deeper minimal techno and house tonight, on my weekly Monday night
broadcast from 6-8pm:

<http://throwdown.com/throwdown/live/in_house_records.asp>

And tomorrow morning I'll be on KZSU playing a more diverse mix of
techno and tech-house on J.C.'s Epiphany of Sound from 9-11am:

<http://kzsulive.stanford.edu/>

Re: techno in SF in general...

I don't get out much, but I blame that squarely on a lack of good techno
events here in the bay area. Regular club events are few and far
between, and what passes for "techno" at most undergrounds is usually
just techy trance or watered-down drum trax. Most of the hard techno is
harsh and undanceable. Detroit techno and electro are completely
underrepresented, and anything from Cologne is, well, verboten.

I may just not be "clued in" to what's going on--and if that's the case,
somebody PLEASE point me in the right direction--but it appears to me
that there's just very little appreciation for good techno in SF. We
export all our good music... take the Context label, for example. You've
got Sutekh, Kit Clayton, and Dave Aju producing mind-blowing shit, yet
they rarely play locally and the label is distributed by Kompakt (a
German uber-label and distro). Almost all of the great techno produced
here in the bay area is released on European labels (Mille Plateaux,
Force Inc., Circus Company, ~scape, etc.), and most of it doesn't reach
local shops (unless you can bear shopping for vinyl at Amoeba).

Sutekh actually DJ'd in SF a couple of weeks back, at the Luna Lounge.
It was a great night, with a really diverse crowd that danced
indiscriminantly to an eclectic mix of glitchy tech-house and quirky
minimal techno. But unless promoters and club owners start taking some
chances with "new" music, we won't have anything like that regularly.

Of course I'm biased, because that's what I'm into. But I'd like to see
a more substantive debate over this issue than "techno sucks"... so does
anyone else have something to add?

-- 
shawn allen
  mailto://shawn@alterior.net
  phone://+1.415.577.3961
  http://alterior.net
  aim://shawnpallen

Subject: Re: [sfraves] looking for techno in SF...

Well I think of the reasons you don't see tekno in the area that much is 
because the major forces that use to do tekno parties have moved on. Or are 
so Ultra UG and elite that you rarely hear about them. Crews that use to do 
good tekno/music parties. Pro-soy any of you guys remember them?? Ernie 
Deaks.. The man the legend!! the guy that opened my eyes to tekno one night 
VERY long ago at the stevenson alley. Harmony Crew.. Can you say Minor,Minor 
and and old time friend Trent.. Those guys also influenced my views on 
tekno.. at one point in time Trent was one of the best Tekno DJ's in the 
area (IMHO) Friends and Family Well they still do parties but you got to be 
somewhat "Elite" status to be able to attend. And there lineups vary so much 
that you can't really call it a tekno party but they rarely do events 
anymore. Cloud Factory Known for Good tekno, house and a bag of tricks. Then 
you had the all tekno crew of Gateway with the house DJ at the end I believe 
it was always Sean Murray if im not mistaken?

And you have other groups as well that most of the people are still around 
here and there but for the most part. Most of the crews in question I named 
have moved on from doing parties and the younger new skewl kids that are 
doing all the events Didn't even go to parties back then, and if they did it 
wasn't in the bay area so they don't know the "Deaks" the "Trents" of the 
past all they know is "Mars, Mystere, Dyloot, Tom slick" etc..

Now I know most of you techno snobs are going to gasp at this next comment 
but I Never liked the stuff that sutekh and the likes of the others in that 
type of sound produce.. if it is that same minimal glitchy noisy type of 
techno. A person like myself that has "Self diagonosed" ADD finds it to be 
UN-dance floor friendly and boring. Yes I know they push gear past it 
designed limits and are brilliant producers, but there music is still 
boring.. To myself and I would think to most promoters.

Another opinion is that to me people either love or hate techno.. it is one 
of those types of sounds rarely do you get use to it.. I think you like 
techno from the first time you hear it or it sucks.. and unfortunately I 
think for most it is the ladder.. And that could be because of it's hard 
metallic sound or repetative abrassivness I dunno.. but to me those are all 
the reasons why I love it.


But yes boys and girls there was a time in SF when if you attended an UG 
party in SF you were most likely going to get hammered with about half the 
night of blistering techno.

Just my views as I sit back and watch the scene go through it's many 
phases...

Macadio


.
>
>I may just not be "clued in" to what's going on--and if that's the case,
>somebody PLEASE point me in the right direction--but it appears to me
>that there's just very little appreciation for good techno in SF. We
>export all our good music... take the Context label, for example. You've
>got Sutekh, Kit Clayton, and Dave Aju producing mind-blowing shit, yet
>they rarely play locally and the label is distributed by Kompakt (a
>German uber-label and distro). Almost all of the great techno produced
>here in the bay area is released on European labels (Mille Plateaux,
>Force Inc., Circus Company, ~scape, etc.), and most of it doesn't reach
>local shops (unless you can bear shopping for vinyl at Amoeba).
>
>Sutekh actually DJ'd in SF a couple of weeks back, at the Luna Lounge.
>It was a great night, with a really diverse crowd that danced
>indiscriminantly to an eclectic mix of glitchy tech-house and quirky
>minimal techno. But unless promoters and club owners start taking some
>chances with "new" music, we won't have anything like that regularly.
>
>Of course I'm biased, because that's what I'm into. But I'd like to see
>a more substantive debate over this issue than "techno sucks"... so does
>anyone else have something to add?
>
>--
>shawn allen

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: Shazbot on An Epiphany Of Sound tomorrow, 9a-11a PST

Hey folks,
I wanted to make sure that everyone tunes in tomorrow to check out
Shazbot.  In his 4 years as a vinyl collector, Shazbot (Shawn Allen) has
dabbled in a variety of musical styles, from drum and bass and 2-step to
garage and deep house; from west-coast tribal and UK tech to Detroit
electro and Cologne glitch; from jackin' acid and quirky breakbeats to
minimal techno and electronic dub. Drawing from a vast array of musical
influences, his diverse selections are at once foreign and familiar,
cerebral yet danceable, and undeniably interesting.

We're on-air in the bay area at 90.1 FM and online at
http://kzsulive.stanford.edu

Peace.


http://www.jcthedj.com

-- 
I'll be waking up very soon safely back on my own planet, I just know it

KZSU Radio or Stanford University." (or words to that effect.)

> that there's just very little appreciation for good techno in SF. We
> export all our good music... take the Context label, for example. You've
> got Sutekh, Kit Clayton, and Dave Aju producing mind-blowing shit, yet
> they rarely play locally and the label is distributed by Kompakt (a
> German uber-label and distro). Almost all of the great techno produced
> here in the bay area is released on European labels (Mille Plateaux,
> Force Inc., Circus Company, ~scape, etc.), and most of it doesn't reach
> local shops (unless you can bear shopping for vinyl at Amoeba).

we do have some great techno DJs locally tho, Chris Jackson, Forest
Green, Andy W during one of his sobriety attacks, etc., and credit
where credit's due btw, Resource Records is another great local label.
or rather family of labels.

anyway, I've been gone for years and I've only just gotten back, so I
can't really comment on the scene, but I remember watching DJ Rush
destroy the universe at a 200-person loft party.

I think SF techno might have gotten a bit too experimental, elite, and
"intelligent" for its own good. it's not about being smart. it's about
destroying the universe.

-- 
DJ Soundwave
www.djsoundwave.com

20 minute mini breaks mix:
http://www.djsoundwave.com/docs/short_sharp_shock.mp3

original breaks tracks and remixes:
http://www.djsoundwave.com/docs/out_there.mp3
http://www.djsoundwave.com/docs/word_up.mp3
http://www.djsoundwave.com/docs/example.mp3

original drum and bass tracks:
http://www.djsoundwave.com/docs/fremont.mp3
http://www.djsoundwave.com/docs/coffee.mp3

political underground hip-hop track:
http://www.djsoundwave.com/docs/gangsta.mp3

graphic design, paintings, space bunnies:
http://www.bowkett.net

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

References: <FDF244FB-D9E6-11D8-AA7E-003065DA480A@earthlink.net>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Re: (NRR) Republicans, Democrats & political

At 06:03 PM 7/19/2004, DJ Soundwave wrote:


>but, realistically, I can't have Republicans in office, and I can't
>shoot them in the head without getting in trouble for it, so, it's a
>rock and a hard place, innit. the devil and the deep blue sea.
>
>to each his own...

I also voted for Nader in the last election and have supported Dennis 
Kuchinch in the primaries.  The Green Party platform, however, best 
represents my political ideology.

I have come to separate national politics and local, more grassroots, 
political action in my mind.  Specifically, it is far more likely that I, 
and others like me, can elect Green Party candidates and implement Green 
political agendas in San Francisco.  It is unrealistic to expect to 
accomplish these goals on a national level, and I'm tired of wasting 
"protest votes" in Presidential elections.  One little step at a time.

On the other hand, I find Bush and his administration loathsome to the 
extreme and even though Kerry is very, very far from my ideal candidate, 
I'll put aside personal feelings and beliefs and vote Democratic.  Again, 
one step at a time.

Love,

Apollo



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and causes 
me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war, 
corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong 
its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-Abraham Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

  "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

BlankHey folks - I have some random vinyl for sale, hit me up if you are =
interested...

1. Jon H & Raskal - Drop A Beat - Red Menace (tech-house)
2. Dillon Street Rangers - Black & Fuzzy - Thunk (prog.breaks)
3. Bushwacka! - Break Your Face - Plank (nuskool/prog.breaks)
4. unknown - Isobel (Bjork remix) - white (3 tracks, 2 house, Bjork =
remix is trip-hop)
5. Funky Transport - Banglesonic E.P. - Brique Rouge (tech-house/house)
6. Situation 2wo - Way2Tite - Rip (prog.house/trance - rare track!)
7. Hybrid - True To Form (original & Kreamer & K mixes) - Distinctive =
(prog.breaks/house)
8. Bjork - Human Behaviour (Dom T, Speedy J & Underworld mixes) - =
Elektra
9. unknown - Blue Monday vs. The Ice Cream Man - white (House/breaks =
remixes of BlueMonday by NewOrder)
10. Blur - To The End EP (Pet Shop Boys remix of "Boys & Girls) - Food =
(electrohouse)
11. Third man - Solar Cycle / Planet Hunters (2 mixes of each) - Hook =
(classic trance)
12. Jam & Spoon - (The Complete) Stella (including Moby electro mixes) - =
R&S (classic trance/breaks)
13. Camisra - Feel The Beat - VC
14. Austin Leeds - Nutmeg - Bliss (prog./tech house & trance)

You know the drill - cash is king, paypal accepted too - I do not =
deliver unless you're buyin' me beer or smoking me out, lol.

Marc(O)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] looking for techno in SF...

--- Monikat <technoslut303@yahoo.com> wrote:
> hello!  so i escaped from the states for a while and
> got my ass to detroit and sonar and had an
> awesome time, and now i'm back in the bay and i need
> a maintenance dose of techno - badly.  i haven't
been
> on this list in a while so i'm a little behind on
what's
> going on these days, but if there's any regular
minimal techno, or dare i say it, detroit techno or
kompakt style stuff
> going on please please pass the word.

Hello all,
I'm fairly new to this list. I usually lurk on most
lists, but I wanted to speak on this. I try to make it
out when any good, Detroit DJs are booked in SF. I
have noticed a lack of interest in techno as well,
probably for some of the reasons Macadio had
mentioned. However, I have been to a few parties that
pulled in a decent crowd. Richie Hawtin, Carl Craig,
John Arnold, Mathew Dear all had a pretty good
attendance imo. There is definitely an elitist vibe
from some fans of this realm of music. I personally
would like to see that attitude squashed.
I don't understand how people can talk trash about
whatever genre is hot for the youngins. Yet they don't
do enough to support the music they covet. Techno
sounds and feels much better on a decent system then
it does on your ipod or in your cubicle.
So for those who aren't offended. I just wanted to
drop a quick email to see how many people on this list
would be interested in attending a small monthly event
with a low cover charge and some really dope talent in
the Techno scene. I know I will be walking the walk
and checking out the monthlies that Shawn mentioned.

Basically, my friends and I are trying to start a
monthly 313 flavored event in SF. I will post a full
announcement soon, but I just wanted to see if I could
generate some early hype and get people to help spread
the word. Please shoot me an email off list if you'd
like more info. events@djcarceri.com

CODEC
Friday August 20th @ Rx

Lucas Rodenbush (Live PA)
--Transmat, Soma, Solid Trax recording artist. One of
the premier bay area techno producers is back in the
Bay, bringing some exclusive new material, Laptop
stylee....

Christian Bloch (Live PA)
--Tresor, Matrix, Thinner recording artist. Christian
hails from Detroit via Denmark.  His widespread
talents range from Berlin dub, classic Detroit beats,
gritty and textured German beats to an unmatched
English minimalism. 

CODEC Resident DJs:
Tokyo Component
Scott Edmonds
Carceri

Rx Gallery
132 Eddy Street @ Mason
SF
21+ $5 before 12

Bio, mixes and more:
http://www.ebeaudio.netfirms.com
http://www.christianbloch.com
http://www.djcarceri.com
http://www.scottedmonds.com

Subject: [sfraves] SF Love Parade

--=====================_729629==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

First U.S. Loveparade Planned for October
World's largest electronic music parade comes to San
Francisco

SAN FRANCISCO  The world's largest electronic music
festival and parade is coming to San Francisco on
October 2, 2004. First held in Berlin in 1989,
Loveparade San Francisco is expected to draw thousands
of revelers to the Bay Area for a celebration of
electronic music with a mission of fostering
tolerance, respect and understanding between nations.

San Francisco has long been a desired location for
huge, outdoor, eclectic events, including the worlds'
largest Gay pride celebration and the famous Castro
Halloween and Folsom Street Fair parties. Loveparade
promises to be an event of the same caliber, drawing a
colorful and diverse audience while increasing the
existing tourist draw to the city.

This is the first time Loveparade has been held in the
United States; similar events are regularly held in
other cities around the globe, including Mexico City,
Cape Town, and Tel Aviv.

The event has garnered excitement from the business
community and beyond. California Assemblymember Mark
Leno was among those to recently offer his
congratulations on the city's acquisition of the
parade, calling it a "momentous and historic"
celebration. "I commend your commitment to create an
international community where music, dance, love and
diversity can creatively flourish."

International DJ/Producer Paul Van Dyk stated, "I was
very excited when I heard that the Loveparade will
take place in North America for the first time. I am
sure that the positive and peaceful vibe of this event
will be an extra feature in the amazing cultural life
of San Francisco and is going to become an annual
highlight."

The Loveparade will begin along San Francisco's scenic
Embarcadero and make its way through the South of
Market area. It will end along the waterfront in the
newly redeveloped Mission Bay district with a daylong
celebration featuring music, dancers, and a variety of
vendor booths. Top local and international DJs will
also be featured at the waterfront festival, as well
as on the floats as they make their way along the
parade route. For more information please visit
www.loveparadesf.org.

Mission of Loveparade San Francisco
Loveparade San Francisco exists to produce a parade of
love and diversity through electronic music and dance.
Loveparade San Francisco is a San Francisco based
501(c3) nonprofit.

Contact
Loveparade San Francisco
1388 Haight Street #149
San Francisco CA 94117

phone: 415-820-1449
email: info@loveparadesf.org




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and causes 
me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war, 
corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong 
its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-Abraham Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

  "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

Subject: [sfraves] Seeking help for a friend... [nrr]

--0-954029030-1090357862=:85544

Here it goes, I have a friend who's extremely introverted.  He sufferes from low self esteem, and has a very dificult time making new friends.  I wish other people could get to know him like we do...  He's really a sweet guy who wants to "have a life" but is terrified of people and what they may think of him.  After years of trying, I manged to get him to a rave hoping it would help him snap out of it, and this is what he did:
 
Before the rave:

   Before leaving the house he demonstrated that he's an expert on procrastination
   Notciably excited, yet nervous and anxious
   Was extremely talkative in the car
   curious about he supposed to do and not do..
Once we arrived he:

   Stayed Quite
   Stood in the corner alone
   Was noticably terrified
   was uncomfortable being around soo many people.  (Fortunatly he stuck it out)
   Lost 100 IQ poiints when confronted by anyone who was simply trying to be friendly.  (I know he wanted to be friendly but couldnt).
   Used every excuse to avoid people or get out of a conversation...  (I've never seen anyone come up with soo many creative ways of avoiding a simple conversation.)
Afterwards:
 
I asked him how he liked it, and he stated that It was coo, and he wishes he could be like those people...  I tried telling him to simply be himself, and to relax.  Afterall, they are simply people who are there to have a good time, and not out to judge him, or ridicule him...  I know for a fact tthat he dug the music...  (when he wasn't looking, I spotted him a few times groovin to the music) :)
 
All in all he says he would like to go to another, but his fear would prevent him from doing so...  It was a minor miracle that I was able to get him out this time...  I hope I didn't scare him further into his shelll...  If anyone has any advice as to how I can help my firend out of his shell, please email me...
 
Thank you, 
A very concerned friend...

Mime-version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset="ISO-8859-1"
Content-transfer-encoding: quoted-printable
X-ELNK-Trace: 3dff75ed0343effeee26750b534f88a60a9da525759e265400890f176d47411b1db6c93d35b5c790cd0c042b896368d8350badd9bab72f9c350badd9bab72f9c
X-Originating-IP: 69.3.238.122
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] looking for techno in SF... 

Chiming in response to a couple of points raised... First of all, anyone
that knows me knows I'm something of a techno evangelist. I wrote the
"Techno Is Back" cover story on Kompakt in this month's XLR8R magazine, as
well as the "techno's not dead" editor's rant at the front of the mag. Most
of what I cover in my writing is techno in one form or other, and almost al=
l
of what I DJ classifies as such. Some will call it minimal techno, some
microhouse, some tech-house, but at the end of the day, to me it's all
techno.

I really don=B9t see why some people think there's an "elitist" attitude
amongst techno listeners. Please, give examples. Whenever I hear charges of
"elitism" flying around I get suspicious -- that usually says more about th=
e
person weighing the charge. Just look at how Bush has successfully used the
tool of elitism to brand Democrats as rich, selfish, and out-of-touch
(strangely, qualities that *ought* to be applied to the ultra-elite such as
Bush and his moneyed supporters).

As for the charges of techno becoming boring, I think people just aren't
hearing enough. I know Kompakt has been tagged as a "chin-scratcher" label,
as a recent URB piece did, but jesus, listen to some of the recent Kompakt
and Speicher releases from Naum, Koze, Reinhard Voigt, M Mayer... it's all
absolutely storming, pounding shit with a vintage Frankfurt trance vibe.
Those tracks are so tough it's almost hard to play them out in SF, except a=
t
a proper rave. They're way too big for most of the bars and small clubs I
play here. And as for the more minimal stuff, a lot of it's really gone a
long way from the glitch experiments of Twerk, Sutekh, et al. (Sutekh, btw,
has been busting out some really fierce live sets lately.) Perlon is turnin=
g
out some of the sexiest, most ripply shit out there, and it's all infused
with the bass lines and forward momentum to make people move. Same goes for
Ricardo Villalobos, Luciano, all the Parisian cats (Krikor, Ark, Cabanne),
everyone affiliated with Areal, Traum, Trapez.

Ultimately, I think part of the problem is simply perception -- techno head=
s
like myself haven't figured out how to market this to SF crowds, neither th=
e
old-school ravers nor the younger kids, even the rock kids, to whom it woul=
d
easily appeal. Part of the problem is simply that "techno" is a dirty word
these days, besides being so broad that it doesn't mean much. When I say
"techno" I'm talking about music very very different from your Drumcode and
Intec releases, you know? And finally, there's very little name recognition=
,
especially of European techno artists, in San Francisco. It's hard enough
just to BUY Kompakt & Perlon records in SF shops... no one really knows who
the labels or artists are.

I sure don't know what the answer is -- my own monthly, the third-Saturday
party Soda at Rx -- is hardly drawing massive crowds yet. But I do think
that this music, including related strains of French acid, punkier techno
(for instance, the crossover between Blackstrobe's retro acid style and
Alter Ego's more classic minimal techno, as heard on Alter Ego's "Rocker"
12"; also heard in many Bpitch Control releases) could appeal to a lot of
folks -- and make for one hell of a good party. I've seen it go off in
Montreal and Barcelona; I just have no idea how to make it happen here.

Philip


---------------------------------------------------------------------

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Seeking help for a friend... [nrr]

At 02:11 PM 7/20/2004, Cheryl H wrote:
>All in all he says he would like to go to another, but his fear would 
>prevent him from doing so...  It was a minor miracle that I was able to 
>get him out this time...  I hope I didn't scare him further into his 
>shelll...  If anyone has any advice as to how I can help my firend out of 
>his shell, please email me...

uh... well my sarcastic side wants to ask if narcs really do have friends, 
but I'll be nice

this is such a classic story - I have heard this several times and the 
ending is usually "then he took some E and life did a u-turn"

basically, he needs to learn new behaviors, new ways of looking at the 
world - talk therapy is useful, but it takes so long to wear away
the roughness and things that are out of place.  it may all make sense at a 
intellectual level, but getting that understanding into
automatic behaviors (that self reinforce) is hard.

drugs are useful too to deal with the biological end of things, but they 
are not the only solution/cure all, despite all the advertising.
they are only useful as supportive tools.

as for the non-illegal drug way (Eli Lilly would recommend Paxil for his 
social anxiety disorder, but MDMA is cheaper, not as addictive, and
more effective, if properly used), you really can't do much until he is 
ready to change.  He has to get to the point where the cost of changing is
less than that of not changing.  all you can do is offer support and 
perhaps try pushing his buttons a bit to shake him out of his "trance".
but that takes some skill and you have to make sure your own ego is not 
getting stroked in doing so.

doug

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Seeking help for a friend... [nrr]

Sounds like your friend might need more than just to
be helped "out of his shell."  He could have an
anxiety disorder of some sort and that can be serious.
 I work with someone who has social anxiety disorder
and its a real problem for him.  

Your friend might want to talk to a psychologist or
psychiatrist about this possibility.  If that's too
much maybe he could just take a look around
http://www.socialphobia.org/ amd see if any of the
materials are helpful to him.

Best,

Peter

Subject: RE: [sfraves] Seeking help for a friend... [nrr]

As odd as it might sound to those on the list that know me, I go through the 
same thing almost every time I go out...which may explain the large 
quantities of liquor I imbibe (but that's another story altogether).

Anyway - sounds like he has a touch of social anxiety disorder. I totally 
understand that. It's hard. I still feel like the proverbial "new guy" and 
I've been here for a year now. It's really hard to get out of that rut - you 
feel like anything you say is gonna sound retarded (and usually does), like 
everyone is looking at you funny (and if you're around a bunch of people who 
know each other, they probably are - no matter how benign the looks may be). 
It really sucks on a lot of levels. And as nice as the people are out here, 
it seems to me like they take a lot longer to decide if you're ok or not. 
Maybe that's just me, I dunno.

Well - if you want, tell yer boy to get in contact with me - we can be the 
two losers no one knows at the party together! lol

Marc(O)

It's after 2:30pm on Tuesday and i'm just crawling out of bed.
 
That's a sign of a most FANTABULOUS birthday weekend.

I can't thank you guys enough for coming out and helping me bring in
another year of immaturity! For those of you who couldn't make it, I'm
still going through the messages you sent along and thanks for that too!
It means alot to me.
 
To those who had personal goals of seeing me go from vertical to
horizontal - I am happy to report that at worst I was diagonal.  Which
is a good & happy place to be (believe me, you wouldn't want to see me
horizontal - and NO, its does NOT count if my "feet are vertical"!) LOL
But thanks a ton for the effort - the drinks were highly appreciated!  ;
)
 
Well thanks again, y'all.
 
~dina

--part1_1d2.26626b88.2e2f0025_boundary
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

        Usually, your first party is your best... You go through alot of 
experiences that you'd probably never go through... But I'd say QUEST in 2000 @ 
Homebase was my best rave I'd ever gone to. Being the fact that alot of my 
friends were never in the scene... and I'd finally convinced them to attend it with 
me... I've never felt such a good vibe from a party like I did that day...

       I remember when it was ok to just stand there at a rave and someone 
would walk up to you and just start conversation, chat for a bit... and then 
just go dance and party together... it was really about the music...

       Ever since the raves started being about the "drugs" and not the 
music, attitudes have changed, parties have changed, and people have changed... 

       If there was ever going to be a party where the vibe felt like 1999 - 
2000 parties... I'd definately be there... 

Lucky

--part1_1d2.26626b88.2e2f0025_boundary--

Subject: [sfraves] what are you doing now?: conversation nrr

--0-1549464865-1090365082=:43290
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

hello, this is a continuation of a fictional piece:
 
"hey, ig."
"what."
"what are you doing now?"
"i am currently working on several projects. i am also working on my relationship."
"what relationship?"
"i've got a few going on. the one that is currently pending is the one i am most interested in though."
"oh, really."
"yes. i find the new stuff to be very satisfying, as i usually do. i can't help but chase. it is in my nature."
"oh, i see."
"do you really?"
"i think so."
"good, then i will continue with my more mundane projects and relationships."
"how many relationships are you actually having, ig?"
"i have absolutely no idea. i did not enter into all of them voluntarily."
"i see."
"i know." :)

MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="0-1771954528-1090368069=:28038"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] NRR... Meth Matters...a sobering view

--0-1771954528-1090368069=:28038
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii


Sent to me by a friend. Heed the advice, and keep your mind and emotions where you want them to be. 

love~Heidi 

 

>To all-
>A sobering portrayal in the NY Times today on the effects of Meth on the 
>brain.
>
>sheila
>
>
>July 20, 2004
>This Is Your Brain on Meth: A 'Forest Fire' of Damage
>By SANDRA BLAKESLEE
>
>People who do not want to wait for old age to shrink their brains and bring 
>on memory loss now have a quicker alternative - abuse methamphetamine for a 
>decade or so and watch the brain cells vanish into the night.
>
>The first high-resolution M.R.I. study of methamphetamine addicts shows "a 
>forest fire of brain damage," said Dr. Paul Thompson, an expert on brain 
>mapping at the University of California, Los Angeles. "We expected some 
>brain changes but didn't expect so much tissue to be destroyed."
>
>The image, published in the June 30 issue of The Journal of Neuroscience, 
>shows the brain's surface and deeper limbic system. Red areas show the 
>greatest tissue loss.
>
>The limbic region, involved in drug craving, reward, mood and emotion, lost 
>11 percent of its tissue. "The cells are dead and gone," Dr. Thompson said. 
>Addicts were depressed, anxious and unable to concentrate.
>
>The brain's center for making new memories, the hippocampus, lost 8 percent 
>of its tissue, comparable to the brain deficits in early Alzheimer's. The 
>methamphetamine addicts fared significantly worse on memory tests than 
>healthy people the same age.
>
>The study examined 22 people in their 30's who had used methamphetamine for 
>10 years, mostly by smoking it, and 21 controls matched for age. On 
>average, the addicts used an average of four grams a week and said they had 
>been high on 19 of the 30 days before the study began.
>
>Methamphetamine is an addictive stimulant made in clandestine laboratories 
>nationwide. When taken by mouth, snorted, injected or smoked, it produces 
>intense pleasure by releasing the brain's reward chemical, dopamine. With 
>chronic use, the brains that overstimulate dopamine and another brain 
>chemical, serotonin, are permanently compromised.
>
>The study held one other surprise, Dr. Thompson said: white matter, 
>composed of nerve fibers that connect different areas, was severely 
>inflamed, making the addicts' brains 10 percent larger than normal. "This 
>was shocking," he said. But there was one piece of good news: the white 
>matter was not dead. With abstinence, it might recover.





http://www.djspecdrum.com/

Gateway to my Gemm music superstore



--0-1771954528-1090368069=:28038--

Importance: Normal
X-Virus-Scanned: by amavisd-new at sixfeetup.com
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Spirit of Raving: Q1: Best experience @ an Event...

I have to agree here.

you'll always find people that have experienced some phenomena (i.e. a
rave)  a number of times and so the phenomena loses its novelty.  when
this happens, they say things like "it was much better back in the day,
etc. etc."  they may even claim that the phenomena has changed when really
all that's changed is the person experiencing it.

the bad news:  you'll never have that 1st experience again.  innocence
lost.  you'll yearn for nostalgia.

the good news:  you'll never have to have that 1st experience again. 
innocence is finally lost.  nostalgia is overrated.  feeling that "things
have changed" means you're uncomfortable (in a good way).  the stage is
set for learning.

learning is the key to eternal youth.

old ass jaded ass old guy,
Jonas

>

> On Tue, 20 Jul 2004 Luckyn007@aol.com wrote:
>
>>         Usually, your first party is your best... You go through alot of
>> experiences that you'd probably never go through... But I'd say QUEST in
>> 2000 @
>> Homebase was my best rave I'd ever gone to. Being the fact that alot of
>> my
>> friends were never in the scene... and I'd finally convinced them to
>> attend it with
>> me... I've never felt such a good vibe from a party like I did that
>> day...
>>
>>        I remember when it was ok to just stand there at a rave and
>> someone
>> would walk up to you and just start conversation, chat for a bit... and
>> then
>> just go dance and party together... it was really about the music...
>>
>>        Ever since the raves started being about the "drugs" and not the
>> music, attitudes have changed, parties have changed, and people have
>> changed...
>>
>>        If there was ever going to be a party where the vibe felt like
>> 1999 -
>> 2000 parties... I'd definately be there...
>>
>> Lucky
>>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Spirit of Raving: Q1: Best experience @ an Event...

i remember when ford started car production in flint,
1903. once the friday "end of the week" whistle blew
me and the crew went home for a shower, grabbed the
gear and came back at midnight, broke in and threw
wicked ass party. 

boy, that was the best party EVER... only if someone
would throw a party like back in the day. '03-'07

sorry, being silly ;-) he he

matt

price in spades. Crystal Psychosis being the least of the problems. Hair
falling out, teeth falling out, sores all over. NASTY. Let's not forget
people with a shitload of money who basically went poor due to financing
their habits....the shit is evil.

I highly recommend anyone stay clear away from it.

M-

Subject: [sfraves] BSP:  Evil Breaks presents...FLUX w/ Carbon Community Live!

if you like bangin', icky sticky, dark, funk nasty breakbeats...i really 
hope you get the chance to come down and see these guys bring it live.  
we're bringing Carbon Community all the way from Texas to throw down in San 
Francisco.

for a sample of what to expect, check out their website at 
www.thecarboncommunity.com.  click on "tracks."


Evil Breaks presents
FLUX
Friday, July 30th
9pm-3am, 21+
$5 before 11pm

Featuring:
Carbon Community (Moonshine/Bless Records/www.theCarbonCommunity.com)

This duo based out of Dallas, TX is about to make their first San Francisco 
appearance and they will be doing a Live performance that is sure to rock 
your senses and blow your mind. With their multiple releases on Moonshine 
records, and their more recent releases on Bless, they have been making 
quite a name for themselves in the Global breaks community.

A:Dubl (Breakthru)

Icon (Mach 5, Sister NYC, djIcon.com)

Aaron Jae (AaronJae.com/Evil Breaks)

DJ Bam (Invibe/Evil Breaks)

M.O.D. (Evil Breaks)


This event is 21+ and is being held at the Shadow Lounge located at the 
corner of 9th and Folsom. Going strong from 9pm-3am, only $5 before 11pm.


-------------
< Brandon / DJ Bam >

DJ Bam - serving breaks and beats
http://www.invibe.com/bam

Subject: RE: [sfraves] Seeking help for a friend... [nrr]


that really sounds like social anxiety disorder to me, I like to go about 
things the more "natural route" however...plain and simple, check out a book 
called "living with Joy" by Sanaya Roman, also check out "Soul 
Love"-awakenning your heart centers (everyone should read these, very 
incredible books) www.orindaben.com ...it is a channelled book which has 
offered me almost a "prozac" effect after reading it.  It deals with self 
asteem and positive self talk and absolutely everything in between..  I want 
to add yet another bit of advice as I have often seeked out friends who are 
in great need of help...make sure thay WANT TO Be HEALED or else your 
efforts will not be affective.  I just went to Santa Cruz on my bday and 
treated myself to a wonderful reading (psychic) and the lady was VERY 
helpful as I have been pretty depressed for quite sometime.  I do not know 
if your friend is into things like that, but it was very useful for me.
here is a number of a clairovoyant whom I have seen who is very helpful..
Maria Silvermoon (minister/clairovoyant/teacher (831) 338 4947 she is a 
pisces.
other things to check out...
"You can Heal Your Life" by Louisse Hay-new thought patterns
"the Power of Now" by Eckhart Tolle
Well, I hope some of these things can help...
Much Love,
Danny

to smacken-backen und fix de morkin, yobetcha! "
-The Swedish Chef

>From: Cheryl H <cheryl1393@yahoo.com>
>To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
>Subject: [sfraves] Seeking help for a friend... [nrr]
>Date: Tue, 20 Jul 2004 14:11:02 -0700 (PDT)
>
>Here it goes, I have a friend who's extremely introverted.  He sufferes 
>from low self esteem, and has a very dificult time making new friends.  I 
>wish other people could get to know him like we do...  He's really a sweet 
>guy who wants to "have a life" but is terrified of people and what they may 
>think of him.  After years of trying, I manged to get him to a rave hoping 
>it would help him snap out of it, and this is what he did:
>
>Before the rave:
>
>    Before leaving the house he demonstrated that he's an expert on 
>procrastination
>    Notciably excited, yet nervous and anxious
>    Was extremely talkative in the car
>    curious about he supposed to do and not do..
>Once we arrived he:
>
>    Stayed Quite
>    Stood in the corner alone
>    Was noticably terrified
>    was uncomfortable being around soo many people.  (Fortunatly he stuck 
>it out)
>    Lost 100 IQ poiints when confronted by anyone who was simply trying to 
>be friendly.  (I know he wanted to be friendly but couldnt).
>    Used every excuse to avoid people or get out of a conversation...  
>(I've never seen anyone come up with soo many creative ways of avoiding a 
>simple conversation.)
>Afterwards:
>
>I asked him how he liked it, and he stated that It was coo, and he wishes 
>he could be like those people...  I tried telling him to simply be himself, 
>and to relax.  Afterall, they are simply people who are there to have a 
>good time, and not out to judge him, or ridicule him...  I know for a fact 
>tthat he dug the music...  (when he wasn't looking, I spotted him a few 
>times groovin to the music) :)
>
>All in all he says he would like to go to another, but his fear would 
>prevent him from doing so...  It was a minor miracle that I was able to get 
>him out this time...  I hope I didn't scare him further into his shelll...  
>If anyone has any advice as to how I can help my firend out of his shell, 
>please email me...
>
>Thank you,
>A very concerned friend...
>
>

"However enticing or discomforting the trend of the indie star-turned-DJ may be, tonight's set from DJ-turned-Ladytron founder and chief songwriter Danny Hunt pleases everyone. Before he acquired bandmates and secondhand analog equipment, Hunt started a UK club night for his Invicta Hi-Fi label, spinning eclectic '60s, soul, and post-punk tunes that highlight both the organic and electronic. Remixes of DJ buddies Soulwax and DJ/not-DJ buddy Erlend ye should round out a night celebrating the dancier aspects of rock and bring a Liverpudlian disco aura to San Francisco. "

Taken from Flavorpill http://sf.flavorpill.net/mailer/issue116/index.html

"I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and causes 
me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war, 
corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong 
its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-Abraham Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

  "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

I'm pretty much a lurker, but couldn't resist posting. I suffer from the
same type of problems as your friend, although not as severe, and I =
found
mustering up the will to go out and approach people incredibly dificult. =


My advice:=20

Encourage him to continue going out and make new friends, but don't be
pushy. I found forcing myself into uncomfortable situations, extremely =
hard,
but extremely rewarding. He will stumble and fall, and that=92s ok, he =
simply
needs to keep going. As he gets more comfortable, and meets new people, =
it
will get easier. Growth only comes through pain and struggle, and maybe =
if
he's willing, try some MDMA. It was used as a psychotherapeutic tool for
cases similar to this 20-30 years ago. It will help break the Ice and =
help
him to open up. Trust me, I know =3D)

I wish you and your friend the best of luck, I don't envy his road ahead =
but
believe me it will get easier.

I'm gonna go back to lurking now =3D)

If your friend wants to talk he can IM me at:

AIM: jarvik1197

-j

From: Cheryl H [HYPERLINK

Sent: Tuesday, July 20, 2004 2:11 PM

To: sfraves@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] Seeking help for a friend... [nrr]

Here it goes, I have a friend who's extremely introverted. He sufferes =
from
low self esteem, and has a very dificult time making new friends. I wish
other people could get to know him like we do... He's really a sweet guy =
who
wants to "have a life" but is terrified of people and what they may =
think of
him. After years of trying, I manged to get him to a rave hoping it =
would
help him snap out of it, and this is what he did:

Before the rave:

Before leaving the house he demonstrated that he's an expert on
procrastination

Notciably excited, yet nervous and anxious

Was extremely talkative in the car

curious about he supposed to do and not do..

Once we arrived he:

Stayed Quite

Stood in the corner alone

Was noticably terrified

was uncomfortable being around soo many people. (Fortunatly he stuck it =
out)

Lost 100 IQ poiints when confronted by anyone who was simply trying to =
be
friendly. (I know he wanted to be friendly but couldnt).

Used every excuse to avoid people or get out of a conversation... (I've
never seen anyone come up with soo many creative ways of avoiding a =
simple
conversation.)

Afterwards:

I asked him how he liked it, and he stated that It was coo, and he =
wishes he
could be like those people... I tried telling him to simply be himself, =
and
to relax. Afterall, they are simply people who are there to have a good
time, and not out to judge him, or ridicule him... I know for a fact =
tthat
he dug the music... (when he wasn't looking, I spotted him a few times
groovin to the music) :)

All in all he says he would like to go to another, but his fear would
prevent him from doing so... It was a minor miracle that I was able to =
get
him out this time... I hope I didn't scare him further into his =
shelll... If
anyone has any advice as to how I can help my firend out of his shell,
please email me...

Thank you,

A very concerned friend...

=20

In a message dated 7/20/2004 4:01:31 PM Pacific Daylight Time, 
sfraves-digest-help@hyperreal.org writes:


> Part of the problem is simply that "techno" is a dirty word
> these days,

possibly the reason for that is the fact that there are far too few that know 
what techno is. i've been longing to come up with a compilation or event 
that's entitled, "No... THIS is Techno!" `;) in response to so many compilations 
that errantly claim what's contained on their comps is actually techno. we 
really need to educate the populous on what is out there and provide more events 
to show and prove what techno is in truth. another fact beyond that, is that 
mostly people who share a passion for techno are seldom united in their 
ambitions and go at it alone.
       We as DEF created a website for the knowledge and proliferation of all 
forms of techno music on the west coast. so that people who aren't sure what 
techno is, may be able to find others who are interested in techno and to join 
a growing west coast techno community.
 check out:
http://www.defsf.com/

 we've been around & involved with the SF techno scene for roughly one year 
throwing our own events and assisting others through DEF Audio. one of DEF's 
goals is to provide assistance in the promotion of techno music and others 
throwing techno related events. if you are interested in listing an event with DEF 
please register at defsf.com, find the events link, and create an event. we 
are also soon due to be sending out a west coast techno events calendar on a 
regular basis. if you would like to receive information about west coast techno 
events please log on to defsf.com and register or join our mailing list via the 
information below. `;)
++spects++
-Sean Ocean-

a west coast techno alliance.

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Spirit of Raving: Q1: Best experience @ an Event...

Beyond novelty, I think it also has to do with changes.

Our scene changes very rapidly, either you grow along with it or you
get left behind. As to whether it changes for the better or worse,
it's really up to the individual.

When trance was huge in 1997-2001, u hear the househeads complaining
about how the old house days was better, because they refused to go
with the flow and embrace trance. Of course, house took over once
again from 2001 and the cycle continues.

Personally, I've been a jaded party kids 3 times over already, but
each time I managed to eventually find excitingly new emerging music
that made it fresh for me all over again. That's what keeps me going:
I know the old days were gr8, but tomoorow there'll mgiht very well be
something entirely different and as exciting.

Don't look back, look forward. Trust me, the best days are yet to come.  ;)


Love,

- Jeff




On Tue, 20 Jul 2004 17:08:58 -0700 (PDT), Jonas R. <djjonas@sf-vibe.com> wrote:
> I have to agree here.
> 
> you'll always find people that have experienced some phenomena (i.e. a
> rave)  a number of times and so the phenomena loses its novelty.  when
> this happens, they say things like "it was much better back in the day,
> etc. etc."  they may even claim that the phenomena has changed when really
> all that's changed is the person experiencing it.
> 
> the bad news:  you'll never have that 1st experience again.  innocence
> lost.  you'll yearn for nostalgia.
> 
> the good news:  you'll never have to have that 1st experience again.
> innocence is finally lost.  nostalgia is overrated.  feeling that "things
> have changed" means you're uncomfortable (in a good way).  the stage is
> set for learning.
> 
> learning is the key to eternal youth.
> 
> old ass jaded ass old guy,
> Jonas
>

From: John B <SvnLyrBrto@yahoo.com>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Spirit of Raving: Q1: Best experience @ an Event...

Well, one of the things that gets *ME* into the occasional "it's not as 
good as back when" fit isn't so much pure nostalgia as certain people I 
miss.

There are good parties still being thrown, no doubt.  But there are 
people I miss, who don't, or rarely, go to parties anymore.  There are 
crews I miss, who don't throw parties anymore.  There are friends whom 
I hardly get to see at all anymore.  There are groups of friends, who 
used to be inseparable, whom have drifted apart, or have had drama tear 
them apart.  Hell, there are a ton of people, right here on this list, 
whom I used to see every week at Blake's, who I don't think I've seen 
in almost a year.

Not that there aren't good things going on now.  But there are 
definitely some major good times that are in the past.

Of course, while I don't deny there are good parties still happening, 
my own best memories are in the past as well.  There was a stretch, 
throughout the first half of 2002, where EVERYTHING seemed to come 
together for me as a raver.  And more of my most happy party memories 
come from that period than any other.  And the two parties that anchor 
the ends of that stretch were thrown by one of those aforementioned 
"crews that don't throw parties anymore" whom I really, Really, REALLY 
miss.  That crew being UNITY, and the parties being "Imagine Us In 
Wonderland" in January, and "Imagine" in June.

I posted a review of "Imagine" to SFRaves a few days after the party 
itself.  It just so happens, I had dropped a copy into my livejournal 
as well.  I just dug it up, and read it again.  And just reading that 
review, just remembering that party, is enough to bring me into "tears 
of happiness" mode.  To give you an idea of that moment, to answer the 
"Best experience @ an Event..." question, here is a repost of my old 
review of "Imagine", Saturday, June 22, 2002:



Imagine...

  Oh...

My...

God...

If there's one crew that can always bring out the very best of 
everything the rave scene is about, it's Unity. Part of me can still 
hardly believe how perfectly this whole weekend went. From the 
excitement of getting ready; to the anticipation of waiting for the 
doors to open; to the hours of PERFECT partieing ai Imagine, to the 
awesome afterpartie... Everything was just... amazing. I'm still 
dumbfounded at what an amazing partie that was.

I shouldn't be. Since when has Unity EVER let us down? This gives 
Unity's own: "Imagine us in Wonderland", back in January, a serious run 
for its money as best partie EVER. Certianly it was the best LARGE 
partie ever. Of course, I NEVER doubted Duckee for a second. I had 
bought my ticket (#156) MONTHS in advance, and had been awiting the 
22nd with increasing anticipation for the whole time. I knew it would 
be am awesome party... but Oh... My... God!!!

The only things about the whole weekend that went in any way wrong 
actually happened BEFORE Imagine. Since the venue had supposedly been 
having problems meeting fire code, they delayed letting everyone 
(including the Unity crew) in for about forty-five minutes while the 
walked through the place. That, and the pre-party I was going to go to 
fell through. Kinda a bummer, but I just spent the extra time getting 
ready.

And if there is EVER a time to go all out, it's a Unity party. My 
pockets were loaded down with so much Kandy, candy, and toys, I'm 
AMAZED that I breezed through security with no problems like I did. 
Just a quick pat-down, and I showed him that my camera was really a 
camera and not a brick, and I was in. 'Tis a shame that courteous and 
respectful security types are so rare that it deserves a mention in a 
review. But Unity even delivered on THAT. Like everything about 
Imagine, that's the way it should be ALL the time.

So after saying Hey to the people I spotted in line, and the crew 
members who weren't busy yet, I spent about ten minutes at a bench near 
the back getting kandied up. The whole time, I was getting the "what 
the fuck???" look from this one security guard; who nevertheless was 
pretty friendly, and even handed me a couple things I dropped.

So, with my pants less weighted down, I was ready to dance. And I did 
so for the first hour and a half or so. When I stopped for my first 
water/Red Bull break, I started making the rounds to say hey to 
everyone who had been arriving in the meantime...

And, oh my... I saw SOOOO many people I knew there. I couldn't even 
begin to list them here. I even found people whom I NEVER expected that 
I'd see at such a "candy" party as an Imagine. Imagine being a larger 
partie than I usually attend, I found them everywhere while making the 
circuit around the building. That ate up a fair bit of time, untill I 
found myself back in the main room for the Check Ceremony.

And that's just another thing I LOVE about the Unity crew. Where so 
many other crews see the scene as something to exploit to fatten their 
own wallets; Unity throws their parties for the RIGHT reasons. That 
they forego making a profit, so that they can make every partie a 
benefit, is just astoundingly cool.

But moreso than the check ceremony itself... The rest of the happenings 
in that lull were just overwhealming. Alison read her poetry to an 
enthralled crowd; and some beautiful poetry it was. But the video... 
Oh... My... God... I was in tears of happiness before it was even a 
halfway through. That just brough back so many memories of the previous 
Unity parties. That one crew has dome SOOO much good here is just 
staggering.

Soon, it was time for Denise to play. I got up on stage during her set 
to snag some pictures of the crew and crowd. And Denise herself posed 
for a pic that should come out REALLY cute when I get them developed. 
And wow... that's the first time I got up there, at a Unity party, or 
otherwise. And to look at that sea of smileing faces is just short of 
overwhealming... intoxicating even.

But I couldn't burn time standing up there... not with Denise playing. 
So I hopped down, and worked my way back to where there was room to 
dance. And yah... again I was running into MORE friends I hadn't seen 
yet that night! Eventually I *DID* get to dance to Denise a little... 
only about ten minutes tho...

But I *DID* get to dance a lot to ANTHONY MAD!!! Oh... My... God!!! 
With local DJs like Anthony and Denise, who NEEDS those out of town 
"superstars"??? Anthony positively tore the roof off!!! I couldn't stop 
bouncing and bouncing and bouncing... maybe THAT's why so many people 
mistake me for Tigger? I was shocked as hell when I heard what I 
thought was Anthony trainwrecking tho. Anthony? Trainwrecking? I 
couldn't believe it! But it turns out that was not the case. I worked 
my way back up front to get some pics of him, and I saw the truth. SOOO 
many people were dancing, WITH THE BEAT, that they were litterally 
bouncing the needles off the records every so often!!! How fucking cool 
is THAT?!?!?

After Anthony was done, I took another longish water/Red 
Bull/socializing break. I ran into even MORE friends; met some peeps I 
hadn't seen in FOREVER, totally bonded with some more people... getting 
to know them much better.... making plans for more parties in the 
future... going from friend to friend to friend.... hanging out in the 
light tunnel... I could hardly believe the positive vibes of the party! 
Not that I EVER doubted Unity... but damn!!!

So for the last half hour, we all popped back down for the finale. 
Damn... A thousand or more of the BEST people, dancing non-stop, to the 
BEST music, with the BEST crew in the scene on stage leading us on. 
Could anything in the world be better? So the music took a short break 
while duckee got on stage to say his thank you's. Oh... My... God... Is 
there ANYONE more postivibe in the scene than the Unity crew???? I 
can't think of anyone! Then the music started again... a few more 
minutes of music, topping out with.... what else?

Imagine there's no heaven
It's easy if you try
No hell below us
Above us only sky
Imagine all the people
Living for today...

Imagine there's no country
It isn't hard to do
Nothing to kill or die for
And no rerligion too
Imagine all the people
Living life in peace

Imagine no possetions
I wonder if you can
No need for greed or hunger
A brotherhood of man
Imagine all the people
Shareing all the world

You may say I'm a dreamer
But I'm not the only one
I hope someday you'll join us
And the would will live as one.

(Originally by John Lennon (obviously), but recited all from memory (no 
cheating on my part!))

(Words to live by (even more obviously))


Thank you Unity!


cya,
john

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Spirit of Raving: Q1: Best experience @ an Event...

So here's a theory I have for a long time about how parties or the
scene seems to be more drug-oriented than b4.....

Parties are never "drug-oriented" and "music-oriented", people are.

By extension, people are never  "drug-oriented" and "music-oriented"
at large, the individuals are.

And in many cases, the "individuals" that make you feel the way you do
are YOU and your friends.

-----

People generally will go out for both the music and the drugs. The
reason you feel a party is more drug-oriented is probably because:

1. You didn't see any good DJs or new music, it's all the same shit
u've heard b4
2. You see way more e-tards in hug puddles than usual
3. you and you friends went out just to do drugs
( feel free to add your reasons)

For #1, it's mainly beacuse you're more knowledgable now and have seen
more DJs than u have when u first started partying. The novelty worn
off. At the same time, each genre of EDM has a natural cycle of 4-5
years and there'll always be a period of exciting innovative music
followed by formulative rehashes.

For #2, I think it's mainly the fact that you're not into the music at
party, so you actually stop dancing and look around and notice what
goes on @ EVERY PARTY since the dawn of time. Really, it's always been
about drugs as much as the music. Sometimes u ignore it, sometimes you
overlook it, sometimes you're too naive to even notice it. But it's
always been there, and it always has been about the same level, it's
really a matter of how much attention you paid to it.

#3: Why would you and your friends would go to a party where the
headliners are DJs u've already heard 50 times? Drugs. Now if u go to
a party because they book a number of DJs u've NEVER seen b4, then you
went because of the music. Hence, you can't expect the crowd to come
out "for the music" unless the faces are fresh and the music is hot.
If producers are making innovative music, and when a lot of new faces
in the DJ world emerge, then you can be reasonably sure that the party
scene at large will be music-oriented. Personally they were 92, 96-97
and 2000 for me. Notice there's a 4 yrs cycle.

My point is, drug use is pretty constant in our scene
proportitionally, but music goes in cycles. So the drug use seems
worse only relatively, IMHO. So if one feels the scene is more
drug-oriented than it was, it's mainly a reflection of his/her lack of
enthuiasm in the music coming out today than anything else.

But anyways, that's just my theory.

- Jeff

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR:  Ordering Pizza in the Near Future?

Near future?

Back when I was still in high school, I had a friend who worked at the 
local Pizza Hut.

Even back then, their phones were hooked into a callerID box that would 
bring up your name, address, and so on, on a computer screen when you 
called them.  No doubt, it's more sophisticated now... then the 
information was just what you gave them the last time you ordered.  So 
if you'd never ordered pizza from that line before, they had bupkis.

But at least Pizza Hut has a legitimate reason for asking for your 
address.  Radio Shack, OTOH, trying to get my address every time I 
bought something... with cash.... was obnoxious as all hell.


cya,
john

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: cheap flights to Vancouver?

First of all, how last min is this? 7-day adv or more? Or this weekend?


If you have 14-day dav or more, use the usual online booking services
to search for specials. Oribtz has the better checking of availabilty
and price comparisons, Travelocity has the actual flight specials in
full text so you can see all the valid travel dates, restirctions,
etc.

If u need to fly in less than 7-days, first check United and Alaska,
they frequently has SF<->VAN specials for this/next weekends. Next u
should try PriceLine. Many ppl has good success with it for last min
flights.

Personally, f I need to fly within 7 days, I usually ask my friends to
hook me up with companion passes and fly stand-by.

- Jeff
