Subject: Re: [sfraves] Seeking help for a friend... [nrr]

Cheryl,

	It's nice that you are concerned and trying to coax your friend =
out of=20
his shell. Perhaps taking a public speaking class or joining=20
Toastmasters (a sort of hobby group for people to practice giving=20
speeches) could be the thing for him. A class environment like this is=20=

generally more supportive and less socially stressful while still=20
helping build confidence to speak to people in social situations.

	I found the public speaking class I took at SF State to be good =
not=20
only for improving my comfort level with getting up and talking in=20
front of a group, but also for the feedback that gave me a greater=20
awareness of things like breathing, my tendency to mumble, speaking too=20=

rapidly, body language, posture, gestures, etc., that can cause=20
problems for peoples' interactions without them being consciously aware=20=

of an issue until it is pointed out by someone else. Kind of like when=20=

there is something green hanging out of your nose.  8)
=09
	Another strategy might be continually introducing your friend to=20=

people in social settings, and steering them toward topics or styles of=20=

communicating that you know he is more comfortable with. You can have a=20=

secret code between the two of you so that he can nudge you or=20
something when he needs to let you know he's feeling like "I can't take=20=

this any more, I have to go stand over in the corner now."

	At parties, perhaps your friend might be more comfortable =
expressing=20
himself physically first rather than interacting with strangers, such=20
as by dancing with you or someone he knows, or twirling glowsticks on=20
his own, or even just taking pictures of other people. If you have a=20
polaroid or digital camera to take someone's picture and be able to=20
give or show it to them, that's a great ice breaker.

	Having something to do with his mouth could also help reduce the=20=

feeling of pressure to talk. If your friend doesn't smoke, give him a=20
lollipop or better yet a pacifier to suck on. People won't expect him=20
to communicate as much, and will probably assume he's on E and become=20
more friendly, especially if he's dressed like a candy raver.   8)

Groove on,
				<<< Starchild >>>


On Tuesday, July 20, 2004, at 08:05  PM, <jarvik@betacaeli.com> wrote:

> I'm pretty much a lurker, but couldn't resist posting. I suffer from=20=

> the
> same type of problems as your friend, although not as severe, and I=20
> found
> mustering up the will to go out and approach people incredibly=20
> dificult.
>
> My advice:
>
> Encourage him to continue going out and make new friends, but don't be
> pushy. I found forcing myself into uncomfortable situations, extremely=20=

> hard,
> but extremely rewarding. He will stumble and fall, and that=92s ok, he=20=

> simply
> needs to keep going. As he gets more comfortable, and meets new=20
> people, it
> will get easier. Growth only comes through pain and struggle, and=20
> maybe if
> he's willing, try some MDMA. It was used as a psychotherapeutic tool=20=

> for
> cases similar to this 20-30 years ago. It will help break the Ice and=20=

> help
> him to open up. Trust me, I know =3D)
>
> I wish you and your friend the best of luck, I don't envy his road=20

> believe me it will get easier.

Hydraulix, SUF)
with party techno from Europe. His fresh vibrant and funky dj sets appeal to 
a wide audience
of hungry clubbers, ravers and partyheads  be it on the beaches of Spain, 
in the midst of Russia

Danny Picard <blooshaman@hotmail.com> wrote:

that really sounds like social anxiety disorder to me, I like to go about 
things the more "natural route" however...plain and simple, check out a book 
called "living with Joy" by Sanaya Roman, also check out "Soul 
Love"-awakenning your heart centers (everyone should read these, very 
incredible books) www.orindaben.com ...it is a channelled book which has 
offered me almost a "prozac" effect after reading it. It deals with self 
asteem and positive self talk and absolutely everything in between.. I want 
to add yet another bit of advice as I have often seeked out friends who are 
in great need of help...make sure thay WANT TO Be HEALED or else your 
efforts will not be affective. I just went to Santa Cruz on my bday and 
treated myself to a wonderful reading (psychic) and the lady was VERY 
helpful as I have been pretty depressed for quite sometime. I do not know 
if your friend is into things like that, but it was very useful for me.
here is a number of a clairovoyant whom I have seen who is very helpful..
Maria Silvermoon (minister/clairovoyant/teacher (831) 338 4947 she is a 
pisces.
other things to check out...
"You can Heal Your Life" by Louisse Hay-new thought patterns
"the Power of Now" by Eckhart Tolle
Well, I hope some of these things can help...
Much Love,
Danny

>guy who wants to "have a life" but is terrified of people and what they may

>procrastination
> Notciably excited, yet nervous and anxious
> Was extremely talkative in the car
> curious about he supposed to do and not do..

>
> Stayed Quite
> Stood in the corner alone
> Was noticably terrified

>it out)

>simple conversation.)

>

>he could be like those people... I tried telling him to simply be himself, 
>and to relax. Afterall, they are simply people who are there to have a 
>good time, and not out to judge him, or ridicule him... I know for a fact 
>tthat he dug the music... (when he wasn't looking, I spotted him a few 
>times groovin to the music) :)

>prevent him from doing so... It was a minor miracle that I was able to get

>  
> Cheryl
> 
> Douglas Fraser <doug_fraser@microcinema.com> wrote:
> At 02:11 PM 7/20/2004, Cheryl H wrote:
> 
>>All in all he says he would like to go to another, but his fear would 
>>prevent him from doing so... It was a minor miracle that I was able to 
>>get him out this time... I hope I didn't scare him further into his 
>>shelll... If anyone has any advice as to how I can help my firend out of 
>>his shell, please email me...
> 
> 
> uh... well my sarcastic side wants to ask if narcs really do have friends, 
> but I'll be nice
> 
> this is such a classic story - I have heard this several times and the 
> ending is usually "then he took some E and life did a u-turn"
> 
> basically, he needs to learn new behaviors, new ways of looking at the 
> world - talk therapy is useful, but it takes so long to wear away
> the roughness and things that are out of place. it may all make sense at a 
> intellectual level, but getting that understanding into
> automatic behaviors (that self reinforce) is hard.
> 
> drugs are useful too to deal with the biological end of things, but they 
> are not the only solution/cure all, despite all the advertising.
> they are only useful as supportive tools.
> 
> as for the non-illegal drug way (Eli Lilly would recommend Paxil for his 
> social anxiety disorder, but MDMA is cheaper, not as addictive, and
> more effective, if properly used), you really can't do much until he is 
> ready to change. He has to get to the point where the cost of changing is
> less than that of not changing. all you can do is offer support and 
> perhaps try pushing his buttons a bit to shake him out of his "trance".
> but that takes some skill and you have to make sure your own ego is not 
> getting stroked in doing so.
> 
> doug
> 
> 
> ---------------------------------------------------------------------
> To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
> For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

All the people saying "get him therapy" or "give him drugs" have a
point, but the Johnny Appleseed of Ecstasy was a therapist. This is
when E was legal, and he's something of a legend -- "Pihkal" and
"Altered State" actually give different spellings of his name, but I'm
inclined to trust "Pihkal". Anyway he discovered this stuff and it
revitalized his career as well as changing lives all over the country.
And then its recreational qualities were discovered, then
criminalization, then acid house, yadda yadda...

Anyway -- point is, therapy and Ecstasy are not actually mutually
exclusive. You could actually give him both.

Anyway, you should totally do something about that, because everybody
knows that shy people are really all serial killers waiting to happen.

> > > I wish it were that simple...  I've tried getting him to
> > take E but he flat out refuses...  So thats out of the
> > question, for now...  I tihnk the therapy would be slower,
> > but more usefull...
> > >  
> > > thanks for the info
> > >  
> > > Cheryl
> > > 
> > > Douglas Fraser <doug_fraser@microcinema.com> wrote:
> > > At 02:11 PM 7/20/2004, Cheryl H wrote:
> > > 
> > >>All in all he says he would like to go to another, but
> his
> > fear would 
> > >>prevent him from doing so... It was a minor miracle that
> I
> > was able to 
> > >>get him out this time... I hope I didn't scare him
> further
> > into his 
> > >>shelll... If anyone has any advice as to how I can help
> my
> > firend out of 
> > >>his shell, please email me...
> > > 
> > > 
> > > uh... well my sarcastic side wants to ask if narcs really
> > do have friends, 
> > > but I'll be nice
> > > 
> > > this is such a classic story - I have heard this several
> > times and the 
> > > ending is usually "then he took some E and life did a
> > u-turn"
> > > 
> > > basically, he needs to learn new behaviors, new ways of
> > looking at the 
> > > world - talk therapy is useful, but it takes so long to
> > wear away
> > > the roughness and things that are out of place. it may
> all
> > make sense at a 
> > > intellectual level, but getting that understanding into
> > > automatic behaviors (that self reinforce) is hard.
> > > 
> > > drugs are useful too to deal with the biological end of
> > things, but they 
> > > are not the only solution/cure all, despite all the
> > advertising.
> > > they are only useful as supportive tools.
> > > 
> > > as for the non-illegal drug way (Eli Lilly would
> recommend
> > Paxil for his 
> > > social anxiety disorder, but MDMA is cheaper, not as
> > addictive, and
> > > more effective, if properly used), you really can't do
> much
> > until he is 
> > > ready to change. He has to get to the point where the
> cost
> > of changing is
> > > less than that of not changing. all you can do is offer
> > support and 
> > > perhaps try pushing his buttons a bit to shake him out of
> > his "trance".
> > > but that takes some skill and you have to make sure your
> > own ego is not 
> > > getting stroked in doing so.
> > > 
> > > doug
> > > 
> > > 
> > >

----- Message from g00fRiDER <goofrider@gmail.com> on Tue, 20 Jul 2004
21:35:15 -0700 -----
                                                                                        
      To: "Jonas R." <djjonas@sf-vibe.com>                                              
                                                                                        
      cc: Dan Haskovec <dan@pry.com>, luckyn007@aol.com, karina@hyperreal.org,          
          sfraves@hyperreal.org                                                         
                                                                                        
 Subject: Re: [sfraves] Spirit of Raving: Q1: Best experience @ an Event...             
                                                                                        

Beyond novelty, I think it also has to do with changes.

Our scene changes very rapidly, either you grow along with it or you
get left behind. As to whether it changes for the better or worse,
it's really up to the individual.

When trance was huge in 1997-2001, u hear the househeads complaining
about how the old house days was better, because they refused to go
with the flow and embrace trance. Of course, house took over once
again from 2001 and the cycle continues.

Personally, I've been a jaded party kids 3 times over already, but
each time I managed to eventually find excitingly new emerging music
that made it fresh for me all over again. That's what keeps me going:
I know the old days were gr8, but tomoorow there'll mgiht very well be
something entirely different and as exciting.

Don't look back, look forward. Trust me, the best days are yet to come.  ;)


Love,

- Jeff

"scosol@scosol.org" <scosol@scosol.org> wrote:
*My* sarcastic side says narcs don't know how to quote.

How did your friend ever become your friend, what with his seemingly 
major social issues?????

Study that process, then repeat.

Cheryl H wrote:

> uh... well my sarcastic side wants to ask if narcs really do have friends, 
> but I'll be nice
> 
> I don't know about narcs having friends, but I do appreciate the lack of sarcasm...
> 
> this is such a classic story - I have heard this several times and the 
> ending is usually "then he took some E and life did a u-turn"
> 
> I wish it were that simple... I've tried getting him to take E but he flat out refuses... So thats out of the question, for now... I tihnk the therapy would be slower, but more usefull...
> 
> thanks for the info
> 
> Cheryl
> 
> Douglas Fraser wrote:
> At 02:11 PM 7/20/2004, Cheryl H wrote:
> 
>>All in all he says he would like to go to another, but his fear would 
>>prevent him from doing so... It was a minor miracle that I was able to 
>>get him out this time... I hope I didn't scare him further into his 
>>shelll... If anyone has any advice as to how I can help my firend out of 
>>his shell, please email me...
> 
> 
> uh... well my sarcastic side wants to ask if narcs really do have friends, 
> but I'll be nice
> 
> this is such a classic story - I have heard this several times and the 
> ending is usually "then he took some E and life did a u-turn"
> 
> basically, he needs to learn new behaviors, new ways of looking at the 
> world - talk therapy is useful, but it takes so long to wear away
> the roughness and things that are out of place. it may all make sense at a 
> intellectual level, but getting that understanding into
> automatic behaviors (that self reinforce) is hard.
> 
> drugs are useful too to deal with the biological end of things, but they 
> are not the only solution/cure all, despite all the advertising.
> they are only useful as supportive tools.
> 
> as for the non-illegal drug way (Eli Lilly would recommend Paxil for his 
> social anxiety disorder, but MDMA is cheaper, not as addictive, and
> more effective, if properly used), you really can't do much until he is 
> ready to change. He has to get to the point where the cost of changing is
> less than that of not changing. all you can do is offer support and 
> perhaps try pushing his buttons a bit to shake him out of his "trance".
> but that takes some skill and you have to make sure your own ego is not 
> getting stroked in doing so.
> 
> doug
> 
>

Subject: RE: [sfraves] Seeking help for a friend... [nrr]

I hope you were posting those web-sites as a joke because they have some
serious misinformation in them, here are a few mistakes I found:

"DXM is a cough medicine that dries out the lungs, and makes dehydrating
even more dangerous and likely to happen."=20

Um no, Guaifenesin must be what this statement is referring to. It
doesn't really dry out the lungs, but rather is an an Expectorant (water
is also an expectorant), it loosens up the saliva and evacuates it from
the body. Large doses of it causes you to vomit. DXM, on the other hand
could cause dehydration because it can increase sweating and also can
cause serotonin syndrome when used in conjunction with MDMA, MDEA, and
MDA.

"Pills are at least 75 mgs and usually are from 80-120 mgs."

Um, no. We only wish. Pills can be anything from 0mg to who knows what.

"One way to see of the pill is pure MDMA or has been altered with other
drugs is to look at the color. Pure MDMA pills are white without any
impurities."

Haha. No.

"will sell "Extacy Kits" that test the quantities of the pill and also
determine the strength of it."

Maybe it will tell you if the pill has MDMA in it, but it wont tell you
anything else.

"Extacy"

It's Ecstacy.

There are a ton of other mistakes in this article. Who the heck wrote
it? It really does more harm then good.

"I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and causes 
me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war, 
corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong 
its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-Abraham Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

  "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

From: AndyW <andy@saturn5.com>
X-X-Sender: andy@atari
To: Cheryl H <cheryl1393@yahoo.com>
cc: "scosol@scosol.org" <scosol@scosol.org>, <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
In-Reply-To: <20040721205319.73837.qmail@web90003.mail.scd.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0407211554420.1989-100000@atari>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Seeking help for a friend... [nrr]


Perhaps just dealing with being shy doesn't mean you need to brand him as
a problem (force feeding E, going to counseling, anti-depressants /
anti-anxiety, etc).  You sound like my old doctor, and you don't even get
offerred a new set of Pings when you sign your thousandth Zoloft scrip.

My recommendation is get some sets of DJs, he'll tend to like some more
than others.  When those DJs play, go check it out.  He'll feel more
comfortable because he was involved in the choice.  When he feels he owns
the situation more, the shyness will be less of an issue.  Hell, he
doesn't have to experience it the same way you do... try a music first
approach.  The music can grow on him in a totally non-social way... so
he'll be dealing on some level when you get out there rather than feeling
like a total stranger.

I still have trouble meeting people, or not making an ass of myself.  But
I have learned, with the help of my friends to embrace my lame ass (just
don't take pictures of my doing so).

andyw

-&e->>>get him out this time... I hope I didn't scare him further into his
-&e->>>shelll... If anyone has any advice as to how I can help my firend out of
-&e->>>his shell, please email me...
-&e->>
-&e->>
-&e->> uh... well my sarcastic side wants to ask if narcs really do have friends,
-&e->> but I'll be nice
-&e->>
-&e->> this is such a classic story - I have heard this several times and the
-&e->> ending is usually "then he took some E and life did a u-turn"
-&e->>
-&e->> basically, he needs to learn new behaviors, new ways of looking at the
-&e->> world - talk therapy is useful, but it takes so long to wear away
-&e->> the roughness and things that are out of place. it may all make sense at a
-&e->> intellectual level, but getting that understanding into
-&e->> automatic behaviors (that self reinforce) is hard.
-&e->>
-&e->> drugs are useful too to deal with the biological end of things, but they
-&e->> are not the only solution/cure all, despite all the advertising.
-&e->> they are only useful as supportive tools.
-&e->>
-&e->> as for the non-illegal drug way (Eli Lilly would recommend Paxil for his
-&e->> social anxiety disorder, but MDMA is cheaper, not as addictive, and
-&e->> more effective, if properly used), you really can't do much until he is
-&e->> ready to change. He has to get to the point where the cost of changing is
-&e->> less than that of not changing. all you can do is offer support and
-&e->> perhaps try pushing his buttons a bit to shake him out of his "trance".
-&e->> but that takes some skill and you have to make sure your own ego is not
-&e->> getting stroked in doing so.
-&e->>
-&e->> doug
-&e->>
-&e->>
-&e->> ---------------------------------------------------------------------
-&e->> To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
-&e->> For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

-----Original Message-----
From: AndyW [mailto:andy@saturn5.com]=20
Sent: Wednesday, July 21, 2004 4:01 PM
To: Cheryl H
Cc: scosol@scosol.org; sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Seeking help for a friend... [nrr]


Perhaps just dealing with being shy doesn't mean you need to brand him =
as
a problem (force feeding E, going to counseling, anti-depressants /
anti-anxiety, etc).  You sound like my old doctor, and you don't even =
get
offerred a new set of Pings when you sign your thousandth Zoloft scrip.

My recommendation is get some sets of DJs, he'll tend to like some more
than others.  When those DJs play, go check it out.  He'll feel more
comfortable because he was involved in the choice.  When he feels he =
owns
the situation more, the shyness will be less of an issue.  Hell, he
doesn't have to experience it the same way you do... try a music first
approach.  The music can grow on him in a totally non-social way... so
he'll be dealing on some level when you get out there rather than =
feeling
like a total stranger.

I still have trouble meeting people, or not making an ass of myself.  =
But
I have learned, with the help of my friends to embrace my lame ass (just
don't take pictures of my doing so).

andyw

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Seeking help for a friend... [nrr]

	I really don't understand why you guys seem to think Cheryl is a narc. 
She didn't come on here trying to buy Ecstasy or something, just 
looking for advice. It seems to me that a real narc would email a bunch 
of people from the list individually.

	Perhaps something like, "Sorry to bother you, I'm having kind of an 
emergency, I'm supposed to have a private birthday party for my best 
friend this weekend. We had planned to surprise her by making it an E 
party and made a bunch of preparations... unfortunately the guy who was 
supposed to supply the favors got busted, and now we have no one to 
turn to. Do you know anyone who could come up with about 30 hits on 
short notice? We have money and paying will not be a problem."

	Cheryl doesn't seem like a narc to me, just a concerned friend. It's a 
pretty ugly accusation unless there's some real evidence.

Peace, love & liberty,
					<<< Starchild >>>

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: hillsborough tragedy of 1989 and the SUN scandal, finally an apology!

disaster, where 86 people lost they life crushed in one of the cages.

the sun the day after the event published a front page story in disfavor of 
the liverpool fans, stating that some of them had "animal behavior" 
urinating on police officers trying to help the inured and picking pockets 
of the victims.

15 years late the sun apologizes, admitting "it was worst mistake in the 
history of journalism"!

 Starchild, 
 
Thank you  :)  It pains me to see good hearted people lonely and isolated all the time...  
Its funny you brought up a "public speaking class" becasue hes taking one right now...  He's doing very well, despite his flushed look when he gives his presentation...  :)

Cheryl

Starchild <sfdreamer@earthlink.net> wrote:
Cheryl,

It's nice that you are concerned and trying to coax your friend out of 
his shell. Perhaps taking a public speaking class or joining 
Toastmasters (a sort of hobby group for people to practice giving 
speeches) could be the thing for him. A class environment like this is 
generally more supportive and less socially stressful while still 
helping build confidence to speak to people in social situations.

I found the public speaking class I took at SF State to be good not 
only for improving my comfort level with getting up and talking in 
front of a group, but also for the feedback that gave me a greater 
awareness of things like breathing, my tendency to mumble, speaking too 
rapidly, body language, posture, gestures, etc., that can cause 
problems for peoples' interactions without them being consciously aware 
of an issue until it is pointed out by someone else. Kind of like when 
there is something green hanging out of your nose. 8)

Another strategy might be continually introducing your friend to 
people in social settings, and steering them toward topics or styles of 
communicating that you know he is more comfortable with. You can have a 
secret code between the two of you so that he can nudge you or 
something when he needs to let you know he's feeling like "I can't take 
this any more, I have to go stand over in the corner now."

At parties, perhaps your friend might be more comfortable expressing 
himself physically first rather than interacting with strangers, such 
as by dancing with you or someone he knows, or twirling glowsticks on 
his own, or even just taking pictures of other people. If you have a 
polaroid or digital camera to take someone's picture and be able to 
give or show it to them, that's a great ice breaker.

Having something to do with his mouth could also help reduce the 
feeling of pressure to talk. If your friend doesn't smoke, give him a 
lollipop or better yet a pacifier to suck on. People won't expect him 
to communicate as much, and will probably assume he's on E and become 
more friendly, especially if he's dressed like a candy raver. 8)

Groove on,
<<< Starchild >>>


On Tuesday, July 20, 2004, at 08:05 PM, wrote:

> I'm pretty much a lurker, but couldn't resist posting. I suffer from 
> the
> same type of problems as your friend, although not as severe, and I 
> found
> mustering up the will to go out and approach people incredibly 
> dificult.
>
> My advice:
>
> Encourage him to continue going out and make new friends, but don't be
> pushy. I found forcing myself into uncomfortable situations, extremely 
> hard,
> but extremely rewarding. He will stumble and fall, and thats ok, he 
> simply
> needs to keep going. As he gets more comfortable, and meets new 
> people, it
> will get easier. Growth only comes through pain and struggle, and 
> maybe if
> he's willing, try some MDMA. It was used as a psychotherapeutic tool 
> for
> cases similar to this 20-30 years ago. It will help break the Ice and 
> help
> him to open up. Trust me, I know =)
>
> I wish you and your friend the best of luck, I don't envy his road 
> ahead but
> believe me it will get easier.
>
> I'm gonna go back to lurking now =)
>
> If your friend wants to talk he can IM me at:
>
> AIM: jarvik1197
>
> -j

> never seen anyone come up with soo many creative ways of avoiding a 
> simple
> conversation.)
>
> Afterwards:
>
> I asked him how he liked it, and he stated that It was coo, and he 
> wishes he
> could be like those people... I tried telling him to simply be 
> himself, and
> to relax. Afterall, they are simply people who are there to have a good
> time, and not out to judge him, or ridicule him... I know for a fact 
> tthat
> he dug the music... (when he wasn't looking, I spotted him a few times

> prevent him from doing so... It was a minor miracle that I was able to 
> get

> shelll... If

>Perhaps just dealing with being shy doesn't mean you need to brand him as
>a problem (force feeding E, going to counseling, anti-depressants /
>anti-anxiety, etc).  You sound like my old doctor, and you don't even get
>offerred a new set of Pings when you sign your thousandth Zoloft scrip.
>
>My recommendation is get some sets of DJs, he'll tend to like some more
>than others.  When those DJs play, go check it out.  He'll feel more
>comfortable because he was involved in the choice.  When he feels he owns
>the situation more, the shyness will be less of an issue.  Hell, he
>doesn't have to experience it the same way you do... try a music first
>approach.  The music can grow on him in a totally non-social way... so
>he'll be dealing on some level when you get out there rather than feeling
>like a total stranger.
>
>I still have trouble meeting people, or not making an ass of myself.  But
>I have learned, with the help of my friends to embrace my lame ass (just
>don't take pictures of my doing so).
>
>andyw

Subject: [sfraves] Fw: [nyc-raves] Does a New York DJ need a license?  Village Voice
 7/02/04


>>From: legalizedancingnyc@yahoogroups.com
>>Subject: Does a New York DJ need a license?  Village Voice 7/02/04
>>
>> http://www.villagevoice.com/issues/0427/flylife.php
>>ny mirror
>>
>>
>>Fly Life
>>by Tricia Romano
>>Licensed to DJ
>>Does a New York DJ need a license?
>>July 2nd, 2004 4:45 PM
>>
>>Just when you thought New York nightlife couldn't get any worse, it does.
>>JEREMY RODRIGUEZ is perhaps the first person in the history of the world to
>>get a ticket for DJ'ing. The Texas native was spinning on June 5 at Cash
>>Checking, a new bar in Williamsburg, when police paid a visit to the venue.
>>After spending considerable time speaking to one of the venue's employees,
>>the police asked for the DJ's ID and then walked off with it for 40 minutes. 
>>
>>When they returned, they handed him back his ID-with a pink slip of paper
>>slyly folded underneath. It was a summons for Rodriguez, who had only been
>>spinning for a short time before the cops' arrival, to appear in court on
>>July 22 for "Operation of Sound Reproductive Device Without a Permit." The
>>section of the New York City noise code cited, 10.108.23, says a police
>>spokesperson, allows a violation to be given to a person operating "any sound
>>production device in a public area, even if it's in a bar. If music can be
>>heard from public sidewalk," then there can be a violation. However, it seems
>>a bit strange to cite the DJ, not the bar. The NYPD spokesperson would only
>>say, "I don't know the circumstances." 
>>
>>Rodriguez, who is not the club's resident DJ, says that when he arrived on
>>the corner of North 3rd Street and Kent Avenue and got out of his car, "I
>>could hear the music, so it was kind of loud. The employee was there, so I
>>thought it was OK." He said the employee had come over and turned the volume
>>down a "significant" amount when the cops arrived. The owner, THOMAS
>>SANDBICHLER, says, "The violation was given because we had the door open and
>>the music spilled into the street. They thereby said we were operating
>>amplified equipment on the street. That's not part of the license. It's a
>>bullshit summons." 
>>
>>The bar's already tallied up several violations, says Sandbichler. ("They
>>give out tickets like candy," he says.) The visits are fueled by 311 calls,
>>which may become more frequent citywide if the mayor's plan to overhaul the
>>noise code goes through. (According to the mayor's office, noise ranks number
>>one in complaints to the 311 line, and averages 1,000 calls a day.) While the
>>mayor's proposing to do away with some provisions that are too vague (such as
>>limiting the standard of judging a noise complaint as "unreasonable to a
>>person of normal sensitivities"), other suggested changes may turn out to be
>>more strict (such as throwing out the noise meter and going by the "plainly
>>audible" standard). Wait, I'm deaf-that might work wonderfully! Meanwhile,
>>Rodriguez, who just moved back to the States after six years in Barcelona, is
>>probably wondering why in the hell he ever returned. 
>>
>>
>>
>>    
>>
>  
>

>
> >To all-
> >A sobering portrayal in the NY Times today on the effects of Meth on=20
> >the brain.
> >
> >sheila
> >
> >
> >July 20, 2004
> >This Is Your Brain on Meth: A 'Forest Fire' of Damage
> >By SANDRA BLAKESLEE
> >
> >People who do not want to wait for old age to shrink their brains and
bring
> >on memory loss now have a quicker alternative - abuse methamphetamine =

> >for
a
> >decade or so and watch the brain cells vanish into the night.
> >
> >The first high-resolution M.R.I. study of methamphetamine addicts=20
> >shows
"a
> >forest fire of brain damage," said Dr. Paul Thompson, an expert on=20
> >brain mapping at the University of California, Los Angeles. "We=20
> >expected some brain changes but didn't expect so much tissue to be=20
> >destroyed."
> >
> >The image, published in the June 30 issue of The Journal of=20
> >Neuroscience, shows the brain's surface and deeper limbic system. Red =

> >areas show the greatest tissue loss.
> >
> >The limbic region, involved in drug craving, reward, mood and=20
> >emotion,
lost
> >11 percent of its tissue. "The cells are dead and gone," Dr. Thompson
said.
> >Addicts were depressed, anxious and unable to concentrate.
> >
> >The brain's center for making new memories, the hippocampus, lost 8
percent
> >of its tissue, comparable to the brain deficits in early Alzheimer's. =

> >The methamphetamine addicts fared significantly worse on memory tests =

> >than healthy people the same age.
> >
> >The study examined 22 people in their 30's who had used=20
> >methamphetamine
for
> >10 years, mostly by smoking it, and 21 controls matched for age. On=20
> >average, the addicts used an average of four grams a week and said=20
> >they
had
> >been high on 19 of the 30 days before the study began.
> >
> >Methamphetamine is an addictive stimulant made in clandestine
laboratories
> >nationwide. When taken by mouth, snorted, injected or smoked, it=20
> >produces intense pleasure by releasing the brain's reward chemical,=20
> >dopamine. With chronic use, the brains that overstimulate dopamine=20
> >and another brain chemical, serotonin, are permanently compromised.
> >
> >The study held one other surprise, Dr. Thompson said: white matter,=20
> >composed of nerve fibers that connect different areas, was severely=20
> >inflamed, making the addicts' brains 10 percent larger than normal.=20
> >"This was shocking," he said. But there was one piece of good news:=20
> >the white matter was not dead. With abstinence, it might recover.
>
>
>
>

pretty ugly accusation unless there's some real evidence.

>>> looking at the
>>>> world - talk therapy is useful, but it takes so long to
>>> wear away
>>>> the roughness and things that are out of place. it may
>> all
>>> make sense at a
>>>> intellectual level, but getting that understanding into
>>>> automatic behaviors (that self reinforce) is hard.
>>>>
>>>> drugs are useful too to deal with the biological end of
>>> things, but they
>>>> are not the only solution/cure all, despite all the
>>> advertising.
>>>> they are only useful as supportive tools.
>>>>
>>>> as for the non-illegal drug way (Eli Lilly would
>> recommend
>>> Paxil for his
>>>> social anxiety disorder, but MDMA is cheaper, not as
>>> addictive, and
>>>> more effective, if properly used), you really can't do
>> much
>>> until he is
>>>> ready to change. He has to get to the point where the
>> cost
>>> of changing is
>>>> less than that of not changing. all you can do is offer
>>> support and
>>>> perhaps try pushing his buttons a bit to shake him out of
>>> his "trance".
>>>> but that takes some skill and you have to make sure your
>>> own ego is not
>>>> getting stroked in doing so.
>>>>
>>>> doug
>>>>
>>>>
>>>>
>>>
>>
> ---------------------------------------------------------------------
>>>> To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
>>>> For additional commands, e-mail:
>> sfraves-help@hyperreal.org
>>>>
>>>>
>>>> 
>>>> ---------------------------------

>>>> Vote for the stars of Yahoo!'s next ad campaign!

Subject: [sfraves] This Friday!!  SKYNET [UK] @ SOMA Sessions

SOMA Sessions
SF Drum 'n Bass Fourth Fridays
http://www.somasessions.com

SOMA Sessions is San Francisco's premier Friday night
Jungle/Drum 'n Bass party.  On every Fourth Friday we
invite leading hand-picked DJ talents from around the
globe to play extended sets in an intimate setting
which forms the idea of the "session"...


Friday July 23, 2004

SKYNET (Skynet Recordings, Discrete, nVision - UK)
Following his early years as a self-aware nuclear
defense system hell-bent on the destruction of the
humans, Brighton's Skynet kindled his creative side
and forged innovative D&B with partner Stakka on the
Liftin' Spirit, Audio Blueprint and Underfire labels.
Producing together since 1993, their efforts
culminated in the timeless Clockwork LP of 2001.
Winding forward, 2004 finds Skynet bearing a prolific
solo output and no fewer than three imprints- Skynet
Recs, Discrete and nVision. Join The Terminator
himself on this mission into the future of
techstep....

RANDO (Levitated Recordings, Phuturo - SF)

DJ M (SOMA Sessions)


** Discount $8 presale will call tickets available now
at http://somasessions.com **

Tickets:  $8 presale, $10 door
Hours:  10:30pm - 3am
Entry:  21+ with photo ID
Bar:  $3 drink specials all night

Sponsored by:
RINSE Magazine [http://rinsemag.com] - Drum & Bass /
Jungle / Breakbeats

Location:
AsiaSF, 201 Ninth Street at Howard St, San Francisco
Before the show try AsiaSF's Cal-Asian cuisine and
nightly performances! For dinner reservations call
415.255.ASIA or visit http://asiasf.com.

Branding & print design:
Ryan @ Citizen-7 [http://www.citizen-7.com]

Hey I just wanted to add that I've been trying to coordinate a monthly for
George and myself at Anu for a while now, and that this night is a bit of a
last minute test run to see how we fit.  I'd appreciate support from anyone
that can stop down between the BBQ and Tyler's Bday mayhem even if just for
one drink, a good showing will help our cause in getting the monthly.  I'll
be hitting up both myself, I hope there are still some sane people left by
the time we show up at Tyler's...

Oh and I promise a jamming set from Sen-Sei and myself, we had a blast
playing at LivingRoom Lounge together last month and might be recording this
one to play on XM Satellite Radio at a later date, plus with George's bass
slappin' goodness thrown in how can you go wrong?  ;)

-Andrew

Subject: [sfraves] christian bloch, techno in SF, miss kittin + 

nice!  i'm excited to see christian bloch is playing! 
i hear that he's living out here now, so hopefully
we'll get to hear him more often.  i got to hear him i
believe play live at an afterparty last year after
movement in detroit and he played some amazing acid. 
so thanks to whoever's organized this.  

as for techno in SF, the main tips i got were Soda at
the Rx Gallery (3rd saturday, i believe), Hugger
Mugger, and then i'll have to dig through my emails
for more and more info.  actually, if anyone promoting
these events and other techno parties wants to email
the list again w/ the info, that would be much easier.
 

also, folks should check out miss kittin at mezzanine
next friday w/ matthew dear and the ghostly int'l
tour.  i saw part of miss kittin's set at sonar and
she was great.  word on the street is she spins a good
deal of techno  and her mixing is hot.   (it was
definitely great at sonar.)  

yah, it's been hard being back in the bay after being
in barcelona.  i like being among my friends again,
but for me, the nightlife scene is just not doing it. 
i've been trying to go out more lately and it's been a
bit disappointing, though i don't really expect much. 
  the spaz party i went to was severely underattended,
which was a disappointment as i was really looking
forward to it, and the last few spaz parties i went to
(in the fall and winter) were really good, and made me
feel like a party kid again.  i went out to hear boo
williams last night at the top, and ok, i know it's
deep house, but when i heard him at rawhide several
years ago he was great.  this time it was just, uh,
really cheesy and not my cup of tea.  and not many
people there.  at least my househead friend liked it. 
there's not many events we can go out to together
since our tastes are usually diametrically opposed.  

is techno big in any other cities in the u.s.? 
(besides new york).  i find myself scouring the
internet looking for events in other west coast cities
and feel a bit pathetic.  i mean, i have other
interests in my life besides techno, but  i just need
a good night out dancing to keep me inspired
sometimes.  

oh, finally, philip sherburne, i tried to reply to
your reply to me about sf techno, etc., but for some
reason i can't reply to your email - it just comes
back failure delivery.  :( 

monikat

From: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
	boundary="=====================_644707==.ALT"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] SRR:  Global Calendar Change!

--=====================_644707==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed


Global Calendar Change!



Let's Make the Circumpolar Rainbow Bridge!

Or if you don't believe in such things, another excuse
to go enjoy some time with friends on a Sunday
afternoon. ;)


Declaration of The Great Calendar Change of 2004
(To be read at every Day Out of Time celebration at
high noon)
On this Day Out of Time, White Spectral Mirror, the
365th day of the Thirteen Moon/28-day calendar year,
we, the people, are gathered in numerous celebrations
and festivals at sites around the world -why? Because
we are celebrating the Great Calendar Change of 2004.
As of the next day, Blue Crystal Storm, the first day
of the Thirteen Moon/28-day calendar year, there will
be a New Time on Earth. What does this mean?

It means that for the first time in human history, the
people of the Earth - not from one country, but from
many countries and diverse cultural traditions - will
be in support of and already following the new
calendar. The times in which we are living are
dangerous and complex. The Earth's future is in the
balance. The people know that things will not get
better until we are living in a New Time. There are
but a few years until the cycle of history closes in
2012. The people know this. The signs are everywhere
that the great standards are changing. A new way must
be found for the next evolutionary leap. We can no
longer wait for a Caesar or a Pope, a president or a
prime minister to issue the mandate for this kind of
change. That is why we, the people of the Earth, have
undertaken this change by ourselves and of our own
volition. It is reason and common sense, intelligence
and compassion for all of life that move us to make
this change. We know that the future is ours to
create.

In over 90 countries now the new harmonic standard of
Thirteen Moons/28 days has spread and is now being
followed. This is an irreversible change. This is a
movement that cannot nor will not be stopped. It is
the force of evolution itself. It is in accord with
the principles of higher spiritual evolution. It is in
accord with the transformation of our biosphere into
the noosphere - the unified mental field of planet
Earth. This is a cause of the greatest joy and
celebration. We, the people, know that by 2012, Earth
and all of her tribes and nations will be unified
under the new standard of peace, Thirteen Moons/28
days.

Though supported by the League of Nations, the
International Chamber of Commerce and individuals as
diverse as Eastman Kodak and Mahatma Gandhi, the
Calendar Reform movement of the 1920s and 1930s, did
not succeed. But its efforts were not in vain. It
prepared the ground for such a change. In the seventy
years since that noble effort, the reasons for making
the change have become blatant and glaring. The
disorder of society, reflecting the disorder of an
irregular standard of measuring time, is now worldwide
and epidemic in scope. This time the urgent call for
calendar change has come from a people's movement that
has already succeeded in becoming a widespread
planetary phenomenon. What seems impossible today,
will be common sense tomorrow. Such is the obvious
logic of a perpetual standard of measuring our time,
the harmonic standard of Thirteen Moons/28-days.

Henceforth, may this wave of the future penetrate all
sectors of global society. May those who doubt find
renewed faith. May those who stand on the side lines
wondering, jump in and find a new, unifying commitment
to a future of peace. We who make this change, do so
under the Banner of Peace, an internationally
recognized instrument for establishing world peace
through culture. For that reason this Day Out of Time
is also known as the International Peace through
Culture Festival. On this day we pray for universal
forgiveness. Meditating on our unity, marching and
dancing in rhythm to the New Time, we proclaim: Time
is no longer money. Time is art. May peace prevail on
Earth. May the standard of the New Time call forth
that day soon when our swords are beat into plowshares
and children of all races, colors and creeds are
playing and praying together in the sunshine of the
promised land whose time has finally come. May the New
Time of peace prevail on Earth!

~~~~~~~~~~~~~

 From Lake Baikal to Venezuela,
from Australia to Oregon;
The Great Calendar Change of 2004,
The World is Entering the New Time!

~~~~~~~~~~~~~

San Francisco Day-out-of-Time
Events > Community

San Francisco, California

San Francisco Day-out-of-Time

When: July 25, 2004, White Spectral Mirror,
Noon-Beyond
Where: Golden Gate Park, Hippie Hill
What: Potluck, drum circle, costume party

Organized by Marco
E-mail: 
<http://sea1fd.sea1.hotmail.msn.com/cgi-bin//cgi-bin/compose?curmbox=F000000001&a=0f5f269ae27f2e1dcd6d856038105fa4&mailto=1&to=LenzaVista@aol.com&msg=MSG1090693117.31&start=1136440&len=81137&src=&type=x>LenzaVista@aol.com

www.foundationforthelawoftime.org/d...globaldoot.html





Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and causes 
me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war, 
corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong 
its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-Abraham Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

  "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

--=====================_644707==.ALT--

maybe i'm just stubborn, but i find myself irritated
as hell by the "New Calendar/Thirteen Moon" etc.
stuff.  sure, i like for us to work with a thirteen
moon cycle as opposed to the arbitrary months.  but as
a pagan, with roots in europe, i refuse to throw out
the seasonal and cyclical pagan calendar i follow
which is pre-christian and pre-capitalist to start
using a "new global" system with symbols i simply do
not relate to, and i resent it being pushed on me as
"THE" new calendar, and "THE" way to save the world.

"no, i want to get payed for the whole thing, and if i make an ad, then the people should have to pay for my ad too, and i don't feel like doing any ads for anyone today." :)

From: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
	boundary="=====================_5197000==.ALT"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] NRR: UK GOVERNMENT REVEALS PLANS TO VACCINATE CHILDREN AGAINST
  DRUGS

--=====================_5197000==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

For Immediate Release: JULY 26, 2004

UK GOVERNMENT REVEALS PLANS TO VACCINATE CHILDREN AGAINST DRUGS

Children may be "vaccinated" against the effects of cocaine and other drugs 
in a plan recently revealed by the UK government, reports the well-regarded 
British newspaper, <http://en.groundspring.org/en/go?j=5452812&u=35762>The 
Independent. The article explains that "Doctors would immunize children at 
risk of becoming smokers or drug users with an injection" and that the 
program would operate in a way similar to the "current nationwide measles, 
mumps and rubella vaccination programme." Further the authors reveal that 
"such vaccinations are being developed by pharmaceutical companies and are 
due to hit the market within two years."

Earlier this month, the US-based Center for Cognitive Liberty & Ethics 
published a relevant and timely report, which addresses the imminent 
emergence of these same "pharmacotherapy" drugs into the US market. Among 
other well-documented information, the report notes that the US National 
Institute on Drug Abuse (NIDA) has allocated $12 million dollars to Xenova, 
the UK-based pharmaceutical company running trials on the "anti-cocaine" 
vaccine mentioned in the article.

The plan currently being researched and debated in the UK is therefore of 
concern to those monitoring trends in US drug policy. The CCLE's policy 
report, "Pharmacotherapy and the Future of the Drug War" is the first 
publication to address the ethical and legal dimensions of this new breed 
of pharmaceuticals. The report acknowledges potential benefits if these 
drugs are used voluntarily, but warns that coercive or compulsory use of 
such drugs to "immunize" drug abusers or "at risk" potential users would 
violate a number of legal rights and trample the fundamental human right to 
freedom of thought.

Richard Glen Boire, a legal scholar at the CCLE, believes that vaccinating 
children with "anti-drug" drugs would be "alarming and unlawful, and would 
signal the first time that neuropharmaceuticals were overtly used to 
enforce government policy."

Aside from the human rights concerns, the UK plan raises serious health 
questions regarding the long-term effects of these drugs on the complex 
neurochemistry of the brain.

The CCLE pharmacotherapy report directly addresses the potential legal and 
health consequences of US implementation of a compulsory "anti-drug" 
vaccination program, which now seems closer to reality than ever before in 
light of the UK government's recent announcement.

Pharmacotherapy and the Future of the Drug War is available 
<http://en.groundspring.org/en/go?j=5452812&u=35763>here. Hard copies of 
the report are available for $30.00; a PDF may be accessed free of charge.

For more information, please contact:
Stephanie Anderson, Communications & Publications Coordinator
Center for Cognitive Liberty & Ethics
Phone & Fax: 530.750.7912
<mailto:info@cognitiveliberty.org>info@cognitiveliberty.org




Moksha Tribe: www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101: http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

nothing."
-Helen Keller

being."
-William James

"It's taken me all my life to learn what not to play."
-Dizzy Gillespie

Subject: [sfraves] [bsp]  GO FUNK YOURSELF!   Wednesdays @ The Top

------=_NextPart_000_0056_01C4745D.5C8BC1A0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

 
Hey everybody!  After 7 years or so, Audible Colors is
changing its name and broadening its horizons!  I'm also
joining the crew in promotional and booking efforts, and 
promise you many pleasant surprises in store. What WON'T
change is our dedication to bringing you the finest in local
and out-of-town DJ talent each and every week.  What 
WILL change is you'll be seeing participation from a variety
of new crews, as well as some tech-house, micro-house,
and minimal techno entering the mix along with the usual
bumpin' house you've come to expect on Wednesday
nights. Another reason to check out this night is that the
residents, Sammy D and Justin Martin, are not only great
DJs, but are extremely talented up-and-coming producers
with tracks coming out on Derrick Carter's Classic label, in
addition to their tracks already out on Ben Watt's Buzzin'
Fly, Utensil, Roam, & DHP, with many more to come.
These guys are hot and only getting hotter, ya heard?
Come check it out sometime, you won't be disappointed!
 
-------> Greg  "Big Appetite" Bird
 
 
NOW.on with the show!
_________________________________________________
 
Justin Martin and Sammy D
invite you to.
 
"GO FUNK YOURSELF!"
 
every Wednesday at The Top
424 Haight St. in the Lower Haight
10pm-2am / 21+ / $5
_________________________________________________
 
This week's special guests
from Good Family Recordings:
 
=> MIKE FRUGALETTI & DEE <=
 
(chunky dirty house and tech-house)
 
http://www.goodfamilyrecordings.com/
http://www.goodbeats.com/v3/profiles/mikefrugaletti/bio.htm
 
plus residents Justin Martin & Sammy D (Classic / Roam)
 
http://www.rookrecords.com/JustinMartin.htm
http://www.rookrecords.com/Sammy_D.htm
 
________________________________________________
 
Come on down for another night of stiff drinks, hearty laughs,
and whumpin' beats on The Top's newly revamped soundsystem!
 
 

------=_NextPart_000_0056_01C4745D.5C8BC1A0--

Yo.
 
I haven't been subscribed to this list for quite some time, but back
when I was it seemed like there were dozens, if not hundreds, of
messages each day.  I've seen about 5 messages today.  What's the story?
Are there still lots of people subscribed but just not that much
activity? Or have most people "jumped ship?"  I'd be interested to hear
from a long-time subscriber as to just what has been going on with this
list and where it stands today.
 
Thanks!
 
-----------> Greg Bird

Subject: [sfraves] *~STILLDREAM~* Aug 13, 14 & 15th +Tickets in Stores Friday+

Alright everybody the day is here, time to let the cat out of the bag. The 
moment we have been waiting all year for!

Stilldream 4 Year Anniversary Campout

Date: August 13, 14, & 15th

Full Line-Up!

Aaron Liberator, UK
www.sufcollective.co.uk
(Stay Up Forever, Smitten, Cluster, Low Rent Operator, High Wire, Wah Wah)
Need some information on the liberators? Here is an interview:
http://www.truelove.co.uk/labels/suf/biography.htm
His vibrant and funky techno style mixes the London sound (RAW, Hydraulix, 
SUF)
with party techno from Europe. His fresh vibrant and funky dj sets appeal to 
a wide audience
of hungry clubbers, ravers and partyheads  be it on the beaches of Spain, 
in the midst of Russia
or in a warehouse party / free festival back home in the UK.

Mystre (Frequency 8, SF)
Detonate (Klubstompers, Seattle)
Sarah Shoxx (Klubstompers, Seattle)
Effendi (Klubstompers, Seattle)
Nick Tornetta (www.nicktornetta.com, Seattle)

This will be an all weekend Camping event, with over 40 dj's (showcasing 
techno, trance and house),
international headliners as well as a bunch of your local favorites. After 
last years rockin anniversary
we have been working to make this one the best Stilldream Party Ever!

Interested in vending for this event please contact us
at promo@techno-truth.com

Subject: Re: [sfraves] a question about SFR

Seems like there are still a lot of people here, though the lion's
share of posts are from a handful of individuals ;)  There are posting
jags about this and that, some BSPs you won't see elsewhere, (some for
good reason) and good conversations, sometimes.

..and sometimes people get in 30-post-long strings about some candy
kids' spelling errors.

Same as it ever was, I suppose.  It's still a good way to stay
connected with new scene folk and what's going on outside the deep
underground.

Cheers,
George C
www.djorigami.com

Subject: [sfraves] Carbon Community on 90.5 KSJS - TODAY!!!

Check it out!  Carbon Community and DJ Icon throw down.  Perfect warmup 
session for FLUX on Friday night.

-----------------
Bassline FM
Thursdays 2pm to 5pm on 90.5KSJS
Tune in online at:  http://www.ksjs.org/ksjs_live.html


Get ready for another high energy packed show this Thursday. Texas's own 
Dave from Carbon Community will be coming down doing a live pa performance 
inside the studio of KSJS . A live pa performance has never been done 
before, on Basslinefm.

As well as DJ Icon, making her debut onto the program. You may remember her 
from MTV's "The Wade Robson Project", an amateur dance competition 
television show.

These two acts will be performing at a party called Flux, taking place this 
Friday at the Shadow Lounge. Be sure to give us a call to get on the guest 
list this Thursday at (408) 924-KSJS.


07-29 Dave from Carbon Community, DJ Icon

Carbon Community

Two things are for certain. If you see The Carbon Community on a flyer, you 
can be sure that it will be a show like you have never seen before. 
Secondly, this is only the beginning for the dynamic duo. The Carbon 
Community has a sound that will propel them far into the future of 
electronic music, and will establish them as a pillar in the breakbeat 
world.

DJ Icon

ICON has been known for spinning a hybrid of Trance, UK Hard House, and 
Nu-Skool Breaks. She has a unique style of mixing these genres together to 
create a slamming high-energy set that gets people moving on the dance 
floor. Gradually over the past few years, ICON made the transition and 
natural progression from Four-on-Four beats to Breakbeat fusions. Currently 
she focuses mostly on all forms of Breaks including Nu-Skool, Funky, 
Trancy/Melodic, and Electro. However, ICON knows the importance of 
versatility so she still plays other genres of music when appropriate.

-------------
< Brandon / DJ Bam >

DJ Bam - serving breaks and beats
http://www.invibe.com/bam

July 24th:  Euphoric Dreams 2 @ Reno area outdoor venue
July 30th:  Flux w/ Carbon Community @ Shadow Lounge
August 6th: Regulus @ UG venue
August 20th: Mighty Breaks w/ Grandmaster Flash and 2 Bad Mice @ Mighty
August 21st: Vintage w/ Grandmaster Flash, 2 Bad Mice, Tony @ All-ages 
Oaktown venue

Subject: Re: [sfraves] a question about SFR

A few numbers for ya...

The highest list subscription base that I know of was in summer '99, ~1150
email addys

Today we are at ~425.

Which kinda jives with back in my early years on this list, I believe 
summer '96 was about ~450-500.

Oh and the above numbers don't include digest subscriptions.

SFR definitely ebbs and flows, it's certainly interesting to watch it over 
a long period of time. This list has assumed a number of different
personalities over the years. Lately it's been pretty chill, drama-free,
which I think nice. But I guess the crazy flame-wars this list used to 
have were pretty exciting too ;-)

-t

------------------------------------------
terry estioko     | terry@hyperreal.org
SFRaves moderator | http://www.sfraves.org

From sfraves-return-114226-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Thu Jul 29 17:27:28 2004
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-114226-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 54728 invoked by uid 1103); 29 Jul 2004 17:27:27 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 54713 invoked from network); 29 Jul 2004 17:27:27 -0000
Message-ID: <20040729172725.93769.qmail@web21528.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Thu, 29 Jul 2004 10:27:25 -0700 (PDT)
From: Peter Rothman <dangrsmind@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] [SRR] Question for the DJs: Improving my DJ Skills

So I've been DJing for about 3 years now in the
bedroom (well actually the livingroom) and I've
finally gotten to the point where most of the time I
can do good mixes.  However, I note that when anything
goes wrong, i.e. my kids distract me, I have to go to
the bathroom, I've had one too many or one too few
beers, etc. my mixing falls apart quickly.  I'm sort
of ready to play for an audience but worried that my
mixing will collapse the first time I try.

Most of the time when this happens I find that I
simply can get a good estimate of whether the new
record is faster or slower with the headphines no
matter what I do.  Of course if I bring it in to the
mix I can hear its wrong and usually can adjust it
that way, but I couldn't do that during a live or
recorded set.  I'm looking for suggestions on how to
improve my skills on this point.  Anyone have some
suggested exercises that might help me work on these
sorts of issues?

I don't have great equipment (Stanton 80s, Numark
mixer) , but its what I could afford at the time.  I
got my headphones for free from a failed Internet
music company MusicBank.  I currently can't afford to
replace my equipment so even if that's a lot of my
problem I need to work around it.  Oh and my tape deck
died so I currently can't record my mixes.

When I started out I had a bit of money so I took
lessons from a great DJ and teacher friend of mine,
but now I can longer afford lessons.  So although I
know some folks on the list are providing DJ lessons
for money, I can't afford that.  I wish I could.

FWIW I play a variety of house styles, mostly SF style
funky house with some deep house,  tech house, and
progressive depending on my mood.  I'm interested in
intermixing, creating compositions with records, not
just simple blending of one track into the next.  I've
messed around a bit with mixing spoken word and other
weird shit as well with some pretty good results. 
That's what I'm trying to do anyway.

Any help will be greatly appreciated!!

Peace,

Peter

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Mime-Version: 1.0 (Apple Message framework v618)
In-Reply-To: <20040729172725.93769.qmail@web21528.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20040729172725.93769.qmail@web21528.mail.yahoo.com>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII; format=flowed

From: Philip.X.Diaz <st_indigo@earthlink.net>
Date: Thu, 29 Jul 2004 10:48:48 -0700
To: SFRaves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.618)
X-ELNK-Trace: b815ca255710aa4c0ba167aeb931aee97e972de0d01da940d434c7ef5716ef9a263b5c79339e233c350badd9bab72f9c350badd9bab72f9c350badd9bab72f9c
X-Originating-IP: 66.47.248.108
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] [SRR] Question for the DJs: Improving my DJ Skills

have a bunch of your friends get really stoned and watch you spin.  if 
you make any sort of mistake, no matter how small, they should point 
and laugh at you, and then throw things at you (pillows, balled-up 
paper, stuffed animals found after the last party, etc).  every once in 
awhile, one of them should come over and tweak your pitch slider at 
random, just to throw you off.

keep this up for a good solid year.  i guarantee you'll improve.

it also helps to have cheap Salvation Army bought belt-drive decks, and 
don't even bother with a monitor.

that's how i learned.  :-)

-philip-

Subject: RE: [sfraves] [SRR] Question for the DJs: Improving my DJ Skills

practice, practice practice!

record your mixes and listen to them...

know your music....

if a kid distracting you throws you off, then practice more....
you will get 100 kids distractibg you at a gig.

get a set of 1200's .... sorry kids, anything less: suck for beatmatching.
(not trying to open a debate about stanton vs vestax vs newmark vs technics)

but honestly, 1200's or some of the vestax are a must for consistancy.....

my 2 cents...
Gabriel

Save Bob, Sat. August 28th.  This time with new and improved Kissing
Booth.  No, for reals this time.

Subject: RE: [sfraves] [SRR] Question for the DJs: Improving my DJ Skills

Well I practice frequently (5-7 days a week for about
1 hour.)  Much to the horror of my downstairs
neighbors who are not into house music to say the
least.  I'm moving to a house out by SF state soon
where I'll be able to turn it up properly without
having the police knocking on the door.  The question
is what shoudl I practice?  

I've take to studying records, noting specific mix
points and so forth and keeping this all in some cool
little notebooks I found.  But even if I know the
vinyl, I still need to be able to mix on the fly with
something I don't know.  I don't want to fall into the
trap of memorizing speeds and  sets and so forth.  I
probably could do that now and play an acceptable setI
think.

As for the 1200s, wish I had the $$$ but I'll put 'em
on my xmas list ;)

Thanks!

Peter

X-Originating-IP: [69.105.225.60]

References: <20040729172725.93769.qmail@web21528.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Thu, 29 Jul 2004 12:14:14 -0700
MIME-Version: 1.0

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Priority: 3
X-MSMail-Priority: Normal
X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook Express 6.00.2800.1106
X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V6.00.2800.1106
Message-ID: <BAY8-DAV6205d8m5mYc00044907@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 29 Jul 2004 19:13:47.0516 (UTC) FILETIME=[2C8223C0:01C475A0]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] [SRR] Question for the DJs: Improving my DJ Skills

The only thing you can really do to improve, is play all the time. Every
chance you get. If you get too frustrated, take a couple days off and come
back fresh to it.

As far as having lame equipment. I have been the king of lame equipment the
last year. After my DJM500 died, along w/ my subs and amp, I was left w/
nada for almost 6 months. I could ONLY spin on other peoples setups, and
then rarely at that. Somehow - my desire to play ended up working in my
favor and I got better.  Equipment can HELP, but it does NOT make the DJ. If
you can spin on crap equipment, you can pretty much spin on anything.

As far as when your mixes fall apart - remember to take a deep breath, calm
yourself down, and get back on it. Pick a track you know real well, that you
can work in anywhere - use it to ease yourself back into the mix. It'll come
together again soon.

Patience grasshoppa!
----- Original Message -----
From: "Peter Rothman" <dangrsmind@yahoo.com>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Thursday, July 29, 2004 10:27 AM
Subject: [sfraves] [SRR] Question for the DJs: Improving my DJ Skills


> So I've been DJing for about 3 years now in the
> bedroom (well actually the livingroom) and I've
> finally gotten to the point where most of the time I
> can do good mixes.  However, I note that when anything
> goes wrong, i.e. my kids distract me, I have to go to
> the bathroom, I've had one too many or one too few
> beers, etc. my mixing falls apart quickly.  I'm sort
> of ready to play for an audience but worried that my
> mixing will collapse the first time I try.
>
> Most of the time when this happens I find that I
> simply can get a good estimate of whether the new
> record is faster or slower with the headphines no
> matter what I do.  Of course if I bring it in to the
> mix I can hear its wrong and usually can adjust it
> that way, but I couldn't do that during a live or
> recorded set.  I'm looking for suggestions on how to
> improve my skills on this point.  Anyone have some
> suggested exercises that might help me work on these
> sorts of issues?
>
> I don't have great equipment (Stanton 80s, Numark
> mixer) , but its what I could afford at the time.  I
> got my headphones for free from a failed Internet
> music company MusicBank.  I currently can't afford to
> replace my equipment so even if that's a lot of my
> problem I need to work around it.  Oh and my tape deck
> died so I currently can't record my mixes.
>
> When I started out I had a bit of money so I took
> lessons from a great DJ and teacher friend of mine,
> but now I can longer afford lessons.  So although I
> know some folks on the list are providing DJ lessons
> for money, I can't afford that.  I wish I could.
>
> FWIW I play a variety of house styles, mostly SF style
> funky house with some deep house,  tech house, and
> progressive depending on my mood.  I'm interested in
> intermixing, creating compositions with records, not
> just simple blending of one track into the next.  I've
> messed around a bit with mixing spoken word and other
> weird shit as well with some pretty good results.
> That's what I'm trying to do anyway.
>
> Any help will be greatly appreciated!!
>
> Peace,
>
> Peter

From: "Steve Osteen" <SOsteen@pinnaclesys.com>

	"Gabriel B" <retroactivefunk@hotmail.com>,

X-OriginalArrivalTime: 29 Jul 2004 19:15:04.0233 (UTC) FILETIME=[5A3C3990:01C475A0]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] [SRR] Question for the DJs: Improving my DJ Skills

Hi Peter!

I completely learned how to beatmatch with a four year old next to me
the whole time. He is now seven years old and I can beatmatch in ten
seconds or less and pay attention to him at the same time.

 It also helps to have a mixer that allows you to mix in the headphones
so you don't have to annoy neighbors. Unfortunately for me, I got so use
to mixing in the headphones that the first time I used a "real" mixer I
had a hard time adjusting. To solve that problem I had to go out and buy
a new "real" mixer so that I could practice how to mix on a club type
system.

I'm still far from pro/perfect, but I love pulling off 2 minute long
progressive trannies.

I practice about 3-5 days a week depending on how much time I've spent
in the studio working on tracks that week.

Steve Osteen
Progressive DJ/Producer
www.tussinspace.com

X-OriginalArrivalTime: 29 Jul 2004 19:17:43.0533 (UTC) FILETIME=[B92F79D0:01C475A0]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] [SRR] Question for the DJs: Improving my DJ Skills

My other suggestion - which may sound like suicide to some folks - but helps
me TREMENDOUSLY - is find a buddy to bring over his/her records, and spin
them. You don't already know them, and you are forced to learn to mix on the
fly. You can see just how intuitive you are when you spin someone else's
wax....trust me on that.

It's a great way to practice!

M
----- Original Message -----

> > >From: Peter Rothman <dangrsmind@yahoo.com>
> > >To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
> > >Subject: [sfraves] [SRR] Question for the DJs:
> > Improving my DJ Skills
> > >Date: Thu, 29 Jul 2004 10:27:25 -0700 (PDT)
> > >
> > >So I've been DJing for about 3 years now in the
> > >bedroom (well actually the livingroom) and I've
> > >finally gotten to the point where most of the time
> > I
> > >can do good mixes.  However, I note that when
> > anything
> > >goes wrong, i.e. my kids distract me, I have to go
> > to
> > >the bathroom, I've had one too many or one too few
> > >beers, etc. my mixing falls apart quickly.  I'm
> > sort
> > >of ready to play for an audience but worried that
> > my
> > >mixing will collapse the first time I try.
> > >
> > >Most of the time when this happens I find that I
> > >simply can get a good estimate of whether the new
> > >record is faster or slower with the headphines no
> > >matter what I do.  Of course if I bring it in to
> > the
> > >mix I can hear its wrong and usually can adjust it
> > >that way, but I couldn't do that during a live or
> > >recorded set.  I'm looking for suggestions on how
> > to
> > >improve my skills on this point.  Anyone have some
> > >suggested exercises that might help me work on
> > these
> > >sorts of issues?
> > >
> > >I don't have great equipment (Stanton 80s, Numark
> > >mixer) , but its what I could afford at the time.
> > I
> > >got my headphones for free from a failed Internet
> > >music company MusicBank.  I currently can't afford
> > to
> > >replace my equipment so even if that's a lot of my
> > >problem I need to work around it.  Oh and my tape
> > deck
> > >died so I currently can't record my mixes.
> > >
> > >When I started out I had a bit of money so I took
> > >lessons from a great DJ and teacher friend of mine,
> > >but now I can longer afford lessons.  So although I
> > >know some folks on the list are providing DJ
> > lessons
> > >for money, I can't afford that.  I wish I could.
> > >
> > >FWIW I play a variety of house styles, mostly SF
> > style
> > >funky house with some deep house,  tech house, and
> > >progressive depending on my mood.  I'm interested
> > in
> > >intermixing, creating compositions with records,
> > not
> > >just simple blending of one track into the next.
> > I've
> > >messed around a bit with mixing spoken word and
> > other
> > >weird shit as well with some pretty good results.
> > >That's what I'm trying to do anyway.
> > >
> > >Any help will be greatly appreciated!!
> > >
> > >Peace,
> > >
> > >Peter
> > >

BlankHey there folks....

Once again, someone (Jonas R) was silly enough book me to play some =
records out. So tonight @ Lingba Lounge, from 9:30 to 11pm I will be =
dropping some deep & funky-ish house, as well as the odd atmospheric =
breaks jammy as well.=20

To be honest, I haven't touched my house records in over a year - so if =
you hear some totally cheesed out mixes, don't be surprised - but I =
think it's gonna be fun nonetheless.=20

So come out and play! Feel free to ply me with drinks, or throw your =
drink garnishes at me...whichever suits your needs.

Marc(O)

>From: "Steve Osteen" <SOsteen@pinnaclesys.com>
>To: "Peter Rothman" <dangrsmind@yahoo.com>,"Gabriel B" 
><retroactivefunk@hotmail.com>,<sfraves@hyperreal.org>
>Subject: RE: [sfraves] [SRR] Question for the DJs: Improving my DJ Skills
>Date: Thu, 29 Jul 2004 12:15:03 -0700
>
>Hi Peter!
>
>I completely learned how to beatmatch with a four year old next to me
>the whole time. He is now seven years old and I can beatmatch in ten
>seconds or less and pay attention to him at the same time.
>
>  It also helps to have a mixer that allows you to mix in the headphones
>so you don't have to annoy neighbors. Unfortunately for me, I got so use
>to mixing in the headphones that the first time I used a "real" mixer I
>had a hard time adjusting. To solve that problem I had to go out and buy
>a new "real" mixer so that I could practice how to mix on a club type
>system.
>
>I'm still far from pro/perfect, but I love pulling off 2 minute long
>progressive trannies.
>
>I practice about 3-5 days a week depending on how much time I've spent
>in the studio working on tracks that week.
>
>Steve Osteen
>Progressive DJ/Producer
>www.tussinspace.com
>
>-----Original Message-----
>From: Peter Rothman [mailto:dangrsmind@yahoo.com]
>Sent: Thursday, July 29, 2004 11:18 AM
>To: Gabriel B; sfraves@hyperreal.org
>Subject: RE: [sfraves] [SRR] Question for the DJs: Improving my DJ
>Skills
>
>Well I practice frequently (5-7 days a week for about
>1 hour.)  Much to the horror of my downstairs
>neighbors who are not into house music to say the
>least.  I'm moving to a house out by SF state soon
>where I'll be able to turn it up properly without
>having the police knocking on the door.  The question
>is what shoudl I practice?
>
>I've take to studying records, noting specific mix
>points and so forth and keeping this all in some cool
>little notebooks I found.  But even if I know the
>vinyl, I still need to be able to mix on the fly with
>something I don't know.  I don't want to fall into the
>trap of memorizing speeds and  sets and so forth.  I
>probably could do that now and play an acceptable setI
>think.
>
>As for the 1200s, wish I had the $$$ but I'll put 'em
>on my xmas list ;)
>
>Thanks!
>
>Peter

>From: "electrofunk138" <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>
>To: "Peter Rothman" <dangrsmind@yahoo.com>,"Gabriel B" 
><retroactivefunk@hotmail.com>,<sfraves@hyperreal.org>
>Subject: Re: [sfraves] [SRR] Question for the DJs: Improving my DJ Skills
>Date: Thu, 29 Jul 2004 12:18:11 -0700
>
>My other suggestion - which may sound like suicide to some folks - but 
>helps
>me TREMENDOUSLY - is find a buddy to bring over his/her records, and spin
>them. You don't already know them, and you are forced to learn to mix on 
>the
>fly. You can see just how intuitive you are when you spin someone else's
>wax....trust me on that.
>
>It's a great way to practice!
>
>M
>----- Original Message -----
>From: "Peter Rothman" <dangrsmind@yahoo.com>
>To: "Gabriel B" <retroactivefunk@hotmail.com>; <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
>Sent: Thursday, July 29, 2004 11:18 AM
>Subject: RE: [sfraves] [SRR] Question for the DJs: Improving my DJ Skills
>
>
> > Well I practice frequently (5-7 days a week for about
> > 1 hour.)  Much to the horror of my downstairs
> > neighbors who are not into house music to say the
> > least.  I'm moving to a house out by SF state soon
> > where I'll be able to turn it up properly without
> > having the police knocking on the door.  The question
> > is what shoudl I practice?
> >
> > I've take to studying records, noting specific mix
> > points and so forth and keeping this all in some cool
> > little notebooks I found.  But even if I know the
> > vinyl, I still need to be able to mix on the fly with
> > something I don't know.  I don't want to fall into the
> > trap of memorizing speeds and  sets and so forth.  I
> > probably could do that now and play an acceptable setI
> > think.
> >
> > As for the 1200s, wish I had the $$$ but I'll put 'em
> > on my xmas list ;)
> >
> > Thanks!

> > Peter

> > > record your mixes and listen to them...

> > > know your music....
> > >
> > > if a kid distracting you throws you off, then
> > > practice more....
> > > you will get 100 kids distractibg you at a gig.
> > >
> > > get a set of 1200's .... sorry kids, anything less:
> > > suck for beatmatching.
