> > > >From: Peter Rothman <dangrsmind@yahoo.com>
> > > >To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
> > > >Subject: [sfraves] [SRR] Question for the DJs:
> > > Improving my DJ Skills
> > > >Date: Thu, 29 Jul 2004 10:27:25 -0700 (PDT)
> > > >
> > > >So I've been DJing for about 3 years now in the
> > > >bedroom (well actually the livingroom) and I've
> > > >finally gotten to the point where most of the time
> > > I
> > > >can do good mixes.  However, I note that when
> > > anything
> > > >goes wrong, i.e. my kids distract me, I have to go
> > > to
> > > >the bathroom, I've had one too many or one too few
> > > >beers, etc. my mixing falls apart quickly.  I'm
> > > sort
> > > >of ready to play for an audience but worried that
> > > my
> > > >mixing will collapse the first time I try.
> > > >
> > > >Most of the time when this happens I find that I
> > > >simply can get a good estimate of whether the new
> > > >record is faster or slower with the headphines no
> > > >matter what I do.  Of course if I bring it in to
> > > the
> > > >mix I can hear its wrong and usually can adjust it
> > > >that way, but I couldn't do that during a live or
> > > >recorded set.  I'm looking for suggestions on how
> > > to
> > > >improve my skills on this point.  Anyone have some
> > > >suggested exercises that might help me work on
> > > these
> > > >sorts of issues?
> > > >
> > > >I don't have great equipment (Stanton 80s, Numark
> > > >mixer) , but its what I could afford at the time.
> > > I
> > > >got my headphones for free from a failed Internet
> > > >music company MusicBank.  I currently can't afford
> > > to
> > > >replace my equipment so even if that's a lot of my
> > > >problem I need to work around it.  Oh and my tape
> > > deck
> > > >died so I currently can't record my mixes.
> > > >
> > > >When I started out I had a bit of money so I took
> > > >lessons from a great DJ and teacher friend of mine,
> > > >but now I can longer afford lessons.  So although I
> > > >know some folks on the list are providing DJ
> > > lessons
> > > >for money, I can't afford that.  I wish I could.
> > > >
> > > >FWIW I play a variety of house styles, mostly SF
> > > style
> > > >funky house with some deep house,  tech house, and
> > > >progressive depending on my mood.  I'm interested
> > > in
> > > >intermixing, creating compositions with records,
> > > not
> > > >just simple blending of one track into the next.
> > > I've
> > > >messed around a bit with mixing spoken word and
> > > other
> > > >weird shit as well with some pretty good results.
> > > >That's what I'm trying to do anyway.
> > > >
> > > >Any help will be greatly appreciated!!
> > > >
> > > >Peace,
> > > >
> > > >Peter

Subject: Re: [sfraves] [SRR] Question for the DJs: Improving my DJ Skills

Or you could sell everything you own and buy new records all the time like 
me. lol j/k

Some of my most Refreshing (READ: FUN) sets have been the one's where you 
get home with new records and fly by the seat of your pants....

Recording myself is/was the best way to get aquainted with your music and 
critique you mixing.

In other words, fix that tape deck! (or go get one at a garage sale for 10 
bucks)

Go To http://www.GabrielBlack.net for streaming and downloadable dj sets of 
Deep and Funky Tech-House Madness!
Check out http://www.myspace.com/gabrielblack for self produced tracks
Visit my label http://www.Sierrarecordings.com
001 Gabriel Black with Jay Tripwire and JJVaas Remixs (out now)
002 JJVaas with EBE and Gabriel Black remixs (who knows when?)
And vote for me at the dj list! http://www.thedjlist.com/djs/GABRIEL_BLACK/
I've started renting out my Mackie Rig for small/medium sized rooms, hit me 
up!

>>> > > not

>>> > > >messed around a bit with mixing spoken word and

Subject: Re: [sfraves] [SRR] Question for the DJs: Improving my DJ Skills

Another thing I used to do to help train my ear for
beatmatching is:

Take your head phones OFF.

Get two records spinning.

Have both records palying through the speakers.

You will be train wreking at first but try beat
matching by ear through the speakers not the head
phones. 

This will come in handy when playing live during the
third track. 

Hope this helps.

=)
matt 
aka dj dub

From sfraves-return-114244-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Fri Jul 30 17:22:47 2004
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-114244-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 35052 invoked by uid 1103); 30 Jul 2004 17:22:47 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm

X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>

list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 35038 invoked from network); 30 Jul 2004 17:22:47 -0000
Message-ID: <4688f3110407301022d43a79b@mail.gmail.com>
Date: Fri, 30 Jul 2004 10:22:41 -0700
From: DJ Soundwave <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>
To: SFRaves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
In-Reply-To: <20040730164215.14380.qmail@web51710.mail.yahoo.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
References: <20040730164215.14380.qmail@web51710.mail.yahoo.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] [SRR] Question for the DJs: Improving my DJ Skills

I actually feel more comfortable mixing with my headphones off.
usually if I get a mix going where the records are like exactly
synched, I'll take my headphones off for a second and chill.

Marco's advice with the records you haven't heard before thing is good
advice. That's why you should always spin after record shopping,
without listening to the tracks first. (Except at the record store
obviously.) I also always listen to the tracks afterwards without
spinning, like over and over again if they're good tracks, but I'm
more into producing than DJing, so that's kind of an analytical thing.

But it is good to do that from a DJ perspective, too, because the more
thoroughly you learn your favorite tracks, the more completely you'll
understand their phrasing. Counting phrases is just like counting
beats, except like one level of magnification up. Instead of looking
for every fourth beat, you're looking for every 16th measure, etc. The
weird thing about phrasing is that it's much less uniform than rhythms
are. (Which is why creating a good drum loop is not the same thing as
creating a good techno track -- something I still haven't been able to
do.)

Anyway, the reason phrasing is good is because you want your
transitions to seem logical and ideally you want them to not even seem
like a transition between two records, but a transition between two
ways of mixing the same record. I saw a trance DJ actually who was a
master of this shit. He'd have two records playing into the mixer at
all times, and all he did was ride the levels and the EQ. Not how you
expect to see trance DJs spin, but the crowd went apeshit, and to be
honest I think he had a pretty good idea of music theory, because all
the tracks he chose harmonized effortlessly. Harmony and key
signatures are worth learning if you spin anything like trance where
melody is a primary factor.

To quote the much-hated Paul Oakenfold, "Keys are very important
because they fuck with your feelings."

Not a trance DJ myself, I'm just saying, credit where credit is due.


Giles/DJ Soundwave

X-OriginalArrivalTime: 30 Jul 2004 17:43:44.0235 (UTC) FILETIME=[C250A3B0:01C4765C]

Subject: RE: [sfraves] [SRR] Question for the DJs: Improving my DJ Skills

Phrasing is easy, just remember 4. Something major will(should if you
are producing) happen at every 4x4=3D32 beats or :1234:1234:1234:1234:,
fourth measure.

The human ear is expecting it and you should give it if you want people
to go ape shit.

Steve Osteen
Progressive DJ/Producer
www.tussinspace.com


-----Original Message-----
From: DJ Soundwave [mailto:dj.soundwave@gmail.com]=20
Sent: Friday, July 30, 2004 10:23 AM
To: SFRaves
Subject: Re: [sfraves] [SRR] Question for the DJs: Improving my DJ
Skills

I actually feel more comfortable mixing with my headphones off.
usually if I get a mix going where the records are like exactly
synched, I'll take my headphones off for a second and chill.

Marco's advice with the records you haven't heard before thing is good
advice. That's why you should always spin after record shopping,
without listening to the tracks first. (Except at the record store
obviously.) I also always listen to the tracks afterwards without
spinning, like over and over again if they're good tracks, but I'm
more into producing than DJing, so that's kind of an analytical thing.

But it is good to do that from a DJ perspective, too, because the more
thoroughly you learn your favorite tracks, the more completely you'll
understand their phrasing. Counting phrases is just like counting
beats, except like one level of magnification up. Instead of looking
for every fourth beat, you're looking for every 16th measure, etc. The
weird thing about phrasing is that it's much less uniform than rhythms
are. (Which is why creating a good drum loop is not the same thing as
creating a good techno track -- something I still haven't been able to
do.)

Anyway, the reason phrasing is good is because you want your
transitions to seem logical and ideally you want them to not even seem
like a transition between two records, but a transition between two
ways of mixing the same record. I saw a trance DJ actually who was a
master of this shit. He'd have two records playing into the mixer at
all times, and all he did was ride the levels and the EQ. Not how you
expect to see trance DJs spin, but the crowd went apeshit, and to be
honest I think he had a pretty good idea of music theory, because all
the tracks he chose harmonized effortlessly. Harmony and key
signatures are worth learning if you spin anything like trance where
melody is a primary factor.

To quote the much-hated Paul Oakenfold, "Keys are very important
because they fuck with your feelings."

Not a trance DJ myself, I'm just saying, credit where credit is due.


Giles/DJ Soundwave



On Fri, 30 Jul 2004 09:42:15 -0700 (PDT), matthew johnson
<mpj_bay@yahoo.com> wrote:
> Another thing I used to do to help train my ear for
> beatmatching is:
>=20
> Take your head phones OFF.
>=20
> Get two records spinning.
>=20
> Have both records palying through the speakers.
>=20
> You will be train wreking at first but try beat
> matching by ear through the speakers not the head
> phones.
>=20
> This will come in handy when playing live during the
> third track.
>=20
> Hope this helps.
>=20
> =3D)
> matt
> aka dj dub

--- Happy <happy@cannabass.com> wrote:

> 
> >>From: legalizedancingnyc@yahoogroups.com
> >>Subject: Does a New York DJ need a license? 
> Village Voice 7/02/04
> >>
> >>
> http://www.villagevoice.com/issues/0427/flylife.php
> >>ny mirror
> >>
> >>
> >>Fly Life
> >>by Tricia Romano
> >>Licensed to DJ
> >>Does a New York DJ need a license?
> >>July 2nd, 2004 4:45 PM
> >>
> >>Just when you thought New York nightlife couldn't
> get any worse, it does.
> >>JEREMY RODRIGUEZ is perhaps the first person in
> the history of the world to
> >>get a ticket for DJ'ing. The Texas native was
> spinning on June 5 at Cash
> >>Checking, a new bar in Williamsburg, when police
> paid a visit to the venue.
> >>After spending considerable time speaking to one
> of the venue's employees,
> >>the police asked for the DJ's ID and then walked
> off with it for 40 minutes. 
> >>
> >>When they returned, they handed him back his
> ID-with a pink slip of paper
> >>slyly folded underneath. It was a summons for
> Rodriguez, who had only been
> >>spinning for a short time before the cops'
> arrival, to appear in court on
> >>July 22 for "Operation of Sound Reproductive
> Device Without a Permit." The
> >>section of the New York City noise code cited,
> 10.108.23, says a police
> >>spokesperson, allows a violation to be given to a
> person operating "any sound
> >>production device in a public area, even if it's
> in a bar. If music can be
> >>heard from public sidewalk," then there can be a
> violation. However, it seems
> >>a bit strange to cite the DJ, not the bar. The
> NYPD spokesperson would only
> >>say, "I don't know the circumstances." 
> >>
> >>Rodriguez, who is not the club's resident DJ, says
> that when he arrived on
> >>the corner of North 3rd Street and Kent Avenue and
> got out of his car, "I
> >>could hear the music, so it was kind of loud. The
> employee was there, so I
> >>thought it was OK." He said the employee had come
> over and turned the volume
> >>down a "significant" amount when the cops arrived.
> The owner, THOMAS
> >>SANDBICHLER, says, "The violation was given
> because we had the door open and
> >>the music spilled into the street. They thereby
> said we were operating
> >>amplified equipment on the street. That's not part
> of the license. It's a
> >>bullshit summons." 
> >>
> >>The bar's already tallied up several violations,
> says Sandbichler. ("They
> >>give out tickets like candy," he says.) The visits
> are fueled by 311 calls,
> >>which may become more frequent citywide if the
> mayor's plan to overhaul the
> >>noise code goes through. (According to the mayor's
> office, noise ranks number
> >>one in complaints to the 311 line, and averages
> 1,000 calls a day.) While the
> >>mayor's proposing to do away with some provisions
> that are too vague (such as
> >>limiting the standard of judging a noise complaint
> as "unreasonable to a
> >>person of normal sensitivities"), other suggested
> changes may turn out to be
> >>more strict (such as throwing out the noise meter
> and going by the "plainly
> >>audible" standard). Wait, I'm deaf-that might work
> wonderfully! Meanwhile,
> >>Rodriguez, who just moved back to the States after
> six years in Barcelona, is
> >>probably wondering why in the hell he ever
> returned. 
> >>
> >>
> >>
> >>    
> >>
> >  
> >
> 
> 
>

Subject: [sfraves] BSP:  Evil Breaks presents...FLUX w/ Carbon Community Live!

Well folks, it's tonight!  I don't know what else I can say to encourage 
anyone to come.  If you caught the BasslineFM show yesterday, you got a 
taste of what Carbon Community is about.  Dave (of Carbon Community) said 
he'd light himself on fire to keep the party pumping if he had to.  Now 
that's commitment (or perhaps desperation, but I'd like to think it's 
commitment *wink*).

So anyhow, it's Friday, folks.  Get out of the house, drop five bones and 
listen to some breaky choons.

Hope to see some of you there!

Evil Breaks presents
FLUX
Shadow Lounge, 9th and Folsom
Friday, July 30th
9pm-3am, 21+
$5 before 11pm

Featuring:
Carbon Community (Moonshine/Bless Records/www.theCarbonCommunity.com)

A:Dubl (Breakthru)

Icon (Mach 5, Sister NYC, djIcon.com)

Aaron Jae (AaronJae.com/Evil Breaks)

DJ Bam (Invibe/Evil Breaks)

M.O.D. (Evil Breaks)

This event is 21+ and is being held at the Shadow Lounge located at the 
corner of 9th and Folsom. Going strong from 9pm-3am. Only $5 before 11pm.

-------------
< Brandon / DJ Bam >

DJ Bam - serving breaks and beats
http://www.invibe.com/bam

July 24th:  Euphoric Dreams 2 @ Reno area outdoor venue
July 30th:  Flux w/ Carbon Community @ Shadow Lounge
August 6th: Regulus @ UG venue
August 20th: Mighty Breaks w/ Grandmaster Flash and 2 Bad Mice @ Mighty
August 21st: Vintage w/ Grandmaster Flash, 2 Bad Mice, Tony @ All-ages 
Oaktown venue

-------------

> > >>From: legalizedancingnyc@yahoogroups.com
> > >>Subject: Does a New York DJ need a license? 
> > Village Voice 7/02/04
> > >>
> > >>
> >
> http://www.villagevoice.com/issues/0427/flylife.php
> > >>ny mirror
> > >>
> > >>
> > >>Fly Life
> > >>by Tricia Romano
> > >>Licensed to DJ
> > >>Does a New York DJ need a license?
> > >>July 2nd, 2004 4:45 PM
> > >>
> > >>Just when you thought New York nightlife
> couldn't
> > get any worse, it does.
> > >>JEREMY RODRIGUEZ is perhaps the first person in
> > the history of the world to
> > >>get a ticket for DJ'ing. The Texas native was
> > spinning on June 5 at Cash
> > >>Checking, a new bar in Williamsburg, when police
> > paid a visit to the venue.
> > >>After spending considerable time speaking to one
> > of the venue's employees,
> > >>the police asked for the DJ's ID and then walked
> > off with it for 40 minutes. 
> > >>
> > >>When they returned, they handed him back his
> > ID-with a pink slip of paper
> > >>slyly folded underneath. It was a summons for
> > Rodriguez, who had only been
> > >>spinning for a short time before the cops'
> > arrival, to appear in court on
> > >>July 22 for "Operation of Sound Reproductive
> > Device Without a Permit." The
> > >>section of the New York City noise code cited,
> > 10.108.23, says a police
> > >>spokesperson, allows a violation to be given to
> a
> > person operating "any sound
> > >>production device in a public area, even if it's
> > in a bar. If music can be
> > >>heard from public sidewalk," then there can be a
> > violation. However, it seems
> > >>a bit strange to cite the DJ, not the bar. The
> > NYPD spokesperson would only
> > >>say, "I don't know the circumstances." 
> > >>
> > >>Rodriguez, who is not the club's resident DJ,
> says
> > that when he arrived on
> > >>the corner of North 3rd Street and Kent Avenue
> and
> > got out of his car, "I
> > >>could hear the music, so it was kind of loud.
> The
> > employee was there, so I
> > >>thought it was OK." He said the employee had
> come
> > over and turned the volume
> > >>down a "significant" amount when the cops
> arrived.
> > The owner, THOMAS
> > >>SANDBICHLER, says, "The violation was given
> > because we had the door open and
> > >>the music spilled into the street. They thereby
> > said we were operating
> > >>amplified equipment on the street. That's not
> part
> > of the license. It's a
> > >>bullshit summons." 
> > >>
> > >>The bar's already tallied up several violations,
> > says Sandbichler. ("They
> > >>give out tickets like candy," he says.) The
> visits
> > are fueled by 311 calls,
> > >>which may become more frequent citywide if the
> > mayor's plan to overhaul the
> > >>noise code goes through. (According to the
> mayor's
> > office, noise ranks number
> > >>one in complaints to the 311 line, and averages
> > 1,000 calls a day.) While the
> > >>mayor's proposing to do away with some
> provisions
> > that are too vague (such as
> > >>limiting the standard of judging a noise
> complaint
> > as "unreasonable to a
> > >>person of normal sensitivities"), other
> suggested
> > changes may turn out to be
> > >>more strict (such as throwing out the noise
> meter
> > and going by the "plainly
> > >>audible" standard). Wait, I'm deaf-that might
> work
> > wonderfully! Meanwhile,
> > >>Rodriguez, who just moved back to the States
> after
> > six years in Barcelona, is
> > >>probably wondering why in the hell he ever
> > returned. 
> > >>
> > >>
> > >>
> > >>    
> > >>
> > >  
> > >
> > 
> >

Subject: Re: FW: [sfraves] Fw: [nyc-raves] Does a New York DJ need a license?
   Village Voice 7/02/04

It sucks that they decided to ticket the DJ, but it's totally reasonable
to ticket a club that's generating a lot of noise on the street. Nobody is
disputing that there was a lot of noise, btw:

> Rodriguez, who is not the club's resident DJ, says that when he arrived
> on the corner of North 3rd Street and Kent Avenue and got out of his
> car, "I could hear the music, so it was kind of loud. The employee was
> there, so I thought it was OK." He said the employee had come over and
> turned the volume down a "significant" amount when the cops arrived. The
> owner, THOMAS SANDBICHLER, says, "The violation was given because we had
> the door open and the music spilled into the street. They thereby said
> we were operating amplified equipment on the street...."

It sounds like maybe the cop could have chosen a more appropriate code
violation to cite the club for. If the guy was cited for the wrong thing,
he'll get it dismissed. Obviously, playing a flute (unamplified, quiet) is
a lot different from a club that's blasting amplified music out their
front door.

Subject: [sfraves] BSP:Forwarding benefit party info for a few friends

Hit 'em Up Records Presents... 

Reach Out 

...a benefit party to help fight leukemia 

Saturday, August 21st 2004 
============================= 
HEU Control Room:: 

Mars (F-8, SF)
This CyberTrance Pioneer joins us to celebrate the release of Sonic Sunrise, a full length album featuring all original tracks and a documentary DVD

Mystre (F-8, Dancing Spirit, SF)
One of the Bay Area's top trance DJ's who was instrumental in helping pave the way for CyberTrance music in America

DJ Rigatony (Sagitariun, Liquid, Plush, Ink, Sac) 
A 15 year veteran in the house scene who has earned his title as the God Father of Funk

Ultraman, Rayden and Kyo with MC Maximillian (Divine Intervention, Sac) 
Mek (Stilldream, Techno Truth, Sac) 
TM (HEU, Luddites, Sac) 
Acetrixx & DJ Dunn (Tri-Gar, HEU, Sac) 

*Special Capoeira performance by the Brazilian Arts Center of Sacramento 
=========================== 
PixelBiscuit Lounge:: 

DJ CANYON (PixelBiscuit, Wish, Butter, SF) 
NATE HARRISON (PixelBiscuit, Breakbeat Agency, SF) 
JOHN THOMPSON (PixelBiscuit, Butter, Santa Rosa) 
KEN Q - (Roof Top Recordings, SF) 
Hip-Hop/Downtempo (7pm-10pm) 
Breakbeats, Tech-House, & Progressive (10pm-2am) 

Photos by SIR RICHERT TOP SIRLOIN 
Balloon Sculpture by TWISTERELLA 

go to pixelbiscuit.com for 10,000+ party photos 
======================================= 
Hit 'em Up Records is dedicated to "changing lives one record at a time". A significant portion of the proceeds will be donated to the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society. 


www.leukemia-lymphoma.org/all_chap 

www.hitemuprecords.com 

24 hour HEU infoline: (916) 221-4077 

Reach Out is 100% fully permitted and Secured!!! 
New Virgin Location. 
Located at Club Gravity 430 D Street in Marysville, CA 
7pm - 2 am 
18+ with valid ID. 
3 full bars for the 21 and up. 
A limited number of 2,000 presale tickets go on sale in July for $15. 
Admission will be $20 at the door. 
THIS EVENT WILL SELL OUT. 
Only purchase tickets from authorized outlets. 
Please respect the venue so that we may have future events there. 
No weapons, drugs, or markers. 

Authorized Presale Outlets:: 



Sacramento:

4604 Roseville Road
Suite 100
North Highlands, CA 95660


Sacramento: 
In tha Mix 
2329 I Street 
(916) 442-0499

The Underground 
620 Plumas St. 
(530) 674-2878

1816 Haight Street 
(415) 221-4142

Hit 'em Up Records Presents... 

Reach Out 

...a benefit party to help fight leukemia 

Saturday, August 21st 2004 
============================= 
HEU Control Room:: 

Mars (F-8, SF)
This CyberTrance Pioneer joins us to celebrate the release of Sonic Sunrise, a full length album featuring all original tracks and a documentary DVD

Mystre (F-8, Dancing Spirit, SF)
One of the Bay Area's top trance DJ's who was instrumental in helping pave the way for CyberTrance music in America

DJ Rigatony (Sagitariun, Liquid, Plush, Ink, Sac) 
A 15 year veteran in the house scene who has earned his title as the God Father of Funk

Ultraman, Rayden and Kyo with MC Maximillian (Divine Intervention, Sac) 
Mek (Stilldream, Techno Truth, Sac) 
TM (HEU, Luddites, Sac) 
Acetrixx & DJ Dunn (Tri-Gar, HEU, Sac) 

*Special Capoeira performance by the Brazilian Arts Center of Sacramento 
=========================== 
PixelBiscuit Lounge:: 

DJ CANYON (PixelBiscuit, Wish, Butter, SF) 
NATE HARRISON (PixelBiscuit, Breakbeat Agency, SF) 
JOHN THOMPSON (PixelBiscuit, Butter, Santa Rosa) 
KEN Q - (Roof Top Recordings, SF) 
Hip-Hop/Downtempo (7pm-10pm) 
Breakbeats, Tech-House, & Progressive (10pm-2am) 

Photos by SIR RICHERT TOP SIRLOIN 
Balloon Sculpture by TWISTERELLA 

go to pixelbiscuit.com for 10,000+ party photos 
======================================= 
Hit 'em Up Records is dedicated to "changing lives one record at a time". A significant portion of the proceeds will be donated to the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society. 


www.leukemia-lymphoma.org/all_chap 

www.hitemuprecords.com 

24 hour HEU infoline: (916) 221-4077 

Reach Out is 100% fully permitted and Secured!!! 
New Virgin Location. 
Located at Club Gravity 430 D Street in Marysville, CA 
7pm - 2 am 
18+ with valid ID. 
3 full bars for the 21 and up. 
A limited number of 2,000 presale tickets go on sale in July for $15. 
Admission will be $20 at the door. 
THIS EVENT WILL SELL OUT. 
Only purchase tickets from authorized outlets. 
Please respect the venue so that we may have future events there. 
No weapons, drugs, or markers.

Content-Type: text/plain;

I'm forwarding this info along for a friend. 
Should be a great party, John Tejada is the shiz!
 
------------------------------------------------------------
 
Saturday, July 31st 
 
Join us for an evening with DJ/Producer

<< JOHN TEJADA >>
(Palette / Playhouse)



Come hear the music of the underground where it was meant to be heard! 
This event will take place at a San Francisco warehouse location. 
Call the info line the day of the event.

415-435-8711  or  415-335-0432 
10pm - 6am   /  $10 admission
 
California-based John Tejada is easily one of the most productive
DJ/producers in modern dance music. While most of his colleagues work on
establishing a signature sound within one specific genre, John Tejada
works in all genres simultaneously. Whether house, tech-house, techno,
electronica or drum & bass, every scene gets something from this
multitalent, and Tejada manages to move within each field as if it were
his own. John  travels regularly around the world rocking dance floors
with his signature tech-house sound.  This night will be no exception.
This is what you've been looking for all  along but didn't even know it.
Trust us!
 
Check out this link to listen to (or download) on of John's recent sets:
http://www.bentcrayon.com/sounds.htm
 
 
Local DJ's include:


<< Sammy D & Justin Martin >> 
(Classic / Buzzin' Fly / Roam) 
     Killin' it tag team style!

<< Carlos Gibbs & Jackson >> 
(Deep House Project) 

<< JeniLuv >>
(Fist Fight) 

<< Craig Kuna >>
(ESDJCO / Tech-know)
 
 
See you on the dance floor!

	Don't worry, opponents of dance music will surely be making that 
argument. We don't need to make it for them. I think our community's 
role in this is to say, "Hearing music on the street from time to time 
is a good thing. House music is a positive social value. If they want 
to issue tickets, someone should be ticketing cops for giving out 
irresponsible citations." Unity against the anti-rave authorities!

	Thanks BTW to Apollo for posting this news, and also the excellent 
(and troubling) ACLU animation 
(http://www.aclu.org/pizza/index.html?orgid=EA071904&MX=1414&H=1).

Peace, love & liberty,
					<<< Starchild >>>


On Friday, July 30, 2004, at 03:58  PM, Dan Haskovec wrote:

> It sucks that they decided to ticket the DJ, but it's totally 
> reasonable
> to ticket a club that's generating a lot of noise on the street. 
> Nobody is
> disputing that there was a lot of noise, btw:
>
>> Rodriguez, who is not the club's resident DJ, says that when he 
>> arrived
>> on the corner of North 3rd Street and Kent Avenue and got out of his
>> car, "I could hear the music, so it was kind of loud. The employee was
>> there, so I thought it was OK." He said the employee had come over and
>> turned the volume down a "significant" amount when the cops arrived. 
>> The
>> owner, THOMAS SANDBICHLER, says, "The violation was given because we 
>> had
>> the door open and the music spilled into the street. They thereby said
>> we were operating amplified equipment on the street...."
>
> It sounds like maybe the cop could have chosen a more appropriate code
> violation to cite the club for. If the guy was cited for the wrong 
> thing,
> he'll get it dismissed. Obviously, playing a flute (unamplified, 
> quiet) is
> a lot different from a club that's blasting amplified music out their
> front door.
>
>
> On Fri, 30 Jul 2004, Brian Lafferty wrote:
>
>> ACLU where are you? So does this mean a person playing
>> the flute in Central Park or a saxaphonist in the
>> Subway is now a fugitive? I don't think that ordinance
>> will last long.
>>
>> B
>>
>>
>> --- Amanda Pusley <apusley@calbaptist.edu> wrote:
>>
>>>  thats the most bullshit i've heard!!

>>> --- Happy <happy@cannabass.com> wrote:
>>>
>>>>
>>>>>> From: legalizedancingnyc@yahoogroups.com
>>>>>> Subject: Does a New York DJ need a license?
>>>> Village Voice 7/02/04
>>>>>>
>>>>>>
>>>>
>>> http://www.villagevoice.com/issues/0427/flylife.php
>>>>>> ny mirror
>>>>>>
>>>>>>
>>>>>> Fly Life
>>>>>> by Tricia Romano
>>>>>> Licensed to DJ
>>>>>> Does a New York DJ need a license?
>>>>>> July 2nd, 2004 4:45 PM
>>>>>>
>>>>>> Just when you thought New York nightlife
>>> couldn't
>>>> get any worse, it does.
>>>>>> JEREMY RODRIGUEZ is perhaps the first person in
>>>> the history of the world to
>>>>>> get a ticket for DJ'ing. The Texas native was
>>>> spinning on June 5 at Cash
>>>>>> Checking, a new bar in Williamsburg, when police
>>>> paid a visit to the venue.
>>>>>> After spending considerable time speaking to one
>>>> of the venue's employees,
>>>>>> the police asked for the DJ's ID and then walked
>>>> off with it for 40 minutes.
>>>>>>
>>>>>> When they returned, they handed him back his
>>>> ID-with a pink slip of paper
>>>>>> slyly folded underneath. It was a summons for
>>>> Rodriguez, who had only been
>>>>>> spinning for a short time before the cops'
>>>> arrival, to appear in court on
>>>>>> July 22 for "Operation of Sound Reproductive
>>>> Device Without a Permit." The
>>>>>> section of the New York City noise code cited,
>>>> 10.108.23, says a police
>>>>>> spokesperson, allows a violation to be given to
>>> a
>>>> person operating "any sound
>>>>>> production device in a public area, even if it's
>>>> in a bar. If music can be
>>>>>> heard from public sidewalk," then there can be a
>>>> violation. However, it seems
>>>>>> a bit strange to cite the DJ, not the bar. The
>>>> NYPD spokesperson would only
>>>>>> say, "I don't know the circumstances."
>>>>>>
>>>>>> Rodriguez, who is not the club's resident DJ,
>>> says
>>>> that when he arrived on
>>>>>> the corner of North 3rd Street and Kent Avenue
>>> and
>>>> got out of his car, "I
>>>>>> could hear the music, so it was kind of loud.
>>> The
>>>> employee was there, so I
>>>>>> thought it was OK." He said the employee had
>>> come
>>>> over and turned the volume
>>>>>> down a "significant" amount when the cops
>>> arrived.
>>>> The owner, THOMAS
>>>>>> SANDBICHLER, says, "The violation was given
>>>> because we had the door open and
>>>>>> the music spilled into the street. They thereby
>>>> said we were operating
>>>>>> amplified equipment on the street. That's not
>>> part
>>>> of the license. It's a
>>>>>> bullshit summons."
>>>>>>
>>>>>> The bar's already tallied up several violations,
>>>> says Sandbichler. ("They
>>>>>> give out tickets like candy," he says.) The
>>> visits
>>>> are fueled by 311 calls,
>>>>>> which may become more frequent citywide if the
>>>> mayor's plan to overhaul the
>>>>>> noise code goes through. (According to the
>>> mayor's
>>>> office, noise ranks number
>>>>>> one in complaints to the 311 line, and averages
>>>> 1,000 calls a day.) While the
>>>>>> mayor's proposing to do away with some
>>> provisions
>>>> that are too vague (such as
>>>>>> limiting the standard of judging a noise
>>> complaint
>>>> as "unreasonable to a
>>>>>> person of normal sensitivities"), other
>>> suggested
>>>> changes may turn out to be
>>>>>> more strict (such as throwing out the noise
>>> meter
>>>> and going by the "plainly
>>>>>> audible" standard). Wait, I'm deaf-that might
>>> work
>>>> wonderfully! Meanwhile,
>>>>>> Rodriguez, who just moved back to the States
>>> after
>>>> six years in Barcelona, is
>>>>>> probably wondering why in the hell he ever
>>>> returned.
>>>>>>
>>>>>>
>>>>>>
>>>>>>
>>>>>>
>>>>>
>>>>>
>>>>
>>>>
>>>>

>>>>>>>> From: legalizedancingnyc@yahoogroups.com
>>>>>>>> Subject: Does a New York DJ need a license?
>>>>>> Village Voice 7/02/04

>>>>> http://www.villagevoice.com/issues/0427/flylife.php
>>>>>>>> ny mirror
>>>>>>>>
>>>>>>>>
>>>>>>>> Fly Life
>>>>>>>> by Tricia Romano
>>>>>>>> Licensed to DJ
>>>>>>>> Does a New York DJ need a license?
>>>>>>>> July 2nd, 2004 4:45 PM
>>>>>>>>
>>>>>>>> Just when you thought New York nightlife
>>>>> couldn't
>>>>>> get any worse, it does.
>>>>>>>> JEREMY RODRIGUEZ is perhaps the first person in
>>>>>> the history of the world to
>>>>>>>> get a ticket for DJ'ing. The Texas native was
>>>>>> spinning on June 5 at Cash
>>>>>>>> Checking, a new bar in Williamsburg, when police
>>>>>> paid a visit to the venue.
>>>>>>>> After spending considerable time speaking to one
>>>>>> of the venue's employees,
>>>>>>>> the police asked for the DJ's ID and then walked
>>>>>> off with it for 40 minutes.
>>>>>>>>
>>>>>>>> When they returned, they handed him back his
>>>>>> ID-with a pink slip of paper
>>>>>>>> slyly folded underneath. It was a summons for
>>>>>> Rodriguez, who had only been
>>>>>>>> spinning for a short time before the cops'
>>>>>> arrival, to appear in court on
>>>>>>>> July 22 for "Operation of Sound Reproductive
>>>>>> Device Without a Permit." The
>>>>>>>> section of the New York City noise code cited,
>>>>>> 10.108.23, says a police
>>>>>>>> spokesperson, allows a violation to be given to
>>>>> a
>>>>>> person operating "any sound
>>>>>>>> production device in a public area, even if it's
>>>>>> in a bar. If music can be
>>>>>>>> heard from public sidewalk," then there can be a
>>>>>> violation. However, it seems
>>>>>>>> a bit strange to cite the DJ, not the bar. The
>>>>>> NYPD spokesperson would only
>>>>>>>> say, "I don't know the circumstances."
>>>>>>>>
>>>>>>>> Rodriguez, who is not the club's resident DJ,
>>>>> says
>>>>>> that when he arrived on
>>>>>>>> the corner of North 3rd Street and Kent Avenue
>>>>> and
>>>>>> got out of his car, "I
>>>>>>>> could hear the music, so it was kind of loud.
>>>>> The
>>>>>> employee was there, so I
>>>>>>>> thought it was OK." He said the employee had
>>>>> come
>>>>>> over and turned the volume
>>>>>>>> down a "significant" amount when the cops
>>>>> arrived.
>>>>>> The owner, THOMAS
>>>>>>>> SANDBICHLER, says, "The violation was given
>>>>>> because we had the door open and
>>>>>>>> the music spilled into the street. They thereby
>>>>>> said we were operating
>>>>>>>> amplified equipment on the street. That's not
>>>>> part
>>>>>> of the license. It's a
>>>>>>>> bullshit summons."
>>>>>>>>
>>>>>>>> The bar's already tallied up several violations,
>>>>>> says Sandbichler. ("They
>>>>>>>> give out tickets like candy," he says.) The
>>>>> visits
>>>>>> are fueled by 311 calls,
>>>>>>>> which may become more frequent citywide if the
>>>>>> mayor's plan to overhaul the
>>>>>>>> noise code goes through. (According to the
>>>>> mayor's
>>>>>> office, noise ranks number
>>>>>>>> one in complaints to the 311 line, and averages
>>>>>> 1,000 calls a day.) While the
>>>>>>>> mayor's proposing to do away with some
>>>>> provisions
>>>>>> that are too vague (such as
>>>>>>>> limiting the standard of judging a noise
>>>>> complaint
>>>>>> as "unreasonable to a
>>>>>>>> person of normal sensitivities"), other
>>>>> suggested
>>>>>> changes may turn out to be
>>>>>>>> more strict (such as throwing out the noise
>>>>> meter
>>>>>> and going by the "plainly

Subject: [sfraves] Thursday night... Urban Montage & Bow Wow Wow

OK... so like after class.. i went over 2 Cloud 9 4 some Urbam Montage Grooviness.. LoL.. it was funny.. I got in2 long converstaions w/ like the owner.. He's really CooL man!

So Mustafa got ther like on time 2 start his House Groove opening 4 the night.. he spun alota ummmmm.. well... funky tribal house & alota breakbeatie vocal house oooooh my gosh.. so yummy.,... there was like these well.. a keybaord player was like totally laying on some extra yummmy melodies & there was even a bass player adding extra heavy baselines 2 alot songs... wait.. sounds kinda 2 familiar that set up.. hmmmmmm???

Anywaze.. i cut out a while from Urban & had dinner w/ an old Homie.. but when i got back.. there was someone else spinning house upstairs.. 4got his name... but it was a good playful house filled set!!  Then down stairs... aaaaaaaaaaaw yeah... Sharp & Mal were tearin'; up on the decks like fuckin' crazy man... oh man.. I Loved it!!!  I mean... they were totally just goin' w/ all the hard bouncey Jungle.. it was Sweet!! fuckin' Danced my ass off 'til close!

OK... then i was kinda stuck 'cause well... i couldn't find a ride home like usual... LoL

So i was heeeeeella tripppn' 'cause I wasn't sure what 2 do... there was still this bar like kinda open still i usually know people kickin' it @.. so i went there 2 look 4 bar fly straglers.. none, but met a cool Dude w/ like Awesome piericings... then I was like right by Cats Club.. so I ended up hangin'out w/ the outside crowd of 1984... 

OK.. this was a trip... I was hangin' out w/ the lead singer from BowWowWow, that girl, & I didn't even know it.. Hello 2Day... she was standing in front of Cats passing out fliers 4 their show comin' up @ Pound SF.. LoL.. & we were like all talkin' about music & Raves & shit & just everything.. LoL.. she's a sweetheart, but man, she lost hella weight & the pix on the flier was like taken 20 years ago or soemthing w/ ADrian (the drummer from No Doubt) photoshopped like in the back 'cause he's playin drums w/ them on this trour thingie... LoL.. Fun

OK.. so then, OK, Hello 2Day, ED (1 of my closest Homies who I was in SFLNC w/) was there & SEAN who still works there... YAY.. it was Dope... I was like able 2 catch up w/ both of them & Hello 2Day.. talk talk talk.. it was Aw3some!  LoL.. so i went in 2 1984... OK... "Love Is A Battlefield","Don't put another dime in the jukebox","I eat cannibals".... oh my gosh.. I was dancing so hard & free 'cause that's all U can do 2 80's Grooves.. Loved it!!  LoL.. 1 of the bouncers there was like well.. he's 1 of my friends from like a few yrs ago when he started bouncing @ DNA... LoL.. it was fun hangin' out w/ him & well.. i didn't mean 2 make him like laugh w. my 80s dancing... but he was.. LoL

It was fun... somehow I managed 2 fill in the time between.. I got 2 hang out w/ ok.. check this.. I was @ NHC 4 the 1st time in like a year now i think 'cause ED got the lease 2 it now... Good Shit... so Awesome being back there again... & Sean lives w/ him.. so yeah.. that was Dope!!!  Sean played a few Hip Hop tracks that he produced.. Doooooooope!!! Yummy!!

LoL.. I got back @ my house exactly @ 6:14 & Hello 2Day.. my parents thought I got home earlier.. LoL...

LoL

Good Times... :P

Take Care,
Peace-> ObY {8O)

> works in all genres simultaneously. Whether house, tech-house, techno,
> electronica or drum & bass, every scene gets something from this
> multitalent, and Tejada manages to move within each field as if it were
> his own. John  travels regularly around the world rocking dance floors

"I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and causes 
me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war, 
corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong 
its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-Abraham Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

  "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

Subject: RE: [sfraves] Review- Graham Gold @ 1015


This is much of a review but I did find Apollo's evil-twin brother.  I say 
evil only because I like how it sounds with evil-breaks.  Graham Gold was 
kickin' and it is so nice to get the dance step jacked back into me.. I can 
only wait for Criostopher Lawrence tonight. Graham played a 3 hour set.. not 
too bad.. the dude is like 50.. and still puts it down.. mad props to the 
lad!

The crowd was frikkin' weird.. in one room hip-hop hoochies, in another the 
asian mafia, a third was off-and on pretty good music but nobody dancing.. 
but the main room was en fuego!!  It was only really bad when the other 
rooms emptied into the main and everybody was all mixed up like bad raver 
soup.  LOL...

C ya
Ranger


SFR: Ranger
Santa Cruz
plurranger@hotmail.com

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Fw: [dcraves] awesome.

Stoned Del. student gets lost in Conn.

Associated Press
07/11/2004

A Delaware college student ate a bag of hallucinogenic mushrooms and drove
around in a pair of stolen cars before arriving, confused, on a mountain in
northwest Connecticut police said.

Paul Cunningham, 21, hiked to a nearby home Thursday night and asked to call
911, police said.

"I think I stole a car," Cunningham told a dispatcher. "I'm not sure."

Police said Cunningham, of Dover, Del., confessed that eating an entire bag
of mushrooms, "probably wasn't a good idea." He allegedly told investigators
that he had no idea how many laws he broke during a three-day excursion that
took him 300 miles from home.

A student at Wilmington College, he told a state trooper that he bought the
drugs in Dover on Monday, according to the Republican-American of Waterbury.
The next day, he went for a drive and twice got lost in Connecticut.

He told police he remembers taking a train to LaGuardia Airport in New York,
where he found a car with its keys in it. He's unsure where he went from
there.

"I once again found myself lost in Connecticut," Cunningham reportedly told
police.

After locking the keys in the stolen car, Cunningham allegedly stole a van
from a Southbury rest stop.

In Canaan, he decided to climb Music Mountain to see what was on the other
side, police said. Investigators believe the exercise cleared Cunningham's
head.

"I want to correct my mistakes," Cunningham reportedly told Trooper Andre
Roy. "In retrospect, this was a bad idea."

He volunteered a written confession, police said. He was arraigned Friday
and was held on $2,500 bail. Both stolen vehicles were recovered.

http://www.delawareonline.com/newsjournal/local/2004/07/11stoneddelstuden.ht
ml

-rock on.
